 Cut 3p from petrol duty.

 Cut tax on saving, not specific how and by how much.

 Bring back married couples allowance boosting income of marrieds without children.

 Increase state pension - not known by how much. Pledge to go one better than Labour.

 Set against joining euro in next parliament, so pound is safe in your pocket.

 New top rate tax of 50p on taxable income over £100,000.

 Rises in state pension between £5 and £15 coupled with a compulsory second pension funded by the government if unable to pay.

 Shift duties from "wealth creating" goods and services to undesirable ones that pollute.

 Minimum wage for everyone over 16 rather than 21.

 Want to join the euro, saying goodbye to the pound in your pocket.

A petrol tax cut to match the Tory pledge of 3p off fuel duty is out of the question. webTitle: Review: The Cherry Orchard, Cottesloe Theatre, London

fields.headline: Intimations of upheaval
fields.standfirst:
The Cherry Orchard
Cottesloe Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Cherry Orchard
Cottesloe Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
This, by my reckoning, is the fourth Cherry Orchard that the National has given us in 27 years. But, even if Trevor Nunn's new production does not efface memories of its predecessors, it is a good, well-cast version that gives us Chekhov's concrete particularity. Played on a sparse rectangle with the audience on three sides, it also gains from the Cottesloe Theatre's revealing intimacy.

The most intriguing performance predictably comes from Vanessa Redgrave as Ranevskaya. Conventionally the character is played as a heedless romantic. Redgrave instead offers us a restless, tactile, highly sexed and deeply maternal woman forever guided by her instincts. She genuinely loves her old house, as you can see by the way she swoops on the nursery sofa to shower it with kisses.

But she is also the victim of her uncensored passion. Her dream of saving the family estate by marrying the buyer, Lopakhin, off to her adopted daughter, Varya, comically backfires precisely because it is she herself who enchants the upwardly mobile businessman.

Redgrave's highly intelligent performance - and Nunn's production - reminds us that Chekhov's play is about class as well as money, property and misdirected passion. This Ranevskaya's privileged upbringing leads her to remember the nursery furniture but not the housemaid's name. Corin Redgrave's fine Gaev is not just an arrested adolescent but a rank snob. Class is also the key to Roger Allam's excellent Lopakhin: it accounts for his lifelong fascination with Ranevskaya, his incredulous delight at buying the estate and his paralysing inhibition. There is a truly Chekhovian piece of comedy when, in the abortive proposal to Varya, Allam prepares to go down on bended knee and scoops up a bottle of champagne instead.

At times the production succumbs to old-fashioned atmospherics: when the departing Ranevskaya lays a floral tribute on a music-box, Nunn treads a delicate line between irony and sentimentality. And although David Lan's new version is very direct, I can't help wondering what's wrong with the dozen other existing translations. But it is a clear, soundly conceived production that reminds you that, beneath the imperishable beauty of Chekhov's play, lay intimations of revolutionary upheaval.

In rep. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

webTitle: Are they really a gem of a deal?

fields.headline: Are they really a gem of a deal?
fields.standfirst: If you go for the patter and feel tempted to buy sapphires from an offshore sales outfit, then think again. Tony Levene puts one organisation's claims to the test
fields.trailText: If you go for the patter and feel tempted to buy sapphires from an offshore sales outfit, then think again. Tony Levene puts one organisation's claims to the test.
fields.body:
Diamonds are famously a girl's best friend. But what about sapphires - will the blue tinged stones be an investor's best mate? It's yes if you believe an offshore sales outfit working from the Costa del Sol, with a brass plate registration in Geneva and an ultimate owner currently residing in Florida. Over the past few weeks it has been heavily mailing potential UK investors.

It's no , however, if you take notice of almost everyone else and heed warnings that virtually all of your capital could be at risk. In reality, your investment may be little better than flushing your cash down the toilet.

Windsor Cairns, whose coat of arms prominently features the letters WC, is the company currently selling the stones to investors. It mailshots potential UK investors through several mailing lists it buys, including one from an organisation specialising in punters looking for get-rich-quick opportunities.

In its literature and via telephone sales staff, Windsor Cairns makes a number of claims designed to sell sapphires as an investment. It promises "lucrative financial opportunities for the novice and sophisticated investor."

Those who bite are first sent glossy brochures - one including the line "that one by one, the world's most renowned deposits of blue sapphire are running out or not running at all." The shortage message, although denied elsewhere, is a vital element of the WC sales patter.

Potential customers are asked to return the free inquiry form and are then phoned - ostensibly from Geneva but actually from the Costa del Sol - by Windsor Cairns.

The Windsor Cairns sapphire investment trail takes in half the world - from the mines in Sri Lanka, via Spain where the phone centre is located, to Geneva, the registered address, and then to the Florida base of the US entrepreneurs behind the secretive Swiss firm and thence to the Bahamas, the current domicile of Ms Jamie Duncannon who signs letters to customers, with a Geneva letter-heading.

Avery Brooks, an American, is one of the individuals working on the Costa touting the scheme to British investors. He repeatedly tells prospects that he has a masters degree in finance but refuses to divulge the name of the college or university when asked. Brooks admits he has only been "a few months" in the gemstone business. But he is a tenacious salesperson.

Here, we examine claims made by Windsor Cairns and compare that with what independent experts say both here and in Sri Lanka.

Claim 1: Windsor Cairns offers a "secured, tax-exempt investment" which will "safely realise returns of 50% or more annually." The investment, it adds, has seen a "30-year bull market with no downside price correction." There are also charts showing how precious stones have soared in value.

Counterclaim: There is no "safe" investment which returns 50% or more annually - independent financial advisers are at a loss to find any investment no matter what the risk that has regularly offered this much. Even if sapphires had advanced at half that pace, a £1,000 purchase in 1970 would be worth more than £1m now.

Brooks says this claim is based on auction house returns which he cannot name and on "figures from a previous company in this field" which likewise remains anonymous.

Claim 2: "We're looking for political and economic factors. The demand for sapphires has never been greater. There are serious problems with the Tamil Tiger rebels in Sri Lanka; they declared a civil war in May and it's getting worse and worse by the day," says Brooks. Brooks says the civil war has caused disruption in the market place and this has led to "tremendous volatility in markets".

Counterclaim: Sri Lankan news sources report clashes between the Tamil Tigers and government troops almost daily. Most result in heavy loss of life. But the Tamil activity is largely confined to the Jaffna peninsula in the island's north - the sapphire mines are in the south where there is no Tamil activity. The Sri Lanka gem and jewellery authority says the mines are unaffected. And the market is now receiving substantial supplies of quality stones from Madagascar.

Claim 3: Sri Lanka produces "the finest investment grade sapphires". At the same time, Brooks says demand for sapphires has never been greater.

Counterclaim: Just what this is based upon is unclear. Dr Roger Harding, director of London's respected Gemmological Association and Gem Testing Laboratory says there is no such thing as "investment grade" sapphires. He also doubts that demand is at an all-time high relative to supply.

Claim 4: Brooks offers a 2 carat stone at £4,025, a 1 carat "museum" quality stone at £3,600, and a 0.75 carat stone at £1,500.

Counterclaim: Dr Harding says "museum quality" is a salesman's term not recognised in his industry. A US website - Simply Sapphires - sells pairs of 1 carat stones for $150 (around £110).

Claim 5: Brooks appeals to the investor's greed by offering a "tax-free" gain. He tells prospective customers that to save VAT and import duties, the stones are kept sealed in plastic in a vault in Geneva Airport's tax-free zone.

"You can have physical delivery if you want but that will cost a lot more with further expenses when you want to sell. It is money that will be wasted from your profits. More than 99% of our customers use the Valimpex tax-free zone," he says. "You also have a special international capital gains tax allowance," he adds.

Counterclaim: It is true that if you never import the jewels, you do not pay duty and VAT. But there is no such thing as an international CGT allowance. Leaving them in a tax-free vault means you never see the stone so you cannot get an independent valuation.

Claim 6: Brooks says sapphire investment is "more liquid than unit trusts."

Counterclaim: Unit trusts can be sold overnight for cash. Selling a gemstone could take months and there are charges.

Dr Harding says investors should take all these claims with "a pinch of salt."

He says: "Sapphires have done no more than keep up with inflation over the years and the prices quoted would have to be exceptional quality even for someone to spend time examing them. There have been periods in the past when offshore operations tried to sell stones which the purchaser would never see. In those cases, the stones turned out to be worth about a tenth of their sales price."

The watchdog Financial Services Authority says Windsor Cairns is outside its jurisdiction and that investors who send cheques to unregulated concerns do so at their own risk. There is no comp- ensation scheme if they lose out.

Other enforcement agencies admit they are powerless to act due to the way Windsor Cairns splits its functions across international borders.

In a second phone call Brooks admits "our published information is not indicative of the returns. There are a number of unscrupulous individuals in my market. This is not an investment, more a collectable that we keep in a tax-free zone."

 Jamie Duncannon was not available for comment.

Shoot-first policy to cope with the cowboys

The Financial Services Authority says you should always check that a company is authorised before sending any money for an investment. Other ways to avoid trouble with cowboy firms include:

 Insist on having all documentation before you sign or agree to anything. Read the small print.

 Ask about cancellation rights - unless you are sure of these, use a post-dated cheque. Cancel the deal if it is not as you had expected.

 Always print off a copy of the terms and conditions, if you are buying over the internet - the details on the website may have changed when you go back again.

 Never rely on the advice of the sales person alone unless you are sure of the product's value from past experience.

 Get independent advice if you do not understand the product or whether it suits you.

 Check forms before signing, especially if someone else - a tele-operator, say - has filled them in for you.

 Don't buy from a web site unless it gives an address and telephone number to contact if you have a problem - never trust a mobile number or a foreign one unless the firm has a UK office.

 Remember that information about a product is not the same as advice.

 Don't sign up to a deal unless you are completely happy with it.

 Don't give an account number or credit card number unless you are actually in the process of making a purchase. Don't be taken in by requests for these details for "security" reasons.

 Never give out bank account numbers or credit card details on the internet unless you are on a secure site.

 Never divulge a PIN number to anyone.

 The FSA says that it cannot offer any protection if people deal with offshore or unauthorised investments.

 Question everything - if an offer sounds too good to be true, it nearly always is.

 Phone the FSA hotline on 0845-606-1234 if you suspect something.

Leaving them in a tax-free vault means you never see the stone so you cannot get an independent valuation. Claim 6: Brooks says sapphire investment is "more liquid than unit trusts." Counterclaim: Unit trusts can be sold overnight for cash. Selling a gemstone could take months and there are charges. Dr Harding says investors should take all these claims with "a pinch of salt." He says: "Sapphires have done no more than keep up with inflation over the years and the prices quoted would have to be exceptional quality even for someone to spend time examing them. There have been periods in the past when offshore operations tried to sell stones which the purchaser would never see. In those cases, the stones turned out to be worth about a tenth of their sales price." The watchdog Financial Services Authority says Windsor Cairns is outside its jurisdiction and that investors who send cheques to unregulated concerns do so at their own risk. There is no comp- ensation scheme if they lose out. Other enforcement agencies admit they are powerless to act due to the way Windsor Cairns splits its functions across international borders. In a second phone call Brooks admits "our published information is not indicative of the returns. There are a number of unscrupulous individuals in my market. This is not an investment, more a collectable that we keep in a tax-free zone."  Jamie Duncannon was not available for comment. Shoot-first policy to cope with the cowboys The Financial Services Authority says you should always check that a company is authorised before sending any money for an investment. Other ways to avoid trouble with cowboy firms include:  Insist on having all documentation before you sign or agree to anything. Read the small print.  Ask about cancellation rights - unless you are sure of these, use a post-dated cheque. Cancel the deal if it is not as you had expected.  Always print off a copy of the terms and conditions, if you are buying over the internet - the details on the website may have changed when you go back again.  Never rely on the advice of the sales person alone unless you are sure of the product's value from past experience.  Get independent advice if you do not understand the product or whether it suits you.  Check forms before signing, especially if someone else - a tele-operator, say - has filled them in for you.  Don't buy from a web site unless it gives an address and telephone number to contact if you have a problem - never trust a mobile number or a foreign one unless the firm has a UK office.  Remember that information about a product is not the same as advice.  Don't sign up to a deal unless you are completely happy with it.  Don't give an account number or credit card number unless you are actually in the process of making a purchase. Don't be taken in by requests for these details for "security" reasons.  Never give out bank account numbers or credit card details on the internet unless you are on a secure site.  Never divulge a PIN number to anyone.  The FSA says that it cannot offer any protection if people deal with offshore or unauthorised investments.  Question everything - if an offer sounds too good to be true, it nearly always is.  Phone the FSA hotline on 0845-606-1234 if you suspect something.

webTitle: Finding the warmest place for your nest egg

fields.headline: Finding the warmest place for your nest egg
fields.standfirst: As a Swiss bank targets the UK Rupert Jones outlines the options for the affluent
fields.trailText: As a Swiss bank targets the UK Rupert Jones outlines the options for the affluent
fields.body:
If you thought Swiss bank accounts were exclusively the preserve of multi-millionaires, African dictators and crooked tycoons looking for somewhere to stash their ill- gotten gains, then think again.

Credit Suisse, Switzerland's second biggest bank, this week attempted to dramatically beef up its presence in Britain with the launch of a new online investment and banking service. It is targeting the 7m people it dubs the UK's "new affluents".

Credit Suisse's Global Investor Portfolio account, which goes live next month, will allow people to trade shares on 15 stock markets including London, New York and Frankfurt, hold cash in up to four currencies and buy unit trusts from leading-name companies. Personal fi nancial advice will be available to customers from next year.

It's the sort of service that in the past would only have been available to extremely wealthy investors via traditional private banks or investment managers, but Credit Suisse says it will not be restricting the account to the seriously rich - it is targeting people with around £30,000-plus of "invested assets," and has set the minimum needed to open an account at £600.

The numbers of so-called "higher net worth" individuals are expanding rapidly - Credit Suisse reckons that across Europe there are 40m of them - so it's no wonder that growing numbers of institutions are trying to find new ways to hook the newly wealthy. Earlier this year banking giant HSBC and stockbroker Merrill Lynch joined forces to launch a similar online banking and investment services company aimed at those with "investable assets" of £60,000 to £300,000. The company is due to go live in the UK before the end of the year.

So what can higher net worth individuals currently get for their money? And what about the millions of not-so-high net worth people with just a few thousand pounds to invest. What should they do?

£1,000: If this is all the savings/investment cash you've got, you're really looking at a bank or building society account. However, you don't have to put up with a derisory rate of interest, particularly if you're prepared to take to the internet. Nationwide building society's e-Savings account -operated online as part of its FlexAccount current account - pays 7% gross from £1.

£3,000: You should be looking at putting some of this money into a cash Isa (you can invest up £3,000 in one of these during the current tax year).

£5,000: "At this point you can start looking at equity-linked Isas," says Maxine Harvey at Wolverhampton-based independent financial adviser Torquil Clark. These are often invested in unit trusts or investment trusts - funds into which investors pool their money so it can be invested on their behalf by a fund manager. However, first make sure you've got some rainy-day savings in a bank or building society account.

Meanwhile, an account with private bank Cater Allen (part of the Abbey National group) can be opened with a minimum of £5,000. Funds can be held in sterling, US dollars or euros.

£10,000: Those with this sort of amount will probably want to dabble further in stocks and shares Isas (you can invest up to £7,000 this tax year), but may also want to look at a unit trust or an Oeic (open-ended investment company) on top, says Ms Harvey. For wealthier investors, basic portfolio management services start at around £10,000 - Rothschild Asset Management will select funds for you and send half-yearly reports for a 1.5% annual fee.

£20,000: In addition to Isas and unit trusts/Oeics, you might want to stash some money away in something like a with-profits bond. These are offered by insurance companies, and your money is invested in a broad range of shares, gilts and property. They tend to be aimed at people with at least £5,000 to invest and are very much a medium- to long-term investment that should be held for at least five years. A well-heeled investor with £20,000 to play with may want to move up to directly held shares with an advisory investment service from a broker such as Killik & Co.

£50,000: Once you've made full use of your Isa allowances, perhaps bought into a unit trust or two and maybe acquired an insurance company bond, you might want to start to think about some more diversification - perhaps into the US.

£100,000: At this point you may well want to look at specialising further and investing more of your loot in a particular sector or going for something like the Classic Portfolio Service operated by Edinburgh Fund Managers - this is an actively managed "fund of funds" unit trust investing in funds from 20 of the biggest names, says Ms Harvey (it's aimed at people who have £25,000-plus to invest).

£100,000-£250,000: Private client territory. You might want to opt for a portfolio of directly held shares and overseas investments offered by brokers such as Prudential Bache or investment manager Quilter & Co. Meanwhile, Cater Allen Offshore offers a discretionary portfolio management service for clients with £250,000-plus.

£500,000: Minimum needed to become a client of Coutts, the Queen's bank, with bespoke "wealth management services": one-to-one meetings with an adviser, monthly reports and entry to hedge funds.

£1m: With a million to play with, accountants KPMG will offer you a tax and strategic investment service, setting up trusts and minimising tax liabilities, with a personal adviser based in Switzerland, the UK or US.

£10m: Rothschild Asset Management will set up a private unit trust. At this level you'll want your personal investment and tax adviser, who for £100,000 a year will manage your affairs day-to-day.

 For more information about Credit Suisse's Global Investor Portfolio account log on to www.credit-suisse.net

webTitle: Safety in numbers will foil criminals

fields.headline: Safety in numbers will foil criminals
fields.standfirst: Carrying emergency helpline details with you at all times is sensible, as Teri Harman found when she fell victim to a thief
fields.trailText: Carrying emergency helpline details with you at all times is sensible, as Teri Harman found when she fell victim to a thief
fields.body:
Hands up everyone who walks around at all times with the emergency lost and stolen numbers for their plastic cards secreted about their person. I thought not! However, my experience of having both my Woolwich and Halifax debit cards stolen while shopping might make you reconsider.

Halifax, whose emergency number is listed (though not in yellow pages, which is all I had) was able to put me through via the Halifax Direct number.

I didn't know my account number, having left my cheque books at home, and it took some while for them to sift through everyone with my surname to find my account, but compared to Woolwich, this was easy.

Woolwich does not have an emergency number listed. As it was outside branch hours, I phoned the head office. Instead of giving me the correct number, I was put on hold and sent round in circles for what seemed like half an hour, before I managed to make someone understand it was my debit card that had been stolen, not my credit card, and have it cancelled.

Figures released this week by Card Watch showed card fraud losses soared by 53% in the year to May 2000, costing the industry £226m.

More than 13,000 cards are reported lost or stolen in the UK every day - that's about one every seven seconds, so there is every chance it could happen to you.

Although the major growth areas for fraud are in counterfeit and mail order, internet and telephone transactions, where the physical presence of the card is not required nor indeed possible, nearly a third of fraud still occurs in face-to-face transactions with stolen cards and forged signatures.

So what can you do to make sure cards are cancelled quickly and easily, and new ones ordered with the minimum of hassle?

The first point all the banks stress is to report any loss as soon as you even suspect it, though if the cards subsequently turn up you won't be able to use them and will have to wait for replacements. Stolen cards should also be reported to the police.

Most of the banks' emergency numbers are listed in the phone book, but if you don't have access to one, call directory inquiries. If you know your account number and sort code, the cancellation process is quicker, but I found that giving my name and address, plus other security details, like my date of birth, sufficed.

Once a loss is reported, a "stop" is put on cards and you cannot be held liable for any subsequent fraud. Liability for any fraud prior to reporting a loss is generally limited to £50, though in practice Richard Tyson-Davies of Apacs says this is unlikely to be invoked, provided you are a genuine victim - in other words, unless the bank can show you actively colluded with the fraudster or were grossly negligent, an example of which might be keeping a note of your pin number with the card.

My replacement cards took only a few days to arrive, but I had been advised by both banks to keep an eye on my account for debits I didn't recognise. It's a good idea to keep checking your balance, get mini-statements where possible, and report any suspicious withdrawals to your bank immediately. Potentially, a thief could empty your account, leaving you with cash flow problems.

My banks said that it was up to me to report suspect transactions and their fraud teams would investigate. Fortunately, there haven't been any.

All the banks stress that customers will be reimbursed, but there could be a delay of several days. Only Barclays say they will refund the disputed amount straightaway, pending an investigation, while NatWest says it will be ring-fenced so that customers can continue to use their account as if the suspect transactions hadn't happened.

Although you are unlikely to lose out financially at the end of the day if your cards are used fraudulently, and only a small proportion of lost cards are, you might find a card protection scheme a worthwhile investment, saving you all the hassle of having to cancel your lost or stolen cards individually.

In return for an annual fee, these schemes allow you to register all your debit, credit and store cards. If some or all go missing, you can cancel and automatically order replacements for them with one phone call, and lines are open 24 hours a day.

NatWest, Barclays and Halifax all operate their own schemes, while market leader Sentinel (call 0800-414-717) has more than 4m cardholders registered, and will cover all the cards belonging to members of the same household, even if they are in different names, for £12 a year or £30 for three years. Barclays charges £12 for an individual and £18 a year for couples.

Card protection services also typically cover emergency cash advances and replacement of any lost or stolen travel documents, keys or luggage. Another useful add-on is a change of address service, which informs all your plastic card providers if you move house.

However, if you sign up for one of these, it might a good idea to tattoo the number on yourself as, unlike most of the lost and stolen emergency telephone numbers, these do not appear to be listed in the phone book.

webTitle: Review: The Ballroom of Romance, Playhouse, Newcastle

fields.headline: Distilled emotions
fields.standfirst:
The Ballroom of Romance
Playhouse, Newcastle
****
fields.trailText:
The Ballroom of Romance
Playhouse, Newcastle
****
fields.body:
Based on William Trevor's exquisite short story, this is an extraordinary piece of theatre about our dreams and the accommodations we make when they turn to dust. Set in the early 1960s and transposed from Ireland to rural Northumberland, it tells the story of Bridie, who lives with her sick father on their farm. Every Saturday night Bridie puts on her best frock and cycles to Mr Dyer's Ballroom of Romance looking for love. She is getting older; time is running out for her. So in her new red dress, defiant and desperate, she sets out for the ballroom for one last dance.

Despite some problems with audibility, there is only one thing wrong with Northern Stage's production: it cries out to be staged in a genuine village hall. But designer Neil Murray makes the best of the Playhouse, turning the vast stage into a space of undulating hills across which piled-up chairs snake like both physical and psychological debris. The space constantly transforms as the dancers trip across it: at one point the chairs slip down the slope like a landslide of letting go. The piece is largely wordless, almost nothing happens, and yet by the end of the evening everything is different: for Bridie, for each hopeful heart on the dance floor, for us as an audience. It makes you want to dance and cry.

Like so much of director Alan Lyddiard's work, it has a diffuse quality: often, the important things are on the periphery. There are no big statements, only tiny gestures: a woman picking a hair off a man's suit, the men strutting. It takes the lives of ordinary people surviving on the margins and makes them seem special, almost blessed. There is an acuteness about this that is almost frightening, as if the emotion has somehow been distilled: the quickstep turned into a love letter, the foxtrot into a litany of rejection. The piece has a caged grace but it avoids sentimentality. Like Bridie, it has no use for tears.

The play delves into folk memory and it reaches out across town and countryside. It is totally accessible but makes great demands upon its audience. It is a brave 75 minutes that takes us somewhere familiar and yet strange.

Until October 14. Box office: 0191-230 5151.

webTitle: Is your life firm secure?

fields.headline: Is your life firm secure?
fields.standfirst: A new survey highlights the strongest savings and pension providers, says Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: A new survey highlights the strongest savings and pension providers, says Patrick Collinson
fields.body:
How financially secure is the company that manages your pensions and savings? A survey this week identifies which companies have the greatest financial strength, and which are moving up and down the tables.

The results, validated by actuaries KPMG and trade newspaper Money Marketing, reveal that some companies run on a fairly narrow margin of spare "free assets", while others have spare cash that adds up to more than a third of their liabilities.

Top of the table sits Royal London, with a free asset ratio of 34.8%, while at the bottom is NPI, with 5.1%. The average is 15%.

The life companies don't like the general public seeing these figures, believing they will be misread. A low free asset ratio does not mean that a company is veering towards bankruptcy, and neither does a high free asset ratio mean that a company's products are the best on the market.

But the figures do give pension buyers some important indications:

Solvency: The DTI has extremely rigid rules designed to ensure that your money is never at risk. All of the companies in the table below meet these guidelines. But a low and falling free asset ra tio should raise questions in the mind of an investor. For example, NPI's free asset ratio declined from more than 10% in 1993 to just 4% last year. Its shortage of capital became so pressing that it sought a takeover, which many observers in the industry interpreted as a rescue. It was taken over by giant Australian insurer AMP last year, so it now has a rich parent standing behind it, and its free asset ratio is now moving up.

Investment returns: Companies with relatively high free asset ratios, such as Standard Life, have long argued that it allows them to put more money into equities, producing better returns. Conversely, they argue that companies with low ratios have to buy low-earning gilts to cover their burgeoning liabilities. However, Equitable Life, which has historically run a low free asset ratio, has argued that all the others are doing is hoarding cash and not paying it out to policyholders. But the sting in the tail for Equitable Life is that after it lost a £1.5bn court case on guaranteed annuities earlier this year, it found itself financially challenged. It is currently arranging a white knight takeover.

Demutualisation windfalls: The free asset figure is not the same as the amount of money that can be distributed if a mutual company is taken over, but it does give an indication of how much spare cash it has. A bidder for Royal London, for example, will have to stump up a lot of money just to cover the free assets, which belong to policyholders in the with-profits fund.

The good news is that, on average, free asset ratios rose last year. This is because 1999 was a particularly good year for investment returns, with the FTSE up 24% during the year. Of the 38 companies in the survey, 31 saw their ratio increase, while seven - Teachers Provident, Scottish Friendly, Britannic, Royal Liver, Sun Life of Canada, CGU Life and Sun Life - saw declines.

The bad news is that next year's figures will not be anywhere near as good, because the stock market is down sharply so far this year.

Conversely, they argue that companies with low ratios have to buy low-earning gilts to cover their burgeoning liabilities. However, Equitable Life, which has historically run a low free asset ratio, has argued that all the others are doing is hoarding cash and not paying it out to policyholders. But the sting in the tail for Equitable Life is that after it lost a £1.5bn court case on guaranteed annuities earlier this year, it found itself financially challenged. It is currently arranging a white knight takeover. Demutualisation windfalls: The free asset figure is not the same as the amount of money that can be distributed if a mutual company is taken over, but it does give an indication of how much spare cash it has. A bidder for Royal London, for example, will have to stump up a lot of money just to cover the free assets, which belong to policyholders in the with-profits fund. The good news is that, on average, free asset ratios rose last year. This is because 1999 was a particularly good year for investment returns, with the FTSE up 24% during the year. Of the 38 companies in the survey, 31 saw their ratio increase, while seven - Teachers Provident, Scottish Friendly, Britannic, Royal Liver, Sun Life of Canada, CGU Life and Sun Life - saw declines. The bad news is that next year's figures will not be anywhere near as good, because the stock market is down sharply so far this year.

webTitle: Facing up to harsh realities  when death hits your family

fields.headline: Facing up to harsh realities  when death hits your family
fields.standfirst: It's a delicate subject, but when someone dies the practicalities have to be faced. Liz Stuart has a guide to the options faced by those left behind
fields.trailText: It's a delicate subject, but when someone dies the practicalities have to be faced. Liz Stuart has a guide to the options faced by those left behind
fields.body:
As EastEnders fans have discovered, funerals are not cheap. When Ian Beale was handed the bill for Ethel's cremation he complained that he had no idea that the service would be so expensive.

His reaction reflects that of most people when it comes to the practicalities of death; there are 650,000 funerals a year in the UK, but, according to NOP research, just one in five people knew the correct cost, and a third underestimate by a quarter the amount needed to cover a funeral director's fees, flowers, hiring a hearse, a coffin or casket and burial or cremation fees.

The price has risen dramatically over the past two years, by 25% according to the Homeowners Friendly Society, which markets a plan to help with funeral costs. Much of this is because local authorities have had to overhaul cremation facilities as environmental regulation becomes tighter.

The average amount spent is just over £2,000 for a burial and around £1,200 for a cremation, according to Gilmour Research, but with so many variables, this depends on how grand the ceremony is. More than seven in 10 people choose cremation, but you can choose more than just the method of your disposal; cars, flowers and gardens of rememberance may all be bought. A spokesman from the Co-operative Funeral Service, which has more than 500 outlets nationwide, says: "Funerals can be as simple or elaborate as people want them to be. We would always encourage people to think about their own funeral arrangements in advance as this lifts a significant emotional burden from their families."

There is a huge range of costs depending on where death occurs. The average burial in London costs £2,646, against £1,741 in the north, or £1,221 in Bristol, and while the average cost of a cremation in the capital is £1,215, that goes down to £692 in Cardiff. The only areas which have seen a reduction in costs are the north-west and Yorkshire, where cremations are 8% cheaper than two years ago.

The Manchester Unity Friendly Society, which publishes an independent survey on the cost of funerals, makes the point that many directors do not respond accurately to telephone enquiries. "Only one funeral director gave the full price at the beginning when asked the cost of a basic funeral. Most directors did not mention that the £200-plus crematorium fee was not included in their quote: over the past 10 years we have found that people tend to hide the true costs."

Its mystery shopping survey revealed that, for instance, for someone who has died in London, the average quote for a burial was £1,131, whereas the actual cost was £1,515, a difference of 34%. But the CFS spokesman says that his organisation always gives the true cost up front and any changes must be agreed upon in writing. It also provides its services free for funerals of children up to age 16, although associated costs will have to be paid.

The invoice usually arrives two to three weeks after the ceremony and a £40 discount is generally offered for settlement within 30 days. Most directors will be happy to wait until probate or insurance money comes through provided they are kept fully informed of progress.

Low-cost funeral The most basic funeral in Woolwich, south London, costs £950 from CFS. The same service costs £790 in Tredegar, Wales and £795 in Glasgow. This covers the cost of a wood veneer coffin but does not include what are called "disbursements": cremation or burial fees, doctors' fees and obituary notices, which typically add £400 to the above amount.

The cheapest flowers available from the Funeral Shop website are pink and white sprays for £40 or a black and white wreath for £50, including VAT, postage and packing. Some will be eligible for money from the Department of Social Security. The maximum is £600 plus basic disbursements, and the claimant must be receiving social security payments, not have savings of more than £500 (or £1,000 if they are over 60), and cannot claim if they have a brother or sister who has sufficient funds.

Expensive funeral The most pricey at the CFS's Woolwich branch costs £2,195. For this the level of service is the same as for the basic funeral, but the coffin is more elaborate and will be made of solid oak or ash. However, the ceremony can be as expensive as you wish. The CFS will occasionally im port the Promethean coffin from the States, which is made of solid brass with gold trimmings and costs £14,000. A horse-drawn hearse will add an additional £500 to the bill and a six-foot spray is £200, depending on the area. The most expensive coffin on the Funeral Shop website is the £2,500 Last Supper Casket and a top-of-the-range wreath of red carnations is £115. Gardens of remembrance can be constructed featuring a bench (£100), a wooden armchair (£75), a laurel sundial (£60) or a patio set (£450).

Green funeral You may wish to opt for a more environmentally sound funeral. The Natural Death Centre in London gives advice on woodland burials, where the body is generally placed in a cardboard coffin and a tree is planted rather than a headstone. A burial of this type in Greenhaven, near Rugby, will cost £570 for the grave, the tree, a biodegradable coffin and collection of the body. The same service at Hinton Park, on the Hampshire-Dorset border, costs £1,075. All of these sites allow you to organise the funeral independently, without the use of a director. This may be done by storing the body at home (the heating will have to be turned off, or dry ice may be used, costing £27.48 from the British Oxygen Company on 020-8985-5544) and a nurse will lay out the body. Rent a transit van or estate car to transport the body and register the death yourself with the registrar of births, deaths and marriages. Doctors' certificates cost around £82 and you can ask a priest or minister to preside over the service, or use of a humanist officiant, who will charge around £85. Coffins start at £45 for a chipboard model including delivery. You may opt to bury the body on your own land, although there are strict regulations governing this.

Buying a funeral Like-for-like funerals can vary by hundreds of pounds, so although it's not the best of times to do so, a ring-round is a good idea. Yellow Pages should list all the local directors. You should try to ensure they are members of the Funeral Ombudsman scheme.

Make a list of items you want to be included before contacting a firm. This may include for a cremation: hearse, coffin, director's fees, removal, chapel of rest, family car, cremation fee, minister, casket and a doctor's certificate, and for a burial you would need to add the cost of a grave-digger, headstone and plot, and obviously replace the cremation fee with a burial fee.

Make sure that you get an accurate quote. Some funeral directors may imply that doing so shows disrespect for the dead; do not let this put you off.

The Office of Fair Trading has a helpful website at www.oft.gov.uk/html/funerals; Funeral Shop is at www.funeralshop.co.uk; for information on do-it-yourself burials log on to the Natural Death site at www.naturaldeath.org.uk or contact the charity on 020-8208 2853; the Co-op funeral information is at www.coop.co.uk; for Muslim and other alternative funerals see www.globalideasbank.org.

The plans available

There are financial plans tailored to saving for a funeral. They are big business in the US, where more than 60% of funerals are funded this way, but in Britain fewer than 2% are paid for in advance.

Golden Charter has a variety of plans. These cost from £1,125 for the Standard Way, funded on a monthly basis covering the services of a funeral director, a basic coffin and hearse, to the most expensive Golden Approach, which costs £2,235 and includes a wooden casket, two limousines and a hearse, a chapel of rest and floral tributes.

Chosen Heritage offers a basic plan for £1,057 and if the person dies abroad or the funeral is not needed for some reason, relatives will be refunded. More than 120 local funeral directors offer prepayment plans, backed by the Funeral Planning Trust, and the Cooperative Funeral Service offers its own plan.

Alternatively, you can take out an insurance-based plan. Homeowners Friendly quotes a premium of £8 per month for a female non-smoker aged 60, which on her death will pay £2,161.

 Golden Charter, 0800-833-800; for details of local director plans contact 01508-532-632; Chosen Heritage 0800-525-555; Homeowners Friendly 01423-855-000

webTitle: No cash for Scottish Life members

fields.headline: No cash for Scottish Life members
fields.trailText: A wealth of windfalls could be on the horizon if a number of rumoured insurance company takeovers come to fruition - but policyholders of Scottish Life hoping for big cash payouts look set to be disappointed.
fields.body:
A wealth of windfalls could be on the horizon if a number of rumoured insurance company takeovers come to fruition - but policyholders of Scottish Life hoping for big cash payouts look set to be disappointed.

The rumours as to who is planning to take over who reached fever pitch this week. It looks pretty certain that Scottish Life will be bought - probably by either Liverpool Victoria, the UK's biggest friendly society, or insurer Royal London, both of which are also mutuals.

A takeover would mean windfalls to many Scottish Life policyholders but most of this money would probably be paid out in the form of a longer-term enhancement of their policies.

Liverpool Victoria's plans could be derailed because there has been speculation that it, too, might be taken over. One company said to be interested in acquiring Liverpool Victoria, which has 1m members, is Dutch insurer Aegon, which is also rumoured to be contemplating bidding for Equitable Life.

Trying to work out exactly what policyholders would re ceive in the event of a Scottish Life takeover is no easy task because of its fiendishly complex company structure.

In essence, the 275,000 with-profits policyholders can expect to receive a variable amount of "compensation" following a takeover. How much they get will depend on the type, size and age of the policy. However, they would probably not get this variable compensation as a cash payment - it would be paid out over time in the form of enhanced policy bonuses.

But those with-profits policyholders who are also mem bers of the company can expect a separate flat-rate cash payment for "loss of membership rights" which might be in the region of £500.

However, quite a large chunk of the with-profits people - including those in Scottish Life occupational pension schemes, people with personal pensions written under trust, and those with endowment policies that have been assigned to their building society - aren't company members and so wouldn't get this payment.

webTitle: Following the herd

fields.headline: Following the herd
fields.trailText: If you're considering buying or selling a house this autumn, you'll be looking anxiously at the forecasts for property prices. Everyone agrees that there's a slowdown in the rate of increase and there are signs that in places prices have peaked and are beginning to slip into reverse.
fields.body:
If you're considering buying or selling a house this autumn, you'll be looking anxiously at the forecasts for property prices. Everyone agrees that there's a slowdown in the rate of increase and there are signs that in places prices have peaked and are beginning to slip into reverse.

But the question is, what happens next? Will prices come to a gentle halt and stay at their present value? Or is the rollercoaster of the housing market only pausing briefly at the summit before plunging irresistibly downwards?

The mortgage lenders say that even though house prices are faltering, they won't slump in the way that we saw in the past decade. This "soft landing" theory says that prices might fall slightly, but will soon stabilise and we won't see prices going into tailspin and the return of that Shetland pony rider of the apocalypse, negative equity.

But is this optimistic outlook to be believed? And are the mortgage lenders and the estate agents the best judges of how people are likely to behave under pressure? Because in the end, whether prices stabilise or collapse will depend on hundreds of thousands of buying and selling decisions taken by ordinary punters like you and me.

So how about asking the experts in human behaviour? How do psychologists interpret the way we make decisions about when to buy and sell property? And do they see any likelihood of homebuyers escaping the cycle of boom and bust?

Well, the bad news for the mortgage lenders, who are pencilling in plans for £140bn in new lending next year, is that there seems to be little support among economic psychologists for the theory that house prices are set for a period of levelling off.

"There isn't any reason in principle why there shouldn't be stability in house prices, but it doesn't seem at all likely in practice," says Paul Webley, professor of economic psychology at the University of Exeter.

A key reason why he believes that there will continue to be volatility in house prices is that it's a market in which most of the traders have little experience. Which means that if we only buy and sell every eight years or so, we're a bit like people who only gamble on the Grand National -perennially inexperienced punters who are easily influenced by whatever seems to be the consensus. And when there's a stampede, we're all likely to follow.

Anyone looking for signs of the current psychological state of homebuyers, he says, should consider the variations in the attitudes of different generations. Veterans of the long decline in prices in the 90s will remain cautious. But people who have only been homeowners in the past few years, when prices have been rising, will have a more buoyant outlook and are likely to be ready to gamble on paying even higher prices.

Cary Cooper, professor of psychology at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, sees a near future in which there will continue to be sharp rises and falls in property values.

"You can relate the housing market to fluctuations in prices of information technology shares, where people are trying to realise profit quickly. It becomes unpredictable and is very strongly influenced by the psychology of the times," he says.

"Whether it's from TV or newspapers, a communal perception about house prices begins to develop. There might be people who think their own house has been over-valued by increases and they might then decide it's time to sell and make what they can - and when trends begin, people follow."

Much as families ended up panic buying during the petrol shortage, even though they knew it wasn't a good idea, he says that homebuyers can be pushed by a "mixture of fear and insecurity" into chasing the swings of the market, adding even more downward or upward pressure on prices.

Professor Cooper also identifies the influence of a changing attitude to housing. The past 20 years, he says, has seen the rise in the idea of a house as a financial asset rather than as somewhere to live. And the more that people use housing as a form of speculative investment, the greater the risk of surges and collapses in value.

Dr Guy Fielding, who lectures at the University of Oxford, also says that the psychology of how we buy and sell encourages a herd instinct rather than rational decision making.

"We don't make these decisions very often, and people are very influenced by rumour, gossip and what friends and relatives say, rather than any objective opinions. This type of behaviour amplifies trends very quickly."

If the psychologists are right, and the house price rollercoaster is still in motion, we could be in for a bumpy ride.

webTitle: Zimbabwe v New Zealand: Second Test

fields.headline: Kiwis in control as Zims follow on
fields.trailText: New Zealand took total command of the second Test on day three in Harare as Zimbabwe's batting line-up collapsed and were forced to follow on.
fields.body:
New Zealand took total command of the second Test on day three in Harare as Zimbabwe's batting line-up collapsed and were forced to follow on.

The Kiwis had posted an impressive 465 in their first innings thanks mainly to Chris Cairns' superb century, and the hosts were six for one at stumps second time round, having been skittled for 166 in their first reply.

After Gavin Rennie had fallen to Cairns the previous evening, Grant Flower and Stuart Carlisle steadied the ship for the Zimbabweans and led their side to 76 for one this morning.

But Cairns made the vital breakthrough once again when he had Carlisle caught by Mathew Sinclair at third man.

Alistair Campbell was snared for a duck by Shayne O'Connor, who finished the day with three for 43 off 28 overs, one run later - and Grant Flower was next to head back to the pavilion with the score on 118.

Flower fell one run short of his half-century when he lost patience and flashed outside the off stump to be caught by Adam Parore after 286 minutes at the crease.

Grant's brother Andy continued to play his shots but lost Guy Whittall for nine just before tea.

The hosts were in trouble at 146 for five, and the dismissal of Andy Flower - trapped lbw by Craig McMillan for 48 - sparked another flurry of wickets.

Zimbabwe slumped to 166 all out, losing their last five wickets for only 20 runs, and their misery was complete when O'Connor had Rennie caught by Craig Spearman for one before the close of play.

The Kiwis had posted an impressive 465 in their first innings thanks mainly to Chris Cairns' superb century, and the hosts were six for one at stumps second time round, having been skittled for 166 in their first reply. After Gavin Rennie had fallen to Cairns the previous evening, Grant Flower and Stuart Carlisle steadied the ship for the Zimbabweans and led their side to 76 for one this morning. But Cairns made the vital breakthrough once again when he had Carlisle caught by Mathew Sinclair at third man. Alistair Campbell was snared for a duck by Shayne O'Connor, who finished the day with three for 43 off 28 overs, one run later - and Grant Flower was next to head back to the pavilion with the score on 118. Flower fell one run short of his half-century when he lost patience and flashed outside the off stump to be caught by Adam Parore after 286 minutes at the crease. Grant's brother Andy continued to play his shots but lost Guy Whittall for nine just before tea. The hosts were in trouble at 146 for five, and the dismissal of Andy Flower - trapped lbw by Craig McMillan for 48 - sparked another flurry of wickets. Zimbabwe slumped to 166 all out, losing their last five wickets for only 20 runs, and their misery was complete when O'Connor had Rennie caught by Craig Spearman for one before the close of play.

webTitle: Keown's Arsenal rescue smells like team spirit

fields.headline: Keown's Arsenal rescue smells like team spirit
fields.trailText: Although success is the biggest single factor behind great spirit, there are other ingredients which Arsenal seem to have in abundance. That includes a strong clutch of personalities.
fields.body:
Anyone needing a reminder of the importance of spirit got that on Wednesday. First Claudio Ranieri admitted his Chelsea players lacked the togetherness to match their quality. Then Martin Keown scored those two memorable late goals to rescue Arsenal.

Of course the comeback Keown inspired against Shakhtar Donetsk was no coincidence. At 2-0 down some sides might have let their heads drop or wondered if they were just not fated to do well. But that is not the way at Highbury.

And although success is the biggest single factor behind great spirit, there are other ingredients which Arsenal seem to have in abundance. That includes a strong clutch of personalities for a start.

There may be several languages and cultures at Arsenal but still very much involved are the old guard such as Keown, Tony Adams, Lee Dixon and David Seaman. New arrivals will be left in no doubt what is required of them as Arsenal players.

In fact midway through the 1997-98 season, when Arsenal won the Double, I believe the established bunch had their say in no uncertain terms. Apparently there were splits between the foreign lads and the locals and around Christmas they got together and thrashed things out. Before that, form was patchy. After it they scarcely looked back.

The group of lads who came through together at Manchester United offer a similar base. And although talk of disastrous spirit at Chelsea may be an exaggeration - three wins on the bounce will change all that - it must be difficult to build the same unity at Stamford Bridge, where the players have not grown up together but come together. There is no real base, and Ranieri's insistence on having a British backbone is logical.

I think a manager sets an important tone in terms of spirit. You can see how Egil Olsen's personality seemed to affect the old togetherness at Wimbledon, and I always thought the training ground should be a place the players looked forward to coming to rather than some sort of prisoner of war camp.

The captain is also important. I had one of the best of all time in Bryan Robson, who was an inspirational leader and was instrumental in keeping the team together. But the one who really stood out for me was Nigel Pearson at Sheffield Wednesday.

Nigel was not a world-class player but he was a world-class captain. He made sure no one stepped out of line, resorting to physical threats if necessary, but he also ensured everyone was involved. If we went on a trip and the lads decided to go for a drink or a game of golf Nigel would make sure no one was left out.

And of course socialising did not have to mean sinking pints. I worked at Atletico Madrid, where the players were not big drinkers, and after a 2-1 defeat by Real in the local derby the team were in tears. I told them not to worry about training the next day but to come in anyway, and we went out for a meal and had a laugh. After that everyone felt fine again. It's little things.

Which is not to say that you can't breed success or togetherness unless everyone is the best of mates. There were factions in the great Liverpool team, and I've even heard stories that the players didn't always get on at Old Trafford under Sir Matt Busby in the 60s.

In many ways that's natural. It's not easy to get 15 personalities to gel, but what matters is that they gel as a team; that they have respect for one another's ability and for the club.

The biggest problems I faced in terms of spirit were probably at Nottingham Forest, where I inherited the Pierre van Hooijdonk business. He was an awful example to the rest of the club, always moaning and griping. He just wanted away.

Bad eggs such as that can upset the spirit but even at Forest the depression was down to results as much as anything. In my first game we won at Everton with a Van Hooijdonk goal and I've never seen a dressing room so lively, not even after victory in a cup final. Whatever anyone says, nothing breeds spirit like success.

webTitle: Leeds sense victory in £15m Ferdinand chase

fields.headline: Leeds sense victory in £15m Ferdinand chase
fields.standfirst: Redknapp hints at change of heart over young defender
fields.trailText: Leeds United were yesterday given the first indications that West Ham are ready to negotiate a joint British record £15m transfer of Rio Ferdinand to Elland Road.
fields.body:
Leeds United were yesterday given the first indications that West Ham are ready to negotiate a joint British record £15m transfer of Rio Ferdinand to Elland Road.

After coveting the England international for the best part of six months, Leeds are increasingly optimistic of breaking down West Ham's resistance after an apparent change of heart from the manager Harry Redknapp.

Redknapp claimed yesterday that Leeds had made a second £15m offer and, though saying he did not want to sell one of his best players, admitted for the first time he was giving serious consideration to sanctioning a transfer that would be hugely unpopular with West Ham's fans.

Although the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has repeatedly been in contact with West Ham, the plot thickened last night when the Yorkshire club denied having lodged a second offer. Instead, their original bid is still on the table and Redknapp's statement, though causing confusion at Elland Road, has given renewed hope that he is ready to make an about-turn.

"They [Leeds] won't give up, will they?" Redknapp had written on his personal website. "Fifteen million pounds is an incredible amount of money.

"Everyone knows how much I rate Rio. He's a great defender and could easily end up the best in Europe. They know how great a player he is and what a great signing he would be.

"I would be lying if I said it hadn't crossed my mind to sell him for that kind of money and bring a few players into the squad to strengthen it even more. At times I think about how many players I could bring in with that money."

Though never saying that he wants to leave, Ferdinand is known to have been tempted by Barcelona's overtures in the summer and West Ham's position at the bottom of the Premiership has put Leeds in a strong bargaining position.

Despite concerns about the mooted abolition of the transfer system, the Leeds manager David O'Leary has not been deterred in his pursuit of the 21-year-old centre-half. Indeed, the frailties exposed in his squad before Tuesday's Champions League defeat of Milan have made him more determined to lure Ferdinand.

At the same time, Leeds privately regard Redknapp's admission of needing money to bolster his squad as a veiled invitation that he is ready to do business. "We have not made a second bid but our original offer still stands," said Ridsdale.

The new Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri has assured Tore Andre Flo he has a future at Stamford Bridge after speculation linking the Norwegian striker with a move abroad.

"It's certainly not the case, as some newspapers have said, that I am going to be on my way," said Flo. "I have had a talk with Claudio Ranieri and he seemed very positive to me. He said he liked me as a player, which is a nice thing to hear from your manager."

 Mark Bosnich, third-choice goalkeeper at Manchester United, has rejected a third loan move, this time to Napoli, newly promoted to Serie A. The Australian previously turned down Celtic and Middlesbrough.

 Kaba Diawara, unwanted at Blackburn, has been signed by West Ham on loan until the end of the season. The Frenchman, once with Arsenal, was due to return to Paris St-Germain but was snapped up by the Upton Park club as cover for injured strikers.

webTitle: England take red route to revive spirit of '66

fields.headline: England take red route to revive spirit of '66
fields.trailText: A helpful linesman from the former Soviet Union could prove hard to come by, but England will try to recapture the spirit of 1966 during next month's World Cup qualifier against Germany by wearing red shirts for the last match at the old Wembley stadium.
fields.body:
A helpful linesman from the former Soviet Union could prove hard to come by, but England will try to recapture the spirit of 1966 during next month's World Cup qualifier against Germany by wearing red shirts for the last match at the old Wembley stadium.

Kevin Keegan is keen for his players to don the red jersey on October 7, not only because it was worn by England when they defeated West Germany to win the World Cup 34 years ago but also because his side beat Germany wearing those colours at Euro 2000.

"It's the right occasion for the red shirt," said the FA's executive director David Davies. Supporters will be encouraged to attend wearing red.

Among the guests at the match will be the 1966 finalists Bobby Charlton, Franz Beckenbauer and Uwe Seeler. Lady Ramsey, the widow of England's then manager Sir Alf, has had to turn down her invitation.

Meanwhile, the FA is leading a campaign to keep the existing transfer system. It is gathering support from leagues, clubs and federations across the European Union and will send signed statements calling for the retention of the system to Uefa next week. The FA wants fans to add their weight to the appeal. Supporters can email info@the-fa.org.

webTitle: Byelection blow to Ulster peace deal

fields.headline: Byelection blow to Ulster peace deal
fields.trailText:
The peace process in Northern Ireland has suffered another
                                                  setback with a previously safe Ulster Unionist seat in South
                                                  Antrim falling to Reverend Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist
                                                  party.
fields.body:
The peace process in Northern Ireland has suffered another setback with a previously safe Ulster Unionist seat in South Antrim falling to Reverend Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party.

The DUP candidate, Reverend Willie McCrea, a vehement opponent of the Good Friday agreement, defeated UUP candidate David Burnside by 822 votes in last night's byelection, to take what had formerly been the party's second safest seat in Northern Ireland. He received 11,601 votes, overturning a 16,000 Ulster Unionist majority.

After the result was announced, Rev Paisley claimed that Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble and the Good Friday agreement were "finished".

"I think Mr Trimble is finished, absolutely finished. We're going to see that this province is not going to bow to [Sinn Fein leader] Gerry Adams or to Dublin or to [British prime minister Tony] Blair or [Irish taoiseach Bertie] Ahern or Trimble. The writing is on the wall for Trimble now. He must go, and go quickly."

Mr Trimble, who will meeting senior party colleagues later today to discuss the disastrous result, has insisted he has no intention of quitting. But there is no doubt he is under severe pressure and could face a leadership challenge from the anti-agreement wing of his deeply divided party at the annual conference in Belfast on October 7.

Last March, South Belfast MP Reverend Martin Smyth won 43% of the vote in a leadership contest against Mr Trimble and several sources fear Mr Trimble might not be so fortunate a second time. The ousting of Mr Trimble by an opponent of the Good Friday agreement would place the accord in jeopardy.

The Stormont first minister is also being squeezed over the government police bill, due to go to the House of Lords early next month.

Mr Paisley warned that the DUP intended to try to take as many as possible of the eight Ulster Unionists seats at the general election, which he said would make the peace accord democratically untenable.

He claimed Mr Blair was still ignoring DUP proposals for democratic majority rule as the only viable alternative to the peace deal.

"The agreement is not a democratic document. The alternative doesn't need the support of nationalists, it needs the support of democrats who accept the ballot box without the need for guns."

One of Mr Trimble's close allies, Stormont trade minister Sir Reg Empey, denied the end was nigh for his party leader or the Good Friday accord. "Any person who is leading the party has got to confront the fundamental issues. Nobody as yet has put forward a coherent alternative. The DUP can appeal to the emotions but they cannot deliver on the ground."

webTitle: Hughes urges tougher curbs for most dangerous sex offenders

fields.headline: Hughes urges tougher curbs for most dangerous sex offenders
fields.trailText:
Britain's most dangerous sex offenders
                                                                  could be held indefinitely in prison under
                                                                  new plans being considered by the Liberal
                                                                  Democrats.
fields.body:
Britain's most dangerous sex offenders could be held indefinitely in prison under new plans being considered by the Liberal Democrats.

Simon Hughes, the party's home affairs spokesman, said the use of "indefinite sentences" would not necessarily mean prisoners gained longer sentences, but there would be a more controlled release of them into society.

Serious sex offenders would be given a minimum tariff, but it would be up to judges to assess whether satisfactory arrangements had been made for them to be let out.

Mr Hughes' call for a review of the current sentencing policy came as the party addressed an issue which has been a national preoccupation following the abduction and murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne in July. There has been strong pressure for a "Sarah's law" which would allow parents access to the sex offenders' register.

Earlier this month the government ruled this out, but introduced other proposals, including fingerprinting and photographing offenders on their release and life bans on them contacting their victims.

Indefinite sentences are not an option at present unless a serious sex offender has re-offended, but the Home Office is looking at applying this to a small number of extremely dangerous sex offenders under separate legislation.

Yesterday Liberal Democrats called for "serious consideration" to be given to this measure, and called for the victims of sex offenders to be told where and when their abusers would be released. Proposing the motion, Gary Glover said: "Victims of serious crimes should not be terrified day after day, week after week by fear of meeting offenders."

Delegates also called for sex offenders convicted outside Britain to be placed on the register when they enter this country, and for the public to have access to this. But there was condemnation of the News of the World and its recent campaign to name and shame paedophiles, widely criticised by police and probation services at the time on the grounds it would drive offenders underground.

"It didn't take the News of the World to make the world aware of this problem," said Mr Hughes. "The News of the World were entirely irresponisble and entirely self serving."

webTitle: Blunkett denies teacher crisis

fields.headline: Blunkett denies teacher crisis
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The education secretary, David Blunkett, yesterday acknowledged that teacher shortages in England were running at about the same level as last year, but denied there was a national crisis caused by schools' continuing inability to fill vacancies.
fields.body:
The education secretary, David Blunkett, yesterday acknowledged that teacher shortages in England were running at about the same level as last year, but denied there was a national crisis caused by schools' continuing inability to fill vacancies.

Following surveys showing thousands of unfilled secondary school posts throughout the country, Mr Blunkett pointed to research by the Department for Education and Employment research showing there were around 1,000 vacancies in secondary schools at the start of the new academic year. This compares with 1,250 in January.

Speaking at the official launch in London of the General Teaching Council - an independent body representing the teaching profession in England - Mr Blunkett admitted the government did face a challenge to improve recruitment, particularly in London, and in the shortage subjects of maths and science.

The drive to attract more graduates into the profession had produced a 5 % increase in applications, but the number of unfilled vacancies remained static at autumn 1999 levels, Mr Blunkett said.

His department said that it had decided to carry out its own survey of the shortages to find out the true scale of the problem, following head teachers' claims that the situation is the worse for 20 years.

Mr Blunkett said measures, including training salaries, £6,000 bursaries and "golden hellos" for teachers in subjects with acute shortages such as maths and science, would make a difference.

webTitle: MacIntyre goes under... the weather

fields.headline: MacIntyre goes under... the weather
fields.trailText: The investigative journalist Donal MacIntyre is being lined up to present a new programme: on the weather. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The investigative journalist Donal MacIntyre, whose reputation suffered a knock when he was accused of distorting a report on a nursing home, is being lined up to present a new programme: on the weather.

BBC bosses want him to front an Eye of the Storm-type show, which would take him into the heart of hurricanes and tornadoes around the world.

The programme is being developed by the BBC's science unit, but a corporation spokesman was keen to stress that the new direction for MacIntyre did not mean his investigations were taking a back seat. "He is still attached to the investigations unit," he said.

MacIntyre was accused earlier this year of misrepresenting a Medway nursing home in one of his programmes. Police investigated the allegations and two people were cautioned. The BBC says MacIntyre is still considering whether to take legal action against the Sunday Telegraph, which claimed he had edited the film in a biased way

The BBC concedes it is unlikely that MacIntyre's investigative shows will continue in the same format as before - not least because everyone recognises him now.

webTitle: Putin seeks his guru

fields.headline: Putin seeks his guru
fields.standfirst: After a busy week internationally, Ian Traynor reports from Moscow on how the Russian press see the big stories
fields.trailText: After a busy week internationally, Ian Traynor reports from Moscow on how the Russian press see the big stories.
fields.body:
In what might be termed a symbolic truce between the hunter and the hunted, President Vladimir Putin, an ex-career KGB officer, has just been out to the Moscow suburbs to visit Alexander Solzhenitsyn, the elderly Nobel prizewinning author who was hounded out of Russia by the KGB in the 1970s.


Solzhenitsyn
The Vremya-MN newspaper describes Putin's homage to the grand old man of Russian letters as a PR stunt and ''a populist move''.

''The head of state can't be seen seeking advice unless the adviser is an undisputed authority, a generally recognised guru - and not even Solzhenitsyn can be called that.''

Less critically, the Trud newspaper, owned by the Gazprom gas monopoly, notes that both men have a lot in common, an ardent desire to ''save the nation'' and restore Russian greatness.

It talks of '' a rapprochement'' between a Russian president and one of the most bitter critics of modern Russia's development.


US Election
Russia has been thrust into the US election campaign with the Republicans publishing a 209-page denunciation of the Clinton administration's eight years of bungling policy towards Russia.

''There are no new facts nor sensations in the report,'' the pro-government Nezavisimaya Gazeta reports sniffily.

''It's just an electioneering document. The Republicans accuse their presidential opponent of establishing a relationship with the leadership of Russia.

"A corrupt leadership, the report's authors insist. The only leadership there was, the Democrats respond.''

The opposition Segodnya paper notes that the report's publication was brought forward from next July to be wielded as a campaign weapon.

''The report itself proves that Washington and Moscow are closer than ever before.''


Cosmonaut Dies
The death at 65 years old of German Titov, the second man into space in 1961 after Yuri Gagarin, is featured in all the papers.

''He still holds the record as the youngest man in space - he flew when he was 25 - and has a crater on the moon named after him,'' the English language Moscow Times noted.


Kremlin Media Clampdown
The opposition Segodnya, part of the Vladimir Gusinsky media empire which the Kremlin is currently trying to tame, reports that a new ''rapid reaction group'' made up of spin doctors and secret policemen is being formed in the Putin administration to counter opposition media.

The brainchild of Gleb Pavlovsky, a PR consultant and key Putin adviser, the unit is to specialise in character assassination, rapid rebuttal of inconvenient reporting, and blackmail to discourage critical coverage of government policy, the newspaper says, citing sources in the Kremlin.

webTitle: Fights,  Explosions, and War

fields.headline: Fights,  Explosions, and War
fields.trailText: BLUE TWO
fields.body:
BLUE TWO

A new display has appeared in the window of Chelsea's of Chelsea, the fashionable West London boutique. Said to encapsulate the virtues of 'Strength' and 'Determination', 'Passion' and 'Commitment', it is filled with images of Celestine Babayaro diving headlong into challenges, and Marcel Desailly impressively fending off a Bradford front line. Installed by the new boss, it's been praised for its dream-like qualities by some critics, while others wonder whether they haven't seen it somewhere before.

Describing the piece ahead of tomorrow's stupidly early Premiership encounter with Manchester United, new man Claudio Ranieri said: "In sport you can lose but the fans have to be proud of the team fighting to seek victory until the last minute." As the crowd applauded he went on: "I want to see how hard my players will play and fight during the match", adding: "We need to realise who has the right ability and spirit to be part of the future, who wants to die on the pitch and who doesn't." Actually, that last bit was Gianluca Vialli after last season's 3-2 defeat at Old Trafford, but you get the general idea.

So the Chelsea boys will have to pull their finger out or else or else Ranieri will sign another multi-million pound foreigner. Following yesterday's spurious link to Ajax's Danish winger Jesper Gronkjaer - substantiated on onefootball.com by quotes from Gronkjaer's agent which he never actually made - the Blues are today in talks with Celta Vigo over winger Gustavo Lopez. "He is a player we have looked at for some time," Colin Hutchison said of the Argentine international. "No fee has been agreed, it hasn't gone that far. We are waiting to see how the situation develops." He's not the only one.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *
