* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SIDEWAYS, SIDEWAYS AND AWAY!

Aston Villa manager John Gregory - football's Mr Gregory - is a very nice man. You wouldn't ever catch him standing in an empty room trying to start a fight. Or a fire, come to that. So we're not surprised that he's sensibly and rationally decided to put Ugo Ehiogu's not-quite-as-upwardly-mobile-as-planned £9m move to Middlesbrough on hold until this weekend's fixture between the two teams is out of the way. After all, if he didn't, this already tense fixture would be a Paul Merson-shaped powderkeg waiting to explode - and who wants that? Not John, that's for sure.

"Middlesbrough have been on to us about Ugo," a clearly not-to-be-hurried Gregory explained. "We have been talking to them, but I am not going to rush this through for the weekend," he yawned, filing his nails with an insouciant flourish. "I certainly don't want to do that as I don't want to be in the position where Ugo is playing against us."

Let's hope Gregory's level-headed approach is catching on at Villa Park: if chairman Doug Ellis keeps calm, he'll find it much easier to talk West Bromwich Albion out of the £4.5m he is contractually obliged to pay them when he sells the 27-year-old defender. Ehiogu joined Villa from the Baggies for £40,000 nine years ago, and as part of that deal Albion are entitled to 50 per cent of any sell-on fee. Ellis, however, is seeking to negotiate a compromise involving "a lump sum and a smaller percentage". Which sounds totally fair to us.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Some people were saying that Paulo Di Canio and Joe Cole were like a circus act because they were trying all sorts of tricks against Liverpool. But that is a load of rubbish" - Harry Redknapp tries to disprove the age-old theory that footballers + tricks = car with doors falling off.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

G WHIZZ

During the past few years, the G-14 group* of Europe's top football clubs have - like a certain central European state in the 1930s - made a series of increasingly belligerent demands. "Give us a bigger Big Cup or we will set up a breakaway super league!" they threatened, and before you could say 'Czechoslovakia' those panic-stricken folk at Uefa shot their hands up in surrender. "While you're at it, give us a greater share of the money too," the G-14 barked. Once again, Uefa meekly appeased them.

For a while, an uneasy peace held. Until today that is, when the G-14 announced they are to form an association, and basically go legit. This is bound to precipitate new demands for even more Big Cup cash. So what was Uefa's response to these never-ending demands? Did they offer Luxembourg to the G-14 as lebensraum? Or cave in completely? Well, surprisingly, no. Instead, they decided to strike back - as only Uefa can - with a bureaucratically worded letter.

"If you form an association, you will be breaking Uefa and Fifa statutes and taking an opposite position which carries a sanction of being outcast from football's structures," a scary letter to every club in the G-14 said today. It may not sound much, but for Uefa this is bold with a capital B - threatening, as it does, to expel the clubs from all football should they go ahead.

But seeing as the G-14 are already committed to their plans, a classic football fudge is also a possibility. Perhaps a European Super League will be set up with the big clubs getting even more big money. Perhaps an increasingly powerless Uefa will remain - nominally at least - in charge. Perhaps. What do you think?

* The G-14 are Barcelona, Real Madrid, Manchester United, Liverpool, Bayern Munich, Juventus, Internazionale, Milan, Ajax, Paris St Germain and, ahem, Porto, PSV Eindhoven, Borussia Dortmund and Marseille.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

West Ham are interested in Rayo Vallecano striker Juan Perez 'Bolo'. "I have to admit the prospect of playing for a big English team is very interesting," the 26-year-old is reported to have said.

Coventry are preparing a £2m bid for Blackburn's out-of-favour Lee Carsley.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Dennis Bergkamp has denied he wants to leave Arsenal and says he is to discuss a new contract in October. "Of course I want to stay at Arsenal," he said. "I love playing in England and living in London and the club has been very good to me."

Celtic striker Mark Burchill has signed for Birmingham on a three-month loan deal with a view to a permanent £1.5m transfer.

Gary Rowett wants to play for Scotland. The Leicester defender, who was born in the West Midlands, said: "I know my grandfather on my mum's side is from Dumfries - I've done a lot of research. I've got his birth certificate to prove it and lots of other papers. I've spent a lot of time tracing my family's background."

Celtic captain Tom Boyd has been awarded a testimonial match that could earn him at least £400,000.

Wales squad to play Norway in Cardiff on October 7 and Poland in Warsaw on October 11 in World Cup qualifiers: P Jones, Freestone, Crossley; Ward, Delaney, G Roberts, Melville, Coleman, Symons; Page, Barnard, Robinson, Savage, M Jones, Pembridge, Speed, Johnston, Giggs; Hartson, Blake, Saunders, I Roberts.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TEAM NEWS IN BRIEF

Bradford v Southampton. David Hopkin and Ian Nolan are ruled out for Bradford, although Benito Carbone and Dan Petrescu are set to return. Marian Pahars, who scored the winner at Valley Parade last season is doubtful because of a hamstring injury. Uwe Rosler stands by.

Coventry v West Ham. Youssef Chippo, who took a finger in the eye from a team-mate during Coventry's goal celebrations in the Worthington Cup, is fit to play. Kaba Diawara goes straight into West Ham's squad after signing on loan. He will provide cover for Paolo di Canio and Frederic Kanoute, who both have hamstring problems, while Davor Suker has a groin injury.

Derby v Leeds. Craig Burley played one hour for Derby's reserves this week and is set to make his first start of the season. However Leeds captain Lucas Radebe, who trained for the first time today since his neck injury in Barcelona, will not be risked until Tuesday's match against Besiktas at the earliest.

Ipswich v Arsenal. Ipswich defender Titus Bramble has recovered from a hip injury but James Scowcroft and Fabian Wilnis face late fitness checks. Tony Adams, Robert Pires, and Patrick Vieira all miss out for Arsenal.

Liverpool v Sunderland. Robbie Fowler will have to be content with a place on the Liverpool bench despite scoring five in the reserves in midweek. Sunderland manager Peter Reid is set to name the side that beat Derby.

Man Utd v Chelsea. Teddy Sheringham is likely to be recalled as Andy Cole's partner in place of Dwight Yorke. Meanwhile Chelsea are still without Ed de Goey, Gustavo Poyet and Mario Stanic through injury, while Celestine Babayaro is away on Olympic Games duty.

Middlesbrough v Aston Villa. Middlesbrough will be without Christian Karembeu, who has a knee problem, as well as Gary Pallister and Steve Vickers. But on-loan Gary Walsh remains in goal. David Ginola, who has been taken off in each of his two appearances this season, will start for Villa.

Newcastle v Charlton. Newcastle's new £2.25m signing Lomana Tresor Lua Lua goes straight into the squad but striker Carl Cort is a doubt after suffering a minor reaction to a hamstring problem. Charlton's Richard Rufus has recovered from the injury that kept him of the Worthington Cup defeat at Stoke.

Tottenham v Man City. Ramon Vega will make only his second start this season alongside Chris Perry. Mauricio Taricco remains doubtful with a groin injury but Tim Sherwood is likely to return in midfield. City's Kevin Horlock could miss out with an ankle problem.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 2: Division Three Football - Live (7pm) Who needs Robot Wars or The Bill or some second-rate Steven Seagal movie when you can enjoy live Third Division football? Not us, that's for sure.

Sky Sports 3: Hold the Back Page (10pm) Brian Woolnough's bouffant: stronger and longer than ever before.

Sky Sports 1: Premiership Preview (11.30pm) If only we could say the same about the rest of his body.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WICKED WHISPERS

Which smooth-talking football pundit - who has been shagging Laura from Fiver reader Pat Viner's office - apparently bursts out laughing at the crucial moment?

webTitle: All set for the week ahead

fields.headline: All set for the week ahead
fields.standfirst: The Labour party conference starts this Sunday. It will probably be the last before the general election and is a key chance for Tony Blair to recover from his slump in the polls. Julian Glover looks at what to expect
fields.trailText: The Labour party conference starts this Sunday. It will probably be the last before the general election and is a key chance for Tony Blair to recover from his slump in the polls. Julian Glover looks at what to expect.
fields.body:
 Where is it? This year's Labour conference - and next year's, too - is held in Brighton. These days, conferences have become so large that only a few towns can cope with holding them. Blackpool used to be one of them - but New Labour crossed the town off the list.

 When is it? The conference begins on Sunday afternoon, when Tony Blair holds a question-and-answer session. This is nominally with delegates, but Mr Blair will have more than half a mind on how his answers will go down with the electorate.

 The conference ends on Thursday 28 September with a rendition of the red flag and - on past form - a barnstorming speech by John Prescott. The same day will bring the guest of the week: Nelson Mandela flies in to cheer up the party faithful.

 Who's going? The 720 Labour party delegates expected to attend make up only a fraction of the 4,000- 5,000 people likely to turn up for at least part of the week. Trade Unions account for around 400 people, and MPs, MEPs, Members of the Scottish Parliament, peers, Welsh Assembly and National Policy Forum members make up another 700. On top of them come hundreds of journalists, lobbyists and exhibitors. Older Labour activists complain that they feel excluded at an event that increasingly resembles a trade fare.

 The key moment will be Tony Blair's address to the conference. Last year, he abandoned staccato soundbites for a potent attack on what he called the "forces of conservatism" stalking Britain. This year he'll speak days after falling victim to those same forces in the petrol crisis. Will he cave in to popular demand for cheaper fuel, ride out the storm by pointing to Labour successes in other areas, or tackle the demonstrator's demands head on? How he handles the situation will say a lot about the nature of the next general election.

 Expect other highlights to include Gordon Brown's speech. He too will have to respond to claims he should cut tax on fuel - but will also speak against the background of claims he lied over what he knew about donations to the Labour party.

 The full agenda of the conference will be published on Sunday. With it will come a guide to the hundreds of events on the conference fringe. The petrol crisis will certainly be a talking point here - even if it is ignored on the floor of the conference itself.

 Expect complaints about government policy from backbench Labour MPs worried that they may lose their seats - and their jobs - in a year's time. Watch out too for the vote on reform of the House of Lords - there is a good chance that conference will vote for a fully elected upper house, against Tony Blair's wishes.

 No prizes for guessing the hate figure of the week. William Hague will come in for plenty of criticism - not least because focus groups show that mention of his name is more likely to deter people from voting Tory than encourage it.

 Protest of the week will come from truck drivers who may try to blockade the conference to highlight the rising cost of fuel. Will they prove more effective than last year's demonstration by the Countryside Alliance? It filled the streets of Bournemouth with hunting horns and tweed, but left Labour policy unchanged.

 Everyone will have their ears open to catch the song of the week: in 1997 Labour bopped to D-Ream's "Things Can Only Get Better and last year Tony Blair entered the hall to give his speech to the sounds of Fatboy Slim's Praise You. With the Tories ahead in the polls, no doubt this year's choice will be a little more sombre.

Watch out too for the vote on reform of the House of Lords - there is a good chance that conference will vote for a fully elected upper house, against Tony Blair's wishes.  No prizes for guessing the hate figure of the week. William Hague will come in for plenty of criticism - not least because focus groups show that mention of his name is more likely to deter people from voting Tory than encourage it.  Protest of the week will come from truck drivers who may try to blockade the conference to highlight the rising cost of fuel. Will they prove more effective than last year's demonstration by the Countryside Alliance? It filled the streets of Bournemouth with hunting horns and tweed, but left Labour policy unchanged.  Everyone will have their ears open to catch the song of the week: in 1997 Labour bopped to D-Ream's "Things Can Only Get Better and last year Tony Blair entered the hall to give his speech to the sounds of Fatboy Slim's Praise You. With the Tories ahead in the polls, no doubt this year's choice will be a little more sombre.

webTitle: DoCoMo to form alliance with AOL

fields.headline: DoCoMo to form alliance with AOL
fields.trailText: Japan's NTT DoCoMo has agreed a tie-up with US internet giant AOL, reports Luisa Metcalfe.
fields.body:
NTT DoCoMo, Japan's dominant mobile phone company, is to form an alliance with US internet giant AOL.

The deal, reported in Japanese newspaper Sankei Shimbun, will boost AOL's flagging fortunes in Asia and win it a place on more than half of the mobile handsets in Japan.

It will also take DoCoMo's state-of-the-art "i-mode" technology - an early success story in selling internet access and messaging over wireless handsets - to the US market for the first time.

AOL will not make a significant difference to DoCoMo's earnings, but the deal will open up the US telecoms market to the Japanese company, while confirming AOL's position as a dominant global internet player.

Access to AOL content is invaluable in the drive to capture a proportion of the next-generation mobile phone market. Sankei reported that the companies will form a joint venture in the US, with DoCoMo expanding its i-mode mobile phone internet access service by co-operating with existing mobile phone companies.

The deal will give DoCoMo a 40% stake in AOL's Japanese operations.

webTitle: You bet your life: week six

fields.headline: You bet your life: week six
fields.standfirst: Each week throughout the season, Football Unlimited's finest take on the bookies, and you the reader, in an attempt to find the best gambler since Freddie Laker. It's a marathon not a sprint, brought to you in association with Blue Square
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £112.61
Paul MacInnes = £87.02
Sean Ingle £74.50
Football Unlimited punters' collective = £67.50
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £112.61
Paul MacInnes = £87.02
Sean Ingle £74.50
Football Unlimited punters' collective = £67.50

Scott Murray

Chelsea to beat Manchester United £5 @ 4/1

Logically, there is really only one winner of this match, and it ain't Chelsea. United are already three points clear of their nearest title challengers - let's not patronise Leicester fans by pretending they'll stay the distance - and the way they're beginning to play doesn't auger well for those who like a bit of excitement come May. Factor in Chelsea's abject form and United's home record - they haven't been turned over at Old Trafford since 1999 - and you're looking at a home banker.

But are Chelsea really such a long shot? There's no need to list names to prove the quality they possess, and last week's home defeat at the hands of Leicester will surely come to represent the nadir of their season. Claudio Ranieri's players will run out tomorrow morning with something to prove to their new manager - who can't have failed to improve rock-bottom team spirit - so if United hit a couple of bum notes, hosts and visitors alike could be wearing shocked expressions come 1.15pm on Saturday.

OK, it's unlikely - but at this price I think the visitors are worth a pop.

Paul MacInnes

Preston to win at half time against Sheffield Wednesday. £5 @ 3/1

For a split second last Saturday afternoon I was in ecstacy. I had backed a certain Mr K Phillips to score first against Derby and midway through the first half the radio commentary switched to the Stadium of Light. "Sunderland have opened the scoring," the breathless pundit said, "and the goal has gone to Kevin Kilbane." A crushing blow, particularly when Phillips went on to score the winner. But that brief moment will remain with me, and I won't be frightened to make such bets again.

There is the bit of the bonkers in this week's wager. The bookies have obviously decided that this Saturday will be the first day of Sheffield Wednesday's season. They have them at evens to beat David Moyes' well-drilled Preston side, despite the fact that the Owls are yet to win at Hillsborough and have lost three of their four home matches.

I think Preston could win the match outright at 9/4. But the odds are better on North End having the advantage at half-time, and with new US striker Brian McBride making a favourable impression plus the possible return of leading scorer Jonathan Macken, it's a possibility. So while a half-time bet is risky, I have plumped for it all the same. And we'll see what the commentators have to say about that.

Sean Ingle

Manchester United v Chelsea to draw @ 9/4; West Ham to beat Coventry @ 7/4; Aston Villa to beat Middlesbrough @ 7/4 and Blackburn to draw with Bolton 9/4. Four £1 trebles and one £1 accumulator.

Value stalks me. I see it everywhere; it whispers to me, even in my dreams. And, most of all, it's there in Blue Square's betting slip. Or at least I think it is. Because every time I see a bet that seems to offer the 'v' word (like Villa to beat a Middlesbrough side who haven't won at home all season and have Karembeu and Pallister out), I think: yeah, let's do it. But then - almost instantly - the crushing doubts start, and I scramble for a safety net.

That's why I've picked four value-heavy bets and permed them within an inch of their lives. That way, I figure, if one fails and the other three come off, I'll still win big money. Well, it sounds rational enough to me, as do the bets themselves. Coventry haven't won at home all season so why should they be favourites against West Ham? Bolton have won all four of their away games in the league so why can't they get a point at Blackburn? And Chelsea, for all their problems, have a new manager and a great record at Old Trafford, so a point isn't out of the question, is it? Is it?

Last week Blue Square's Patrick Murray suggested my smug-o-meter (as if I possess such a thing) was out of control for the 21 minutes where it looked like my treble would come off. Not likely Patrick, not likely. Because I wasn't watching my bets I was watching my team. And they, alas, didn't win either.

Football Unlimited Punter's Collective: Ben Taylor, contract manager

Aston Villa to beat Middlesbrough @ 7/4, Liverpool to beat Sunderland @ 2/5, Tottenham to beat Manchester City @ 4/7. £5 treble.

A nice little treble to kick things off with - so, I should look for 'value' and ignore trebles eh? We'll see.

The problem here is that I'm a Villa supporter, and it's an unwritten rule that you shouldn't back your own team. Still, let's be honest, Boro are a pretty poor bunch and we thumped them 4-0 at their place on Valentines Day last season. If you need further evidence, Julian Joachim scored twice that night. Enough said??

Liverpool won't be much value but are winning games at Anfield and showing some pretty good stuff as well. I think they'll squeak it 2-1.

I like Spurs - they're dull and workmanlike, and in pretty decent form -and it won't be long before someone puts five past City. I don't think it will be this weekend, but a deflection in the 91st minute will do. Get in there!

webTitle: The Insider

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst: She goes to the parties so you don't have to
fields.trailText: She goes to the parties so you don't have to
fields.body:
Hard to know what to do in New York - the opportunities are so endless. Bit like hedging your bets on a dinner date in case something better turns up - only the something better is always something better. Take Monday. Mr Avant-garde himself, Miguel Adrover, had a late show - 9pm start which means 10. The Big party was due to start at 8ish, so... do you a) go to Big, leave, go to the show, then go back to Big? Or b) go to the Chanel No 5 party at the apartment of property tycoon Henry Buhl, dash back to Adrover, then go to Big? Or c) have dinner with friends? In the end, b) seemed the best bet. Chanel No 5 bash: hosted by Vogue, well chic pad, cool uptown address, cool downtown art collection by Cindy Sherman and Nan Goldin. Adrover: 537 outfits later (OK, so it only felt that long). Big party: too big, got separated from mates. Wished I'd gone for c).

Then... Tuesday. Calvin's got some do on in his new store. No one's quite sure what it's in aid of but the wall-to-wall Brit hacks don't seem to care . Fancy seeing you here. Fancy seeing you here. Fancy seeing you, you and you here. 'nother glass of champers, anyone? Left none the wiser. Marc Jacobs' signature show was late and downtown on some basketball court, conveniently situated next door to a fave Italian haunt. Suzy Menkes to the left. Hamish Bowles to the right. Could you ask for more fashion salubrious company? I'll have whatever pasta they had.

Then... Sophie Dahl's birthday party, also downtown. Didn't actually get in , not because I was blagging it but because a miserable bouncer was doing his job too officiously. You don't pay $5 for the karaoke option when it's a birthday party, do you? Caught up with Soph at the Diane von Furstenberg show where her sexiness was second only to that of the designer herself. Take note, NY: 70s-style wrap dresses don't work on sticks.

T hen... suddenly available for Marc Jacobs' after-show party which was held somewhere - but by this point, past caring. Next door was a bar, the other side a cupcake shop . The New Yorkers packed the bar, the Brits reminisced about their childhoods. Sweet. Sat on wooden benches on the sidewalk. Picked off icing and smuggled out drinks. Planned the next day's packed schedule. And organised who was going where next night. Manolo? Tommy Hilfiger? Let's wait and see if something better turns up.

webTitle: The king of cool ( and he irons his jeans )

fields.headline: The king of cool ( and he irons his jeans )
fields.standfirst: Deborah Bee meets fashion darling Marc Jacobs  as he launches his diffusion line
fields.trailText: Deborah Bee meets fashion darling Marc Jacobs as he launches his diffusion line
fields.body:
Five hours ago, wild horses couldn't have dragged me into a pair of pressed jeans. Years of wrestling my mother over the ironing board have left mental scars. Shirts... yes. Trousers... thanks very much. Jeans... "Oh for God's sake, Mother, you don't iron jeans." If alarm bells are ringing, you're in for a shock. The knife-sharp, pressed-so-hard-it-turns- the-denim-white crease will shortly adorn every pair of jeans worth its salt. Why? Because Marc Jacobs says so.

If you haven't heard of Marc Jacobs - if you've been living under a stone for the past couple of years - he is the reason pleated skirts stopped reminding you of school and why denim has become cool again. For the past three years, his signature collection, shown in New York, has won the hearts of women everywhere (women after a certain look - luxurious but simple, classic but eclectic) and the plagiarism of the high street.

He has become the darling of the fashion world, backed by LVMH since 1997 and winning awards for womenswear and accessories. He has even been pronounced "New York's dauphin of grungy, understated cool" by American Vogue - not bad for a designer who, after a swift rise to fame following a degree at Parsons, was fired from Perry Ellis in 1995 for a collection that is said to have begun the whole grunge trend.

This month, Jacobs has produced a mainline collection for spring/ summer 2001, opened a menswear store in New York and introduced a secondary clothing line, Marc. In three weeks, he will roll out his latest looks at Louis Vuitton. A busy man, but strangely unassuming. "I don't think I'm at all influential," he says. "I don't understand it. I'm not being modest. I'm just a hard worker."

The morning after the shop opening party, Jacobs is holed up in his suite at the Mercer Hotel in SoHo. In five hours, he will deliver the new Marc line, intended to complement his existing range but also to address a new, younger, funkier customer.

We meet in the lobby for coffee. His hair is fluffy and he runs back to his room for a sweater. He's sweet and reserved and shy. Get him on his specialist subject, though, and he swings into gear pretty quickly.

"I don't think my approach to design is that different. True, I don't talk about the sky in India being my inspiration or creating a fantasy. I get criticised for that sometimes, for being unimaginative or uncreative, but that's fine because those are two words I find very difficult anyway. I just like to be, and I like to do. I don't think you should have to validate a garment by saying what inspired it. If someone is wearing it, it's valid."

But like it or not, his style has become definitive. Take the jeans - reinventing something held to be naff has become his trademark prank.

"It's always kind of fun to embrace something awful," he laughs. "When I did the grunge collection, we showed Converse sneakers in duchess satin, Birkenstocks with $5,000 pleated dresses I'd cut the hems off. It wasn't to be rebellious, it was the discord of the whole thing I loved - and still do."

This skewed way of looking at fashion extends into every area of his life. "Some of my favourite objects are inspired by things that aren't valued. There's a tumbler at Tiffany designed by Elsa Perretti. It's in beautiful, elegant crystal but Elsa maintains it was inspired by a Dixie cup - you know, those classic little disposable cups worth two cents a piece. I find real comfort in things that are familiar and banal. I like to elevate garments by putting them in beautiful fabrics."

Jacobs' mainline collection, shown last week, was quite a departure from his past two which sparked the prim look of the late 90s. This season was sexier, more energetic. You couldn't help but know he'd relaxed with it, had fun with the bright spaghetti-strapped dresses wrapped with wide leather belts with huge diamanté buckles. "The past couple of seasons, I stopped getting excited about fashion, it became a formula. It felt like we were starting over again this season. It hadn't been much fun; now it is."

The new Marc collection, complete with ironed jeans, continues Jacobs' passion for "embracing the awful". There are clear plastic bomber jackets, hot pink ra-ra skirts, bobby socks with court shoes and those funny elastic belts with plastic clasps we loved, then learned to hate. There are also super-fine cashmere T-shirts, classic canvas trenchcoats, elegant single-breasted jackets and wispy chiffon skirts. Put it together and suddenly what was once scarily familiar from your childhood has a new context, a new status.

"I have not reinterpreted these wacky ideas into luxury fabrics," Jacobs says. "I have elevated them and given them a new time. There is still the right creased jean and the wrong creased jean. We found a pair in a thrift shop that had obviously been worn and worn, ironed and ironed, so the idea was to recreate them."

But while the challenge of making it work on the catwalk is one thing, the challenge of wearing it is quite another. Wouldn't your average woman in a Lurex-threaded jacket look less Joe Cool, more Joan Collins?

"There is a certain type of girl who can pull off this look. She is self- assured, with a frivolous side. Sexy but edgy, comfortable in her own skin."

Five hours later, the appreciation of Jacobs' new Marc line is evident among the gathered fashion elite. Backstage, the girls are begging to keep their outfits - a sure sign that the collection will be a hit.

"All the girls love it." Jacobs smiles. "At the fittings, [Brazilian model] Ana Claudia was running up and down shouting: 'I want all the T-shirts, I want all the shoes, I have to have the jeans.' It sounds terrible but all those models who wear all those fantastic clothes on all those runways, if they like something, well, then I'm happy. I don't design clothes to sit in a closet. I make clothes for people to wear.

"If I were Ana Claudia," he adds, "if I were going to New York and London and Milan and Paris, I'd be sick to death of clothes. I wouldn't want those jeans if they could walk on their own." I, on the other hand, ordered two pairs.

webTitle: Will the real Tony Blair please stand up?

fields.headline: Will the real Tony Blair please stand up?
fields.standfirst: Andrew Roth writes exclusively for Guardian Unlimited about what drives the prime minister. Read his view of Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy here
fields.trailText: Andrew Roth writes exclusively for Guardian Unlimited about what drives the prime minister. Read his view of Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy here.
fields.body:
A behavioural psychologist trying to find the real Tony Blair among his many conflicting smiling postures would be inundated by choice.

He could be tempted to see the prime minister as a rightwing social democratic entryist who succeeded in capturing the victory-starved Labour party from within, unlike those who had left to establish the Social Democratic Party as a rival show.

With the help of his Svengali, Peter Mandelson, Blair pursued a policy friendlier to Europe, stripped Labour of its long-dead Clause IV, and made plans for a Labour-Liberal Democratic alliance.

Under this scheme, there were to be two seats in the cabinet for the Liberal Democrats, to help block a feared leftwing veto. Only Labour's massive 179-seat 1997 majority (instead of the 30 predicted by Mandelson) blocked this part of the project.

A plot-sniffing rightwing psychologist might favour a rival scenario. As the son of Leo Blair (a leader of the pre-war Glasgow young communists), Tony Blair, with the help of Peter Mandelson (who, at 18, sold the Morning Star at Kilburn station) has brought more leftwingers into government than even Harold Wilson.

The Foreign Office is the most leftwing ever, with Robin Cook and Peter Hain ruling the roost. At International Development we have Clare Short, who like leader of the Commons Margaret Beckett was in the hard-left Campaign Group until 1988.

And there are two other former semi-Trotskyist northerners in the Cabinet: Stephen Byers and Alan Milburn, who once hung out in Newcastle's Days of Hope socialist bookshop, known locally as "Haze of Dope".

The conflict between these scenarios leads to a more realistic synthesis: that the PM, apart from his Anglo-Catholicism, has no rooted ideology whatever and is a political weathervane subject to any puff of hot air from one of Philip Gould's focus groups.

A leak in July revealed Blair's insecure reaction to Gould's doom-laden over-interpretation of the fears of Middle England: "We should think now of... locking up street-muggers," responded the barrister-PM. "Something tough, with immediate bite." And then the fatal: "This should be done soon and I... personally should be associated with it."

What other government chief would come up with plans for on-the-spot £50 fines for hooligans or putting 3m DNA prints on a police database, without consulting either the police or his own home secretary? Apart from undermining cabinet responsibility, this suggests a man without a fixed political ideology apart from a scaled-down Clintonism.

Well to the right of the recent Democratic convention in the United States, Blair favours a new self-made entrepreneurial elite, particularly if multi-ethnic and contributing generously to Labour party funds (but without Ecclestone-like demands).

The absence of thought-through ideology undermines the prime minister's serious achievements in office, such as devolution. Having, in theory, devolved power to Wales and London - as well as Scotland - Blair muddied his monument by trying to impose Alun Michael on Wales and anybody-but-Ken on London.

His achievement in Northern Ireland was undermined by pulling the rug from under the wildly popular Mo Mowlam in favour of massively unpopular Peter Mandelson. Similarly, the House of Lords has been shorn of all but 92 of its hereditary peers without any early guarantee of even a substantial elected minority.

Geneticists might find such fluidity a hereditary trait. His father, Leo Blair, made the jump from pre-war Young Communist League to the Conservative ethos he swallowed whole while in a wartime officers' mess. When he became a law lecturer after the war, he hoped to become a Tory MP and was only stopped by ill-health.

But Leo made sure his son went to suitable schools, Durham Choristers and Fettes, the grandest and strictest Scottish public school.

In fact, Leo Blair was not the prime minister's father's real name. Born illegitimately, Leo was given up for adoption to a family of leftwing Clydeside shipriggers, the Blairs. His adoptive grandmother, Mary Blair, was so attached to Leo that she blocked off all later contact with his real parents, claiming he had died in the second world war.

Although young Tony stood as a victorious Tory candidate at 11 in a 1964 mock-election at Durham Choristers school, he was slow to develop an interest in politics.

At St John's College, Oxford, at the end of the turbulent 1960s, he showed no outside interest except in playing guitar in the rock group Ugly Rumours and listening to the idealistic Catholicism of a visiting Australian.

The Tories, who have tried to tag him an early leftwinger, an anti-European with CND sympathies on the basis of his 1982 byelection contest in Beaconsfield, are miles wide of the mark.

Once Blair decided, as a young barrister, on a career in Labour (with the encouragement of his chambers chief Derry Irvine, now lord chancellor, and his room-mate Cherie Booth) he had to adopt the political garments required by Labour's then-tiny selection panels. (Famously, Richard, now Lord, Marsh had borrowed a CND badge to secure his selection for Greenwich.)

Far from being aligned with the left, Blair adapted himself to their tastes too, but considered party activists to be a "small group of utterly unrepresentative people" who "hijacked the party" and almost "tipped it into extinction".

This explains his utter insensitivity to Labour activists in later years. Blair and Harriet Harman had no qualms about sending their children to posh, selective schools, against which Labour workers had been agitating for years.

To compensate for this abrasiveness, in office Blair has delivered on his promise of making New Labour a party for which the disillusioned ex-Tories in Middle England could vote. The petrol crisis may have changed all that.

And Labour has another problem: 30,000 members have left since 1997. Can the party summon up enough door-knockers to enthuse ex-Labour voters? Even Mo Mowlam is giving up in disgust. Tony Blair will need more than his smile to continue his success.

 One of Britain's best-known and best-informed political biographers, Andrew Roth is the author of Parliamentary Profiles, a renowned series of reference books which has kept track of the doings and sayings of Britain's MPs over the last four decades. His opinions on MPs have long been treated with respect within the House of Commons.

webTitle: High court rules conjoined twins can be separated

fields.headline: High court rules conjoined twins can be separated
fields.standfirst: The High Court judgment
fields.trailText: Conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, who both faced death if they were not separated by surgeons, must be operated on, the court of appeal ruled today.
fields.body:
Conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, who both faced death if they were not separated by surgeons, must be operated on, the court of appeal ruled today.

In a dramatic and long-awaited decision, the three judges sitting in London said doctors should go ahead with the procedure to divide the pair.

The operation will condemn "unviable" Mary to an almost certain death but save the life of the healthier Jodie.

Their devout Roman Catholic parents from the Mediterranean island of Gozo, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had asked the three judges to overturn a high court ruling last month giving surgeons the go-ahead for the operation.

But after more than three days of deliberation, they disagreed with the parents and upheld the court's ruling. Solicitors for the parents and Mary were given permission to appeal to the House of Lords.

Earlier today, one of the judges had described the decision as an "excruciating dilemma".

Lord Justice Alan Ward commented on the immense problems posed by the case as he arrived at the London court today and said he believed it was inevitable the decision he and his fellow two judges would eventually make would split the nation.

Lord Justice Ward said: "It has been excruciatingly difficult. One's heart bleeds for the family. Fifty per cent of the population will agree with the decision - 50% will think we have gone potty," he said.

Doctors admit the operation to separate the two children is bound to result in the death of "unviable" Mary, but say it could save healthier Jodie and offer her the chance of a full life.

In an unprecedented recent hearing which drew worldwide attention, Lord Justice Ward, sitting in the appeal court with Lord Justice Brooke and Lord Justice Robert Walker, starkly said the court had been asked to decide: "Do we save Jodie by murdering Mary?"

The case raised for the first time ethical and moral questions which could have a profound impact on the law, particularly with regard to unlawful killing.

Critics have already suggested it could provide a way of introducing euthanasia in such tragic cases "by the back door".

The twins, given false names to protect their identity, were born at St Mary's hospital, Manchester, on August 8, after their parents, who are from a Mediterranean community, came to England to give them the best chance of survival.

Following the births, the parents took advice from friends and a priest and decided that separating the twins was "not God's will" and nature should take its course, even if that meant the loss of both children.

All sides agreed that Mary will have a short existence. She has just a primitive brain and lives only because she is attached to her "bright and alert" sister and relies on her heart and lung functions to oxygenate her blood.

The court was originally told doctors expected both would die within six months without the operation. But during the hearing new evidence raised "the horrible spectre" that they could survive longer, possibly for years, joined together with Mary slowly draining away Jodie's life until both died.

However an emotional plea was made to the court by the Archbishop of Westminster for "innocent" Mary to be allowed to live out her tragic existence.

The Most Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor said Mary possessed the same "basic worth and dignity" of every human being, adding: "She has done nothing which could justify killing her".

He rejected the argument that Mary's horrific disabilities made her life "futile". He argued the wishes of the parents, who had the best interests of both children equally at heart, should be respected, and the family should be allowed to leave the country, if necessary, and take up an offer of care in Italy.

webTitle: Frostrup gaffe leaves new BBC1 chief embarrassed

fields.headline: Frostrup gaffe leaves new BBC1 chief embarrassed
fields.trailText: September 22: New BBC controller Lorraine Heggessey describes Mariella Frostrup fronting an edition of Panorama as 'a joke'. Matt Wells reports.
fields.body:
The new controller of BBC1 has described the decision to approach Mariella Frostrup to front an edition of Panorama as a "joke", apparently without realising that the presenter had already been signed up.

Lorraine Heggessey said Ms Frostrup would not be appropriate because presenters of the BBC's flagship current affairs show should have "serious journalistic credentials" - Ms Frostrup is more known for her velvet-voiced TV commercials than hard-edged journalism.

Yet on the day the interview appeared, the BBC confirmed that Ms Frostrup would present a Panorama investigation into the phenomenon of Big Brother-style reality television programmes. The gaffe is an embarrassment for Ms Heggessey, who was only appointed to the position last week.

The BBC attempted yesterday to limit the damage caused by her comments, saying she had not been involved in the decision to approach Ms Frostrup. But some BBC figures privately welcomed her remarks, since they appear to display her commitment to serious journalism on BBC1. There had been fears that the channel would become too entertainment-led, under plans to reposition the BBC's television stations.

In the interview with the Daily Telegraph, Ms Heggessey was asked about the idea to approach Ms Frostrup, which was first revealed by the Guardian. She replied: "Mariella's a talented broadcaster but I'm not sure she'd be right for Panorama. I don't know if anybody really did suggest it, but if they did, it was probably said as a joke. The presenter should always be someone with serious journalistic credentials."

Yesterday, a spokeswoman for the BBC confirmed that Ms Frostrup would present an edition of Panorama as a "one-off". She said: "Lorraine has not yet started as controller of BBC1, and this is not her commission. The decision was taken before she was involved."

Ms Heggessey was making the point that "people with the right credentials" should front all programmes.

The BBC insisted Ms Frostrup, with her background in arts and cultural programming - she is a former presenter of a film review show on Channel 4 and fronted the BBC's Edinburgh festival coverage - made her suitable to report on the impact of programmes like Big Brother.

The decision to approach Ms Frostrup, made at a time when the BBC is attempting to revive Panorama's flagging ratings, raised eyebrows among senior figures at the programme.

In unpublished comments during the same interview, Ms Heggessey did not deny reports that the BBC might reduce Panorama's length from 40 minutes to half an hour. The annual run has been cut from 38 to 30 programmes and the budget increased by £100,000 in an attempt to revive the show.

webTitle: The Wind Will Carry Us

fields.headline: The Wind Will Carry Us
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: From first to last, the impression is of utter confidence and mastery... It is a film that lingers in the mind
fields.body:
Abbas Kiarostami's The Wind Will Carry Us, a quotation from the Iranian poet Forough Farroukhzad, catches the viewer unawares with its meditative beauty, like an enigmatic lyric with a repetitive, incantatory stanza form. And these are qualities which, far from being difficult or alienating, are refined and clarified by the unaffected directness of Kiarostami's cast, professional and non-professional, from whom he elicits sublimely natural performances. From first to last, the impression is of utter confidence and mastery.

The action begins in the village of Siah Dareh in the dramatic plains of Iranian Kurdistan - a fertile and sunlit terrain (very different from, say, the rocky and misty Kurdish landscape that Samira Makhmalbaf realises in her Blackboards, duenext year). An "engineer", played by Behzad Dourani, arrives from Tehran, with a camera crew that we are never allowed to see. He appears to take an interest in the local customs, in the health of an old woman in the village, and in the local cemetery. He is harassed by calls from his own family on a rented mobile phone.

Perhaps he is here to record local tribal customs that will be carried out on the old woman's death; perhaps his own family have something to do with it. We never find out definitively. He and his colleagues head off, and the mystery of this remote community is not so much left intact as enlarged and disseminated. The obvious idea of contrasting rural and urban existences is dissolved by the ineffable strangeness of the engineer's playful, humorous intrigue with the villagers. It is a film that lingers in the mind.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip shaves its head, puts on a pair of Doc Martens and heads for Prague
fields.trailText: Ugo Ehiogu is set to join Middlesbrough next week in a £9m deal, reports the Express. "We have been talking with Boro for the last two weeks, but I can't say when there will be a conclusion," said Villa manager John Gregory.
fields.body:
Ugo Ehiogu is set to join Middlesbrough next week in a £9m deal, reports the Express. "We have been talking with Boro for the last two weeks, but I can't say when there will be a conclusion," said Villa manager John Gregory.

New Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri has failed with an audacious £8.5m bid for Ajax winger Jesper Gronkjaer according to most of the papers. "Chelsea are looking for a left-sided midfielder and Jesper is top of their list," is what Gronkjaer's agent Vincenzo Morabito is supposed to have said yesterday. But this morning he told planetfootball that he said no such thing and the rumours linking Gronkjaer to Stamford Bridge are "completely untrue."

Instead Planet Football claim that Chelsea are more interested in Atletico Madrid's attacking midfielder Hugo Leal. However the Portuguese youngster also interests Parma and Inter.

If West Ham do decide to sell Rio Ferdinand, they could replace him with Japan centre-half Tsuneyasu Miyamoto from Gamba Osaka. "We are going to take the lad. It's a big commercial deal for the club - and he is a decent player," admitted Redknapp.

And Planet Football also claim that West Ham are "ready to swoop" for Rayo Vallecano star Juan Perez "Bolo" as well. The 26-year-old striker has made a good start to the season for Rayo, and the website claims his "hot form" has put him "at the top of Hammers boss Harry Redknapp's shopping list."

Dennis Bergkamp is ready to leave Arsenal unless he is guaranteed first-team football, according to the Mail and the Sun - however most of the other papers put a much less sensationalist spin on the same set of quotes from the Dutchman.

Coventry manager Gordon Strachan is planning a £2.5m bid for Blackburn midfielder Lee Carsley, reports the Mirror.

Mark Bosnich has turned down a move to Napoli.

Wimbledon have made a £1m offer for Sunderland defender Darren Holloway.

webTitle: BBC withdraws radio feed after foreigners listen in for free

fields.headline: BBC withdraws radio feed after foreigners listen in for free
fields.trailText: September 22: The BBC has been forced to pull down its analogue satellite radio feed as listeners were getting licence fee-funded services.
fields.body:
The BBC has been forced to pull down its analogue satellite radio feed after discovering that listeners in continental Europe and Ireland were able to receive licence fee-funded services for free.

BBC sport broadcast rights, which are negotiated for UK territories, do not entitle the BBC to broadcast sporting events outside the UK. But listeners in the Irish Republic and continental Europe, who do not pay a licence fee, were able to pick up Radios 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 Live without paying.

A spokeswoman for BBC Radio 5 Live confirmed that the BBC's satellite had been pulled down. "We've purchased only rights for UK territories. It's not very nice for people listening abroad, but our remit is to look after the UK licence fee payers," she said.

fields.trailText: September 22: Despite ITV's news returning to its former 10pm slot, the BBC is adamant that it will still move its 9pm news to 10pm as well.
fields.body:
Insiders at BBC News have reacted with a defiant shrug of the shoulder to Culture minister Chris Smith's remarks on News 24 this morning. "We'd back our ten o'clock bulletin to the hilt against a revamped News At Ten," said one. "If we go up against them we'll kill them."

A BBC spokeman said this morning: "We announced our plans for the evening news in August and we don't see any reason to change those plans."

He added: "We are committed to nightly news every week night, but the ITV plans will be confusing for viewers."

More to follow...

webTitle: News at Ten return

fields.headline: News at Ten's back - over to you, Greg
fields.standfirst:
The return of News at Ten is an embarrassing climbdown for ITV boss David Liddiment, but it could prove more of a lasting headache for Greg Dyke and the BBC.

Minister urges BBC to rethink news move
ITV backs down by Jessica Hodgson
fields.trailText: The return of News at Ten is an embarrassing climbdown for ITV boss David Liddiment, but it could prove more of a lasting headache for Greg Dyke and the BBC. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
ITV's "steps of the court" deal with the independent television commission is a breathtaking end to the long-running wrangle over News at Ten.

Despite the network's attempts to present the deal as an "imaginative compromise", it is clearly a rather embarrassing climbdown given that ITV has always insisted that rescheduling was simply not on the cards.

But David Liddiment and his team at the Network Centre decided that a few spots of blood on the carpet now were preferable to having their innards splattered all over the walls if they lost their court battle later.

Liddiment wistfully admits that he rather fancied the fight, but decided that being locked in to a News at Ten or News at 10.30pm five nights a week was a far worse prospect than the compromise deal hammered out with the ITC over the past few weeks.

As it stands, he can show the news later on two nights a week, including every Friday. The other day (or it may be two in some weeks and none the next) will be clearly "signposted" in advance. He conceded an extra £42m for ITV's programme budget, but won a few extra minutes of advertising space in peak time to pay for the spending spree. It is a classic compromise of the kind Patricia Hodgson, now chief executive at the ITC, was used to hammering out at the BBC.

ITV's battle now will be with the viewers - will they accept what one BBC executive gleefully described as a "dog's breakfast"? But the BBC can't afford crow for long. As Sir Trevor McDonald mulls over the offer to return to his old News at Ten stomping ground - Mrs McDonald will surely have a say in it - the BBC now has to decide whether to press ahead with its plan to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

So while the deal draws a line under whole sorry story, the troubles are just beginning for Greg Dyke. He will have a fight on his hands to persuade the board of governors that such a nakedly commercial move going head-to-head with News at Ten is an appropriate move for a public service broadcaster to make. Over to you, Greg.

webTitle: News at Ten is back, except when it's on at a later time

fields.headline: News at Ten is back, except when it's on at a later time
fields.standfirst:
Minister urges BBC to rethink news move
Comment by Matt Wells
ITV backs down by Jessica Hodgson
fields.trailText: ITV is to bring back News at Ten as part of a last-minute settlement to its legal wrangle with television regulators, throwing the BBC's plans to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm into disarray.
fields.body:
ITV is to bring back News at Ten as part of a last-minute settlement to its legal wrangle with television regulators, throwing the BBC's plans to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm into disarray.

In a deal to avoid a damaging court battle with the independent television commission (ITC), the broadcaster agreed it would show its evening news at 10pm at least three nights a week. ITV bosses want Sir Trevor McDonald to present the 10pm programme.

The network presented the climbdown as an imaginative solution, but the BBC said it was confused, and Gerald Kaufman, chairman of the Commons media select committee, attacked it as "deplorable".

BBC executives publicly insisted they would press ahead with the plan to move the Nine O'Clock News to go head-to-head with News at Ten, but the Guardian understands that Greg Dyke, the director general, is deeply concerned about the implications of yesterday's deal. The BBC's governors may not approve the plan in the light of the ITV compromise.

The deal represents a victory for the regulator's new chief executive, Patricia Hodgson, the former head of policy at the BBC, who has only been in her new post for a few weeks.

But ITV has won three important concessions. First, the "new" News at Ten will be 20 minutes long, the same length as the current 11pm programme. Second, there will be more commercial breaks in peak time. Third, ITV bosses can push back News at Ten to a later slot on Fridays and one other night a week, if they want to screen long drama shows or films. The 6.30pm news is unaffected, and late regional bulletins stay at 11.20pm.

Sources at ITV believe Sir Trevor is keen to present the new programme, but will not decide until returning from a weekend in Jamaica. If he returns to News at Ten, the vacancy at the 6.30pm bulletin could be filled by Dermot Murnaghan.

ITV's judicial review of the regulator's earlier insistence that it reschedule the 11pm Nightly News, which has been scoring far lower ratings than the old News at Ten, was due to begin next week. The action has now been dropped. ITV said yesterday that it did not want to risk losing the court case and being forced to bring back News at Ten five nights a week with no concessions.

David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, who proposed the deal, denied it would confuse viewers. "It's the best of both worlds," he said. ITV would clearly "signpost" the days when News at Ten would be screened later.

Mr Liddiment, who has previously insisted that ITV would not back down in the two-year battle, said the risk of losing a court battle was not worth taking. "As an overall package, it's one that we can live with."

Ms Hodgson also denied the deal was a fudge, saying it would re-establish a "habit" of news at 10pm, but gave ITV the commercial flexibility it required to compete in the digital TV age. "This agreement has been reached in a new spirit which is about balancing public service obligations with commercial realities. It is good for news ratings, and good for ITV's bottom line."

After ITV was allowed to scrap News at Ten two years ago, audiences for its news bulletins at 6.30pm and 11pm fell by 13%. Senior politicians, including the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and Tony Blair, expressed concern. But the network said 1m more people were watching its programmes at 10pm, and netted £100m more in advertising revenue.

Mr Smith, the Tories and Liberal Democrats said yesterday that the deal was a sensible compromise, but Mr Kaufman said the arrangement called into question the competence of the ITC as an effective regulator. "It is deplorable to say we are getting back News at Ten when it may not be News at Ten at all and when it will only be 20 minutes," he said. "I think the ITC has shown itself to be too weak."

webTitle: News at Ten - how the deal was done

fields.headline: News at Ten - how the deal was done
fields.standfirst:
Jessica Hodgson reports on the run-up to today's events surrounding News at Ten from both sides of the fence.
BBC rejects call to move news
Comment by Matt Wells
Minister urges BBC to rethink news move
ITV backs down by Jessica Hodgson
Extra peak time for advertisers
Ad industry gives thumbs-up
fields.trailText: Jessica Hodgson reports on the run-up to today's events surrounding News at Ten from both sides of the fence.
fields.body:
The negotiations that led to yesterday's News at Ten compromise came to the public's notice during the Edinburgh TV Festival, following press reports of an agreement between Charles Allen, chairman of Granada Media, and Patricia Hodgson, chief executive of the independent television commission, to sit down and thrash it out.

But sources at ITV say press coverage created a distorted perception of the discussions that took place. They say talks had been going on for some weeks beforehand and that ITV had decided a "pragmatic solution" was a better outcome than risking a judgement in court that would force conditions on the network.

The ITC had a meeting on Thursday by which the first court hearing, scheduled for next Tuesday, would have had to be ratified. ITV's head of corporate affairs, Nicola Howson, said: "David Liddiment was committed to the idea of maintaining flexibility for scheduling, but we knew it was important to resolve this situation so we could move on."

ITV sources are also keen to stress the importance of director of programmes David Liddiment in the discussions. An ITV source said: "David Liddiment has absolutely led these discussions and has fronted every meeting with the ITC."

But other observers claim that Mr Allen was the real architect of the deal, and it will establish his predominance over the ITV network, effectively sidelining Mr Liddiment, who was adamant that ITV would see the court action through to the bitter end. One source said the deal "has Allen's pawprints all over it, and it raises questions about Liddiment's future".

What seems certain is that both sides were keen to avoid a potentially damaging court case. ITV and the ITC both say officially that they were confident they could win, but insiders on both sides say the outcome was by no means certain.

fields.standfirst:
Comment by Matt Wells
ITV backs down by Jessica Hodgson
fields.trailText: Chris Smith has urged the BBC to reconsider its plans to move its Nine O'Clock news bulletin to 10pm, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Chris Smith, secretary of state for Culture, Media & Sport, has urged the BBC to reconsider its plans to move its Nine O'Clock news bulletin to 10pm, following ITV's agreement yesterday to reinstate News at Ten.

Asked on BBC News 24 how he thought the BBC should respond to the announcement, Smith said: ""I hope the BBC will now have a think about that because having a head-to-head conflict between the main news bulletins of the BBC and the ITV I don't think would make sense."

The minister welcomed ITV's decision, but said he would have preferred the news to appear on five, rather than four, days a week.

fields.trailText: ITN's former chief executive, Sir David Nicholas, has pleaded with ITV Network Centre to keep the News at Ten name, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The former chief executive of ITN, Sir David Nicholas, has welcomed ITV's decision to restore the News at Ten but has pleaded with the Network Centre to keep the News at Ten name.

He was reacting to reports that ITV may be planning to bring a 20-minute bulletin back under a different name.

"I hope they will continue to call it News at Ten," Sir David told MediaGuardian. "Everyone I know, not just in journalism but in marketing, thinks that News at Ten is a very strong brand and I think it is very important, for ITN and ITV, that they keep it."

Sir David was a key figure at ITN from its creation in the 1950s until the early 1990s.

webTitle: News at Ten comeback motivates ITV ad break alterations

fields.headline: ITV alters ad breaks as part of News at Ten plan
fields.standfirst: Ad industry gives thumbs-up to News at Ten move
fields.trailText: ITV has agreed modifications to ad breaks with the ITC as part of its decision to restore the News at Ten slot. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
ITV has agreed a series of modifications to advertising breaks with the ITC as part of its decision to restore the News at Ten slot.

The main change will be an additional 2.5 minutes of advertising in peak time. The total amount of advertising each day will remain unchanged. The ITC has also agreed that programme promotions of up to 20 seconds can be added in centre breaks. Changes to break patterns include two breaks in a 45 minute programme, four breaks in 90 minutes and five breaks in 120 minutes.

"These concessions are important because there was a concern among advertiser about changes in demographic patterns as a result of moving the news earlier. The concerns they have had are balanced by this new flexibility," said Nicola Howson, ITV's head of corporate affairs.

webTitle: Monica Lewinsky to front Channel 5 show

fields.headline: Monica Lewinsky to front Channel 5 election show
fields.trailText: She might not be the obvious choice as a political pundit, but during the US presidential election she undoubtedly has some advantages. Channel 5's latest overseas correspondent, at a cost of over £100,000, is Monica Lewinsky.
fields.body:
She might not be the obvious choice as a political pundit, but during the US presidential election she undoubtedly has some advantages. Channel 5's latest overseas correspondent, at a cost of over £100,000, is Monica Lewinsky.

Ms Lewinsky is to present six topical feature reports from the US looking at the election and other elements of American life. Called Monica's Postcards, each programme lasts around 10 minutes and features Ms Lewinsky reporting on each topic.

As part of its deal with Bill Clinton's former mistress, Channel 5 has arranged a 30-minute interview with Channel 5 News anchor Andrea Catherwood, in which she will explain "the new direction she is taking in her life", according to a C5 internal memo.

Though the broadcaster emphasises the politically astute timing of her 'postcards', Ms Lewinsky is not going to challenge Newsnight's heavyweight political reporting team. Among her subjects will be an interview with Bridget Jones author Helen Fielding, in which Ms Lewinsky will explain why she personally relates to the tormented thirty-something, and a report on the world's longest running soap opera, Days of Our Lives.

webTitle: Targets for pensions

fields.headline: Targets for pensions
fields.standfirst:
Forget the old left's horror of means testing. The government is right to be more generous to poor pensioners

Special report: welfare reform
fields.trailText: Forget the old left's horror of means testing. The government is right to be more generous to poor pensioners
fields.body:
Strange how the world turns upside down. Flaming Baroness Castle will take up her annual "La Pensionaria" stand at the Labour Party conference alongside Jack Jones, the pensioners' Wat Tyler. They will demand a regressive, non-redistributive and unsocialist policy - the restoration of the earnings link for the state pension.

They will run up the red flag for the rights of Lady Thatcher and Lord Tebbit to draw bigger pensions instead of paying out more to the likes of the extra 100,000 pensioners who fell into poverty before the minimum income guarantee was introduced, as revealed in the annual poverty report published yesterday.

Unless the now smokeless rooms behind the scenes in Brighton get this fixed, the conference will vote on restoring the link, redistributing money from the poor to the rich. The unions are all already committed to it, so unless they wisely abstain, a vote would win. Madness on all counts - socially, politically, financially.

The trouble is that 75p, branded on the soul of every party member. They won't be cheered by a dismal Help the Aged Mori poll showing the pensioner vote swinging further and faster against Labour. How could Gordon have sent Labour out naked on to the doorsteps with nothing but these pathetic pennies in their hands?

It will be blazoned on every opposition election leaflet: "Remember the 75p!" Why, they ask, didn't the iron chancellor bend and finesse a bit to get it over £1? But it will be sorted because it has to be. Everyone knows that. The chancellor can only wink and nod in his conference speech, but it will be done.

There are plenty of ways to do it. Next April inflation will lift the pension by £2, then he can roll up the £150 winter fuel sum and £10 christmas bonus. On top of that he could add another £1 with the plausible excuse that it will compensate those who will have to pay tax on what was tax-exempt income.

This amounts to £6, a goodly sum - and he still hasn't broken the principle that the pension only rises with prices. Meanwhile the poorest are lifted off the floor by the minimum income guarantee (MIG), a system already costing more that restoring the old link.

What will the Tories do? They say with glee that they will promise more on the basic pension than whatever the chancellor pays. On present form they could even offer to restore the earnings link. (They are not absolutely ruling it out.) After all, they swore no fuel tax cuts, yet six days later promised one. Their heartland better-off pensioners would be thrilled. It's a natural Tory policy. They are pledged not to keep the MIG's automatic uprating: cutting help to the poorest is the obvious Tory choice, widening inequality where Labour seeks to narrow it. The Tories' first attempt at a pensions policy promising £5.50 on the basic pension was brutally exposed when it turned out to be just 42p new money, gained by cutting the social fund for the destitute and lone parent benefits. They will need something more.

Can Labour hold the line? As usual the problem is that "restore the link", like "petrol tax cuts now" is a simple, comprehensible, popular cry. The government is doing the right thing but it isn't soundbite or billboard friendly. Labour's policies for the poor are a pig to explain even in acres of newsprint, let alone in a 20-second news bite. (Should I describe the new pensioner credit to help those above MIG but below income tax? Very good, very complex.)

Will Labour delegates choose a good doorstep winner over a decently redistributive policy? That is the case Gordon Brown and Alistair Darling will have to make. A conference vote to restore the link would be a damaging embarrassment, especially if it is won on union votes. Who needs this?

Lady Castle says she is fighting the monstrous iniquity of means testing. But if you want to give money to the poor, you have to find them first. She wants this degrading process abandoned. But how? Beveridge never managed to do it. Right from the start of national insurance the universal pension was never big enough to reach the income support (then national assistance) threshold.

No one was ever expected to be able to live on the pension alone. That meant that anyone with only the basic pension always had to be means tested and topped up.

The basic pension is now £67.50. Age Concern reckons that pensioners need a minimum of £90: half of all pensioners currently live on less. And even if the basic pension rose to £90, the poor would still be means tested for housing benefit.

She has the wit to change her mind if she chooses. It was she who first indexed pensions to earnings, but it lasted a short time before Mrs Thatcher broke the link - a folk memory burned deep in Labour mythology. Times change. Universal pensions are not a leftwing idea.

Alas, trust is all they have to go on, since so much will still be invisible at the election.

webTitle: ITC chief who brought back the bongs

fields.headline: ITC chief who brought back the bongs
fields.standfirst:
Jessica Hodgson investigates the key role played by ITC chief executive Patricia Hodgson in forcing a reluctant ITV to restore News at Ten.
Keep News at Ten name says former ITN boss
fields.trailText: Jessica Hodgson investigates the key role played by ITC chief executive Patricia Hodgson in forcing a reluctant ITV to restore News at Ten.
fields.body:
The appointment of Patricia Hodgson as chief executive of the independent television commission this summer gave the ITC clout in forcing ITV's hand on News at Ten.

In the months between the decision, in late 1998, to allow ITV to move the main bulletin and its ultimatum earlier this year, giving ITV only a few weeks to improve ratings, the ITC was branded as toothless.

The appointment of Ms Hodgson, who joined the commission after finding herself sidelined by new BBC director general Greg Dyke this summer, fulfilled two of the ITC's main requirements. Her work in negotiating the BBC charter renewal and licence fee settlement gave her the lobbying and strategy experience the commission was looking for. She is also sympathetic to ITV's need for greater commercial freedom to compete globally.

The ITC denies that Hodgson was particularly instrumental in persuading a reluctant ITV to agree to an eleventh-hour compromise. But a spokeswoman agrees that "Patricia and Charles [Allen, chairman of Granada Media] did work very hard to get the proposal to the commission". It is understood that discussions between Hodgson and Allen precipitated this.

But the decision is far from an outright victory for the public service lobby. The move has also given advertisers a lot to cheer. As one commercial director pointed out, an extra 2.5 minutes of advertising in peak time could bring in an additional 15m viewers.

Ms Hodgson has been forced to concede a lot of ground in the negotiations, settling on a 20-minute bulletin with a fixed slot on only three nights a week. Many, including Channel 4 anchor Jon Snow, believe she could have forced ITV into further concessions. He suggests: "Patricia Hodgson should have gone a lot further and pushed for a longer bulletin, five nights a week."

However, despite claims to the contrary by ITV and the ITC alike, neither side was confident enough to go to court over the issue.

Cynics have speculated that Ms Hodgson has exacted the ultimate revenge on the BBC. Formerly head of strategy and planning, she was given a diminished role by Mr Dyke, only looking after regulation. Now the BBC boss is faced with the prospect of the corporation's soon-to-be-10pm news going head-to-head with ITV's News at Ten.

As one observer pointed out, "Hodgson now has bigger fish to fry, like ensuring the survival of the ITC."

webTitle: Pension for poor could rise by £12

fields.headline: Pension for poor could rise by £12
fields.standfirst:
Special report: welfare reform
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, last night launched a dramatic political fightback by unveiling new promises to help pensioners designed to avert a humiliating defeat at next week's party conference.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Kevin Maguire  and John Carvel
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, last night launched a dramatic political fightback by unveiling new promises to help pensioners designed to avert a humiliating defeat at next week's party conference.

However, a draft national executive statement agreed yesterday fails to restore the link between the basic state pension and earnings, the key demand of many pensioner activists and unions.

The statement commits the government to increasing the guaranteed minimum income for pensioners next April, with a strong hint that it could rise to £90, a £12 increase on the present minimum.

But this will not satisfy campaigners who want the basic pension to rise in line with earnings and the issue threatens to dominate the party conference.

The chancellor made his move as part of a concerted effort to re-establish his authority after accusations that he mishandled reaction to the fuel crisis and lied over his knowledge of a £1m grant to the Labour party by Bernie Ecclestone, the formula one boss.

In a dramatic and often tense Channel 4 live interview, Mr Brown repeatedly insisted that he had not lied during a BBC interview almost three years ago when he said he did not know the true position over the Ecclestone donation.

Mr Brown also insisted last night that he would not cave into demands for cuts in fuel tax imposed by pickets or artifical deadlines.

The pensions move came as an opinion poll for Help the Aged showed the swing in satisfaction away from the government was 20% among the over 64s, compared with 8.5 % in the population at large.

"Britain's older voters have the potential to make a decisive impact on the next general election. Those aged over 64 are potentially four times as powerful a group as younger voters aged 18-24," Help the Aged said.

"They are twice as likely to vote and there are twice as many of them."

Mr Brown said last night: "We can't go back to the earnings link. What we must do is help the poorest pensioners and people on modest incomes, in many cases by more than the earnings link."

Despite widespread anger over this year's 75p increase in the basic state pension, Mr Brown and the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, insisted they would focus extra spending on the poorest pensioners and those with limited savings or occupational pensions who lose out from means testing.

A meeting of Labour's economic commission agreed a three-page draft statement, drawn up by Mr Brown and Mr Darling, to be put before the party conference.

It commits the government to raising the minimum income guarantee in April next year and in a clear signal of the target to be adopted "welcomes" a call by the social security committee's for a £90 a week minimum.

The current minimum income guarantee is £78.60. However, the commission set no deadline.

The statement says: "The government will ensure that the poorest pensioners and those who have not shared in increasing prosperity will see their income substantially raised, as they do at least as well or better than they would with an earnings link."

However, Baroness Castle said: "It's a palliative to make things taste sweeter. I will not be satisfied until the state pension as of right is adequate enough to make people independent."

Mr Brown said: "I believe the Labour party and the trades unions - many of whom have wanted the earnings link - will come behind the NEC statement because they know we are tackling pensioner poverty and we are making pensioners as a whole better off."

But union sources on the commission denied there had been a final agreement. They claimed the statement did not spell out in detail by how much the means-tested minimum income guarantee aimed at Britain's poorest pensioners would rise.
