webTitle: Ad industry reacts to News at Ten

fields.headline: Ad industry gives thumbs-up to News at Ten move
fields.standfirst:
ITV alters ad breaks as part of News at Ten plan
ITV defends News at Ten move
BBC rejects call to move news
ITV backs down by Jessica Hodgson
Comment by Matt Wells
fields.trailText: The advertising industry today broadly welcomed ITV's decision to bring back News at Ten.
fields.body:
The advertising industry today broadly welcomed ITV's decision to bring back News at Ten.

Rupert Howell, president of the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising, hailed the move as a "creative compromise" and an end to the uncertainty in the advertising industry about ITV.

In an interview with MediaGuardian.co.uk, Mr Howell said: "I find it astonishing that we live in a country where bureaucrats regulate what goes on commercial TV channels - it's pathetic and I think they should have better things to worry about. That said, that's the system we have and I think this represents a sensible compromise. For the advertising industry and advertisers it means an end to some of the disruption surrounding ITV. At least it is a resolution.

"It is a creative compromise. It is being positioned as putting News at Ten back but it's not really - it's an inventive compromise.

"The restrictions on peak time minutage have been relaxed. Airtime inflation is a big problem for clients so this helps but we certainly don't want a situation like that in the US where there is lots of clutter on screen and that is something we will be watching. This is a good decision and I think most main UK advertisers will share that opinion."

Howell's comments were echoed by others in the advertising industry. Barry Cook, managing director at D'Arcy, which handles the advertising for some of the UK's biggest spenders including Mars, Procter & Gamble and Fiat, also welcomed the move.

He said: "It's a win, win situation. The concession ITV has secured from the ITC in return for moving the news back to 10pm is an increase in peak minutage from 37 to 40 per day - which means greater opportunity to buy into Coronation Street, Peak Practice etc. This helps all of our clients. For clients targeting ABC audiences like financial services, the return of News at Ten gives a focal point to their viewing."

Mike Moran, commercial director at Toyota, which spends £20m a year advertising on TV, said: "On balance this is good news. What we have now is a very different proposition with lots of flexibility. The increase in minutage may not sound like much but what it means in reality is another 30-second spot in Coronation Street, for example, which delivers between 15m and 18m viewers.

"If there is anything that ITV can be criticised for it is not doing much with the schedule since News at Ten moved to the later slot. It had done a poor job at exploiting the new time, it was not in a strong position when these talks began and its had to take a defensive stance."

However, the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers (ISBA), the voice of British advertisers in the UK, has given a more mixed reaction.Ian Twinn, public affairs director at ISBA, said: "The good news is that we are now further forward than we were 18 months ago. The increase in minutage and the opportunities for flexible scheduling are something we very much welcome and what we have consistently asked for.

"The bad news for advertisers is that the viewing figures for News at Ten before the switch to the later slot were draining away. Advertisers pay for ITV, they are the funders and if people are switching off that's a big concern."

Other industry figures, meanwhile, continue to support Howell's view. Mick Desmond, chief executive at sales house Granada Enterprises, called ITV's decision a win-win situation for all parties. Desmond, who worked closely with the ITV, the ITC and Carlton on the News at Ten issue, said: "It's a big concession and a big win for everyone. The advertisers and agencies I've already spoken to have said they see the move as very positive, and a shrewd move for ITV," he said.

He said there would be an instant impact on terrestrial broadcaster commercial revenues given that they will get an additional three minutes of ad slots during prime time. Desmond added that the pressure would now shift to the BBC and its mooted plans to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

"There's going to be a huge political lobby to persuade the BBC against this move because the last thing everyone wants is a head-to-head on drama and sport at 9pm. We'll join this and lobby hard to try to get the BBC to change its mind.

Andy Farwell, sales director at sales house TSMS, said the decision was a good move for ITV, adding that it gave the network increased flexibility and the right to move the news around.

He said: "The 22:15 slot always used to be a highly sought after commercial spot with car advertisers using it to break their ad campaigns. That's changed over the past few years because of the growth in the number of multichannel homes, meaning that audiences for flagship news programmes has declined."

webTitle: BT appoints ex-Xerox boss as first retail chief

fields.headline: BT appoints ex-Xerox boss as first retail chief
fields.trailText: BT has appointed the former president of Xerox Europe as the first chief executive officer of new UK-based division BT Retail.
fields.body:
BT has appointed the former president of Xerox Europe as the first chief executive officer of new UK-based division BT Retail.

Pierre Danon will report to BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and be a member of the group's executive committee when he starts on October 4.

The appointment is part of a major restructuring programme announced in April. The move separates BT's UK fixed business into wholesale and retail. Retail is expected to generate £10bn in revenue per year, with more than 24m consumer, corporate and government customers.

Sir Peter Bonfield said: "I am delighted that Danon is joining at this exciting time in BT's transformation. His educational and executive background bring to BT's business an outstanding mix of operational and change management experience across a range of disciplines, in a very competitive market."

Danon said: "This is an exciting time for me to be joining BT. It is a company with a strong brand, reputation and heritage that is operating in one of the most dynamic sectors in the world."

Sir Peter Bonfield said: "I am delighted that Danon is joining at this exciting time in BT's transformation. His educational and executive background bring to BT's business an outstanding mix of operational and change management experience across a range of disciplines, in a very competitive market." Danon said: "This is an exciting time for me to be joining BT. It is a company with a strong brand, reputation and heritage that is operating in one of the most dynamic sectors in the world."

webTitle: Blair faces defeat on Lords

fields.headline: Blair faces defeat on Lords
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Lords reform
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is facing defeat at next week's Labour conference after a poll found that party members are overwhelmingly opposed to his decision to reject a fully elected House of Lords.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is facing defeat at next week's Labour conference after a poll found that party members are overwhelmingly opposed to his decision to reject a fully elected House of Lords.

The ICM poll found that 83% of Labour party members believe that at least half of the members of the reformed upper house should be elected. A mere 17% supported the prime minister's view that a minority of members should be elected.

Labour's Campaign for a Democratic Upper House, which commissioned the ICM poll, last night hailed the findings, saying it was confident of "pulling off a conference surprise".

Labour delegates in Brighton will vote on Lords reform after party members mustered enough votes to force the issue on to the conference floor.

Damien Welfare, the campaign's spokesman, said: "This poll shows that a largely appointed upper house is deeply unpopular and Labour should not support it. At this time above all Labour needs to be seen to be listening to the electorate."

However, Mr Welfare conceded that he could lose next week's vote if the unions fall in behind the party leadership.

The Labour leadership underlined its concern about the vote when the Cabinet Office minister, Mo Mowlam, wrote to all delegates urging them to back the findings of the Wakeham commission on Lords reform, which said most peers should be appointed by a non-party commission.

webTitle: AOL and Time Warner submit concessions

fields.headline: AOL and Time Warner submit concessions
fields.standfirst: Mega-merger threatens EMI/Warner music deal EMI/Warner merger: will it crash to earth?
fields.trailText: 10.45am AOL update: AOL and Time Warner have submitted a document setting out concessions for their European merger, according to press reports.
fields.body:
AOL and Time Warner have submitted a document setting out concessions in a bid to gain approval for their £128m European merger, according to press reports.

The Washington Post gained access to the proposals, which attempt to convince European Commission regulators that AOL and Time Warner will not use their combined market power to dominate music downloads over the internet.

The companies are conscious of the effect of the proposed link-up between record groups EMI and Time Warner subsidiary Warner Music, which could benefit from AOL's dominance of the internet service provider market.

However, the Washington Post said the document does not prevent AOL from giving third-party content less favourable treatment on its service. AOL could promote to its own online music over that of its competitors.

The proposals have been submitted ahead of the Sunday night deadline, and will then be sent to competitors in the European internet and music industries for comment.

The European Competition Commission has established itself as a hard taskmaster following its recent blocking of the proposed merger between US telecoms companies WorldCom and Sprint.

The commission must make a final decision on the merger by October 24 - six days after the fate of the EMI Warner deal is decided.

EC officials refused to comment on the reports.

webTitle: Halifax account goes to Delaney Lund Knox Warren

fields.headline: Delaney Lund Knox Warren wins £28m Halifax task
fields.trailText: 2pm: Delaney Lund Knox Warren has picked up the £28m above-the-line account for the Halifax, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Delaney Lund Knox Warren has picked up the £28m above-the-line account for the Halifax, bringing about the end of Bates UK's 12-year hold on the business.

Delaney Lund beat Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R for the account, its biggest new business win to date, and is now working on a branding campaign that is scheduled to break later in the year.

The advertising will aim to clarify what the Halifax stands for and to encourage more customers to open accounts.

The decision brings to an end a two-month-long review by the former building society turned bank. The process had suffered setbacks as a result of numerous other financial clients reviewing advertising partnerships and preventing a number of major agencies pitching for its business.

webTitle: Technology and telecoms stocks plunge

fields.headline: Technology and telecoms stocks plunge
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Technology and telecoms stocks this morning took a hammering on the London Stock Exchange, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Technology and telecoms stocks this morning took a hammering on the London Stock Exchange following a profits warning from US chip manufacturer Intel.

The Techmark 100 Index, the flagship technology index for UK companies, was down 128.87 points to 3,568.39 by midday, while the FTSE 100 was down 52 points, at 6,146.90, after tumbling 81 points in early trading.

Technology, media and telecoms stocks were also hit yesterday following a profits warning from US telecoms giant Sprint Corporation.

Mobile phone company Vodafone lost around 4% this morning, with Scandinavian rivals Ericsson and Nokia down 5%. Even media stocks were affected, with BSkyB down 2.3% to 1001p and United News & Media falling 3.7% to 731.5p.

Sean Johnstone, telecoms analyst at SG Securities, said: "It is a TMT stocks phenomenon, and the news from these companies is very negative at the moment, sending them to levels near the April crash. We are looking for good news, and it is not out there right now."

Johnstone added that November will be a key month for UK telecoms companies, with uninspiring results likely to put the sector back under pressure.

webTitle: Ulster sings to an old, old tune

fields.headline: Ulster sings to an old, old tune
fields.standfirst: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown profiles Willie McCrea and examines the worrying implications for the peace process of the Democratic Unionist party MP's South Antrim byelection victory
fields.trailText: Former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown profiles Willie McCrea and examines the worrying implications for the peace process of the Democratic Unionist party MP's South Antrim byelection victory.
fields.body:
Reverend William McCrea's victory in the South Antrim byelection is a severe blow not only to First Minister David Trimble, but to the power-sharing peace process.

McCrea, who was MP for Mid-Ulster from 1983 to 1997, when he was beaten by Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness, scraped back to parliament by just 822 votes in a low turn-out. But the victory of the Democratic Unionist party candidate ominously underlines the divisions in Ulster unionism, and the general lack of enthusiasm in the loyalist community for the Good Friday peace agreement.

The result was also a victory for reaction and deep-died conservatism. McCrea has been roistering around the wilder fringes of unionism since the early 1970s. An ordained minister, he has always been a stalwart supporter of Reverend Ian Paisley, the leader of the Democratic Unionist party and perennial thorn in the flesh of would-be peacemakers.

The new MP is a fundamentalist, both political and religious. He is Ireland's best known gospel singer, specialising in a curious blend of saccharine assurances of God's love, and blood-and-thunder warnings of divine wrath against unbelievers.

At campaign meetings in the 1970s, when this reporter was covering Northern Ireland, he had a habit of breaking into his own speeches by grabbing a guitar and warbling the praises of the Lord. He has a distinctive quavering, high-pitched delivery well-suited to the evangelistic pulpit, but slightly disconcerting on the political stump.

"The only answer to Ulster's problems," he used to proclaim, his voice rising to a crescendo, "is THE ROPE!"

But McCrea, and all that he represents, has to be taken extremely seriously. The DUP victory in what was once a super-safe seat for the Ulster Unionists, casts a long shadow over the power-sharing executive in Belfast.

The byelection could not have been worse timed for Trimble, who must preside over his party's annual conference next month. Almost certainly, he will be challenged - again - for the leadership, by one of the rightwingers chafing against power-sharing.

The first minister will be looking to Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson for concessions, to prop up his suddenly precarious hold on his own party. What he would dearly love would be postponement, or better still cancellation, of plans to reform the Royal Ulster Constabulary. But even that might not appease the resurgent No Surrender tendency in unionism.

The challenge could come from the Rev Martin Smyth, who ran Trimble desperately close in last year's leadership election. Another would-be standard bearer of the right, Jeffrey Donaldson MP, has already called on Trimble to withdraw from the executive.

Paisley, the old warhorse of Ulster politics, is already bellowing with righteous triumphalism. "I think Mr Trimble is finished, absolutely finished," he gloated after the South Antrim result.

One of the minor ironies of the byelection is that the losing UUP candidate David Burnside - another survivor from the turbulent 1970s - is less than wholly committed himself to power-sharing. If Trimble is brought low by the South Antrim debacle, the ambitious Burnside could be one of those jostling for position.

webTitle: Vote-hunting Bush chases the Florida key

fields.headline: Vote-hunting Bush chases the Florida key
fields.standfirst: As the race for the US presidency hots up, Martin Kettle reports from Washington on the state that could prove the key
fields.trailText: As the race for the US presidency hots up, Martin Kettle reports from Washington on the state that could prove the key.
fields.body:
George W Bush wasn't supposed to be campaigning in Florida today. The Republican party wasn't supposed to be spending more than $5m on political advertising in Florida this month.

When the two main parties did their calculations for the 2000 election, Florida was firmly assigned in the Republican camp.

Not any more.

The Sunshine State has turned into the surprise state in the 2000 election. With Bush's brother Jeb now installed as its governor since 1998, most of the pundits originally assumed that Florida would revert to the Republicans in the presidential contest after going for Bill Clinton four years ago.

Florida's 25 electoral college votes were seen as one of the key building blocks in George W's march on Washington.

But it hasn't worked out that way. As the national polls have moved his way over the past month, Al Gore's long-time belief that Florida was winnable has seemed to be increasingly plausible.

Three polls in the state this month have produced three different results - one had Gore up by four points, another had Bush ahead by two, while the third had them tied at 41 per cent each.

But the disagreement in the polls only adds to the recognition that Florida is "competitive".

Florida is the largest state in the US of which that can be said.

The only larger states are California and New York, both of which are leaning to Gore, and Texas, which is a banker for Bush.

In the 1980s, Florida was predictable too, voting the Republican ticket in four straight elections, until Clinton showed that it was not a lost cause to the Democrats in 1996.

That's still the case now. Which is why Dubya is working a full Friday in Florida today, with stops in Sarasota, Tampa and Miami.

If Florida swings to Gore, then it's all over for Bush. His schedulers had him in the state last week, and now he's there again this week too.

To make sure that Bush doesn't get a free run today, the Democrats have directed Joe Lieberman down to Florida today too, to keep up the pressure and eat into Bush's air time.

This is classic US electioneering. Every day you are tied down on defence is a day you let your opponent have a day on the attack somewhere else.

Gore, meanwhile, will be piling up the votes today in Pennsylvania, a state which used be counted as a toss-up, but where he is now commandingly ahead.

Florida is not just important for the presidential election. It also has a key Senate battle.

The state's Republican senator Connie Mack is retiring, so there is an "open" contest between Democrat Bill Nelson, a genial centrist, and Republican Congressman Bill McCollum, who became a national figure as one of House of Representatives' Clinton impeachment trial "managers" last year.

For Clinton, therefore, this is a grudge election, and it is one of the few states in which the president intends to make his presence felt during the campaign.

Florida also matters a lot in this year's party battle over control of the House.

If the Democrats are going to fulfil their second biggest ambition on November 7, they must pick up at least five seats around the US in order to retake the Congress.

That would enable them to install Dick Gephardt of Missouri in the Speaker's chair that was captured by Newt Gingrich in 1994 and is now occupied by Illinois Republican Dennis Hastert.

Of the 20 or so Republican-held House seats that really matter this time, three are in Florida.

There is McCollum's old district around Disney World in southern Orlando, fellow impeachment manager Charles Canady's seat just east of Tampa (Canady is retiring), and Clay Shaw's ocean-front Costa Geriatrica seat, which takes in both Palm Beach and Miami Beach.

Shaw's seat, in particular, could be affected by a new factor - as could the statewide races - as Florida's many Jewish retirees from up north grab the chance to vote for Mrs Lieberman's boy Joe.

Florida was one of the first Southern states to move solidly away from the Democrats to the Republicans.

Though never a classicly "southern" state, Florida could now be one of the first to mark a swing back to the Democrats in the region.

There is evidence of that swing in neighbouring Georgia, too.

But it's the presidential contest in Florida that really matters in the big picture. It explains why Gore has been to the state three times since the Democratic convention.

It explains, above all, why Bush - who is enjoying a better few days in the campaign - is back there again today.

No Republican since 1924 has won the White House without also winning Florida.

Do what Dubya does too. Keep your eye on Florida. It is the state that Bush simply cannot afford to lose.

webTitle: News at Ten

fields.headline: News at Ten
fields.standfirst: ITV has finally bowed to mounting pressure from the Independent Television Commission (ITC) and the government by agreeing to reinstate its News at Ten bulletin. But just why did the simple rescheduling of a television programme cause so much comment and concern? Claire Porter explains
fields.trailText: ITV has finally bowed to mounting pressure from the Independent Television Commission (ITC) and the government by agreeing to reinstate its News at Ten bulletin. But just why did the simple rescheduling of a television programme cause so much comment and concern? Claire Porter explains.
fields.body:
Why was the bulletin moved in the first place?
ITV's original decision to scrap News at Ten in March 1999, and replace it with a 6.30pm Evening News and the 11pm Nightly News, was attributed in part to its wish to show uninterrupted films, dramas and live sports coverage at peak time. Viewers hated the breaks in films for the half-hour News at Ten, and of course, there was big ad revenue to be had if ITV screened uninterrupted blockbusters.

Did it work?
Well, yes, if you are ITV's advertising director; no, if you were one of the dozens of very vocal campaigners who complained the new late night news had damaged democracy. While viewing figures at certain times rose, contributing to a £100m increase in advertising revenue, those for ITV's news bulletins fell by up to 13.9%. This, said various politicians, prime minister Tony Blair and culture secretary Chris Smith was actually bad news for the electorate, since less people across Britain were tuning in to any daily news as the 11pm bulletin was too late.

So we're getting the old News at Ten back?
Not exactly. It will be back, and at 10pm, but only 20 minutes long and on three times a week, instead of five. It won't be aired on a Friday night, and will also be off our screens on one other night per week when ITV will be free to transmit a movie or another major event, such as football. As for Trevor McDonald - no specific announcement has been made, but it is presumed he will simply revert back to the 10pm slot.

Now is everybody happy?
No. There are rumblings of opposition brewing to the three-nights-a-week arrangement. Gerald Kaufman, the chairman of the House of Commons culture committee, says it's "deplorable" and he has criticised the ITC, saying it had "shown itself to be weak". The BBC won't be happy either. It had planned to capitalise on the 10pm slot by moving its 9pm news back an hour but Chris Smith has urged programme bosses to reconsider. Sky News will be squirming too. Its News at Ten was doing very nicely without competition from ITV.

What right does the ITC have to force the rescheduling?
The ITC is the television industry's regulator and as such, issues licences that allow commercial television companies to broadcast in and from the UK. It does not regulate BBC1, BBC2 or S4C (the Welsh fourth channel). It can advise companies when they have breached their licence, and often this is nothing more than contacting the television company concerned, offering guidance and making it clear that the offence should not be repeated. In a more serious matter, it can issue a formal warning, require on-screen corrections or apologies, disallow a repeat or impose a fine. In the most extreme cases it can shorten the term of a licence or even withdraw it altogether. Throughout its involvement with News at Ten, it has used clipped terminology such as "insisting" and "asking". But the only recourse ITV actually had was to appeal through the courts. If ITV chose not to come forward with a proposal for an earlier bulletin after the ITC's ruling, the body was in a position to "direct" them to move it, backed by statutory powers which ensure television channels fulfil their "public service" obligations.

fields.standfirst: Scott Murray takes you by the hand and leads you through the weekend's Premiership matches
fields.trailText: Bradford City v Southampton
fields.body:
Bradford City v Southampton

Bradford's David Hopkin and Ian Nolan injured themselves playing against Darlington in the Worthington Cup this week, but the return of Benito Carbone, Peter Beagrie and Dan Petrescu more than makes up for their absence.

The home side will fancy their chances here: although Saints were one of only five teams to come away from Valley Parade with a win last season, they are likely to be without in-form striker Marian Pahars - the man who scored their audacious winner last term. Uwe Rosler stands by.

Odds Bradford 5/4 Draw 9/4 Saints 7/4 Last season Bradford 1 (Blake 77) Saints 2 (Windass 56 og Pahars 76)

Coventry City v West Ham United

News to follow...

Odds Coventry 5/4 Draw 9/4 West Ham 7/4 Last season Coventry 1 (Hadji 36) West Ham 0

Derby County v Leeds United

Not the easiest of fixtures for struggling Derby, but these days what is? Leeds have rediscovered their self-belief, which could spell trouble for the winless Rams - but at least Jim Smith's men can take heart from the absence of the melodramatic Harry Kewell, who won a dubious last-minute penalty for the visitors last year.

Craig Burley should make his first start of the season for the hosts after his troublesome calf stood up to a midweek test in the reserves. However Lars Bohinen, who has been suffering from a similar injury, is unlikely to feature.

Meanwhile, Mark Viduka - who was spotted earlier this week by our man at the Olympics strolling out of Sydney's Last Lap nightclub arm-in-arm with Stan Lazaridis - could make an early return to the Leeds side after returning from "Olympic" "duty" with Australia.

Odds Derby 15/8 Draw 9/4 Leeds 6/5 Last season Derby 0 Leeds 1 (Harte 90 pen)

Ipswich Town v Arsenal

Ipswich's promising young defender Titus Bramble has recovered from a hip injury and should be ready to face Arsenal, who have been making a meal of supposedly easier away fixtures of late. The home side are unlikely to have James Scowcroft and Fabian Wilnis to call upon, but George Burley's men have found their feet in the top flight quicker than most observers expected and won't be unduly worried by enforced changes to their side.

Arsenal news to follow...

Odds Ipswich 4/1 Draw 12/5 Arsenal 8/13 Last season n/a

Leicester v Everton (Sunday 4pm)

Everton have selection worries ahead of Sunday's match. Alessandro Pistone and midfield revelation Thomas Gravesen are almost definitely out, while Duncan Ferguson is - surprise! - still injured.

There's better news about Niclas Alexandersson, who came off during Everton's Worthington Cup shame against Bristol Rovers with a stomach upset - he should recover in time to bolster the Toffees midfield. Leicester news to follow...

Odds Leicester 4/5 Draw 9/4 Everton 3/1 Last season Leicester 1 (Taggart 8) Everton 1 (Hutchison 27)

Liverpool v Sunderland

We've lost count of the number of times Robbie Fowler has come back from injury in recent years: could this finally be the time for England's most natural finisher to realise his potential?

Fowler will have to make do with a place on the bench though, as will Titi Camara, who is also returning from treatment. Patrik Berger completes a trio of returning Reds, but Sunderland - who name the same side that beat Derby last week - will be buoyed by the continuing absence of Sami Hyypia from the home defence.

Odds Liverpool 2/5 Draw 11/4 Sunderland 13/2 Last season Liverpool 1 (Berger 2 pen) Sunderland 1 (Phillips 77 pen)

Manchester United v Chelsea (Saturday 11.30pm)

Expect a fair few celebratory fireworks to mark Claudio Ranieri's first match in charge of Chelsea - Dennis Wise and Roy Keane meet again in midfield.

Keane returns from suspension after his Charity Shield hell, and although he's not short of match practice (having played in the Champions League), his Premiership mettle is bound to be tested to the limit by the - shall we say "combative" - talents of Wise.

Paul Scholes is likely to start for United after recovering from a tight hamstring, while Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole get the nod up front. Gianfranco Zola and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink are the likely pairing at the other end.

Odds United 4/6 Draw 9/4 Chelsea 4/1 Last season United 3 (Yorke 10 69, Solskjaer 39) Chelsea 2 (Petrescu 22 Zola 36)

Middlesbrough v Aston Villa

Bryan Robson's up-and-down side were utterly humiliated on live television in this fixture last season, and Villa will be confident of making it three Premiership wins in a row by recording their third straight victory against Middlesbrough.

The loss of Christian Karembeu, Gary Pallister and Steve Vickers will certainly furrow Robson's brow - expect his face to turn to thunder should David Ginola and former Riverside star Paul Merson lead an unchanged Villa side to victory.

Odds Middlesbrough 5/4 Draw 9/4 Villa 7/4 Last season Middlesbrough 0 Aston Villa 4 (Carbone 11 65, Joachim 70 75)

Newcastle United v Charlton Athletic

There are no selection problems for the visitors. Richard Rufus has recovered from the injury that kept him out Worthington Cup action and fellow defender Steve Brown is back from suspension.

Newcastle news to follow... Odds Newcastle 1/2 Draw 13/5 Charlton 5/1 Last season n/a

Tottenham Hotspur v Manchester City

City are sweating on the fitness of midfielder Kevin Horlock, who is 50-50 with an ankle problem. Steve Howey, Gerard Wiekens and Paul Ritchie all have minor knocks but are expected to start.

Danny Tiatto is one name definitely on Joe Royle's team-sheet, though - he's recovered from an illness which kept him away from City's lumbering performance against Gillingham in midweek.

Spurs news to follow...

Odds Spurs 4/7 Draw 12/5 City 9/2 Last season n/a

webTitle: Prague springs into panic

fields.headline: Prague springs into panic
fields.standfirst: As the city readies itself for the arrivals of the bankers and the activists, Kate Connolly pops her head above the Prague barricades and takes in the scale of the fear around her
fields.trailText: As the city readies itself for the arrivals of the bankers and the activists, Kate Connolly pops her head above the Prague barricades and takes in the scale of the fear around her.
fields.body:
"It is just as if," said Vaclav Havel, "we were preparing for civil war."

Even from his perch up at Prague castle, the Czech president has not failed to notice what is happening down in the city.

Schools are closed, hospitals have cancelled all non-urgent operations, the post office says it can't guarantee deliveries, pensioners have been paid to go on holiday away from the city, and others have been warned to stock up on medication and food.

A cordon sanitaire has been established in various parts of Prague, and many taxis, convinced that they'll be unable to make money, have said they'll flee to their country cottages.

"And all this so that a bunch of bankers can meet in the comfort of our usually peaceful city," said Honza Novak, 77, as he bought a bulging bag-full of instant dumpling mix at Prague's Havelska market.

He totally expects that he and his invalid wife will be trapped in their house during "the siege".

The authorities are preparing for a war of sorts. As around 18,000 delegates gather in town for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, thousands of anti-globalisation activists are also streaming in.

The high point of the three-day meeting which runs from September 26 to 28, is expected to be on Tuesday, the opening day, when protesters have planned a so-called "counter summit" to highlight their dissatisfaction with IMF and WB policies.

Following a rally in Prague's Peace Square, they will split into groups and make their way southwards towards the Congress Centre, the venue of the meeting.

"We will continue to surround it until they agree to dismantle the institutions," said Alice Dvorska of Inpeg, an umbrella organisation uniting many of the protesters from humanists to radical ecologists to anarchists.

The Czech Interior ministry has been in a panic from the start. When the government put in its bid to host the conference five years' ago, "Remember Seattle" was not part of either the activists' or bankers' lexicon.

As a result, politicians have been fuelling scare stories and warning people to get out of town or risk facing a situation of armageddon-like proportions.

Even the interior minister, the youthful Stanislav Gross, 30, whose career could be on the line if his security plans fail, admits they might be going rather over the top.

"We hope that the biggest criticism the outside world will be able to levy at us at the end of the conference," he said, "is that we over-prepared.

"But we'd rather be safe than sorry."

As a result, 11,000 police officers - more than a quarter of the country's force - will be on duty, backed up by a reinforcement of 5,000 troops.

Water cannons that have not seen the light of day since protests in the run-up to the Velvet Revolution of 1989, are being rolled out, and tear gas equipment has been borrowed from the German neighbours.

Jiri Suttner of the police presidium has even advised police officers to think about taking out special insurance at their own expense, in case of serious injury.

Hospitals have been teaching their staff what to do in the effect of a biological weapon attack.

Yesterday, the National Nuclear Safety Office announced it had drafted in 25 experts and senior officials who will monitor the level of radioactive and toxic substances in the air, "in case a qualified expert opinion is needed next week," a spokesman explained.

Throughout the duration of the conference, sanitation officers will check noise levels and the quality of water and food.

Demonstrator groups committed to non-violent direct-action say that authorities' scare stories are being used to give them a bad name.

"We hope to create an atmosphere that is festive and celebratory, but that also demonstrates our outrage at the unjust, misguided policies that the IMF and World Bank force upon the world," explained Ms Dvorska.

Mr Havel has remained one of the few level-headed politicians throughout. "It's not the demonstrators who are provoking the agitation but the authorities which are constantly informing the press about their preparation," he said earlier this week.

But the panic continues. The windows of an outlet of Benetton on Na Prikope in central Prague were being boarded over this morning, like many other shops in the vicinity.

And workmen at the Intercontinental Hotel were busy building a brown hardboard shell for a rather vulnerable glass atrium that juts out towards the Vltava river.

And little wonder, when a headline in the country's leading tabloid hysterically instructed readers to "barricade your doors and windows". Prague awaits the end of civilisation as we know it.

webTitle: Sal or the 120 Days of Sodom by Gary Indiana

fields.headline: Shock value
fields.trailText: I was 27 when I first saw Pasolini's Salò. I worked nights at the popcorn concession of the Westland Twins, a Laemmle theatre in Westwood specialising in foreign films of the "mature romance" variety. A friend managed The Pico, an art cinema in the Fairfax District. It was autumn, 1977. I got off work at 10.30. I usually drove home to Los Angeles, stopping at The Pico, where Salò ran that season as a midnight movie. (Actually, I think it was an 11 o'clock midnight movie.) That's how I happened to see this film, or parts of it, almost every night for two months.
fields.body:
I was 27 when I first saw Pasolini's Salò. I worked nights at the popcorn concession of the Westland Twins, a Laemmle theatre in Westwood specialising in foreign films of the "mature romance" variety. A friend managed The Pico, an art cinema in the Fairfax District. It was autumn, 1977. I got off work at 10.30. I usually drove home to Los Angeles, stopping at The Pico, where Salò ran that season as a midnight movie. (Actually, I think it was an 11 o'clock midnight movie.) That's how I happened to see this film, or parts of it, almost every night for two months.

It was a time of compulsive, almost mechanical sleeping around that felt good for a few moments here and there. I had two jobs, and about two hours at the end of the night to pick someone up in a bar. Whatever followed that took at least two more hours, depending on the drive time, so I suppose, in that faraway autumn of 1977, I got an average of three hours sleep a night. That was my life, and Salò became for two months a logical part of it, another little patch of soft, crumbly alienation and waking dream.

Salò remains one of the most scandalous films ever made. An adaptation of the Marquis de Sade's 120 Days of Sodom, it is an unflinching portrayal of sexual cruelty set in fascist Italy. Through a panoply of the unspeakable - blood, excrement, torture and murder - Salò comments on the exercise of power, and on a consumer culture where a limitless choice of gratifications disguises an absence of all choice and all resistance.

It's tricky to consider one of Pasolini's films in isolation, because he occupies so much space as a figure. At the same time, the energy that collects around big, imposing names in the cultural suet deserves a measure of scepticism. Once artists become monuments, the required way of regarding them is almost absurdly contrary to our way of regarding anything else. We are obliged to find worlds of meaning in every scrap of paper they might have doodled on, any material sign of their existence turns into manna. The resulting industry of preservation, worthy as it is, has the paradoxical effect of killing any spontaneous encounter with their work. Are we genuinely moved by Mozart's music, or are we moved because we know that Mozart's music is moving? Is the publication of Kafka's Blue Notebooks a revelation, or evidence that not everything an artist does is worth preserving?

Salò is one of those rare works of art that really achieves shock value. Aesthetic shock does have a salutary value, and it's always amusing to read the outpourings of some cultural wastebasket decrying an artist who deploys shock "for the sake of shock", as if to qualify as a work of art, a work of art has to be something other than a work of art - a tutorial in cherished homilies, an affirmation of quotidian values, and so on. I don't think art has anything to do with morality and it shouldn't: I should be able to kill everybody I don't like in a novel and get away with it, rape a 12-year-old and piss on my father's grave. It's not my job to tell anybody that these things are "wrong". It's my job to show that these things happen, period.

Certain works yank the rug from under the meticulously planted furniture of middle-class morality and the aesthetic torpor that decorates it. John Water's Pink Flamingos, Jean Rouch's Les Matres fous, George Franju's Le Sang des B tes, Andy Warhol's Blue Movie, anything by Hershel Gordon Lewis, scattered moments in the films of Kenneth Anger, Jack Smith and Jonas Mekas - well, you can make your own list of things that lifted the top of your head off. I'm not sure that anyone is obliged to like works of art that fall into this category, or that liking them is never entirely the point, though critics, quite often, mistake the celebration of the ghastly as an "indictment of contemporary malaise", etc - in other words, they can only like something if it can be bent to reflect their own moral certainties.

One way that Salò differs from the unabashedly perverse epiphanies of the cinema of shock is in its pedantic moralism, which might have ruined it if the shock part didn't so thoroughly overwhelm the moralism. There is something absurdly winning about Pasolini's explanation of the shit-eating in Salò as a commentary on processed foods, and the fact that Pasolini was being sincere when he said it. And if you think about it, his interpretation is essentially reasonable, though it's hardly the first thing a viewer thinks when watching a roomful of people gobbling their own turds.

The atmosphere of scandal that misted Salò when it appeared was an aerosol of semen, excrement and blood. Salò was awash in come and shit. The blood was Pasolini's. His murder, a gruesome affair involving a nail-studded fence picket and his own sports car, struck many as all of a piece with the sadomasochism of his last movie, and with a well-advertised lifetime of patronising rough trade. One French reviewer urged that Salò be shown as a defence exhibit at the murderer Pelosi's trial, on the assumption that anybody capable of directing such a film was practically begging to be murdered.

This coincidental intersection of art and life, or art and death, became an inevitable ending, especially in a rightwing Italian press that loathed Pasolini. Once he was dead and past defending himself, the ugliest opinions about him surfaced. Was his open homosexuality the inspiration behind the denunciations and court cases that dogged his career, starting long before the segue from poet and novelist to film-maker? If we consider the artistic fortunes of a Franco Zeffirelli, it appears that only the wrong kind of faggot - a leftist rather than a reactionary, an intellectual instead of a flaming queen, someone who inserted himself in politics, took unpopular positions, made himself vulnerable - would have come in for the judicial harassment and vicious attacks that Pasolini did. While it can fairly be said that no artist of any prominence in Italy, Zeffirelli included, is ever uninvolved in politics on a quotidian level - almost nowhere else on earth is daily life subjected to such beetling, unrelieved ideological nattering - Pasolini's interventions were extreme and unflagging, pleasing to practically nobody across the political spectrum, and, uniquely, were intricately inscribed with the fact of his sexual difference.

Pasolini was quick, and right, to use the word "racism" to describe a certain kind of criticism launched against him, which emanated from the perception of his "essence" as a pervert. He was a target of racism, in this sense, from his earliest days as a teacher, when he was charged with molesting four of his teenage students. One provocation of Salò, like the X portfolio of Robert Mapplethorpe, is its ability to flush this racism into the open, revealing the limits of repressive tolerance - that social threshold of shock that says, We'll accept you if you become like us, love like us, talk like us, believe like us, hate like us .

There is such a mixture of motives and curious impulses at work in Pasolini, longueurs that take your breath away and others that make you wince. In the words of Gombrowicz, discussing Balzac's Human Comedy: "To think how easily the best soup gets spoiled when one adds a spoonful of old grease or a bit of toothpaste to it." And with Pasolini, it might not even be grease or toothpaste, but some misbegotten Brechtian fiddling with sightlines, or his endless indulgence of Ninetto Davolie, whose implacably sunny exuberance is often wearying. Still, Pasolini's elemental weirdness and audacity sustain interest (if not always sympathetic interest) through all but his most trying inventions. He is deeply, seductively cryptic: the more exposed, the more concealed, as if signalling from a world that can only be glimpsed in fragments.

 Extracted from Salò or The 120 Days of Sodom by Gary Indiana, published by BFI Modern Classics. The film is showing at the ICA, London SW1, from October 20 to November 2. Box office: 020 7930 0493.

I'm not sure that anyone is obliged to like works of art that fall into this category, or that liking them is never entirely the point, though critics, quite often, mistake the celebration of the ghastly as an "indictment of contemporary malaise", etc - in other words, they can only like something if it can be bent to reflect their own moral certainties. One way that Salò differs from the unabashedly perverse epiphanies of the cinema of shock is in its pedantic moralism, which might have ruined it if the shock part didn't so thoroughly overwhelm the moralism. There is something absurdly winning about Pasolini's explanation of the shit-eating in Salò as a commentary on processed foods, and the fact that Pasolini was being sincere when he said it. And if you think about it, his interpretation is essentially reasonable, though it's hardly the first thing a viewer thinks when watching a roomful of people gobbling their own turds. The atmosphere of scandal that misted Salò when it appeared was an aerosol of semen, excrement and blood. Salò was awash in come and shit. The blood was Pasolini's. His murder, a gruesome affair involving a nail-studded fence picket and his own sports car, struck many as all of a piece with the sadomasochism of his last movie, and with a well-advertised lifetime of patronising rough trade. One French reviewer urged that Salò be shown as a defence exhibit at the murderer Pelosi's trial, on the assumption that anybody capable of directing such a film was practically begging to be murdered. This coincidental intersection of art and life, or art and death, became an inevitable ending, especially in a rightwing Italian press that loathed Pasolini. Once he was dead and past defending himself, the ugliest opinions about him surfaced. Was his open homosexuality the inspiration behind the denunciations and court cases that dogged his career, starting long before the segue from poet and novelist to film-maker? If we consider the artistic fortunes of a Franco Zeffirelli, it appears that only the wrong kind of faggot - a leftist rather than a reactionary, an intellectual instead of a flaming queen, someone who inserted himself in politics, took unpopular positions, made himself vulnerable - would have come in for the judicial harassment and vicious attacks that Pasolini did. While it can fairly be said that no artist of any prominence in Italy, Zeffirelli included, is ever uninvolved in politics on a quotidian level - almost nowhere else on earth is daily life subjected to such beetling, unrelieved ideological nattering - Pasolini's interventions were extreme and unflagging, pleasing to practically nobody across the political spectrum, and, uniquely, were intricately inscribed with the fact of his sexual difference. Pasolini was quick, and right, to use the word "racism" to describe a certain kind of criticism launched against him, which emanated from the perception of his "essence" as a pervert. He was a target of racism, in this sense, from his earliest days as a teacher, when he was charged with molesting four of his teenage students. One provocation of Salò, like the X portfolio of Robert Mapplethorpe, is its ability to flush this racism into the open, revealing the limits of repressive tolerance - that social threshold of shock that says, We'll accept you if you become like us, love like us, talk like us, believe like us, hate like us . There is such a mixture of motives and curious impulses at work in Pasolini, longueurs that take your breath away and others that make you wince. In the words of Gombrowicz, discussing Balzac's Human Comedy: "To think how easily the best soup gets spoiled when one adds a spoonful of old grease or a bit of toothpaste to it." And with Pasolini, it might not even be grease or toothpaste, but some misbegotten Brechtian fiddling with sightlines, or his endless indulgence of Ninetto Davolie, whose implacably sunny exuberance is often wearying. Still, Pasolini's elemental weirdness and audacity sustain interest (if not always sympathetic interest) through all but his most trying inventions. He is deeply, seductively cryptic: the more exposed, the more concealed, as if signalling from a world that can only be glimpsed in fragments.  Extracted from Salò or The 120 Days of Sodom by Gary Indiana, published by BFI Modern Classics. webTitle: PR Week round-up

fields.headline: PR Week round-up
fields.trailText: Latest news from trade title PR Week.
fields.body:
PR Week leads with the news that the Interpublic Group will next year merge its three global PR brands into two, sparking the full merger of Shandwick and the Weber Group. IPG once again owns the world's largest PR agency network, overtaking Burson-Marsteller of WPP.

However, the story of the week must go to this little client conflict: the International Fund for Animal Welfare has axed Shandwick as its PR agency following news that it was working for the Japanese government to promote commercial whaling operations.

David James, the corporate troubleshooter brought in to help the Dome, has asked City consultancy Cardew & Co to advise him and the New Millennium Experience Company on PR strategies leading up to the Dome's December closure.

Manchester United football club has poached Alison Ryan, public policy chief at NTL, to be its communications director.

Band & Brown has won the account for Reuters Information - the Reuters division that supplies information on and to the world's financial markets.

Biss Lancaster has beaten five UK-based agencies to the business of promoting Jamaica to the UK public on behalf of the Jamaica Tourist Board. The account was formerly held by Barclay Stratton, which worked on the account for 10 but lost out when it repitched.

Fashion giant Tommy Hilfiger has named global marketing head Peter Connolly as its new worldwide president of public relations. Connolly will oversee public relations, marketing, advertising and the firm's online venture, Tommy.com.

US e-business magazine the Industry Standard is to launch a weekly UK and Europe edition on October 19. Mike Butcher, former editor of New Media Age, will be news editor.

webTitle: 22 September: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Anne Heche writes up her life, Gladiator gets even bigger on DVD, Outlaws screens in prison, Ritchie plans role for Madonna, and Elizabeth Berkley signs to Woody Allen project
fields.body:
 Anne Heche (pictured) is all set to write her autobiography at the age of 31. According to Mr Showbiz, the actress will write about her tragic youth which included the loss of her father to Aids when she was 14 and her brother's death in a car crash when she was 17, as well as her relationships with Steve Martin and Ellen DeGeneres.

 Dreamworks have announced that the forthcoming DVD version of Gladiator will include more than four hours of extra material. The company are hoping that it will be the best-selling DVD of the year.

 A preview of action movie Outlaws, starring Bruce Willis, is being screened at a prison in Oregon, America - because 170 inmates appear as themselves in the film in a jail-break scene.

 Guy Ritchie has hinted that he might give his girlfriend, Madonna, a part in his next film. The Snatch director said that he hoped their respective careers would intermingle soon: "We'll have to see if she plays her cards right we'll see if we can work something out," he said at the singer's recent party.

 Showgirls actress Elizabeth Berkley has joined the cast of the latest as-yet-untitled Woody Allen project for Dreamworks. The actress, who recently appeared with comedian Eddie Izzard in the London stage production of Lenny, will join Helen Hunt, Charlize Theron and Allen himself in the feature, which is due to start shooting in the near future.

webTitle: Saddam who?

fields.headline: Saddam who?
fields.standfirst: You may think that naming a child is a simple process, but, as Middle East editor Brian Whitaker explains, in the Arab world, it has multiple layers of complexity
fields.trailText: You may think that naming a child is a simple process, but, as Middle East editor Brian Whitaker explains, in the Arab world, it has multiple layers of complexity.
fields.body:
A reader took me to task this week for being on first-name terms with Saddam Hussein. Why did I constantly refer to the Iraqi dictator in a recent article as "Saddam", the reader's email asked. "Do you address the British prime minister in a serious article as 'Tony'?"

Well, no, I don't. But I suspect that the reader lives in the United States where newspapers, unlike those in most other countries, insist on calling the Iraqi leader "Mr Hussein".

That, I'm afraid, is another example of Americans trying to apply their own cultural practices to the rest of the world.

They seem to be under the impression that "Hussein" is Saddam's surname. It isn't. Calling him "Mr Hussein" is like calling George W Bush "Mr W".

Actually, I much prefer to call him "Saddam". The name comes from an Arabic verb meaning to clash, strike, bang, collide or generally behave in a hostile fashion.

You may think the Iraqi leader's parents were remarkably far-sighted in making such an appropriate choice, but in the Middle East it's usually a sign of superstitious parents who believe that an offensive name will protect their offspring from the Evil Eye.

In any case, referring to Arabs by their first name does not imply the same degree of familiarity that it does in the west.

Since starting to write about the Middle East, I have become quite accustomed to Arabs addressing me formally as "Mr Brian" or, more flatteringly when they misread my name, as "Mr Brain".

By tradition, a male Arab's full name consists of his first name, followed by his father's first name and then his grandfather's first name.

It is by no means rare for two of these names to be the same, and it is theoretically possible, though not very aesthetic, for someone to be called Mohammed Mohammed Mohammed. Using this formula, the Iraqi president's full name would be Saddam Hussein abdal-Majid.

In traditional Arab societies, where everyone knew each other and ancestry was of great social importance, that kind of naming system was perfectly adequate.

Although the old system continues to some extent, many Arabs nowadays have what we would recognise in the west as surnames. Often they describe a person's job or place of origin and some are quite recent acquisitions.

A Moroccan friend tells me that his father chose the family's surname during the French occupation because the authorities insisted that everybody should have one.

Iraq, however, moved in the opposite direction. In the early years of Saddam's rule, surnames were abolished for ideological reasons: they were thought to be socially divisive.

Cynics suggest that the real reason was to hide the fact that, as Saddam consolidated his power, an uncomfortably large number of people rising to positions of influence had the surname "al-Takriti" - indicating that they came from the dictator's home town.

There may be a lesson here for Bahrain, where 10 out of 17 government ministers today carry the name "al-Khalifa", or Kuwait, where eight out of 23 ministers are called "al-Sabah".

Regardless of a person's official name, it is not unusual for an Arab to be known locally, or among friends, as someone completely different.

This led to confusion during the first free elections in Yemen in 1993, when voters were required to write the name of their preferred candidate on the ballot paper.

Some, especially in the rural areas, knew the candidates only by their familiar names and had no idea what they were officially called.

One way that familiar names arise is following the birth of a man's first son (a matter of considerable pride in Arab society), at which point people may start calling him after his son: "Abu Ahmad", "Abu Hassan" - the father of Ahmad, the father of Hassan, etc.

But "Abu" - meaning "father" - can be taken too literally. Abu Nidal, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, wasn't named after a son called Nidal. It's a political nom de guerre, meaning "the father of struggle".

And, though you'll occasionally hear an Arab refer to someone as "Abu Nadhara", don't be fooled into thinking that's his name.

It's simply the way they describe a person with poor eyesight - "the father of spectacles".

webTitle: Life in the Jungle by Michael Heseltine

fields.headline: Life in the Jungle by Michael Heseltine
fields.standfirst:
Hodder and Stoughton, £20
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Tarzan swings through his arboretum and tells how he became lord, but never king, of the jungle
fields.body:
I was born in Wales and throughout my life the country has kept a special place in my heart, though not special enough for me to want to live there. I did my best for Wales by opening the M4 extension, but Northampton and Henley are so much handier for London.

From time to time, people have asked me to publicise my dyslexia to raise awareness of the condition, but my immense success would make me feel like a fraud parading as a victim. I was not overly academically gifted, though I still made it to Oxford where I pursued a political career with gusto. Presidents of the Oxford Union are acclaimed as among the most talented of their generation. In 1954, I was one of those people.

My first four years in the House as member for Tavistock taught me that the basic salary of £3,250 was no sort of income for supporting five houses, several forests and a full complement of staff. Luckily, I was to make a fortune from my Haymarket publishing interests. And I'm not at all ashamed of having bought my own furniture.

Margaret and I never saw eye to eye. She was devious, I was straightforward, she was wrong, I was right. But I was always supportive. I have been accused of being unstable for waving the mace in protest at Labour's disregard for Parliamentary procedure, but this is unfair. I merely picked it up; the waving happened because Jim Prior nudged me.

I've always had the common touch and most of the regeneration of Britain is down to me. In fact, I can hardly remember making a single mistake. Above all, I have always acted with honour. The full details of the Westland affair have yet to emerge but the Times described my behaviour as "a good resignation".

When Margaret stood down at the second ballot, I knew my chance had gone. I was happy to serve under John as Prezza of the board of trade, though countless people, including my PPS, Richard Ottaway and William Rees-Mogg were openly saying I should be PM. I was interested, though only because John was so obviously not enjoying himself, and not out of personal preferment.

It was a tremendous honour to become Deputy PM. My heart attack looked worse than it was and I toyed with the idea of contesting the leadership again in 1997 but I felt that the Dome should remain the apotheosis of my career. What a marvellous achievement it is.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested...

webTitle: 'Silver surfers' the next big thing

fields.headline: 'Silver surfers' the next big thing
fields.trailText: Retired people represent the next big marketing opportunity as they take to the internet in droves, Amy Vickers reports.
fields.body:
Retired people represent the next big marketing opportunity as they take to the internet in droves, according to research from Forrester Research.

Not only do retired people have time and money on their hands but they are picking up the internet much faster than originally anticipated and using it to communicate with their family and buy gifts. Forrester predicts that by 2005 there will be more than 3.2m "retirees" online and says now is the time for companies to act in order to seize this market opportunity.

The news is particularly pertinent given that people in the UK are now retiring much earlier. It is expected that by 2003 the number of senior internet users no longer in full-time work will reach 52%. "PC retirement gifts and the impact of children and grandchildren communicating via email will spur uptake of the internet among the over-55s. And the kick-off to hyper-speed learning happens when consumers spend sufficient time online to pack a year's worth of online experience into a few months," said Forrester analyst Caroline Sceats.

The most dedicated users - a subculture Forrester terms "the addicts" - will use the internet practically every day and represent a valuable market for advertisers. The opposite of this are the "experimenters", who go online for less than two days a week, limiting the chance of them being susceptible to advertising. In the middle are the "adopters", who spend an average of four days a week online.

Now is the time to start targeting these type of people, recommends Forrester. "For net-reticent retirees to turn into profitable customers, media and commerce players must create partnerships to build lifestyle management portals that attract and educate new users," added Sceats.

The report coincides with a deal between over-50s site Vavo.com and Expedia.co.uk to offer a co-branded, exclusive "silver surfers" Travel Club, demonstrating that the growing recognition of this market segment.

It has been said time and time again that the internet is perfect for the older generation, but it is only in the past year that something has been done about it. webTitle: Pi director to helm Batman 5

fields.headline: Pi director to helm Batman 5
fields.trailText: Darren Aronofsky has been confirmed as the director of the forthcoming Batman 5 film
fields.body:
Darren Aronofsky has been confirmed as the director of the forthcoming Batman 5 film. The 31-year-old, best known for directing the ground-breaking 1998 film Pi, will team up with Frank Miller, who is writing a screenplay based on his novel Batman: Year One.

The new Batman, yet to be cast, will be a more youthful version than previous film incarnations and the movie will concentrate on Bruce Wayne's first year as the caped Crusader, reports ananova.

Miller wrote Batman: Year One as a four part series in 1987 and it emphasises the super-hero's human side by showing him suffering from grave self-doubts about his crime fighting capacity and concerns over past mistakes.

One storyline includes Lieutenant James Gordon who later becomes Commissioner Gordon. Sworn enemies initially, he and Batman eventually find they are coming round to the others way of thinking.

webTitle: European Car Free Day

fields.headline: European Car Free Day
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about Britain's underwhelming response to the notion that we might all give up our cars for the day
fields.trailText: 1. You may have noticed that today is European Car Free Day, when we are all urged to leave our vehicles at home.
fields.body:
1. You may have noticed that today is European Car Free Day, when we are all urged to leave our vehicles at home.

2. On second thoughts you probably won't have noticed. Only 10 local authorities in Britain are taking part. Our European partners are much keener on the idea. Indeed, car-free days are something of a global industry.

3. We like our cars, in spite of the appalling costs of owning and running them. And, as the recent petrol crisis shows, everyone knows that the true costs of UK motoring are horrendously high, compared with other countries.

4. While organisations like the RAC huff and puff about the burden of taxes, some folk think they are just about right. Friends of the Earth (FoE), for example, is running a vigorous campaign for traffic reduction.

5. Persuading us to get our bottoms out of our cars is likely to be a heroic task for FoE. We are buying, and using, the things more and more.

6. It's reckoned, rather conservatively, that there will be 40% more cars on the roads by 2031.

7. Investment in British roads is, at best, stagnant. In fact, it has gone down in recent years.

8. The good news is that more people are using public transport. The bad news is that they have to; the roads are jammed.

9. The new holy grail for the planners is Integrated Transport. That nice Mr Two-Jags Prescott even has a ten-year plan.

10. In spite of the torrent of available statistics, transport policy remains stuck in the make-do-and-mend mode. And we remain stuck in our cars.

webTitle: Internet users have higher regard for television

fields.headline: Internet users have higher regard for television
fields.trailText: Research from Initiative Media Futures shows web users hold TV in higher regard than non-net savvy consumers, says Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Despite damning reports about the internet's negative effect on TV viewing, research from Initiative Media Futures shows web users still hold it in higher regard than non-net savvy consumers. Furthermore, the new internet generation rates traditional media higher than do those who do not surf.

When ranking TV in terms of its ability to grab people's attention and give brands stature and likeability, internet users recorded figures of 85%, 83% and 78% respectively, compared with 77%, 74% and 72% of non-internet users.

It is a similar story for specialist magazines, with internet users rating them 16% higher than non-internet users for their brand-building ability.

The research also shows that consumers believe the internet lacks the ability to portray a brand's reliability and stature and has difficulty maintaining consumers' attention.

"There has been a lot of discussion about the internet's impact on TV, but Radar [the name given to the survey] research suggests that, far from abandoning the traditional medium, consumers still love it," said Sue Elms, managng director of Initiative Media Futures.

webTitle: In brief: The Piano Shop on the Left Bank by T E Carhart

fields.headline: In brief: The Piano Shop on the Left Bank by T E Carhart
fields.trailText: Thad Carhart, an American in Paris, walks every morning past a piano shop in his quartier. One day he decides to pop in: and so begins the story of his friendship with the shop's owner, Luc Desforges, and his own rediscovery of the pleasures of the piano.
fields.body:
Thad Carhart, an American in Paris, walks every morning past a piano shop in his quartier. One day he decides to pop in: and so begins the story of his friendship with the shop's owner, Luc Desforges, and his own rediscovery of the pleasures of the piano.

In these days of warts-and-all memoirs, where each new celebrity attempts to trump his or her predecessors with ever more lurid tribulations of drugs and abuse, Carhart's exquisitely laid-back, Francophile meandering came as a breath of fresh air: "charming", "rich with evocation", "unashamedly poetic", said the reviewers. John Carey in the Sunday Times was captivated: "as desultory as an evening stroll, yet full of knowledge . . . when you close it you feel you have been on holiday," he purred.

For Carhart does not only tell the story of his new friendships and struggles with Chopin; he also sketches the workings and the history of the piano, as Luc talks him through the disassembled skeletons awaiting his attention in the sunlit, dusty Parisian atelier. From the trail of broken-backed pianos left by the tempestuous touring Beethoven, to the golden hand-made age of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and the modern giants: Steinway, Bösendorfer, and Fazioli.

Yet Carhart's way of dropping such nuggets into the gently wandering stream of his recollection left some critics dissatisfied. Stephanie Merritt in the Observer wrote that "at times Carhart's effort to stuff these miscellaneous elements into a narrative feels a little strained". In these pages, Steven Poole pointed out that the technical passages lack original musical argument, concluding that it was "an amateur's work, both in that it is written out of love, and in that it is content to stroke the lacquered surface of its subject without delving too deeply into it".

Michael White in the Telegraph complained that Carhart fails to explain "how a piece of wood and metal makes the graduation from machinery to art". "He just doesn't have the words," White grumbled. Odd, then, that John Carey thought quite the opposite: "Remarkably, he can choose words that make us feel and hear the instruments he plays." Perhaps it is with such evocative, painterly books as it is with music: we each hear something different.

webTitle: Pat Pocock steals the show

fields.headline: Pat Pocock steals the show
fields.standfirst: Tanya Aldred and Steven Lynch report from the annual cricketers' knees-up - plus the full list of winners
fields.trailText: Tuesday night was party night at the Royal Albert Hall, but there wasn't a harpist or opera singer to be seen (Henry Olonga did not attend). Instead a throng of dinner-jacketed cricketers ate, drank and danced the night away at the Professional Cricketers' Association's annual end-of-season shindig and prizegiving. Not every county trundler or Wisden Trophy-winner turned up - September is a good time for a holiday - but there was a good turnout, particularly from Surrey, Yorkshire and Warwickshire.
fields.body:
Tuesday night was party night at the Royal Albert Hall, but there wasn't a harpist or opera singer to be seen (Henry Olonga did not attend). Instead a throng of dinner-jacketed cricketers ate, drank and danced the night away at the Professional Cricketers' Association's annual end-of-season shindig and prizegiving. Not every county trundler or Wisden Trophy-winner turned up - September is a good time for a holiday - but there was a good turnout, particularly from Surrey, Yorkshire and Warwickshire.

The programme of events included a cabaret by the Stage Cricket Club, which featured an excruciating rendition of "YMCA" ("Wides, Sixes and Fours"), a long-winded auction for those with money burning a hole in their pockets, then the presentation of awards, which lasted until 11.30pm. The murmur of not-very-hushed voices throughout suggested that part was overlong.

But the Mark Butcher Band (featuring a shorn Eddie from one-hit wonders Charles and Eddie) inspired a heaving dance-floor, and the merry throng and their mostly very gorgeous girlfriends who moved on to Raffles nightclub on the Kings Road looked as if they were having a cathartically raucous evening.

But the big surprise came in mid-show. "Entertainment from Pat Pocock" suggested one of those toe-curling stand-up comedy acts that don't quite work. But Pat, the former Surrey and England offspinner, is a man of many parts (he's also been known to show off his juggling skills) and, clad in a suave jacket and an Andy Williams-style poloneck, he crooned out three songs in a passable imitation of Dean Martin, or maybe Pat King Cole. A top effort, if not quite Top of the Pops material.

Ray Julian

Darren Lehmann

The Primary Club

Alec Stewart

Darren Gough

Lucy Pearson

Net Player 2000 voted by amateur clubs via the Stakeholder for Life website
Marcus Trescothick

MCC Spirit of Cricket Award
Jimmy Adams

ECB Special Award
Cornhill Insurance

PCA Young Player of the Year
Matthew Hoggard

PCA Player of the Year
Marcus Trescothick

webTitle: Intel warning sends shock wave through markets

fields.headline: Intel warning sends shock wave through markets
fields.trailText: A shock profits warning from US computer chip maker Intel Corp has sent serious ripples through the business world and left Britain's technology shares reeling.
fields.body:
A shock profits warning from US computer chip maker Intel Corp has sent serious ripples through the business world and left Britain's technology shares reeling.

The FTSE 100 index kept off its recent lows, but remained deep inside negative territory on Friday morning after Intel's overnight warning that third quarter profits would come in way below expectations.

Initially, the news sent the index tumbling down more than 120 points. By mid morning it had pulled back a little, though it remained around 81 points down at 6,118.2.

When the news broke in the US last night, shares in the company immediately plunged by 21%, sending its value down by $77bn.

Intel's sales growth in the third quarter is now expected to reach only 3-5% compared with the 6-8%, expected by the market.

The company - the world's largest chip maker and manufacturer of computer, networking and communications products - blames a lack of European demand for its microprocessors and expects profit margin percentages to be down by up to 2%. Revenue in the second quarter of this year was $8.3bn.

Intel's statement, which came shortly after a warning by Sprint Corp, has compounded fears of a sharp slowdown in the tech and telecommunications sectors.

Almost all of the top 10 losers on the FTSE 100 were technology shares, such as UK chip designer ARM Holdings which dived 8.1%, while fibre optics firm Bookham Technology dropped 7%.

Telecoms shares also suffered from the fallout, which was worsened by the Nasdaq's overnight decline. The Vodafone Group weighed in with a drop of 2.3%, while Colt Telecom Group was the sector's biggest loser, down 6.3%. BT also lost out, shedding 20 to settle at 728.

There was some cheer on the FTSE today, however, with the Bank of Scotland heading in the opposite direction and rising 2.9%, thanks to merger speculation.

British Airways was also up 2%, as investors breathed a sigh of relief that merger talks with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines had ended.
