webTitle: Should Britain sponsor individual athletes?

fields.headline: Should Britain sponsor individual athletes?
fields.standfirst: Yes, says chief executive of Sport England Derek Casy, who believes that for too long, we have asked our brightest and best sportsmen and women to rely on natural talent and nothing else; juggling training, competition and full-time work. However Janette Wolf, editor of Sportscore, suggests that rather than concentrating on athletes already at the peak of their careers, financing should be directed towards better all-round sports education at the other end of the spectrum, within schools. Read the debate and have your say.
fields.trailText: Yes, says chief executive of Sport England Derek Casy, who believes that for too long, we have asked our brightest and best sportsmen and women to rely on natural talent and nothing else; juggling training, competition and full-time work. However Janette Wolf, editor of Sportscore, suggests that rather than concentrating on athletes already at the peak of their careers, financing should be directed towards better all-round sports education at the other end of the spectrum, within schools. Read the debate and have your say.
fields.body:
Dear Derek,
Well, what a result! A clutch of medals to kick off the Olympic Games and in... cycling. Whoever would have credited it? Well, probably you for one, since the sport was among those bolstered by a huge dollop of Lottery cash. Which only goes to show that if you throw enough money at a problem it soon goes away. Or does it?

If the answer to decades of sporting near misses and spectacular national carpetings is a hothouse, where the chosen few are guided, groomed and whipped into shape, where does that leave the next generation of would-be medal-baggers? Wishing they could be so lucky, I expect. Yvonne McGregors sprint for the womens cycling individual pursuit bronze medal was as agonising to watch as it was inspiring  I dont know many 39-year-olds who could run for a bus, let alone career round a velodrome on a bike. But why start a funding programme with athletes at the peak of their careers? Surely the money would have been far better invested at the other end of the spectrum, where the facilities are rank, where theres never any hot water in the changing rooms and where the kids  on whom future Olympic medals depend  will avoid going for anything more energetic than a fag.

Yours sincerely,
Janette Wolf,
Editor, SportsCore

Dear Janette,
Yes, the medals won by our cyclists have got Great Britains Olympic campaign off to a flying start  as have those from our representatives in shooting, judo, canoeing and the equestrian events. But we hope that its only a start. We are, after all, only half way through these games, and, of course, the paralympics are still to come.

I am glad you agree that our top-level athletes should be supported. For too long, we have asked our brightest and best sportsmen and women to rely on natural talent and nothing else; juggling training, competition and full-time work. One of the most frustrating parts of my job in the past was to receive letters from potential winners or their parents saying they were giving up because they were broke and could not continue. Most other successful sporting nations provide financial support (of one form or another) to their athletes and, if we are to compete on the world stage, we must have similar systems in place here.

You are right, however, to stress the importance of looking beyond our current crop of top-level athletes. In addition to funding those at the peak of their careers our world class programme is beginning also to support the next generation of medal-winners  those who we want to see win in Commonwealth and Olympic games in the next decade. Now I bet you want us to go further and support those who just want to take part on a recreational basis, especially in schools.

Yours sincerely,
Derek Casey

Dear Derek,
Revitalising sports provision in schools is exactly what I had in mind. But I regard this not as a further step as you put it, but as the first one, the most important one, the one you make before you set off for more ambitious destinations like Sydney or Greece.

The main reason for this is that we have to provide all children with a sound level of sporting literacy. Im not talking of those whod know a Wisden from a jar of Marmite. Im referring to those basic skills which are the building blocks of sporting activity, whether it is simple hand-eye co-ordination, flexibility or fitness. Imagine, some children pitch up at secondary school not knowing how to stop a ball with their feet. Is it any wonder that the Premier League sides are all packed with foreign imports?

We cannot possibly expect to excel in sport on an international stage while our schools have poorly-trained teachers, playing fields that vanish, and where there is a general expectation that it is up to parents to support their kids sporting ambitions. I realise of course, that this is hardly your fault, and your scheme to fund national sports co-ordinators will undoubtedly help to raise awareness and hopefully enthusiasm. But what is needed urgently is better all-round sports education within schools.

Yours sincerely,
Janette

Dear Janette,
Arent we supposed to be arguing with each other? The journey to the top of the medal rostrum does begin with the first PE lesson, where the basic skills to which you refer are taught. And the most important person in British sport is the PE teacher. I believe teachers are doing an excellent job, but often need more training and certainly more resources. Some teachers spend fewer than 10 hours on PE during teacher training, and many that I have spoken with have told me that they feel less confident during lessons as a result. And of course, school sport teaches children so many life and social skills, such as working with others. What better way can youngsters gain the confidence to deal with everyday life?

We are working with partners to ensure that teachers get the best support in terms of practical skills and ideas. The TOPs scheme, funded with £7m of Lottery money, provides schools with a range of sports equipment and training in its use. Every primary school in the country will be part of this by July 2001, complementing the new School Sports Co-ordinators.

School sport v top level sport? No, it is not a competition between the two. They both feed off each other, the first providing the base; the second, encouragement to youngsters to get involved through watching a role model. I believe sport can also help social and economic regeneration, but I havent heard you say much about sport in the local community.

Yours,
Derek

Dear Derek,
The basis of our (delightfully polite) argument as I understand it, is to question whether we should go for instant medal gratification by showering money on our Olympic athletes, while local schools and clubs are reduced to having a whip-round every time they want to fill the holes in the Astroturf. Judging from the media euphoria and the evident relief of BBC presenters, it has been money well spent.

I believe however, that this is a short-term and unrealistic approach to raising standards in this much-frustrated, sports-mad country of ours. Yes, it will give youngsters role models in all sorts of sports, but how are they going to emulate this new band of heroes if there are no local facilities, or their own skills have been so poorly nurtured that even one-to-one coaching with Andre Agassi wouldnt ever make a decent tennis player out of them?

Sport performs all sorts of important social functions, as you say. It also promotes life skills like team spirit, self-confidence and a generally healthy approach to life. But if we are ever going to turn our base metal into gold with anything like the panache of Australia or the US, then we are going to have to invert the current funding pyramid so that youth sport gets the lions share and gets it first.

Yours sincerely,
Janette

Dear Janette,

Published figures show that there is a shopping list for swimming pools and sports centres alone, worth some £3-4bn. We agree theres a long way to go.

Yours,

webTitle: Orange enters catering trade

fields.headline: Orange enters catering trade
fields.trailText: 11am: Orange has moved into the catering trade by taking a stake in an online restaurant reservations service Book2eat, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Mobile phone operator Orange has moved into the catering trade by taking a stake in an online restaurant reservations service.

Book2eat allows hungry punters to book a table in real-time over the internet or through WAP phones at restaurants all over the world.

The £1.9m deal will see two Orange directors appointed to the Book2eat board.

"Soon your phone will not only be able to tell you where your nearest restaurant is, but show you the way there, make a reservation and order the special of the day," said Richard Brennan, group commercial director of Orange.

The Book2eat service was launched in March, with 85 London restaurants signing up, including Pied a Terre and the Ritz.

The company is trying to soothe irate restaurant goers, who said in a survey that the most irritating part of eating out was the difficulty in booking a table.

The deal is the latest in a series of internet acquisitions by Orange, after it paid £95m for virtual newsreader Ananova and the same again for virtual personal assistant Wildfire earlier this year.

Orange is owned by France Telecom, which bought it from Vodafone in May for £26bn.

webTitle: Video releases

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Being John Malkovich | The Hurricane
fields.trailText: Being John Malkovich | The Hurricane
fields.body:
Being John Malkovich
Rental and DVD
(£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 15
****

A film so blissfully loopy, you can hardly believe what you're watching. It's the square root of peculiar and bears more relation to Monty Python than anything with a Hollywood mentality. John Cusack is the esoteric puppeteer who gets an office job on the 7 1/2th floor (low overheads, you see) where he discovers a portal into John Malkovich's head. This is just the starting point for Spike Jonze's surreal film, which works partly by remaining true to its own logic and being played in deadly seriousness by its cast, none more so than the eponymous Malkovich, whose study in pretentious self-regard mixed with bafflement is very funny and strangely endearing. Cusack's wife is a dowdy Cameron Diaz, whose chimp is working through a suppressed childhood trauma. There may be some serious point about fame and living vicariously (it's notable that you get a Warholesque 15 minutes to be Malkovich), but mostly this is just Jonze - who has done wacky videos for Björk - and fellow debutant scriptwriter Charlie Kaufman seeing how far they can rattle our portals.

The Hurricane
Rental and DVD
(£19.99)
Buena Vista Cert 18
***

Engrossing reconstruction of the incarceration of boxer Rubin Carter and the eventual overturning of an injustice perpetrated by racism and corruption. Denzel Washington makes a dignified convict and Rod Steiger's presence as a judge reminds you that director Norman Jewison was doing his bit against racism 30 years ago in In the Heat of the Night.

webTitle: Basic Instinct 2 too 'sick' for Verhoeven

fields.headline: Basic Instinct 2 too 'sick' for Verhoeven
fields.trailText: The sequel to Basic Instinct has hit rocky ground after the director walked away from the project claiming the script made him feel "sick"
fields.body:
The sequel to Basic Instinct has hit rocky ground after the director walked away from the project claiming the script made him feel "sick".

Paul Verhoeven, who directed the 1992 original, had signed up to helm the sequel after Sharon Stone agreed to reprise her role as femme fatale Catherine Tramell. Once he began to read the script, however, he quickly changed his mind. According to the Daily Mail, he hurled the script across the room after reading a few segments, claiming it made him feel "sick".

The film apparently begins with Stone driving a Porsche whilst in an uncompromising position with her lover. The car crashes, the lover dies, and a forensic psychologist is sent to check out Tramell.

Verhoeven's prudish outburst comes as a surprise considering the director was responsible for the controversial leg-crossing scene in the original, and for the over-the-top stripper film, Showgirls

Vehoeven now plans to work on other projects whilst Stone has claimed she intends to go ahead with the sequel and hopes to start filming next year. Not surprising considering she looks set to get a $15m pay packet for the film plus a share of the potential box-office profits.

webTitle: Why the FBI spied on Germany's refugee writers

fields.headline: Watched by the G-men
fields.standfirst: In the 30s some of Germany's leading artists and writers fled Hitler's Third Reich and settled in America. From that moment they were spied upon by the FBI. And now new evidence reveals the extraordinary truth of the secret surveillance years.  Martin Kettle  reports
fields.trailText: In the 30s some of Germany's leading artists and writers fled Hitler's Third Reich and settled in America. From that moment they were spied upon by the FBI. And now new evidence reveals the extraordinary truth of the secret surveillance years
fields.body:
Picture a 1940s Los Angeles detective checking out why those cars have been parked on Paseo Miramar outside the German guy's villa for so long. You probably think noir. You probably think Philip Marlowe. You probably don't think RB Hood.

Yet when it came to working the beat in the city that knows how to keep its secrets, Hood was the man. As the special agent in charge of the FBI division in LA throughout much of the 40s and 50s, he had the job of coordinating everything that could be found out about some of the most celebrated foreign exiles ever to make their way to the United States.

In the 40s, his job was to spy on Bertolt Brecht, Erich Maria Remarque, Thomas Mann, his brother Heinrich, and dozens of other celebrated refugees from Hitler's Germany, many of whom had come to Hollywood in search of work. Everything that Hood and his fellow G-men found out about them would eventually find its way to FBI chief J Edgar Hoover in Washington. And now their reports have found their way into Alexander Stephan's extraordinary new book documenting the secret surveillance years.

During the 30s, dozens of German artists, writers and musicians - many, but not all Jewish - fled the Third Reich and eventually found their way to the US. Though they were exiles from fascism, they remained objects of official suspicion, especially if they had leftwing politics or associations. When the second world war ended and the cold war began, the official suspicions grew stronger not weaker. The FBI called these exiles "Communazis" because they believed that though they were refugees from one form of tyranny, they might also be in league with a second form.

The fact that the US government kept files on writers as famous as Brecht and Mann is not a new discovery. But Stephan has used American freedom of information law to unearth more than 10,000 pages of new material which vastly extend what is known about the surveillance operations. Everything from the way the writers lived, their conversations, their friends, their private lives and loves - and even the details of the books they were writing - formed part of the steady stream of information sent back to Hoover.

Hood and his team of agents were interested in everything that the German writers were up to. They tapped their phones. They opened their mail. They kept watch on them. And they interviewed the writers themselves, their circles and their casual acquaintances - mostly without the Germans having the faintest idea of how closely they were being monitored.

When one of the writers met a Russian, or someone who might have contacts with the Russians, Hood kept a note of it. It was Hood who checked the cars outside Lion Feuchtwanger's villa by the ocean. It was Hood who got to know when Heinrich Mann's wife Nelly was stopped for drunken driving in Beverly Hills. It was Hood's men who broke in to Leonhard Frank's house on a fishing expedition for evidence of communist sympathies. And it was Hood's men who searched the luggage of Brecht's mistress, Ruth Berlau.

Why the FBI kept track of the German exiles is easy to explain. "The communist movement", raged Hoover, "stands for the destruction of our American form of government". More surprising was the thoroughness of the surveillance - a thoroughness which in other circumstances might be described as Germanic.

Relatively uncontroversial exiles such as Franz Werfel, the Austrian Jewish playwright who married Gustav Mahler's widow Alma, got the same treatment as overtly political writers such as Brecht, who was identified in FBI files as "a propagandist of communism and sovietism".

Parking your car in the street near the Communist party offices in Los Angeles would merit an entry in Hood's files, as Johanna Kortner, wife of the exiled actor Fritz Kortner, never discovered when she did it inadvertently one day. Writers such as Heinrich Mann, who wrote almost nothing in his late years in the US, would be assiduously documented with the same thoroughness as Feuchtwanger, who continued to write and publish his novels from California, and whose bids for American citizenship Hoover blocked with repeated and ill-concealed glee.

By far the biggest fish in Hood's net, however, was Thomas Mann. The author of Buddenbrooks, Death in Venice and The Magic Mountain was, by a considerable distance, the most famous and eminent German writer of his era, as well as the most celebrated of all the exiles who set tled in the US. As the winner of the Nobel prize for literature and a major public figure, Mann was a hugely influential voice. Any attempts by him to become involved in organisations of which Hoover was suspicious - or attempts by such groups to recruit him - were carefully tracked and recorded by the FBI, as well as by other American security organisations and by the state department.

The portion of Mann's career in the US which most alarmed the watchers was an attempt to form a German exile organisation in America, with Mann as its leader and figurehead. In 1943, the office of strategic services (the forerunner of the CIA) tried to frustrate such a move. "Thomas Mann is extremely important and useful for any group which might be needed later," the OSS recorded, and managed to convey their views to the novelist, who duly backed away from the plan. Mann was in a category of his own. He seems to have been too major a figure to be placed under routine surveillance of the kind to which both his brother Heinrich and his son Klaus - as well as Feuchtwanger and Brecht - were subjected.

Klaus Mann, the author of Mephisto, was a particularly frequent FBI target. Even his postman was recruited as an informant. Klaus attracted attention partly because of his leftwing politics, but also because of his homosexuality. The files unearthed by Stephan refer to Mann as "a well-known sexual pervert" with "communistic sympathies".

The bureau's files contain some very detailed surveillance. When Klaus Mann stayed in the Bedford Hotel in New York, an informant identified only as "T3" reported that a soldier "with fair complexion and dirty blond hair" stayed overnight with him regularly. "Informant advised that the only suitable sleeping place in Mann's room is a single bed", the files report. "Informant further advised that quite a number of 'longhairs' go in and out to see Mann."

The FBI snoopers speculated that Mann may have had a sexual relationship with his sister Erika, one- time wife of WH Auden. "Confidential informants" told agents that the two were having an affair, one file reports. Erika Mann was described in the files as having her hair cut "in a short mannish bob with a part on the right side" and to be close to a group of political actors who were "members of the Hebrew race".

In the end, though, Erika Mann turned the tables on her watchers. She became an informant as early as 1940, and for much of the next 15 years cooperated willingly with dozens of inquiries about members of the German exile community, some of whom she too suspected of pro-Nazi connections.

It was an approach which landed her in increasing difficulties as the cold war developed. When the two Soviet spies Guy Burgess and Donald MacLean defected to Russia in May 1951, Mann was hauled in by the FBI, who suspected that, with her connections, she might have useful information about Burgess in particular. But she had not even heard of the defections until the FBI agents told her about them.

"Erika Mann seems to have talked with US agencies like the FBI more openly and for a longer period than any other exiled writer," Stephan concludes. No such thing can be said of Bertolt Brecht's case, on which Stephan has unearthed more than 400 pages of new documents. "He is of sufficient importance to international communism that the Bureau should be aware of all his activities and contacts," says one document. In another, dated April 1943, special agent Hood sent a memo to Hoover to start internment proceedings against the poet and playwright. In a third, offering a curious tribute, the OSS classifies Brecht as "a gifted dramatist" and a "poet of expressionistic vigour". "Subject is a writer of communist and revolutionary poetry and drama," Hood reported to Washington. "Is looked upon by German communists as their poet laureate."

Hood was as assiduous as ever, sending Hoover English versions, translated by FBI linguists, of one of Brecht's longhand poems. "The poem specifically refers to a United States steamer which was destroyed by its crew since they were paid too small wages," Hood informed Hoover. Brecht's play, Die Massnahme, was also translated inside the bureau for Hood to send to Hoover. "A self-styled 'educational play' which advocates communist world revolution by violent means," Hood reported.

Many of the new documents on Brecht show how seriously the FBI took the links between the poet and the so-called Free German exiles in Mexico, many of whom were unable to get into the US, and Moscow. "It is recommended that the following subjects be placed in the National Censorship Watch List for 90 days," petitioned Hood: "1. [name blacked out], 2. Bertolt Brecht, 1063 26th Street, Santa Monica, California, 3. [name blacked out]."

In 1945, the FBI began tapping Brecht's phone calls and mail. The records show contacts with Hollywood greats such as Charles Laughton, Charlie Chaplin and Billy Wilder - as well as conversations about a friend's plan to store some furniture in Brecht's garage. The contents are often banal, and even merely take the form of a list. "A letter postmarked February 7 was received by Brecht fromWH Auden, 16 Oberlin Avenue, Swarthmore, Pennsylvania" is all that one entry tantalisingly contains. Others are poignant. "Love, I am so glad that you are fighting so courageously," Brecht is reported to have written to his lover Ruth Berlau after she had given birth to their child (who soon died). "Don't think that I do not want to see you when you are ill. You are very beautiful then too."

Stephan takes a lenient view of the story which he has unearthed. Not one of the exiles "was murdered, tortured, deported back to Europe and turned over to the Gestapo", he writes. "Nor do the files indicate that agency interrogations had a direct negative influence on a writer's career". The catalogue of sins committed by the FBI and the other agencies was modest, he judges.

Nonetheless, Stephan believes the last word should lie with the great American jurist Justice Louis Brandeis, who wrote in 1928: "The greatest dangers to liberty lurk in insidious encroachment by men of zeal, well meaning but without understanding."

 Communazis: FBI Surveillance of German Emigré Writers, is published by Yale University Press in October

Klaus Mann, the author of Mephisto, was a particularly frequent FBI target. Even his postman was recruited as an informant. Klaus attracted attention partly because of his leftwing politics, but also because of his homosexuality. The files unearthed by Stephan refer to Mann as "a well-known sexual pervert" with "communistic sympathies". The bureau's files contain some very detailed surveillance. When Klaus Mann stayed in the Bedford Hotel in New York, an informant identified only as "T3" reported that a soldier "with fair complexion and dirty blond hair" stayed overnight with him regularly. "Informant advised that the only suitable sleeping place in Mann's room is a single bed", the files report. "Informant further advised that quite a number of 'longhairs' go in and out to see Mann." The FBI snoopers speculated that Mann may have had a sexual relationship with his sister Erika, one- time wife of WH Auden. "Confidential informants" told agents that the two were having an affair, one file reports. Erika Mann was described in the files as having her hair cut "in a short mannish bob with a part on the right side" and to be close to a group of political actors who were "members of the Hebrew race". In the end, though, Erika Mann turned the tables on her watchers. She became an informant as early as 1940, and for much of the next 15 years cooperated willingly with dozens of inquiries about members of the German exile community, some of whom she too suspected of pro-Nazi connections. It was an approach which landed her in increasing difficulties as the cold war developed. When the two Soviet spies Guy Burgess and Donald MacLean defected to Russia in May 1951, Mann was hauled in by the FBI, who suspected that, with her connections, she might have useful information about Burgess in particular. But she had not even heard of the defections until the FBI agents told her about them. "Erika Mann seems to have talked with US agencies like the FBI more openly and for a longer period than any other exiled writer," Stephan concludes. No such thing can be said of Bertolt Brecht's case, on which Stephan has unearthed more than 400 pages of new documents. "He is of sufficient importance to international communism that the Bureau should be aware of all his activities and contacts," says one document. In another, dated April 1943, special agent Hood sent a memo to Hoover to start internment proceedings against the poet and playwright. In a third, offering a curious tribute, the OSS classifies Brecht as "a gifted dramatist" and a "poet of expressionistic vigour". "Subject is a writer of communist and revolutionary poetry and drama," Hood reported to Washington. "Is looked upon by German communists as their poet laureate." Hood was as assiduous as ever, sending Hoover English versions, translated by FBI linguists, of one of Brecht's longhand poems. "The poem specifically refers to a United States steamer which was destroyed by its crew since they were paid too small wages," Hood informed Hoover. Brecht's play, Die Massnahme, was also translated inside the bureau for Hood to send to Hoover. "A self-styled 'educational play' which advocates communist world revolution by violent means," Hood reported. Many of the new documents on Brecht show how seriously the FBI took the links between the poet and the so-called Free German exiles in Mexico, many of whom were unable to get into the US, and Moscow. "It is recommended that the following subjects be placed in the National Censorship Watch List for 90 days," petitioned Hood: "1. [name blacked out], 2. Bertolt Brecht, 1063 26th Street, Santa Monica, California, 3. [name blacked out]." In 1945, the FBI began tapping Brecht's phone calls and mail. The records show contacts with Hollywood greats such as Charles Laughton, Charlie Chaplin and Billy Wilder - as well as conversations about a friend's plan to store some furniture in Brecht's garage. The contents are often banal, and even merely take the form of a list. "A letter postmarked February 7 was received by Brecht fromWH Auden, 16 Oberlin Avenue, Swarthmore, Pennsylvania" is all that one entry tantalisingly contains. Others are poignant. "Love, I am so glad that you are fighting so courageously," Brecht is reported to have written to his lover Ruth Berlau after she had given birth to their child (who soon died). "Don't think that I do not want to see you when you are ill. You are very beautiful then too." Stephan takes a lenient view of the story which he has unearthed. Not one of the exiles "was murdered, tortured, deported back to Europe and turned over to the Gestapo", he writes. "Nor do the files indicate that agency interrogations had a direct negative influence on a writer's career". The catalogue of sins committed by the FBI and the other agencies was modest, he judges. Nonetheless, Stephan believes the last word should lie with the great American jurist Justice Louis Brandeis, who wrote in 1928: "The greatest dangers to liberty lurk in insidious encroachment by men of zeal, well meaning but without understanding."  Communazis: FBI Surveillance of German Emigré Writers, is published by Yale University Press in October

webTitle: Why is Margaret Drabble inventing authors?

fields.headline: Why is Margaret Drabble inventing authors?
fields.trailText: There's one too many entries in the Oxford Companion to English Literature...
fields.body:
Name:
Margaret Drabble.

Age:
61.

Occupation:
Writer.

That's right, didn't she write Possession?
Er no, that was by AS Byatt, who happens to be Drabble's elder sister. This is not about her.

Sorry. But Drabble writes novels too doesn't she?
Oh yes, lots of them,since her first, A Summer Birdcage, in 1963. Usually they concern clever, frustrated, middle-class women.

Any reason?
Work it out. She is also editor of the Oxford Companion to English Literature, the standard reference book for authors and their work.

I get the feeling we're getting to the point here. Isn't there a new edition out?
There is.

And?
There's one too many entries in the 1,100-word volume. She messed up in the editing?
Not exactly, but one of the entries is made up, invented, a work of fiction in fact.

Which one?
She's not saying. But somewhere between Gilbert Abbottà Beckett and Benjamin Zephaniah, lurks an intruder.

Let's have a flick through: Eudora Welty, got to be her hasn't it?
No, she's real. As is Penelope Shuttle and Louisa S Guggenberger.

OK. Who is it?
She's not saying. "I just did it for fun and to make sure people looked closely at the text," she told Radio 4's Front Row.

Could that translate as "I just did it to drum up a bit of publicity for my new book"?
Maybe, but Pass Notes certainly seems to be falling for it too.

Is Drabble herself in her book?
Ohyes. She gets quite a healthy-sized entry in fact, though she didn't write it herself.

And her sister?
Also not written by Drabble. Also quite healthy in size, though marginally shorter than Drabble's.

Did anyone get to write their own entry?
Only Michael Holroyd, author, biographer and...

And?
Husband of Margaret Drabble.

webTitle: Rural idyll caught with its pants down

fields.headline: Rural idyll caught with its pants down
fields.standfirst: Trollope shocks Gloucestershire with tales of scavengers and drug takers
fields.trailText: Known for its flora, fauna, castles and manors, Gloucestershire has to date succeeded in courting the regal and literary. But now one well-known resident has described the county in terms more synonymous with an inner city than an idyll.
fields.body:
Known for its flora, fauna, castles and manors, Gloucestershire has to date succeeded in courting the regal and literary. But now one well-known resident has described the county in terms more synonymous with an inner city than an idyll.

Joanna Trollope, doyenne of the Aga saga and resident of Cirencester, has departed from her traditional theme of rural romance and made social comment. She claims that children in the Cotswolds go to school without underwear and scavenge through bins.

Gloucester, Ms Trollope says, is "rough" and Cheltenham - renowned for its upmarket shops - has a drugs problem. The Forest of Dean is "peculiar", according to the novelist.

Her comments have baffled Gloucestershire tourism officials, particularly as Ms Trollope's foreword to a Cotswold and Cheltenham guidebook described the area as "beautiful". Ken Jennings, Cheltenham council's head of tourism, said: "I do not recognise Cheltenham from her description." Rachel Lewis, a tourism officer for the Forest of Dean, said: "We just hope people do not take her comments too seriously. I have never seen anyone knickerless in the Cotswolds and while she refers to the Forest as peculiar, it is just an ordinary, close-knit community."

The novelist said in an interview with Radio Times: "Children in these honey-coloured villages go to school with no underclothes. Teachers in the beautiful Cotswolds find pupils scavenging through rubbish bins. I'm certain we have teenage prostitutes. Gloucester is a rough city, Cheltenham has an appalling drugs record, and the Forest of Dean is a peculiar place."

The reputation of Gloucestershire as a rural idyll has attracted celebrities and members of the literati to move in or buy second homes. Prince Charles has his country home at Highgrove House, while the Princess Royal lives at Gatcombe Park. Richard Ashcroft, former lead singer of the Verve, owns a listed house in the hamlet of Taynton and Damien Hirst has a studio within the county.

The novelist Jilly Cooper, who has lived in Bisley near Cirencester for 18 years, said yesterday that Ms Trollope's comments were fitting.

"There are drugs and poverty in Gloucester and the county has got jolly rough areas, as Joanna knows very well. Cheltenham, Gloucester and Stroud are lovely towns but I hear rumours about drugs in some of them. But then Stroud has always been an artists' place and is very bohemian. Stroudies have always been fairly druggy.

"Where I live is ravishingly pretty. There's a fantastic post-mistress and a gorgeous village school. I have no idea if the children in it are wearing knickers or not. But there are problems in some areas with poverty." The writer Henry Porter, who lives in Blockley, near Broadway, believes that much of what Ms Trollope said is "dead right". He said: "I've known Cheltenham since I was a kid. It used to be genteel. But in the mid-1980s it began to remind me of parts of Liverpool in the 1970s. It started to have a lot of social problems."

webTitle: Today's media stories from the papers

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: It's back. News at Ten is back, except when it's not. And, would you believe it, it's all down to the Mirror. And the paper is enjoying fully its unexpected moment of victory.
fields.body:
It's back. News at Ten is back, except when it's not. And, would you believe it, it's all down to the Mirror. And the paper is enjoying fully its unexpected moment of victory.

THE MIRROR
News at Ten is back following a stunning victory for the campaigning Mirror. It fair warms the cockles of your heart. (p1)
In a leader, the paper says: "We will be perfectly happy with the new arrangement - as long as the news is at ten on most nights." Alastair Burnet, Michael Nicholson and Tony Blair lead two pages of rejoicing inside. (p12 and 13)

THE SUN
Perhaps envious that it played the odds on the campaigning front, the Sun confines its News at Ten coverage to seven paragraphs on page three. Telly insiders said the move was "an embarrassing climbdown".

THE GUARDIAN
ITV is to bring back News at Ten as part of a last-minute settlement to its legal wrangle with the Independent Television Commission, throwing into disarray the BBC's plans to move the Nine o'Clock News to 10pm. (p1)
Frostrup gaffe leaves new BBC1 chief embarrassed: Lorraine Heggessey has described the decision to approach Mariella Frostrup to present Panorama as a "joke", apparently without realising that the presenter had already been signed up. (p8)
Leak points to US approval of Time Warner-AOL deal: US regulators seem likely to give the green light, brushing aside objections from competitors including Disney. (p25)

DAILY MAIL
Greg Dyke denies the BBC is dumbing down. "Meet Panorama's new presenter" is the headline/caption to a full-length picture of "voluptuous" Mariella Frostrup on the front page. The story writes itself really. Heggessey is pictured inside with the pull-out quote: "If anyone suggested her, it was probably a joke." (p1 and p9)
News at Ten is there again, but with a timetable of the various wrangles over the last seven years that led to the bulletin's return. (p6)

THE INDEPENDENT
News at Ten returns (p1)
Viewers wait all year for News at Ten to return, then five come along all at once. Count 'em: Sky News, ITN's news channel, BBC News 24's hourly bulletin, ITV's return and the potential BBC1 bulletin.(p5)
BBC2's Later with Jools Holland is in jeopardy: it will either be moved to a primetime slot or axed. (p5)

DAILY TELEGRAPH
ITV agreed to restore News at Ten in a "messy compromise deal to stave off a court battle with television regulators". (p1)
Dumbing down row as Frostrup joins Panorama. The BBC announcement came just hours after Lorraine Heggessey dismissed it as "a joke". (p5)
The flexibility of the new news deal is "precisely what is wrong with it", says the leader. (p27)
Arena Leisure yesterday made a £320m offer to Briain's 59 racecourses. (p31)

THE TIMES
The future of TV news was thrown into confusion last night. (p1)
BBC blunder over Frostrup: the new controller of BBC1 has suffered embarrassment after dismissing the prospect of Mariella Frostrup presenting Panorama. (p9)
Media pages: Business AM is launching into a niche market but might turn into something more substantial. (p20)
The Daily Mail is angry that the Sunday Times will serialise Patrick Jephson's book about Diana. (p20)
The Guardian has returned to its roots by launching a Northern edition. (p21)
Do appearance or ethnic background play too big a part in the selection of BBC on-screen talent? (p22)
Matthew Wright, former Mirror showbiz columnist, describes with delight his switch from tabloid journalism to TV. (p25)
Carol Midgley interviews Murray Walker, who has no plans to retire. (p26)
Top directors like making ads. (p28)

DAILY EXPRESS
Describes the return of News at Ten as "a compromise" and quotes Gerald Kaufman: "It will be on 20 minutes and viewers will lose out - it's a mess". (p6)
The BBC was yesterday accused of more "dumbing down" after the announcement that Mariella Frostrup is to front an edition of Panorama. (p12)

FINANCIAL TIMES
Oftel has lost the confidence of senior officials in the government and European Commission over its handling of BT. (p1)
"Imaginative solution" sees the return of News at Ten on ITV. (p2)
Viglen Technology - famed for its former shareholders including Piers Morgan and the City Slickers - is changing its name to Learning Technologies. Presumably in order to give it a chance to be famed for something else. (p27)
Leo Kirch, German media mogul, will today bring in Lehman Brothers as a strategic partner in a deal worth around £100m. (p32)
The Federal Trade Commission has begun interviews with companies opposed to Time Warner and AOL's proposed merger - a sign that the anti-trust authority is preparing a lawsuit. (p33)

webTitle: Byelection blow to Ulster peace deal

fields.headline: Byelection blow to Ulster peace deal
fields.trailText: The peace process in Northern Ireland has suffered another setback with a previously safe Ulster Unionist seat in South Antrim falling to Reverend Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party.
fields.body:
The peace process in Northern Ireland has suffered another setback with a previously safe Ulster Unionist seat in South Antrim falling to Reverend Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party.

The DUP candidate, Reverend Willie McCrea, a vehement opponent of the Good Friday agreement, defeated UUP candidate David Burnside by 822 votes in last night's byelection, to take what had formerly been the party's second safest seat in Northern Ireland. He received 11,601 votes, overturning a 16,000 Ulster Unionist majority.

After the result was announced, Rev Paisley claimed that Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble and the Good Friday agreement were "finished".

"I think Mr Trimble is finished, absolutely finished. We're going to see that this province is not going to bow to [Sinn Fein leader] Gerry Adams or to Dublin or to [British prime minister Tony] Blair or [Irish taoiseach Bertie] Ahern or Trimble. The writing is on the wall for Trimble now. He must go, and go quickly."

Mr Trimble, who will meeting senior party colleagues later today to discuss the disastrous result, has insisted he has no intention of quitting. But there is no doubt he is under severe pressure and could face a leadership challenge from the anti-agreement wing of his deeply divided party at the annual conference in Belfast on October 7.

Last March, South Belfast MP Reverend Martin Smyth won 43% of the vote in a leadership contest against Mr Trimble and several sources fear Mr Trimble might not be so fortunate a second time. The ousting of Mr Trimble by an opponent of the Good Friday agreement would place the accord in jeopardy.

The Stormont first minister is also being squeezed over the government police bill, due to go to the House of Lords early next month.

Mr Paisley warned that the DUP intended to try to take as many as possible of the eight Ulster Unionists seats at the general election, which he said would make the peace accord democratically untenable.

He claimed Mr Blair was still ignoring DUP proposals for democratic majority rule as the only viable alternative to the peace deal.

"The agreement is not a democratic document. The alternative doesn't need the support of nationalists, it needs the support of democrats who accept the ballot box without the need for guns."

One of Mr Trimble's close allies, Stormont trade minister Sir Reg Empey, denied the end was nigh for his party leader or the Good Friday accord. "Any person who is leading the party has got to confront the fundamental issues. Nobody as yet has put forward a coherent alternative. The DUP can appeal to the emotions but they cannot deliver on the ground."

webTitle: Oftel gets 'tough' on broadband net access

fields.headline: Oftel gets 'tough' on roll-out of broadband net access
fields.trailText: Oftel has issued "tough" guidelines on the roll-out of broadband internet access in the UK, amid mounting criticism that BT is holding up the process.
fields.body:
Telecoms regulator Oftel has issued "tough" guidelines on the roll-out of broadband internet access in the UK, amid mounting criticism that BT is holding up the process.

BT said it is seeking clarification on the guidelines, particularly the demand that its exchanges be made available within four months. A spokesperson said this should apply only to four trial exchanges, which will be ready by January.

The news represents the latest bout of uncertainty in a process that this week saw Oftel bow to pressure from telecoms operators and select 360 BT exchanges for the installation of broadband equipment. Thirty-five companies are bidding for access to local exchanges.

The regulator also moved to end the squabbling between operators and BT, saying it will resolve all disputes over price and space allocation.

David Edmonds, director general of Oftel, said: "Local loop unbundling will bring a step change to businesses, consumers and the telecoms industry itself. I am determined to implement it as quickly as possible so that all companies can compete fairly to deliver these revolutionary new high-speed services."

Edmonds has gone back to the drawing board after admitting earlier this week that Oftel should have been firmer in its handling of the process and submitted proposals sooner.

The announcement comes as operators' complaints over BT's behaviour reach a crescendo, with RSL Communications and Global Crossing withdrawing from the bidding process and Colt Telecom demanding a quicker roll out.

US telecoms group WorldCom yesterday also stepped away, citing "commercial and business reasons", while denying any frustration with BT.

RSL said the broadband internet market was wide open for BT, because initial access for rival operators is restricted to local exchanges. BT said it would take longer to open up urban exchanges, where competitors will be fighting for space.

webTitle: Mother launches cinema campaign for Harvey Nichols

fields.headline: Mother puts Harvey Nichols on national cinema screens
fields.trailText: 8.45am: Mother is launching a national cinema campaign for the luxury fashion house Harvey Nichols. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Mother is launching a national cinema campaign for the luxury fashion house Harvey Nichols - its first in four years.

The spot features Harvey and Hibby, two knitted dolls decked out in designer gear who were the stars of a print campaign that ran earlier in the year.

"Mother has successfully taken the campaign to new creative heights and will continue to position Harvey Nichols at the cutting edge of fashion," said Julia Bowe, marketing director at the London store.

The work breaks at the end of the month and will run until Christmas targeting ABC1 adults over the age of 25. Media planning and buying is through Rocket.

webTitle: CNN launches European website

fields.headline: CNN unveils European strategy
fields.trailText: CNN Interactive, the digital offshoot of CNN, made a decisive bid to corner the market for pan-European news yesterday with the launch of its first English-language website developed specifically for the international market.
fields.body:
CNN Interactive, the digital offshoot of CNN, made a decisive bid to corner the market for pan-European news yesterday with the launch of its first English-language website developed specifically for the international market.

The move is part of CNN's ongoing expansion into Europe and part of a strategy to establish localised online services in a similar way to how CNN International has regionalised its TV channel. In Europe CNN already operates four local-language sites in Danish, Italian, Norwegian and Swedish. It is launching a German site in October.

The launch of CNN.com Europe is backed by £4m pan-European ad campaign, involving WCRS on the creative side, Mediacom on the buying side, Profero on online creative and Firefly for PR.

The new site, accessible from CNN.com or europe.cnn.com, is produced and edited from CNN's new European interactive headquarters in London by a team of 30 journalists.

David Brewer, who was poached from BBC News Online to be managing editor for CNN Interactive for Europe, Middle East and Africa, said the site was aimed at people with information overload who wanted a polished product.

"We've got journalists onboard with more than 30 years' experience who'll be explaining the news with real authority. Our core focus is on high quality news without losing the fact that CNN is built around breaking news." He added that Robin Oakley, who was brought in from the BBC, would play a large part in this authoritative coverage.

In addition to written content, the site offers an archive of all CNN TV's video footage and a snapshot of other European news of interest, presented in a way that viewers will be able to understand, pointed out Brewer. Content on the site is split up into general news, weather, business, sport, technology and entertainment.

"We always said we wanted to do this and now the European market is ripe for this, we thought the time was right," said Scott Woelfel, president and editor-in-chief of CNN Interactive. Woelfel declined to give details of how much CNN was spending on the expansion into Europe.

Further details of CNN Interactive's European strategy are still under wraps, particularly its plans to launch an enhanced TV product akin to Sky News Active. Trials are underway and an interactive text service is planned for Telewest's interactive area. A PDA service is also planned to add to the Wap and SMS services CNN runs.

CNN.com Europe is the 15th CNN-produced site, joining, among others, CNN.com, CNNfn.com and allpoliticas.com, which collectively notch up more than 650m page impressions, or 7m unique users, per month.

webTitle: Virgin Radio unveils digital strategy

fields.headline: Virgin Radio unveils digital strategy
fields.trailText: Virgin Radio has unveiled details of its new digital strategy - a whole new internet radio network. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Virgin Radio, the radio station recently acquired by Scottish Media Group when it bought Ginger Media Group, has unveiled details of its new digital strategy - a whole new internet radio network.

The move, part of the station's plan to extend its reach to new audiences, is centred on the increasing popularity of streamed radio broadcasts to niche audiences, a strategy similar in part to that announced by competitor Capital Radio in July this year.

Virgin Radio's strategy is being introduced in three phases. The first step is to launch a separately branded internet radio station, called Virgin Digital, in October.

While the music content will be the same as that put out by Virgin Radio, the branding, promotions and advertising will be created entirely for a web audience, allowing the radio broadcasters to push listeners to specific online offers and develop more direct response opportunities for advertisers.

The website is already on target to generate more than £1m this year from advertising and sponsorship promotions.

Step two is to break up the current output into four niche stations determined either by thematic strands and demographic groupings. Virgin Radio is keeping its cards close to its chest about what exactly these stations will be and what they'll be called, but says they should launch before the end of this year.

"The endgame is targeted music and advertising; a big step away from our current output, which is very wide," said John Ousby, director of Ginger Online, the digital development arm of Ginger Media Group.

The third step involves the development of more spin-off products such as co-branded internet radio channels, building on the strategy behind the Global Sound Kitchen venture launched in conjunction with Levi's at the start of this year.

Ousby said Virgin Radio was in advanced discussions with a number of big brands and retailers and that it would have another venture in development before the end of the year.

Explaining the methodology behind the new strategy, Ousby said it had been on the cards for some time but it was a case of getting the whole company behind it, "so it's not just the internet venture but the whole business of the radio station. This is an SMG project that involves all departments - from production and programming right through to sales and promotions. It's the way forward for Virgin Radio," he added.

A marketing push is planned alongside the new initiatives to encourage more people in the workplace to listen to the internet radio channels - an audience Virgin Radio sees as a key untapped segment.

Earlier this summer, Capital Radio unveiled details of three niche internet radio stations and a personalised DJ service called Kikido, which are set to launch in the coming months. Virgin Radio, however, claims to have the upper hand given its existing internet radio output is, according to auditor Arbitron Webcast Ratings, the most listened to internet radio station in the world.

webTitle: Nightingale to present live show on internet

fields.headline: Radio 1 DJ to present live music show on the internet
fields.trailText: Veteran Radio 1 DJ Annie Nightingale is to present a music show on the internet starting from November reports Luisa Metcalfe.
fields.body:
Veteran Radio 1 DJ Annie Nightingale is to present a music show on the internet starting from November.

The twice weekly show will be broadcast through NetBeat www.netbeat.com, an established music distribution website which already has one million users.

Although the name has yet to be decided, the 15 minute show will showcase new bands and include cutting edge music as well as revealing interviews with guests, hand picked by Nightingale. Names being bandied about include Irvine Welsh and ex-Happy Mondays singer Shaun Ryder.

Nightingale, famous as much for her longevity as for becoming the first female DJ in the country - she joined the all-male Radio 1 in 1970 - will play the kind of cutting edge music on the web show that she broadcasts in her Saturday night/Sunday Morning Radio 1 slot.

Involved in the show's development from conception, Nightingale said: "TV on the Box, the traditional sort of gogglebox, has really lost its drive and enthusiasm - reality gameshows and watching paint dry are surely not what TV was invented for. I'm always excited by the innovative and what may be risk-taking."

Brighton resident Nightingale was the recipient of the 1998 Woman of the Year Lifetime Achievement Award from the Music Industry and Related Media Organisation.

webTitle: Audi ditches Wieden & Kennedy

fields.headline: Audi ditches Wieden & Kennedy
fields.trailText: Audi has ended its two-year relationship with Wieden & Kennedy.
fields.body:
Audi has ended its two-year relationship with Wieden & Kennedy.

W&K Amsterdam won the £10m pan-European launch task for the Audi A2, its smallest vehicle, in October 1998. The agency's work ran in 10 European markets including the UK. It carried the end-line "More from less" and was targeted at a younger, more environmentally conscience audience.

W&K's appointment marked the first time Audi had used a non-roster agency since setting up Audi Agency Network (AAN), an group of ad agencies based in various locations around the world that come together to work for Audi.

Saatchi & Saatchi's Frankfurt office - an existing roster agency, will now handle the account.

David Miller, the managing director at W&K Amsterdam, confirmed that the two companies are no longer working together.

"We were only taken on to handle the launch of the A2 - our contract has expired," he said.

webTitle: Denmark's voters hold euro in their palms

fields.headline: Denmark's voters hold euro in their palms
fields.standfirst: Next Thursday's Danish referendum on the euro is an early litmus test for fellow sceptical nations and the future of the EU as a whole. Ian Black in Copenhagen gets the sense it might be just be a "nej"
fields.trailText: Next Thursday's Danish referendum on the euro is an early litmus test for fellow sceptical nations and the future of the EU as a whole. Ian Black in Copenhagen gets the sense it might be just be a "nej".
fields.body:
Back in 1992, when Danes rejected the Maastricht treaty, delighted eurosceptic British MPs burst into a lusty "Wonderful Wonderful Copenhagen" to thank them for sticking a Scandinavian spoke into the wheels of European integration.

Plenty of people will be happy if the Danes say "nej" again in next Thursday's referendum on the euro - because it will be a blow to the faltering single currency and the idea of "ever closer union" that Maastricht called for.

With Tony Blair and his Swedish counterpart Goran Persson waiting to decide whether to hold their own referenda, Denmark's choice could make the difference between a Euroland that remains stuck for the time being at 12 (Greece joins the current 11 next year), or expands to cover the whole 15-member EU.

Intensive public opinion polling certainly indicates that a "no" vote is likely: the two latest and most authoritative polls, in Friday's Berlingske Tidende and the rival Politiken, gave opponents a lead of eight to 10 points - spelling gloom for the Social Democratic prime minister Poul Nyrup Rassmussen.

And beyond the polls, the mood is negative, to judge by casual conversation with random taxi drivers - as every journalist knows, the best if thoroughly amateur way to take the pulse of any nation.

"I'm going to vote 'no' because I don't want any more union," explained one middle-aged Copenhagen cabbie. "Many Danes are frightened of this idea of a United States of Europe."

But a younger driver was more concerned about joining a "rich man's club" while candidates queuing up to join the EU from eastern Europe would be left out. "It's a silly idea. We need to see what happens with all those new countries that join."

Anecdotal evidence certainly, but it impresses even those with a far more scientific approach. "Polls can move in different directions but there is a general movement towards a 'no'," observed Anders Milhoj, a university statistician. "Everyone can feel that - and without reading the opinion polls."

But whatever the outcome, Danes have reason to be concerned about the way the single currency has the support of the country's elites (including - in a striking contrast to Britain - the majority of the media), but is opposed by "ordinary", less well-educated people.

Many admit to being confused about the pros and cons of joining: the government-led "yes" campaign, backed by business, insists it will be good for jobs and growth. But the economic advantages may be slight as the krone is already pegged closely to the euro, just as it was to the German mark before that.

Getting a seat on the board of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt seems to many to be a poor substitute for an independent national bank - however illusory that independence is.

Arguing abstractly for the benefits of gaining political and economic "influence" as supporters do, does not seem to be enough to counter uncertainty.

Despite repeated claims that the fundamentals of the Euroland economies are strong - with low unemployment and inflation - the continued battering of the euro against the US dollar has bolstered the image of a weak, undesirable currency.

And Danes care about their krone, even though the austere features of Queen Margaretha will still be on one side of their euro coins even if they say yes. Surrendering it could be a leap into the unknown.

"A nation's coins have a mainly practical function, but they are also a symbol, a tangible guarantee, symbolising trust in the nation, monarch and relations with one's compatriots, particularly if one lives in a tiny country," said Aarhus university anthropologist Torben Vestergaard.

On the other hand, engaging with Europe feels progressive to "yes" campaigners, especially those who have travelled widely. Many of them feel that their opponents are an unsavoury, backward-looking lot: they include the far-right Danish People's party, with its strident anti-immigrant policies, and the leftist Socialist Workers party - a "nightmare combination", in the words of one euro enthusiast.

But there is cynicism about all politicians. It still rankles with the "no" campaign that the stunning Maastricht rejection vote of 1992 - the one which caused those Tories to break into song - was overturned the following year after Denmark won its opt-outs on the single currency, defence and other issues.

Sanctions against Austria reinforced the image of the EU's big boys being too ready to bully smaller countries, while criticism of Danish affairs by the European Commission or Euro MPs goes down just as badly in Copenhagen as criticism of Britain does in Cheltenham.

It matters not a jot that the fears of some Danes are, for the moment at least, entirely misplaced. Nyrup Rasmussen is no more inclined than Blair to harmonise taxes or agree to surrender more powers to Brussels. But the Social Democratic Dane is as vulnerable as Britain's New Labour leader to a determined eurosceptic opposition.

webTitle: Gore joins oil protests

fields.headline: Gore joins oil protests
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the US elections
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush clashed over the rising price of oil yesterday as the issue that has overturned political assumptions in Europe finally took centre stage in the US presidential election.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush clashed over the rising price of oil yesterday as the issue that has overturned political assumptions in Europe finally took centre stage in the US presidential election.

Mr Gore called on the US government - of which he is still a part - to order the release of part of the national emergency fuel reserves to help drive down domestic petrol prices before winter and the November 7 election.

"We need aggressive action right now," Mr Gore said in Maryland. "It's time for Opec to get serious about the supply and price of oil."

Within an hour, the Republican candidate George W Bush denounced Mr Gore's proposal as electioneering. "The strategic reserve should not be used as an attempt to drive down oil prices right before the election, for short term gain at the cost of long term security," he said.

Though there is no sign of the US being hit by anything remotely approaching the civil unrest in Europe, the price of petrol and domestic heating fuel remains a contentious issue. US oil and petrol prices are among the lowest in the industrial world, but prices at the pumps have increased by more than 50% in the past year and there were protests from truckers last winter.

The Democrats want to put themselves on the side of the consumer against the oil companies - partly because both Mr Bush and his running mate Dick Cheney spent many years as oil executives.

As well as urging President Clinton to release oil from the reserves, Mr Gore attacked oil companies for profiteering, and called on Opec nations to increase production.

Mr Gore also said the Republican-controlled Congress should establish a permanent home heating oil reserve, and urged emergency action to help low income families with their fuel bills.

However, the Bush campaign spokeswoman Karen Hughes said dipping into reserves would allow leaders such as Saddam Hussein "to literally put America over a barrel".

Mr Bush's campaign team also put out copies of a recent memo from the treasury secretary, Larry Summers, in which he claimed that attempts to drive down the price by opening the reserve would be "a major and substantial policy mistake".

webTitle: Ministers soften line on fuel tax protests

fields.headline: Ministers soften line on fuel tax protests
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The Cabinet yesterday signalled a softening of its line on fuel tax, admitting that the government had to recognise that people had a real sense of grievance and that ministers needed to listen hard in the debate about the balance between tax and spending.
fields.body:
The Cabinet yesterday signalled a softening of its line on fuel tax, admitting that the government had to recognise that people had a real sense of grievance and that ministers needed to listen hard in the debate about the balance between tax and spending.

The admission came as the Freight Transport Association called on the government to start making concessions or face further protests. The FTA wants fuel tax cut for hauliers, rather than the general motorist. It calculates that diesel fuel for lorries could be cut by 12p if the Tories' proposed 3p cut for the general motorist was given only to professional road hauliers.

At a separate meeting the Road Haulage Association, representing smaller lorry drivers, started to draw up plans for a coherent set of demands to place before the government. The meetings came as Safeway announced that it was increasing the price of a litre of four star petrol from 84.9p to 88.9p, with diesel up to 85.9p from 81.9p.

The ministerial task force will meet the oil companies today to discuss a strategy to protect fuel supplies if there is a repeat of last week's protests. Downing Street said it was still interested in a new legal duty on oil companies to secure the supply of delivery, though the companies oppose the plan.

The French and German governments have sought to deflect popular unrest by threatening a windfall tax on the oil firms, or a monopoly inquiry, but there is little appetite for a similar trial of strength in the Cabinet.

In a change of tone from remarks emanating from the Treasury, Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, said that the government must listen to the concerns of the public over fuel. He told a meeting of business people in London yesterday that people wanted more money for schools and hospitals, but they also demanded cuts in petrol tax.

"In government we have to recognise that many people feel a real sense of grievance about this issue," he said. "We must listen to their concerns, and as the chancellor said, we are happy to enter into a debate about spending and taxation and that should feed into the pre-budget report this autumn and the budget itself next spring."

Earlier this week, in an equally emollient mood, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, interpreted Gordon Brown's recent comments by saying: "He made it clear that we must listen and that we would reflect."

Likening the sudden turnaround in the polls to facing an 800lb gorilla, Mr Blunkett said Labour had to "respect it and talk to it quietly. We have low business taxes, low income taxes but we do have high duty and we are reflecting on that." He added: "We are desperately trying to get the balance right."

Jack Straw, the home secretary, also said the government "would be daft not to take account of public sentiment".

Meanwhile, 250 farmers who plan to disrupt the Labour conference on Monday by driving tractors to Brighton to protest against the cost of fuel have been warned by customs and excise that they could face fines or the confiscation of their vehicles if they use virtually tax-free agricultural diesel to get there.

webTitle: The transport strike that didn't paralyse a city

fields.headline: The transport strike that didn't paralyse a city
fields.standfirst: Bus and rail workers are taking industrial action in Los Angeles in a dispute over overtime. But, as Duncan Campbell discovers, the city's commuters took to their cars 40 years ago.
fields.trailText: Bus and rail workers are taking industrial action in Los Angeles in a dispute over overtime. But, as Duncan Campbell discovers, the city's commuters took to their cars 40 years ago.
fields.body:
The car is king in Los Angeles and public transport in the city is almost an oxymoron. But, this week, a full-scale bus and rail strike in LA has reminded the air-conditioned car-driver that, amazingly enough, some people have to get their way across the city using vehicles called "buses" and "trains", and have to sit next to strangers.

The city enters day seven today of a strike by 4,400 drivers, members of the United Transportation Union. The picket lines are out, sympathetic motorists toot their horns as they drive past strikers and the Los Angeles Times assigned no fewer than 20 reporters to cover its effects.

The strike was prompted by the decision of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA) to introduce a new system of working which would cut overtime costs.

The drivers, who earn between $10 (£7) and $20 an hour depending on how much overtime they do, say that ending the current system would cause them serious financial damage. Talks broke down last Friday, and by Saturday the stoppage had started.

In most other cities in the world, a transport strike of this magnitude would cause chaos on the roads as commuters take to their cars.

But in LA, most of the commuters took to their cars about 40 years ago so the volume of traffic, according to the Highway patrol, was up a mere 5%.

The roots of the problem go back some 50 years, when an unholy alliance of the oil, tyre and automobile industries conspired to buy up land that could have been used for the expansion of a proper public transport system.

Although the miscreants were slapped on the wrist with a fine under anti-trust laws, the damage was done and Los Angeles became a city where the definition of a loser was someone without a car. The people most dependant on public transport are the poorest members of the community, the cleaners and gardeners, the waiters and nannies, mainly Latino or black.

What is significant is that the most active group representing the interests of these passengers, the Bus Riders' Union, is fully in sympathy with the drivers. They argue that, if the 450,000 stranded passengers were from the white middle class, the MTA would been desperate to settle the dispute and find other ways of funding public transport.

So yesterday, parts of LA were reminiscent of crowded cities in central America, where vans cruise the roads with their drivers shouting out their destinations in Spanish and picking up passengers as they go.

The big difference, of course, is that here these "collectivos" are charging $3 or $4 rather than the few cents they would be asking for in Mexico City.

Talks were due to resume in Pasadena. Provided all the negotiators are able to get there.

webTitle: Louisa Young   on the appeal of ugly men

fields.headline: Give me the beast and keep the beauty
fields.standfirst: On the appeal of ugly men
fields.trailText: Louisa Young on the appeal of ugly men
fields.body:
I went to a film last week. I almost said I went to a movie, but it wasn't a movie. Movies are from Hollywood, they have pretty girls and handsome men, special effects and capitalistic morals. This - Beau Travail, Claire Denis's blood-melting tale of the Foreign Legion in Djibouti - was a film.

Of course, it was more interesting, more intelligent, stranger and longer-lasting in the mind (in short, better) than 99% of Hollywood movies. That goes without saying. But what haunts me about it is nothing auteurish or filmic: it is the handsome men. The male faces. In fact, one face. One really ugly face.

You know this face, if you've been to the cinema in the past couple of years. It is the bloke in the beer ad: his father is dying, he brings him a flagon of this very expensive beer on the back of a wagon, drinks it and blames the priest. His name is Denis Lavant. In the ad he is an effective clown, with a monkey mug. In Beau Travail, he is the image of humanity. His face is the story. He is fabulous. And he is so ugly.

The other legionnaires are, without exception, beautiful, and their beauty is lingered on, against bleak deserts and burning skies, and very nice that is, too. But his is the face that came back with me. I dreamed about him. If I were 15 I'd put a picture of him on my bedroom wall. I might anyway.

Casting an eye over the Hollywood boys of the day - Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, Antonio Banderas - I can't actually remember what they look like. Except that they all look like they're wearing foundation and false teeth. Which they probably are. And then Lavant springs to mind, or Daniel Auteuil as the utterly phallic knife-thrower in La Fille sur le Pont, or the mad, dying king in La Reine Margot, all pock-marked, with hollow cheeks and snaggle teeth. And I think: now we're talking. Why?

When I was a girl we had a concept we called sexy acne: ex-acne, combined with a certain strength of character. I suspect now that this was sexy because it suggested that its owner had a knowledge of suffering, and would therefore be wise. Clear skin suggests a worry-free existence and long nights of uninterrupted sleep. Nice now, but not interesting when you're young. An ugly man carries suffering and experience in his face; a pretty man knows only admiration. The nearest a girl can get to being ugly meanwhile is being incredibly beautiful but tastefully ravaged, like Marianne Faithfull, or all bone structure, like Barbra Streisand. Even so, Starville can only handle one at a time of them, and you don't ever get lady stars with no cheekbones at all and bad skin.

Now, in Hollywood, it seems to me the men are being prettified to the same degree that women have been. Even Richard E Grant has started to look like an airbrushed sitcom person not, as he rightfully should, the devil incarnate. Russell Crowe is as far as ugliness for men goes over there, and Crowe counting as ugly just proves that, according to Hollywood, we should all have major plastic surgery. In fact, we might as well just have our throats cut.

So in the US, Lyle Lovett - truly the most attractive Texan ever, and yes he does look like a parsnip - is mocked and tormented for marrying beautiful Julia Roberts. George Clooney - who is clearly moisturised to within an inch of his life - counts as butch. Gérard Depardieu in his Hollywood films looks as if he has been castrated. Across the real world men are spending more and more on products with which to feminise themselves, and in bars across the land you find bland boy-band lookalikes from 16 to 60. Everybody, actors included, wants to be Friends. No wonder film director Roman Polanski is having to have open auditions to find a man who looks like a vulnerable, damaged refugee.

Meanwhile, Lavant, Auteuil and Lovett show us faces which remind us that beauty is wild, strange, weird, interesting and sometimes very ugly.

Faces that just look like human beings. Like themselves. Like men. Like people you want to watch, want to talk to. Their ugliness evokes both reality and imagination: two things so lacking in US culture.

Oh, and the other really good thing about ugly men is they don't look prettier than you when you go out together.

 Shane Watson is away.

webTitle: The best misunderstanding scene

fields.headline: The best misunderstanding scene
fields.standfirst: Me, Myself and Irene
fields.trailText: Me, Myself and Irene
fields.body:
Rhode Island. After his wedding, Charlie (Jim Carrey) arrives home with his new wife. Before carrying her over the threshold, he turns to his diminutive chauffeur (Tony Cox).

"Um, excuse me. Do you people take cheques?"

The limo driver's face freezes.

"Say what? Do you people take cheques ? You mean a black man?"

He squares up to Charlie's knees. Charlie reels back in horror.

"No... I mean, no."

"Don't give me that crackerjack bullshit! That was a racist slur."

"No, it wasn't, really. I would never..."

The driver marches toward Charlie, scowling.

"I'll tell you what, I'll make it real easy for you. Why don't you just pay me in cotton? Or a juicy slice of watermelon? I know - how about you pay me with fried chicken? 'Cause you know us black folks, we just love fried chicken."

"No, no..."

"What? Did you call me a nigger? First you say I don't know how to cash a cheque, and now you're calling me nigger? Throw 'em up, bitch!"

Charlie's wife rounds on her new husband.

"Charlie! Don't you ever use the N word in this house!"

"What? I never... I never said anything remotely racist."

The limo driver narrows his gaze.

"Oh? So it's a little people thing, is it?"

See also:
Blood Simple, After Hours, The Party

Don't see also:
True Lies

Pointless trivia:
During the filming of Me, Myself And Irene, Jim Carrey and the entire production crew attended a private concert by prog rock band Phish, at which Carrey sang two songs with the group: Pink Floyd's Hey You and Come Together by The Beatles.
