webTitle: Obituaries; Louis Hagen

fields.headline: Louis Hagen
fields.standfirst: Wartime torture failed to dim his creative lust for life
fields.trailText: Louis Hagen, who has died aged 84, was a teenage German Jewish refugee, a British army glider pilot at Arnhem, a journalist, writer and children's film producer. He had a spectacular life.
fields.body:
Louis Hagen, who has died aged 84, was a teenage German Jewish refugee, a British army glider pilot at Arnhem, a journalist, writer and children's film producer. He had a spectacular life.

Born in Potsdam, near Berlin, he and his four siblings grew up in a Bauhaus-style villa built by their father, a banker with bohemian leanings. Louis was always known as "Büdi", a diminutive of brüderlein , or little brother. His blissful childhood was shattered in 1934 when, aged 15, he was thrown into Schloss Lichtenburg concentration camp. A housemaid had denounced him to her Nazi boyfriend after finding a postcard he had sent his sister with an anti-Nazi joke on it.

In the camp, Büdi was beaten, starved and forced into hard labour. The guards would strip him naked and force him to crawl, saying, "Cry for your Jewish mamma." He witnessed the murder of fellow prisoners. But the father of one of Büdi's school-friends, a high-ranking Nazi judge, rescued him after four months. He left immediately for England, joining his youngest sister. The other three siblings went to the United States. Their parents escaped in 1941, via the trans-Siberian railway to Japan and thence to America.

In prewar England, Büdi got a job at a steelworks near Oxford. Always humanitarian and left-liberal in his views, his friends included Aneurin Bevan and Jennie Lee, and the future Nobel laureate, biologist Peter Medawar, and his wife Jean, who helped him to learn English.

When war broke out, Büdi joined the Pioneer Regiment, and, renamed "Lewis Haig", became a glider pilot. In September 1944, as part of the doomed allied operation to leapfrog the German frontline, his regiment landed its gliders at Arnhem, in Holland. He got back to Britain and was awarded the military medal by George VI. Büdi was mesmerised by the king's stammer, and remembered the then Queen Elizabeth staring at him, amazed, he felt, to discover a German in her palace.

Brave and diligent, Büdi was also a great hedonist, and found that the temptations of love conflicted with the urge to write. But with the help of his friend, Dido Milroy, he wrote Arnhem Lift (1945), which became a bestseller and was translated into nine languages - though not before his army superiors, he recalled in his unpublished autobiography, outraged by its honesty, banned publication.

Undaunted, Milroy sent the book to a friend, a War Office censor, who allowed it to be published anonymously. Arnhem Lift formed the basis for Brian Desmond Hurst's film Theirs Is The Glory (1946), which re-enacted the battle with some of the participants.

In early 1945 the army transferred Büdi to a glider squadron in India. He was devastated; he wanted to be in Europe for the Nazi defeat. But Büdi lived a charmed life, with a limitless capacity to make the best of everything and enchant people wherever he went. He chanced upon a job as a journalist for the Allied South-East Asia Command's newspaper. Armed with a camera he had no idea how to use, he followed his curiosity, filing reports ranging from the life and times of a Calcutta brothel to colonial racism. His book Indian Route March (1946), followed. He reported from Burma, and had adventures in Bangkok. In Vietnam, he was apparently the first western journalist to interview its communist leader Ho Chi Minh.

Back in Europe after the war, Büdi returned to a Berlin in rubble, its citizens scrabbling amidst the ruins. He wrote Follow My Leader, which comprised intriguing biographies of nine Germans, most of whom collaborated with the Nazi regime. This was followed by The Secret War For Europe (1969), an account of Germany's role in international espionage.

In 1950, he settled in north London with his Norwegian wife Anne Mie, a painter. He set up a film company, Primrose Film Productions, and produced 25 children's films with Lotte Reiniger, his childhood art teacher and doyenne of animated film. Thanks to Büdi, her films, which date back to the 1920s, are still internationally shown.

Despite torture, exile and loss, Büdi was without bitterness. His lust for life was undimmed to the last. Two days before he died, he faxed his doctor requesting her to renew his Viagra prescription. The following night, at a birthday party for his daughter, he said he had had a marvellous life. Death, he added, held no fear for him.

He leaves his wife Anne Mie, daughters Siri and Caroline, and two grandchildren, Lara and Louis.

 Louis 'Büdi' Hagen, writer and producer, born May 30 1916; died August 17 2000

Two days before he died, he faxed his doctor requesting her to renew his Viagra prescription. The following night, at a birthday party for his daughter, he said he had had a marvellous life. Death, he added, held no fear for him. He leaves his wife Anne Mie, daughters Siri and Caroline, and two grandchildren, Lara and Louis.  Louis 'Büdi' Hagen, writer and producer, born May 30 1916; died August 17 2000

webTitle: Jon Favreau: Love and Sex

fields.headline: Lots more Mr Nice Guy
fields.standfirst: Jon Favreau's film Swingers was the comedy hit of 1996. Now he's using his good guy magic to make Love and Sex another independent success
fields.trailText: Jon Favreau's film Swingers was the comedy hit of 1996. Now he's using his good guy magic to make Love and Sex another independent success
fields.body:
Every so often a no-budget independent film sneaks out that is so fresh, it makes everything else at the cinema look old hat. Swingers, a sharply observed twist on the romantic comedy that Jon Favreau wrote when his career as an actor was stuttering, was one of those films. Its release in 1996 spawned catchphrases ("You're so money!"), a revival of lounge clubs in Canada, and countless homages as twentysomethings were inspired to tell their own tale.

Among the many such scripts Favreau has received in the past five years was Valerie Breiman's Love and Sex, a study of one woman's contorted relationship history that so caught his attention that he agreed to star in it, opposite Famke Janssen. He soon discovered just how autobiographical Breiman's script was: while directing, she developed a habit of rushing on set and telling her actors: "No, it happened more like this."

Breiman's film lacks the verbal and visual inventiveness that made Swingers such a delight, but this never impinges on Favreau's performance: he inhabits his character, Adam, like it's his favourite pair of pyjamas. Favreau has nothing but admiration for Breiman: "I don't think anyone is getting the new independent voice particularly right," he says, with the authority of one who is certain he has, "and it's rare that you come across a strong, personal, well-written film like Love and Sex."

He sounds like Breiman's agent, but genuine too - a quality that emerges repeatedly. When he describes his co-starring role in Love and Sex as "a really good second fiddle", he radiates an unassuming geniality that you wouldn't expect from a Hollywood player. On film, his old-fashioned niceness recalls romantic heroes of the black-and-white era: watching him bantering with Janssen, he makes you think of James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan in The Shop Around the Corner. His characters aren't perfect - "I don't mind playing guys who look foolish," he says - but they are essentially good, something that is important to him.

"I would never want to do a rape scene, for example," he says. "It's hard to weigh in on the subject because of the movement towards censorship, but there's a moral imperative in film-making to realise that some people are looking to the screen to learn their lessons. I certainly did."

He was born in New York in 1966, and although his grandmother, father and - before her death when Favreau was 12 - his mother were all teachers, he dropped out of university. He moved to Chicago, and eight years passed in a frustrating haze of adverts and minor parts. Favreau is grateful that fame was elusive: "Prince William," he says, "is 18, he's on the cover of magazines, and he hasn't done anything. I feel sorry for him. At 30 I was in a movie that brought me a lot of attention, I'm getting to do what I want to do and this is the price I pay for it. And then, I'm in a relationship with a woman I probably wouldn't have met if it hadn't been for Swingers, because that was how she approached me: to discuss that film." Doesn't he feel like he's stepped aside from real life? "Yeah," he grins, "but I never liked the other life that much anyway."

Favreau's career reads like a boy's fantasy. He was Courteney Cox's millionaire boyfriend in Friends and Cameron Diaz's fiance in Very Bad Things. He's been an astronaut (Deep Impact), a football player (The Replacements, yet to be released here), even Rocky Marciano in a made-for-TV biopic. "Boys get into acting because they want to meet girls," Favreau smiles, "but it's also to be like a little kid playing cowboys and indians."

At the moment Favreau is editing Made, about two boxers from LA getting swallowed up in New York's crime underbelly, which he has written, produced, starred in and directed. This behind-the-scenes control allows him to help other wannabe actors to break into cinema. On Made, that hopeful is none other than Sean "Puffy" Combs.

Favreau's praise of the buffoonish rapper is unsurprisingly effusive, and it's hard not to laugh when he innocently describes Puffy as "a man who brings a lot of life experience to what he's doing", including his role in Made as a New York crime don. Puffy's involvement did mean that New York's clubs were delighted to accommodate Favreau's cameras; on the downside, his time with Puffy proved to him that his Swingers-style party days are numbered. "It was interesting to get a taste of it," he says, "but I couldn't hang out with him every night. I can't keep up with him that well."

webTitle: Me, Myself and Irene

fields.headline: Me, Myself and Irene
fields.standfirst: The Farrelly brothers' war on taste continues, complete with cow assault and masturbation scene
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There's a lot of crazy energy and debonair disregard for the rules of liberal good taste; but when the laughs fall away and the comedy-nous falters, these things get very wearing indeed
fields.body:
With their stunning bad taste and cheerfully offensive excursions into racial and sexual comedy, the Farrelly brothers have given much amusement, and in the process become Hollywood's licensed jesters in their own carefully delineated field of non-PC entertainment. Me, Myself & Irene, starring Jim Carrey, is their new venture. Broader than broad, it is written, produced and directed by Peter and Bobby, with credits for Mike Cerrone and Bradley Thomas on script and production.

And they give us everything we hope and expect of them - plus a bit more. Frantic masturbation scene involving a sweet young woman? Check. Pointlessly violent assault on a defenceless animal? Check. Jokes involving racial and minority groups? Check. But there's one group in particular to be offended - retards! (I am quoting the exquisitely provocative formulation used by Matt Dillon in There's Something About Mary.) Peter and Bobby raise the issue of those who are, as they say, mentally challenged and appear to add a raucous challenge of their own.

The brothers get away with most of these flourishes on account of their sheer insouciant conviction and comic brio, plus the unspoken understanding that the jibes are a slap at white liberal condescension. But it isn't obvious that the gags about crazy people quite come off - of which more in a moment.

Jim Carrey gives us his usual body-popping, face-squeezing, crowd-pleasing masterclass in physical comedy. With his open, innocent expression, buzz cut and air of perpetual perplexity, he looks like no one so much as Dick York in the 60s TV show Bewitched.

He plays Charlie Baileygates, an all-American white-bread regular guy and Rhode Island state trooper whose life is shattered when his bride falls in love with the, ahem, vertically challenged African-American limo driver who ferries them home from the church. She runs off, leaving Charlie with three black triplets, and Charlie is in denial about his feelings, until they boil over 15 years later in the form of a bizarre split personality. Or, as this film insists on putting it, schizophrenia. Thereafter Charlie's Jekyll and Hyde personalities both fall in love with a young woman called Irene (Renée Zellweger), who is on the run from corrupt federal officials led by the sinister Lt Gerke (a reliably excellent Chris Cooper).

There is a scene at the very beginning of this film in which the Farrellys' horrible genius is deployed to its fullest. On his wedding day, poor, inoffensive Charlie inadvertently offends his small black driver, who erupts with rage and ends up attacking him with what look like martial-arts nunchakas. Naturally, only a real nincompoop could object to this scene; in its sheer excessive outrageousness, it is brilliant, but it also functions unmistakably as a little pre-emptive strike at any uptight bores who are thinking of whining about offensiveness. Here is a funny black midget, it is saying, and here is a joke about someone accidentally offending him. OK?

Then there is the uproarious scene in which Charlie and Irene find a dead cow in the road; trying to carry it out of the way, Charlie discovers it is actually still alive but in agony. So he tries to kill it, first by emptying his pistol into its head and then by strangling it, while the persistent beast moos merrily away. It's inspired in its own delirious way, and let down only by the fact that it is obviously some sort of animatronic cow.

The inevitable self-pleasuring scene comes when Irene enters Charlie's hotel room, dismayed to find him with an official police photo of her, surrounded by sticky crumpled tissues and an absurdly large dispenser of hand-cream. This hardly has the inventiveness of the legendary Cameron-Diaz-hair-gel sequence from There's Something About Mary, which was actually a comment of tactless inspiration on the way modern media encourage male consumers literally and figuratively to jerk off over female images like the miraculously beautiful Diaz. But it does have that bull-in-a-china-shop aptness, an acknowledgement of the open secret of adult male masturbation rarely found in any other film of any genre.

But now we come back to the "schizophrenia" issue, which has had mental health charities up in arms. The split-personality device gives Carrey an opportunity for his usual bravura dual-character playing, in the tradition of the Nutty Professors of Jerry Lewis and Eddie Murphy, and Steve Martin in All of Me. His condition is repeatedly described as "advanced involuntary schizophrenia". Do the Farrelly boys realise that "schizophrenia" is an ignorant solecism here? Worryingly, the answer isn't clear.

The classic definition of a gentleman is someone who never gives offence accidentally. Something similar applies to the Farrellys' brand of non-PC mischief if it is to be successful. But here it looks oddly as if the brothers have simply blundered. Here their sophistication, and their attack radar for mealy-mouthed liberal sensibilities, have gone a bit wrong.

The gag rate of Me, Myself & Irene falls off exponentially in the last half of the picture, and there's a bit of straining to make the plot ends tie up. There's a lot of crazy energy and debonair disregard for the rules of liberal good taste; but when the laughs fall away and the comedy-nous falters, these things get very wearing indeed.

webTitle: Hollywood reporter

fields.headline: Hollywood news
fields.standfirst: Erin's real life drama | Overrated over there
fields.trailText: Erin's real life drama
fields.body:
Erin's real life drama

Erin Brockovich has been in the news lately as a result of the Steven Soderbergh/ Julia Roberts film about her. Brockovich and her lawyer boss Ed Masry, played by Alfred Finney, were apparently blackmailed by Brockovich's ex-husband Shawn Brown, ex-boyfriend Jorg Halaby (played by Aaron Eckhardt) and their lawyer John Rainer, for $310,000. When Masry went public with tape-recordings of his negotiations with the three, they were ordered to stand trial. At one point Rainer tells Masry, "I'm in a position where Shawn can say some really, really damaging things about Erin" (Brown was unhappy about being portrayed as a deadbeat dad - and unlike Halaby, Erin B and Masry, received no money from Universal Studios). Later, Brown can be overheard saying that a certain sum of money will make all Masry's problems disappear forever. The judge in Ventura County Superior Court ordered the men to stand trial for attempted extortion and conspiracy charges, all of which could carry stiff jail sentences.

Overrated over there

The Directors' Guild of America chose this week to call for a complete revamping of the US movie ratings system, created and overseen by the Motion Picture Producers of America (MPAA) and its head Jack Valenti.

The DGA called for "a simple, clean and detailed rating system" that would apply not just to movies but to all media. It also condemned the NC-17 rating, which keeps out children under 17, as "an abject failure" that "unfairly stigmatised" movies and created a situation in which studios will cut adult movies to ribbons in order to secure an R-rating. "This has the effect of not only compromising filmmakers' visions," said the statement, "but also greatly increasing the likelihood that adult-oriented movies are seen by the very groups for which they are not intended."

This is the first time the DGA has criticised the MPAA system, which Valenti last week defended before a hostile Congressional Committee on media violence. The signatories included Rob Reiner, Wes Craven, John Carpenter, Michael Bay, Sidney Pollack, Michael Mann and Gary Ross. Perhaps they shouldn't get too excited; Jack Valenti was once Lyndon B Johnson's press secretary, promoting the Vietnam War at press conferences for years. When it comes to defending the indefensible, Jack Valenti doesn't back down.

webTitle: Home entertainment with Mike Hodges, director

fields.headline: Home entertainment with Mike Hodges
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodges
fields.trailText: The director of Get Carter, one of the hardest, seediest, most brutal depictions of poverty-backdropped criminal life ever committed to celluloid, lives in a lovely cottage deep in rural Dorset
fields.body:
The director of Get Carter, one of the hardest, seediest, most brutal depictions of poverty-backdropped criminal life ever committed to celluloid, lives in a lovely cottage deep in rural Dorset. It is hidden away down a rough dirt track, and is surrounded by a large garden with hammocks and apple trees. "I'm a small man, and quite a gentle one," says Mike Hodges, whose most recent film, Croupier, has become an unexpected US success, two years after FilmFour made it clear that they weren't going to help their own product find a distributor in Britain. "I don't think I've ever punched anyone in my life. But after the success of Carter, women treated me differently. I had criminals come up to me and say, 'Well done for telling it like it is.' I wanted to hang my head and hide."

Hodges' career has been coloured by a discernible lack of pattern. Having started off on World in Action documentaries, he is best known for two films at the opposite end of the spectrum: the violent reality of Get Carter, the story of a bitter man seeking revenge against villains; and the camp fantasy of Flash Gordon, telling the story of a hunk battling Ming the Merciless. He has also made the sci-fi drama The Terminal Man, Pulp, starring Caine again, and the comedy Morons From Outer Space.

"People should come out at the end of a film not being conscious of the director," says Hodges. "Obviously someone like Hitchcock has an immediately recognisable style, but I've always felt that the pot pourri of the film-making process should dictate how the film should be; that the film itself will tell the director what is needed."

So what kind of films would be in the video collection of a director with such an eclectic style? Documentaries figure heavily. "In the mid-90s there were three excellent ones from America, the first of which was Crumb [Terry Zwigoff's film about cartoonist Robert Crumb's family]. It was so detailed, such an incredible portrayal of the couch grass of emotions between this extraordinary family, it makes most other documentaries seem terribly superficial. Then there's Hoop Dreams, again shot over a long period of time so that the film-makers became part of the woodwork and everything was allowed to emerge naturally; and When We Were Kings. I was working in the States in the 70s when TV was in control of the networks, and the only time you would see anything political was on the Sunday morning documentaries. I suppose those three came out of that tradition. And I keep a lot of documentaries here because they always prove useful as source material."

Hodges does not use these classics for borrowing, though. "All this cross-referencing I find a little embarrassing. For Carter, I drew on my experiences in the navy, where I met a really seamy side of British society. The ports we went to were poverty-stricken, and when I shot Carter 15 years later, I went back to North Shields. It was perfect for a hard visualisation of what Jack was like. It had to be a ruthless, uncompromising film and you couldn't romanticise the world it was portraying."

A little different from the world of Flash Gordon, then. "That was based on a comic strip so it had to be like a strip cartoon, and he's the perfect American hero, very dumb indeed. But I was making it with Dino de Laurentiis and an Italian set designer who was completely out of control. He created a set for Arborea, with trees the circumference of this room, and he would say, 'Eesn't eet fantasteec?' And I would say, 'But where am I supposed to put the camera?' He didn't look at the script once."

Other films in the Dorset living room include Truffaut, early Godard, Billy Wilder and John Huston. "And there's no one to replace the great film-makers like Bergman, Kurosawa and Fellini. I did the English version of a Fellini film called The Ship Sails On, and had to go out to Rome to meet him. A born director. We sat down at a restaurant for lunch, about 10 of us, and he'd say, 'No no, this table isn't in the right direction.' So we'd all get up and move it, then he'd change his mind and we'd move it again. He was a charming reprobate, and absolutely hopeless when it came to telling the truth."

Hodges admits to being out of touch with modern directors. "Spielberg and Lucas have done enormous damage to the film art. The music tells you how to emote and feel, it's a button being pushed, it's Pavlovian. I like some of the Coen brothers films, and Scorsese I really admire. Woody Allen's are wonderfully made but rather too smart for me. I didn't like American Beauty. There's a very good film called Happiness which made American Beauty look ludicrous."

Hodges was prepared to give up film-making after FilmFour boss David Aukin told him that the only thing he liked about Croupier was the end credits, but its subsequent success in America has revitalised him. "They're so starved of films with any intellectual content that they went for it," he says.

I suppose those three came out of that tradition. And I keep a lot of documentaries here because they always prove useful as source material." Hodges does not use these classics for borrowing, though. "All this cross-referencing I find a little embarrassing. For Carter, I drew on my experiences in the navy, where I met a really seamy side of British society. The ports we went to were poverty-stricken, and when I shot Carter 15 years later, I went back to North Shields. It was perfect for a hard visualisation of what Jack was like. It had to be a ruthless, uncompromising film and you couldn't romanticise the world it was portraying." A little different from the world of Flash Gordon, then. "That was based on a comic strip so it had to be like a strip cartoon, and he's the perfect American hero, very dumb indeed. But I was making it with Dino de Laurentiis and an Italian set designer who was completely out of control. He created a set for Arborea, with trees the circumference of this room, and he would say, 'Eesn't eet fantasteec?' And I would say, 'But where am I supposed to put the camera?' He didn't look at the script once." Other films in the Dorset living room include Truffaut, early Godard, Billy Wilder and John Huston. "And there's no one to replace the great film-makers like Bergman, Kurosawa and Fellini. I did the English version of a Fellini film called The Ship Sails On, and had to go out to Rome to meet him. A born director. We sat down at a restaurant for lunch, about 10 of us, and he'd say, 'No no, this table isn't in the right direction.' So we'd all get up and move it, then he'd change his mind and we'd move it again. He was a charming reprobate, and absolutely hopeless when it came to telling the truth." Hodges admits to being out of touch with modern directors. "Spielberg and Lucas have done enormous damage to the film art. The music tells you how to emote and feel, it's a button being pushed, it's Pavlovian. I like some of the Coen brothers films, and Scorsese I really admire. Woody Allen's are wonderfully made but rather too smart for me. I didn't like American Beauty. There's a very good film called Happiness which made American Beauty look ludicrous." Hodges was prepared to give up film-making after FilmFour boss David Aukin told him that the only thing he liked about Croupier was the end credits, but its subsequent success in America has revitalised him. "They're so starved of films with any intellectual content that they went for it," he says.

webTitle: Shipman inquiry to be held in public

fields.headline: Shipman inquiry to be held in public
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: There will be a full public inquiry into the crimes of Harold Shipman, the doctor convicted of murdering 15 of his patients by lethal injection, the health secretary Alan Milburn said yesterday.
fields.body:
There will be a full public inquiry into the crimes of Harold Shipman, the doctor convicted of murdering 15 of his patients by lethal injection, the health secretary Alan Milburn said yesterday.

The high court had ordered Mr Milburn to reconsider his decision to hold the inquiry in private and it is likely that the hearing - expected to take months - will be held in Manchester later this year.

A chairman has yet to be appointed after Lord Laming, who would have chaired a private hearing, stood down.

The families of Shipman's victims and eight national newspapers successfully ar gued that there should be a judicial review of Mr Milburn's decision and in July, Lord Justice Kennedy ruled that holding the inquiry in private would breach section 10 of the European convention on human rights. The health secretary was asked to reconsider.

The Department of Health said yesterday the inquiry would be held under the 1921 Tribunals of Inquiry (Evidence) Act which gives the chairman legal powers to compel witnesses to appear and recover any documents. Similar hearings were held following the Aberfan and Dunblane disasters.

It will look at how Shipman was able to murder patients undetected for years, how he obtained drugs and how he was able to cover his tracks by altering medical records and ensuring patients were cremated without postmortem examinations.

Ann Alexander, the solicitor representing 150 families, said she was confident the inquiry would be able to investigate the background to Shipman's murders with the rigour needed to ensure questions were answered and that lessons were learned.

But it is unlikely that Shipman, serving 15 life sentences in Frankland Prison, Durham, will be invited to attend the hearing.

In January, Shipman, a former GP in Hyde, Greater Manchester, was convicted of the murder of 15 patients by lethal diamorphine injections.

Inquests into the deaths of two more patients have recorded verdicts of unlawful killings. A third inquest into the death of Elizabeth Mellor will take place next week.

The death toll from Shipman's killing spree could be as high as 200.

Ms Alexander said the outcome of the inquiry could have widespread implications for family doctors, coroners and for the police.

"The health secretary has obviously taken the sensible course of action and we will make absolutely sure that no stone will be left unturned," she said.

"The inquiry will establish how he was able to get away with killing so many of his patients for so long. It will look at the systems GPs operate within - what controls are in place and how they get hold of drugs."

She added that the public inquiry would also look at how Shipman was able to kill three more women after an initial police investigation in March 1998 had cleared him of any wrongdoing.

Ms Alexander said the relatives of all of the former doctor's victims wanted to hear for themselves what those involved in the Shipman case had to say.

She added that she felt sorry for the families who had been through a long criminal trial, then had to wait almost a year before getting a public inquiry.

Jane Ashton-Hibbert, whose grandmother Hilda Hibbert, 81, died at her home in Hyde while being treated by Shipman in 1996, said she was delighted with the news.

"I am very pleased and I am glad it is going to be a 1921 Act inquiry," she said. "It is going to be very thorough - it's going to have teeth. I think we feel that if it is in the open, people are more inclined to speak freely."

Helen Blackwell, whose mother Bertha Moss, 68, died five years ago, said the public inquiry was vital.

"We need to get it out in the open and to know what went wrong."

webTitle: What the McDonald's ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the McDonald's ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the McDonald's ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
Sir Les Patterson, Australian Cultural Attaché to the Court of St James (alias Barry Humphries), is swaggering through his embassy offices, talking food. "I'm all for nouvelle kwizine," he says, scratching his behind, "but you can't beat good-hearted tucker." He then sits on the edge of a desk, promptly splitting his pants. "Like a McAussie chicken sanger with mayo," he goes on, pointing at a stain on his lapel with a toothless grin. "Or a Big Bondi BBQ burger with cheese and outback sauce," he adds, indicating a particularly nasty mark on his trousers. Sir Les then sings the praises of the new Cheesy Boomerangs with tomato and herb dip, pointing cheerily at the tip of his tie, which has obviously been trailed through said sauce.

The jargon:
McDonald's has just brought out these Australian-style foods to capitalise on the Sydney Olympics and the trend for Aussie things. This 30-seconder also plugs the fact that McDonald's is an official sponsor of the Games.

Personality:
You are young, male, and very probably single. You secretly envy, if not aspire to, the Aussie way of life - their work-to-play attitude, hot weather and uncomplicated approach to relaxation.

Financial status:
These choice delicacies are priced from 69p (for the Cheesy Boomerangs) to £1.59 (the Big Bondi burger) - really anyone from any social/financial strata can afford them.

Telling lifestyle detail:
You could be closely following the Games (in fact, you like sport generally), and Australian lager is most definitely in your drinking "repertoire", as beer advertisers like to call it. Aside from that, you value Big, Hearty Food with a Big Character.

Other relevant data:
Barry Humphries apparently loved the script for this commercial. The agency, Leo Burnett, used Sir Les's usual, ready-stained blue suit and added pukka McDonald's stains to it from the actual Aussie food range itself for true authenticity.

webTitle: Liberal Democrat conference 2000

fields.headline: Affable Charlie lays out the country hotel welcome mat
fields.standfirst: Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
fields.trailText: I had to be in London on Wednesday night, but was up at dawn to get the train back to Bournemouth where I meant to catch Charles Kennedy's keynote speech.
fields.body:
I had to be in London on Wednesday night, but was up at dawn to get the train back to Bournemouth where I meant to catch Charles Kennedy's keynote speech.

But a sign at the station said that, thanks to someone breaking a window at MI6 headquarters, the rail system was in chaos.

As all stout hearted Britons know, it is our duty to defy this kind of thing and lead our lives as normal. To give in, to cancel our legitimate daily activities, creates a victory for terrorism.

On the other hand, I thought, it's only the Liberal Democrats. Who cares? So I stayed to watch it on TV.

Mr Kennedy is quite different from his predecessor. Sir Paddy Ashdown spoke as if reading letters of fire rather than an autocue. He was so passionate, so certain, that you felt that if people didn't like what he was saying, he'd descend into the audience and strangle a few of them.

Charlie Kennedy, by contrast, is more affable. He looks like Kilroy, or Jerry Springer without the mayhem. You also expect him to drop into the audience, but with a microphone, quizzing people on the topic of the day, such as: "Men who love goats and the women who stand by them."

He ran onto the stage as if appearing on a chat show. Naturally he was applauded loudly. "Quit while you're in front is the feeling I have," he said. The audience failed to laugh. (They also failed to laugh at his other "joke": "What's the difference between Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe? Jack's got an official driver to do his speeding for him; Ann Widdecombe has to speed on her own." We've all died on stage at one time or another. It must be awful to do it on live television.)

Given that the theme of his speech was connecting with the people, it was odd too that he spent such a long and lyrical passage time saying how splendid it had been to have the prime minister of Belgium at the conference. I wouldn't bank on this for the manifesto. "We offer you cheap petrol, shorter waiting lists, and a chance to quiz the prime minister of Belgium" is not going to hold Romsey.

But then things improved. There was a fierce attack on the government. "It's Labour's poverty of ambition which is so remarkable. With a majority of 179, they behave like John Major with a majority of three. All too often they seem scared of their own shadows," he said, which struck me as very good way of putting it.

Of the chancellor's conversion to high public spending, he said: "I'd like to think that Gordon saw the light. But the truth is, he felt the heat." But this was nothing compared to the liquid spleen he splashed onto the Tories. His eyes went crinkly. His mouth began to work up and down, so that he resembled the comic actor Arthur Mullard.

He appealed for middle of the road Tories to join them. "You have a home here. You will be very, very welcome," like the oleaginous owner of a country house hotel.

As for William Hague, for whom he seems to have a visceral dislike, "he jumps in the wrong place, at the wrong time and for the wrong reasons. He is the world's first unpopular populist". It was a good line, and was accompanied by a look of complete fury. Some of the anger seemed to communicate itself to the audience, and at last the speech began to smoulder.

Finally he did plunge into the crowd, and more precisely plunged down to Baroness Williams, with whom a colleague and I shared a very pleasant drink one evening, thus allowing me to say truthfully the unlikely sentence: "I spent some of the evening propping up the bar with Shirley Williams."

webTitle: A Country Diary

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Finistere
fields.body:
An Azores high pressure area drifted north over Brittany in mid-September, producing temperatures on the coast close to 30 C. I understand that these climatic conditions did not extend to the misty isles to the north, but "let's not worry about it, and enjoy what we have" was, I fear, the ongoing mindset.

Two swims a day proved attractive from the wide variety of beaches reachable by bicycle. Paul and Monique, who live across the lane and have a seagoing boat moored in the bay, said "Would you like to come fishing on Sunday morning?" This sounded good to me, and Sunday dawned warm and calm with a placid bay and little sea movement beyond the harbour wall.

We were off at 8.30am, rowing a skiff out to Paul's five-metre Antares 600 motor launch, outboard powered, and heading out to sea on a glorious morning with the rising sun lighting up a blue sea. Yesterday's excursion, I learnt, had yielded no fish. Would we do better?

The wind had changed from east to south, and serious sea fishermen will know why this matters. We were in pursuit of sea bass - a suspicious fish which can only be caught by guile and good fortune. We fished at five metres deep, with the imitation sand eel towed at two knots tickover speed, 90 metres behind the boat. It was a successful morning. Paul took us back and forth between Primel Tregastel and St Jean du Doigt at about 800 metres offshore. I caught two sea bass, a firm-fleshed prince of fish, with a total weight of 900 grams, and a mackerel. We returned home after four hours and took a self-congratulatory aperitif on the terrace. One sea bass made a fine dinner for two on Monday.

webTitle: Kennedy's tick box tax plan

fields.headline: Kennedy's tick box tax plan
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
Special report: Charles Kennedy
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy yesterday offered voters the chance to decide directly how some of their taxes are spent as part of his campaign to show that only the Liberal Democrats can be trusted to promote "the people's priorities".
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy yesterday offered voters the chance to decide directly how some of their taxes are spent as part of his campaign to show that only the Liberal Democrats can be trusted to promote "the people's priorities".

In a bid to restore what he sees as waning public confidence in the political process Mr Kennedy wants voters to be able to tick a box on their P60 tax forms to indicate whether they want a specific sum - initially only £2bn to £3bn a year - to be spent on health, education or another public service.

The idea of hypothecation - earmarking some taxes specifically for the NHS, schools, roads or pensions - has long been resisted by the Treasury. However, Mr Kennedy said: "We will let people, not politicians, decide how some of their tax revenues are spent."

Aides later explained that the Lib Dem manifesto will spell out the plan to let people indicate how they would like a penny of the tax paid on every pound - currently worth £2.3bn and rising - to be spent. The party has already pledged an extra penny on tax for education "if necessary" to meet its goals.

As expected, Mr Kennedy used his speech to the party conference in Bournemouth to appeal to moderate One Nation Tory voters - people who believe in "tolerance, decency, fair play" - to defect from what William Hague has done to their own party.

In a departure for the man who succeeded Paddy Ashdown 14 months ago, the genial Mr Kennedy deliberately tried to project real passion - anger even - as he described the rightwing "issues and instincts" which guide what he dismissed, not as the Conservative party but something less - "William Hague's party".

"William jumps in with both feet, in the wrong place, at the wrong time, for the wrong reasons. Desperate for a headline, desperate for a quote, desperate to get attention, he's the world's first unpopular populist," explained Mr Kennedy, in a week when the Tory leadership has backed fuel protesters and their calls for lower petrol taxes.

With a nod to supporters of Kenneth Clarke, Michael Heseltine and Chris Patten he said "you have friends in the Liberal Democrats, you have a home, come and talk to us." Party leaders are keen to find a high-profile defector before the general election - probably next May or June.

Mr Kennedy's office is all too aware that the Lib Dems' own commitment to raise some taxes - including a 50% rate on £100,000-a-year incomes to finance a big pensions boost - is risky when it is courting Tory voters in winnable seats in southern England, so the leader's half-hour speech skated over precise details.

He did reaffirm Lib Dem plans to abolish prescription charges and student tuition fees and give pensioners up to £15 a week extra but the address concentrated on a "what you see is what you get" tone, Mr Kennedy's unpretentious warmth and his repeated insistence that the political system needs the Lib Dems be cause Labour is timid - "scared of their own shadows" - and the Tories increasingly reactionary.

To square the circle he invoked "the F word" - for freedom - and said governments should do less, but do it better and should get off people's backs. "The others are now the old parties of the 20th century, we are the party of the 21st," he claimed

That was typical of this week's upbeat tone in Bournemouth which not even yesterday's disappointing poll dampened. Gallup gave the Lib Dems only 16% compared with 22% in the latest Guardian/ICM poll.

webTitle: Police find piece of rocket launcher and point finger at Irish dissidents

fields.headline: Police find piece of rocket launcher and point finger at Irish dissidents
fields.standfirst:
Hit on one of Britain's most secure buildings seen as latest in Real IRA campaign
Police anti-terrorist branch
Foreign Office
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Dissident Irish republicans were yesterday being blamed for a rocket launcher attack on the London headquarters of the foreign intelligence service, MI6.
fields.body:
Dissident Irish republicans were yesterday being blamed for a rocket launcher attack on the London headquarters of the foreign intelligence service, MI6.

Police are hunting for an active service unit of the Real IRA, who are opposed to the Northern Ireland peace process and were responsible for the August 1998 bomb in Omagh that killed 29 people.

The group is believed to have been behind this summer's bomb on Hammersmith Bridge and a device that failed to explode near a railway line in Ealing, west London. But the latest attack on one of the country's most secure buildings represents an escalation in the campaign and has led to security being stepped up for next week's Labour party conference in Brighton.

The missile was fired - without any warning - at 9.45pm on Wednesday, slightly damaging a window and two glass screens on the eighth floor of the distinctive cream and green security service building at Vauxhall Cross, south London.

Metropolitan police Deputy Assistant Commissioner Alan Fry described the explosion as "an audacious attack in one of the busiest parts of London".

Last night Scotland Yard said part of a rocket propelled grenade launcher was found near the MI6 building in Spring Gardens following a painstaking search of the area by police and forensic experts. A police spokeswoman said it was not known if the launcher had been fired from the spot where it was found. "The launcher is now being examined by experts. This will enable us to determine precisely what type of launcher it is."

She added that the Met officers would continue to carry out "extensive searches" in the area and forensic work would continue.

"The sort of weapon that we believe to have been used in this attack is known to be in the hands of certain groups. Clearly they will be uppermost in our minds," he said.

"Certainly there have been finds both in the south and north of Ireland and similar devices may have been used here. But clearly these devices are readily available in Yugoslavia, Russia and other previous Eastern bloc countries."

But he stressed he was keeping an open mind about who was behind the attack. "Clearly we have to keep in mind the capabilities of dissident Irish groups, but at this stage we will not be ruling out any group who might see the secret intelligence service as a target."

However, the Real IRA are known to have acquired Soviet designed rocket launchers from the former Yugoslavia. Last year Scotland Yard sources said the rebel republican terrorists were establishing new arms supply routes through the Balkans in preparation for a renewed campaign in Britain and Ireland.

Yesterday the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who has responsibility for MI6, said: "I have spoken to the chief of SIS, Richard Dearlove. He has confirmed there was no damage inside the Vauxhall Cross building.

"I asked him to commend SIS staff for maintaining business as usual. If the intention of the attackers was to disrupt SIS's operations, they have failed in their objective."

The prospect of an active terrorist group at large on the mainland, apparently equipped with at least one rocket launcher, prompted an upgrading of security at other security-sensitive buildings. "London will be policed according to the current threat," a spokeswoman said. "This will include high-visibility policing and appropriate security measures. Although the Real IRA called a ceasefire in the aftermath of the Omagh tragedy, it is now known to be active again and security services in Northern Ireland are on full alert against further attacks.

Earlier this month the group was suspected of a mortar attack on the Royal Ulster Constabulary station at Armagh, and also fell under suspicion the previous day when two 80lb bombs were found at a military training camp at Magilligan, County Londonderry.

The Real IRA is the largest in a coalition of dissidents, which, security sources estimate, numbers 120 people. But it is unclear how many are either active or potential terrorists.

Security sources on both sides of the Irish border spend little time drawing distinctions between the Real IRA, now three years old, Continuity IRA, dating from the Sinn Fein split of 1986, and dissident elements in the Irish National Liberation Army. They believe they switch flags of convenience as it suits.

The security forces are also in no doubt that numbers of dissident republicans are growing and their confidence is increasing as well.

Attacks such as the one on the MI6 building, although insignificant in the damage it caused, are crucial to the renegade groups as they send a powerful message to terrorists wavering between the political route to a united Ireland or a return to violence that there is an alternative to the Good Friday agreement and that they have the ability to keep the war going.

The impetus to dissident republicanism came when the IRA's quartermaster quit the IRA with his partner and a dozen others in the autumn of 1997.

They were opposed to Sinn Fein's entry to the talks, and rejected the Good Friday agreement which followed in April 1998.

Earlier this week, it was reported that the former IRA leader had disappeared from his normal haunts in the Republic, and may have moved to the British mainland to direct operations.

When the gardai raided a wine cellar in a derelict country house 25 miles north of Dublin last October, they realised that the Real IRA had acquired some serious weaponry.

The underground bunker was a military training camp and after arresting 10 men, including a 14-year-old, follow-up searches led them to a hay barn.

Hidden in pipes beneath the bales was a Russian anti-tank weapon capable of piercing up to 375mm of armour.

Though the Provisionals were known to have acquired a number of similar rocket grenade launchers, known as the RPG7, from Libya in the 1980s, this find was different. It was an updated version, the RPG18, manufactured in 1990 and the first weapon of its kind found in the Irish republic.

Irish and British intelligence agencies, including MI6, which had been monitoring the travels of two Real IRA members, including its alleged leader, Michael McKevitt from Dundalk, believed they knew where it came from. The new source of weapons was Croatia in the former Yugoslavia, although some reports have suggested that they originated in the first instance in either Serbia or the Kosovo Liberation Army.

Further confirmation came in March when a similar weapon, ready for use, was found abandoned near the Killymeal barracks at Dungannon in Co Tyrone, the base of the 3rd battalion the Parachute Regiment.

Then, in July, Croatian police raided a number of houses and warehouses in the town of Dobranje near the border with Bosnia and seized an arsenal which they believed were destined for Ireland.

The haul included 10 RPG18s.

Favoured by terrorists, rebels and irregular forces around the world, the RPGs are relatively cheap and easy to aquire and operate. The RPG18, called the Mukha in Russian, was introduced in the 1970s as a disposable, single-shot anti-tank weapon. It comprises a glass fibre tube with a 64mm rocket and a range of 200m.

The high velocity rocket can be launched in seconds. After extending the collapsed tube, the operator places it on his shoulder, lines up the target through a pop-up sight, engages the firing mechanism and pulls the trigger.

Writing in a Russian army magazine about "the fly that flies through armour" a weapons expert said: "It could be used by any soldier, even a cook or clerk."

webTitle: Camelot lottery bid

fields.headline: Camelot lottery bid
fields.standfirst:
Camelot back in lottery bid stakes
Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's hopes of running the national lottery suffered a severe setback yesterday after his rival, Camelot, muscled its way back into contention for the next seven-year licence through the high court.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's hopes of running the national lottery suffered a severe setback yesterday after his rival, Camelot, muscled its way back into contention for the next seven-year licence through the high court.

Mr Justice Richards ruled that a decision taken last month by the national lottery commission to enter into exclusive talks with Sir Richard's People's Lottery had been "conspicuously unfair".

At the end of August, the commission announced that neither party could win the licence as they stood but gave the People's Lottery a month to revise its bid and settle a number of outstanding concerns.

Executives from Camelot, which has run the lottery for the past six years, will meet the commission today and have until October 25 to put forward a new bid.

The judgment will prove deeply embarrassing to the commission, chaired by Dame Helena Shovelton, which had already twice delayed its decision on awarding the licence.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, rounded on his opposite number, Chris Smith, saying his department had fallen into a "shambles".

The chief executive of the commission, Mark Harris, said the regulatory body was "naturally disappointed" at the outcome.

The commission would, he added, abide by the judgment as quickly and fairly as possible to remove the "uncertainty that has been hanging over the bidding process."

Mr Justice Richards said there had been "a marked lack of even-handedness" in the commission's dealing with the two bidders.

"I have no doubt the commission was trying to be fair," he noted. "In the result, however, there is in my judgment no escaping the conclusion that the procedure decided on by the commission was conspicuously unfair to Camelot - such unfairness that it rendered the decision unlawful."

He stressed however that the judgment bore no influence on the final decision over which bidder should win the licence, which will run from October 2001.

"I find it remarkable that the commission chose to allow the People's Lottery the opportunity to allay its concerns but denied a similar opportunity to Camelot," he said. "Fairness required that each bidder should have the opportunity to allay the commission's concerns."

The commission will pay Camelot's legal costs, which are expected to be in the region of £250,000.

Camelot had been ruled out from entering final negotiations with the commission be cause of concerns over the propriety of its chief software supplier, US firm G-Tech. During the bidding process, which began in February, it emerged that G-Tech had attempted to cover up a software glitch which meant that some entries were being recorded twice and winners were being shortchanged.

Since the commission made its decision at the end of August, Camelot has offered to buy the UK operation of G-Tech to keep a tighter grip on the operation.

Sir Richard's bid had been turned down chiefly in the last instance because of worries over its ability to pay out prizes in the event of low sales. The People's Lottery had to find an extra £50m which Sir Richard said had now been done.

He remained upbeat in the face of yesterday's verdict. "The People's Lottery obviously respects the court's decision," he said. "However, we remain confident that we have delivered the best bid which offers the most money to good causes."

If Camelot is able to persuade the commission of its bid's merits it will be a remarkable feat of survival. Camelot has raised £8.8bn for good causes but its tenure has been blighted by controversy including accusations of fat cattery and profiteering.

Dianne Thompson, chief executive designate at Camelot, said she was delighted at the result but said of the commission: "We hope they will be totally open-minded and not have a preferred choice.

"It is clear that the best way to secure a truly competitive process is to run a race with more than one competitor and to allow that race to finish. We seek fair and equal treatment."

webTitle: Branson and the bravura biographer

fields.headline: Branson and the bravura biographer
fields.standfirst: Special report: The National Lottery
fields.trailText: During the summer, Sir Richard Branson telephoned this office in something of a lather. He took issue with a piece of commentary which implicitly questioned his motives in bidding to run the national lottery.
fields.body:
During the summer, Sir Richard Branson telephoned this office in something of a lather. He took issue with a piece of commentary which implicitly questioned his motives in bidding to run the national lottery.

His lawyers, Slaughter & May, were on the case, but Sir Richard could not wait.

"Who wrote it?" he demanded. "I did," came the hesitant reply.

"No you didn't. Tom Bower wrote it."

"No, I wrote it."

"Well, you must have spoken to him."

"No, we've never spoken."

At that, Sir Richard softened. The lawyers were called off. He had convinced himself, unnecessarily, that Bower, an investigative author whom he had accused of libel, was teasing out titbits of information ahead of publication of his biography of Britain's Best Loved Entrepreneur.

Ever since it became known that Bower was targeting Branson, there had been a frisson of excitement in the world of Virgin watchers. This was the author who lifted the lid on men like Maxwell and Fayed. If there was any dirt to be dug on the Virgin empire, Bower was the man to dig it. The book was finally published yesterday (Branson, by Tom Bower; £17.99, Fourth Estate) and just a quick read explains Sir Richard's paranoia.

This is 380 pages of unrelenting hostility, charting the businessman's story from his pushy mother to his current, desperate pursuit of the Big Game. It is an addictive read, packed with sex, money, tantrums - top quality tabloidese from beginning to end. Yet it tells us precious little we did not already know about Sir Richard and his business dealings over the past 30 years.

Yes, he duped customs and excise with a mail order record scam back in 1969. Yes, he uses a web of offshore trusts and companies to avoid British tax. And yes, he likes women and has pursued them with some energy.

Two years in the making, the most serious allegation thrown up after 250 interviews concerns the move to take the Virgin group off the stock exchange and back into private hands 12 years ago.

The "explosive" revelation is that while Virgin's investors were offered cash for their shares which valued the business at £248m, Sir Richard had already agreed a deal with a Japanese media firm named Pony Canyon to buy a stake in the newly private Virgin at a price which valued the group at £377m.

The implication is that Sir Richard held back material information, possibly breaking the City's takeover panel code. If Virgin's shareholders had known about the Pony Canyon transaction, they might not have accepted the price offered by Sir Richard - even though this was double the Virgin share price be fore the move to take the company private.

This is a grey area of the law. As Bower knows, the City always distrusts management buyouts such as this; big shareholders assume the managers know more about how much the business is worth. They almost expect to be ripped off.

Bower has failed to deliver proof that Sir Richard is unfit to run the lottery. He has produced an ugly portrait of the man - but he has not penetrated the complex web of Virgin's offshore trusts. A missed opportunity, perhaps.

webTitle: BAT accused of criminality

fields.headline: BAT accused of criminality
fields.trailText: The world's two largest tobacco manufacturers are being sued over allegations that they are actively involved in organised crime.
fields.body:
The world's two largest tobacco manufacturers are being sued over allegations that they are actively involved in organised crime.

Philip Morris and British American Tobacco are accused of widespread smuggling and money laundering in a writ filed by a consortium of Colombian states.

The notice, filed in the US district court in Brooklyn, New York, claims the companies "directly and indirectly" smuggled cigarettes into Colombia.

The pair, it alleges, took part in racketeering activity which included money laundering, wire fraud and mail fraud.

Their actions, states the document, have deprived the republic of Colombia of billions of dollars in taxes, while expanding the market for contraband cigarettes.

A copy of the writ obtained by the Guardian alleges the defendants created a "sophisticated and clandestine smuggling operation" which operated throughout the world.

"Defendants have conceived, directed, controlled and implemented an international conspiracy to defraud the plaintiffs and deprive them of money and property, in order to increase their profits and market share."

The US law firm acting on behalf of the Colombian states, Speiser, Krause, Nolan & Granito, refused to comment.

A New York legal source said that the action was being taken under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, and the writ would be served on the companies over the next couple of days. They will then have around 20 days to respond.

Clive Bates, of anti-smoking group Ash, said he was pleased legal action was being taken against the companies.

"We want recognition that tobacco companies are intimately involved in large scale smuggling," he said.

Last night, British American Tobacco said it had not been served with a writ, and insisted that any such action would be "defended vigorously".

A spokesman said the company had always worked closely with the Colombian states to eradicate smuggling.

"We reject the US court action and a law suit which al leges actions, including smuggling, as completely without merit," he said. "It is also noteworthy that neither the Colombian government nor the Colombian customs authorities have supported the action by the plaintiffs."

At the time of going to press no comment had been received from Philip Morris.

Morris, whose brands include Marlboro and Virginia Slims, and BAT, which is behind Dunhill and Lucky Strike, are two of the leading forces in an industry riddled with controversy. Recent years have seen an unprecedented number of lawsuits filed across the world against manufacturers.

British American Tobacco already faces an official inquiry by the Department of Trade and Industry into allegations it actively encouraged and profited from cigarette smuggling after a cross-party committee of MPs agreed to demand an investigation.

Earlier this year a jury in the US ordered five of the world's largest companies - including Philip Morris and BAT's US arm Brown & Williamson - to pay a record $145bn (£97bn) for harming the health of hundreds of thousands of smokers in Florida.

webTitle: 'We talk all day about what they should do - but we just don't know'

fields.headline: 'We talk all day about what they should do - but we just don't know'
fields.standfirst: A British court rules today on whether Jodie and Mary should be separated. Rory Carroll travelled to the family's homeland to test local opinion
fields.trailText: By sunrise today the first mass will be over and villagers will disperse to homes and workplaces. This evening they will return to the church to hear if their prayers have been answered.
fields.body:
By sunrise today the first mass will be over and villagers will disperse to homes and workplaces. This evening they will return to the church to hear if their prayers have been answered.

Judgment day has come but the villagers have been praying for different outcomes. The God they worship has not spared them the tormenting uncertainty over the fate of the conjoined twins Mary and Jodie.

Some defy the priest and secretly pray that this afternoon's ruling by three British court of appeal judges will overrule the parents by allowing the separation to go ahead, killing Mary to save Jodie. Others pray that nature will be allowed to take its course, even if it means both girls will die.

Others pray for a miracle, for the whispers to be true: in the past few days a rumour has spread that Mary does have a functioning heart after all, and could survive without Jodie.

There is no such evidence but this community, whose location cannot be disclosed for legal reasons, is in awe of the dilemma confronting the twins' parents.

Here there is no oak-panelled court room, just cacti, a sea breeze and sunbaked fields, but the arguments that ripple through the community are the same as those convulsing Britain's philosophers, ethicists and law lords.

Here, 95% of the population is practising Catholic and churches sprout from the surrounding hills. Mass is said six times a day, grottoes of the Virgin Mary adorn street corners and abortion is illegal.

Appearing drawn and pale in her living room, the babies' paternal grandmother spoke falteringly. She has been in regular telephone contact with her son but refrains from asking details to avoid upsetting him further.

"It is out of our hands now," she said. "We can only wait to see what happens. It has been so difficult, so difficult. We cannot do anything more except pray."

Half a mile away the maternal grandmother, hanging washing in a garden of fig trees, shook her head and refused to speak. Neighbours said she has become a virtual recluse.

A life-sized statue of the Virgin Mary clutching an infant Jesus gazes out across the dusty, deserted street where the family lives.

A neighbour sweeping her porch questioned whether the birth was a manifestation of God's will. "It is horrible, it just breaks your heart. No family should have to go through that," she said.

"We have been counting down the days [to the ruling] but don't know what to expect. It doesn't seem right that judges make the decision."

But the compassion was tinged with resentment. Mary, the weaker twin, has no viable separate biological existence because she lack lungs and a heart. If they are not separated Jodie will die from the strain of supporting Mary.

The more time elapses the more likely it is that Jodie will become permanently brain damaged, which her parents said would make it almost impossible to rear her on the island.

In a written court statement, the parents said that if they returned with Jodie alive but seriously disabled, some superstitious islanders would regard her as punishment for an earlier sin.

The neighbour said that was nonsense. "Decades ago perhaps, but not now, there is very little stigma left, if any. For years we all took turns looking after a friend's daughter who had Down's syndrome."

Disabled children are no longer hidden and brought to festivals, she said. A respite centre for disabled children and their parents is due to open this year and the hospital several miles from their home is well-equipped and has a paediatrician who is confident of treating all but the most serious cases. A paediatric cardiology unit is 20 minutes away by helicopter.

Tapping his nose, another local said of the written statement: "If it helps them win then OK. Just don't go thinking we are all primitive."

Despite the court ban on naming the family or the area in which they live, everyone here knows who they are, right down to newly arrived tourists. A newspaper which started a website poll on whether Mary and Jodie should be separated recorded 70% in favour of the operation, despite the opposition of the Catholic church which says no life should be taken.

The parents' main argument is that the surgical separation of the twins would kill Mary and wilful killing is against their religious beliefs.

Sitting in a pew near the altar of his Romanesque church, the village priest claimed the congregation had responded positively when he preached against separation.

Immoral

"It is the same principle as organ donation," he said. "Transplants are valid and moral when the donor is dead, but Mary is not dead. She is alive, she is a human being. It is wrong to kill her, no matter how good the intention.

"No one knows how long the twins might live. First the doctors said six months. Now some say two years. Should Mary be denied that? And what if the rumour is true, what if she does have a heart of her own?"

In the square outside the church, a cafe terrace hosted two groups of male villagers discussing the case, their arguments were punctuated by long silences.

A budding consensus that Jodie should be saved broke down over whether Mary's resulting death would be an unintended effect, and thus acceptable, or euthanasia - effectively murder.

One man said both deaths would be tragic but that the two innocents, baptised in Manchester, would be guaranteed eternal peace in the kingdom of heaven. Those on either side shook their heads but said nothing.

They agreed to meet again today for evening mass. A friend of the family stood up to leave. "We can talk all day about what the parents should do, and what we would do if we were in their shoes, but the truth of it is we don't have a clue. Only if it happens to your own blood can you know."

The judges

The three judges hearing the case of conjoined twins Jodie and Mary have, in effect, the awesome responsibility of ruling which of the sisters has the greatest claim to life.

Yet the legal system makes it almost impossible for the public to examine the judges' personal or religious views - views which might influence their outlook.

British law insists that a judge's "religion, ethnic or national origin, gender, age, class, means or sexual orientation" should not be a factor in deciding whether he or she is fit to hear a case. It could be said that as they base their decisions on the law rather than their beliefs then their own faith is irrelevant.

But some observers have argued that as religion has played an important role in the case - the parents have said they cannot agree to the operation to separate the twins because of their faith and the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Westminster, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has been allowed to make his submissions - the beliefs of the judges could be relevant.

All three judges have religious backgrounds, though they have declined to talk about their beliefs. They are also family men with 13 children between them and the senior judge, Lord Justice Ward, has twin daughters.

Lord Justice Ward , 62, is a former pupil of the Christian Brothers college in Pretoria, South Africa. The college offered what it describes as "holistic education based on Catholic traditions". He married in a Church of England ceremony in Somerset in 1963 while at Cambridge University and was called to the Bar the following year.

He had one son and two daughters by his first marriage and was divorced in 1982. He remarried the following year and had twin daughters in 1984. From 1988 to 1995 he was a judge in the high court's family division and has been a lord justice in the court of appeal since 1995.

At times he brought religion into the hearing. He said: "It was not God's will that [Mary, the weaker twin] should live because it was not born with the capability of living." He also said that one law we have was "handed down from Mount Sinai - thou shalt not kill".

Lord Justice Brooke , 64, is from a family with a strong Anglican tradition. His maternal grandfather was a canon and his uncle a former dean and rector of St Albans. His brother, the former Northern Ireland secretary and Conservative party chairman, Peter Brooke, was chairman of the National Conference of Student Christian Movement and a lay adviser to St Paul's cathedral.

A father of three sons and one daughter, Lord Justice Brooke is a former chairman of the Law Commission who became a Lord Justice of Appeal in 1996.

He brought religion into the case when he pointed out that much of today's law is founded on case law made by judges "long ago" who based their findings on Judaeo-Christian principles.

Lord Justice Walker , 62, was educated at one of Britain's most famous Catholic schools, Downside in Bath, which was founded by Benedictine monks in the 17th century. He married in Hampstead register office, in north London, in 1962 and has one son and three daughters.

Seen by insiders as the most "intellectually rigorous" of the trio, he practised at the Chancery Bar between 1961 and 1994 before being promoted first as a judge of the high court chancery division and since 1997 has been a lord justice of appeal

webTitle: Staff unruffled by rocket strike

fields.headline: Staff unruffled by rocket strike
fields.standfirst:
High profile building that proved tempting target
Police anti-terrorist branch
Foreign Office
fields.trailText: Despite the late hour of the rocket attack on the headquarters of the secret intelligence service, many of the desks were still manned.
fields.body:
Despite the late hour of the rocket attack on the headquarters of the secret intelligence service, many of the desks were still manned.

"It is not a nine-to-five post," a Foreign Office source said yesterday. "The staff need to get in touch with operatives overseas. As a consequence, there are people working at their desks through the night."

The union flag at the front of the building was still flying as the missile found its target. Most government offices lower the flag in the evening, but the SIS has a special dispensation from the Queen to fly theirs all night.

The visible damage was a broken window and charred curtains. Damage to the office was described as minor. No-one was injured, despite the numbers in the building, even at 9.45pm.

The SIS has more than 2,000 staff, some based at Vauxhall and others operating overseas, either attached to embassies as "diplomats" or working under cover.

Those based in the striking block by the Thames yesterday dealt calmly with the attack, according to the Foreign Office. "There was no disruption of operations," a source said.

Even if the damage had been serious, the Foreign Office stressed that the work of the SIS would have been unlikely to have been interrupted. Emergency procedures have been prepared to keep the department running. In spite of all the peoples, groups and countries that the SIS has antagonised down the years, Wednesday night's attack was the first on its head quarters since its founding by the Foreign Office in 1909.

The attack will be seen as vindication by critics who pointed out that the flamboyant new SIS building - designed by Terry Farrell - was too visible a target. Until it moved, it had occupied buildings indistinguishable from other grey blocks round Westminster and Whitehall.

At the time of the move in 1994, the SIS said such a high-profile building chimed with the political mood of the time: that the intelligence services should accept a degree of public scrutiny. For anyone left in any doubt about who occupied the building, it featured in the the James Bond film The World Is Not Enough.

There was controversy over the cost of the building - £230m - of which £85m was devoted to internal fittings. The Foreign Office yesterday replied to these critics, saying the minimum damage caused was a tribute to the trouble taken to make the building as resistant as possible to terrorist attack.

The SIS , better known outside government circles as MI6, is responsible for gathering intelligence overseas. MI5 confines its work to Britain and occupies a discreet building on the other side of the river.

Security at Vauxhall is as high as anywhere in the country. There are guards, video cameras and security barriers. Visitors are taken in by armoured car to an underground car park and then by lift to their destination.

The only member of SIS whose identity has been made public is the head, Richard Dearlove, aged 55, who took over last September. As for the others, the Foreign Office said they did not conform to the public image as Oxbridge types but were drawn from all parts of society. "The reason they are not recognisable in the street is because they look like everyone else," the Foreign Office source said.

webTitle: Railtrack expects £4bn bail-out

fields.headline: Railtrack expects £4bn bail-out
fields.standfirst:
Taxpayers will have to foot two-thirds of bill for west coast line upgrade
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: About £4bn of taxpayers' money has been set aside by the government to ensure Railtrack is able to complete the £5.8bn upgrade of the west coast main line between London and Glasgow, the company admitted to the Guardian last night.
fields.body:
About £4bn of taxpayers' money has been set aside by the government to ensure Railtrack is able to complete the £5.8bn upgrade of the west coast main line between London and Glasgow, the company admitted to the Guardian last night.

The money has been delivered by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, to the industry as part of a £30bn package of investment in rail over the next 10 years.

Negotiations are still going on between Gerald Corbett, Railtrack's chief executive, and the shadow Strategic Rail Authority on the exact amount to be paid.

But the overall effect will be that two-thirds of the cost of one of the biggest rail infrastructure projects in Europe is being funded by taxpayers.

The figure shows that in spite of rail privatisation, the taxpayer is largely responsible for underpinning the railway.

Train operating companies are receiving £1.3bn in subsidies which are due to expire in 2002 but will have to be continued beyond that date for large, unprofitable sections of the railway.

The cost of the west coast main line project has been a source of embarrassment for Railtrack and the government for some time.

Railtrack said yesterday that the cost had more than doubled from £2.2bn when it was started several years ago to £5.8bn when it is due for completion in 2005.

Earlier this year the company quietly admitted that the costs were spiralling. It said it could not finish the project on its own and that it would have to be bailed out.

Robin Gisby, Railtrack's director of network development, said Railtrack would have to make the investment before it could recoup the money, and the railway would have to be tested. "It is not just being handed over to us and we are told to get on with it."

He explained that when the original £2.2bn project was begun the Treasury put £1.4bn into the scheme, "so there has always been some element of public involvement".

The £4bn of state funds is being held by Sir Alastair Morton at the SSRA. A spokesman pointed out that a small part of this money would be set aside for signalling and safety on other parts of the network.

Railtrack's revelations took the rail unions by surprise. Vernon Hince, assistant gen eral secretary of the RMT rail union, said that it exposed the industry's foolishness.

"It is outrageous that the government is being forced to subsidise a private company which makes millions in profits and distributes millions to its shareholders."

Mr Hince said that the disclosure also called into question the proposals for part-privatisation of the London Underground.

The 400-mile west coast line, linking the most populated parts of Britain, is being redeveloped for the first time in 30 years. It is planned that the line will be used by tilting trains, operated by Sir Richard Branson's Virgin company, capable of achieving speeds of 140mph. But there are now doubts this will happen.

Virgin is confident that Rail track will be able to deliver the first phase of the deal - with tilting trains running at speeds of 125mph by 2002 - cutting the journey time between London and Manchester to around two hours.

But bad planning and Railtrack's over-ambitious reliance on a new signalling system could upset the second phase.

Railtrack has even suggested that it would pay Virgin up to £250m to withdraw from the construction project, but the Branson organisation has rejected the idea.

Thousands of passengers along the route constantly suffer the side-effects of the upgrade work. Trains frequently run late, or are cancelled.

Railtrack says it will get worse before it gets better but that when the route is finished it will be fast and efficient.
