webTitle: NHS inquiry into paediatrician 'unjust'

fields.headline: NHS inquiry into paediatrician 'unjust'
fields.standfirst: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: An NHS inquiry which severely criticised the controversial consultant paediatrician David Southall three months ago has done him and his team a grave injustice, according to senior doctors reviewing the evidence. They attack the Griffiths report as ill-informed, misguided and factually wrong.
fields.body:
An NHS inquiry which severely criticised the controversial consultant paediatrician David Southall three months ago has done him and his team a grave injustice, according to senior doctors reviewing the evidence. They attack the Griffiths report as ill-informed, misguided and factually wrong.

Sir Iain Chalmers, director of the clinical trials database at the Cochrane centre in Oxford, and paediatrician Edmund Hey mount an attack of unprecedented ferocity on the Griffiths inquiry, which was set up to investigate allegations of research misconduct against Prof Southall.

"We have concluded that the scandal is what the Griffiths report has done to the nurses and doctors in Stoke, not what was done by these professionals nearly a decade ago," they write in this week's British Medical Journal.

"This review was not conducted to the standard to be expected of any reputable inquiry into allegations of research misconduct."

Their indictment raises questions about the adequacy and usefulness of such inquiries.

Richard Smith, editor of the BMJ, calls in a separate piece for a rethink on what inquiries are for and how they should be run. "Otherwise the politicians' need to be doing something when a crisis occurs may aggravate rather than alleviate problems and may squander resources."

The Griffiths inquiry was set up by government in response to some of the many allegations that have been levelled against Prof Southall in recent years. The paediatrician has been the target of a vitriolic campaign triggered by his work on child abuse. Prof Southall pioneered covert video surveillance of parents suspected of trying to damage their children as a means of seeking attention.

But the accusations that the West Midlands NHS regional director of public health, Rod Griffiths, and his team were initially asked to look into by the then health minister, Lady Hayman, concerned the ethical conduct of research projectsat the North Staffordshire hospital. Central to the review was Prof Southall's study of the CNEP (continuous negative extrathoracic pressure) machine to help newborn babies with breathing difficulties. Following publicity about Prof Southall over covert video surveillance, some parents complained that they had not known their babies were in an experiment with the machine and had never signed a consent form.

The Griffiths report upheld this complaint and others. There were serious inadequacies in the way the trial was designed, it said, and the way consent was obtained from parents. It made recommendations for a new blueprint for clinical research.

Sir Iain and Dr Hey claim that the trial was not inadequate but "ahead of its time". "We believe that almost every statement made about the design, conduct and reporting of the neonatal CNEP study in the Griffiths report was ill-in formed, misguided or factually wrong," they say.

Parents were informed about the study before and after treatment, they say, and there was no evidence that babies suffered and died unnecessarily as a result of the study.

Sir Iain and Dr Hey were asked to review the Griffiths report by the Medical Defence Union, which is supporting Prof Southall, who is still suspended while the North Staffordshire NHS Trust investigates other allegations. They were not paid. Sir Iain said he thought the Griffiths report was badly flawed "probably because they did not observe fairly fundamental elements of due process. If people make allegations orally, one looks for documentary evidence that either confirms allegations are correct or calls them into question."

webTitle: Unlucky lottery

fields.headline: Unlucky lottery
fields.standfirst:
Good causes but bad procedures<BR
Special report: The National Lottery
fields.trailText: After the dome, the national lottery itself has become tainted. What irony that this source of pleasure, gain and - yes, still - good should have become so compromised. Yesterday a court ruled that the way Camelot plc was turned down in favour of the Branson consortium was so unfair that it approached an abuse of power. The judgment damns the National Lottery Commission. Unless it can show it was woefully misled by legal advisers (in which case barristers' heads should roll) someone should carry the can and resign. Dame Helena Shovelton, its chair, and fellow quangocrats must now consider their positions.
fields.body:
After the dome, the national lottery itself has become tainted. What irony that this source of pleasure, gain and - yes, still - good should have become so compromised. Yesterday a court ruled that the way Camelot plc was turned down in favour of the Branson consortium was so unfair that it approached an abuse of power. The judgment damns the National Lottery Commission. Unless it can show it was woefully misled by legal advisers (in which case barristers' heads should roll) someone should carry the can and resign. Dame Helena Shovelton, its chair, and fellow quangocrats must now consider their positions.

This saga could get worse, from the point of view of a battered government. The start of the next contract period is only 11 months hence. If, fair procedures being observed, the Branson consortium were to win, it would have insufficient time to get up and running and a breakdown occurs. That is not an argument for sticking with Camelot; it does however say the lottery commission needs to proceed with haste as well as care.

That Sir Richard Branson has lately become a hate figure for the right does not turn him into a saint. But his consortium remains, in our reckoning, the better of the two candidates to run the national lottery. Ultimately, the issue is not the thickness of the flow of funds into good causes (and let's fervently hope they are going in future to be a lot better). It is not even the fact that the Branson bid is within a not-for-profit framework. The clincher is that the move in recent years to provide public services on contract only works if contractors are kept on their toes. The threat to lose a golden franchise works wonders. If Branson wins he will know he is permanently on trial and that should provide the necessary discipline. That is a judgment the lottery quango is fully entitled to make. But it can only do so if it has treated bidders fair and square in informing them about timetables and provisos.

webTitle: Seed trial by jury

fields.headline: Seed trial by jury
fields.standfirst:
GM verdict raises a crop of new questions

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Lord Melchett's surprise victory in Norfolk crown court has run a coach and horses through Michael Meacher's patiently crafted solution for dealing with the British public's virulent opposition to genetically modified crops. Contrary to expectation, the jury cleared Lord Melchett and 27 other Greenpeace campaigners of criminal damage on Tuesday despite their own admission that they had destroyed a GM maize crop. What now lies in ruins is the government's approach of allowing farm-scale crop trials, but banning commercial growing of GM crops until the trials are complete. The verdict is a green light to protesters and signals to farmers that such is the public distrust of GM, their fields have little or no legal protection.
fields.body:
Lord Melchett's surprise victory in Norfolk crown court has run a coach and horses through Michael Meacher's patiently crafted solution for dealing with the British public's virulent opposition to genetically modified crops. Contrary to expectation, the jury cleared Lord Melchett and 27 other Greenpeace campaigners of criminal damage on Tuesday despite their own admission that they had destroyed a GM maize crop. What now lies in ruins is the government's approach of allowing farm-scale crop trials, but banning commercial growing of GM crops until the trials are complete. The verdict is a green light to protesters and signals to farmers that such is the public distrust of GM, their fields have little or no legal protection.

What will be worrying Mr Meacher is that the ban was effectively a voluntary agreement by the seed companies. Given that the GM seeds had already got EU approval, they have every right to sell them in this country and they would have the backing of European law to do so. They sensibly know such a route would be a public relations fiasco. For the politicians, it would be a disaster, a dangerous conflation of two of the British public's pet hates: GM and Brussels. The task ahead for Mr Meacher is how to keep the seed companies on board.

The bigger political challenge - which looks near impossible - is how to convince the British public that, at the very least, it should allow scientists the opportunity to find out what impact GM crops have on the environment. Norfolk crown court's jury showed how profound the public's unease is. There is little point arguing that this depth of feeling obviously owes much to the catastrophe of BSE, or that other agricultural innovations in the past 50 years - such as the use of pesticides - have caused far worse environmental damage. The opposition is stubborn and incidents such as the GM rape crops inadvertently planted earlier this year and then destroyed only reinforce the belief that this technology is impossible to control.

Once again, sharply on the heels of the fuel crisis, the limits of government power have been starkly exposed by a small, committed group who can call on unexpected reserves of support among the general public. In a final irony, it was the very group that last week defied the law outside oil refinery gates, the farmers, who this week are busy asserting the rule of law.

webTitle: Leader; For Milosevic, poll defeat is not an option

fields.headline: A perilous moment
fields.standfirst:
For Milosevic, poll defeat is not an option

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: It is almost inconceivable that Slobodan Milosevic will voluntarily relinquish his grip on power in Yugoslavia even if his leading rival, Vojislav Kostunica, scores an incontrovertible victory in this Sunday's presidential election. Out of office, Mr Milosevic would be prey to his many enemies and some of his current friends. A spate of assassinations earlier this year of prominent, pro-regime figures, some of them like the warlord Arkan close erstwhile Milosevic associates, showed how vulnerable are those in Serbia who lose the power to protect themselves.
fields.body:
It is almost inconceivable that Slobodan Milosevic will voluntarily relinquish his grip on power in Yugoslavia even if his leading rival, Vojislav Kostunica, scores an incontrovertible victory in this Sunday's presidential election. Out of office, Mr Milosevic would be prey to his many enemies and some of his current friends. A spate of assassinations earlier this year of prominent, pro-regime figures, some of them like the warlord Arkan close erstwhile Milosevic associates, showed how vulnerable are those in Serbia who lose the power to protect themselves.

It is equally unlikely that a new presidential and parliamentary federal leadership in Belgrade, even one still dominated by nationalists, would not, sooner or later, bow to domestic pressure to call Mr Milosevic to account for his innumerable misdeeds. Then again, Mr Milosevic is an indicted international war criminal urgently sought by the UN's Hague tribunal. An ex-president Milosevic might ultimately have little alternative but to flee to a foreign sanctuary. But where? Russia, for all its fraternal sentiments, would find him a diplomatically insupportable embarrassment. China, which maintains ties with Belgrade? Even Beijing might not be so brassy as to defy world opinion in such a case. There is always the Milosevic-friendly, Karen-killing Burmese military junta. Perhaps he could act as their Rangoon consultant on ethnic minority issues. No, it will not wash. The fact of the matter is that there is no hiding place for a dispossessed Mr Milosevic - and he knows it. He has nowhere to run. So instead he runs for the presidency.

It would be wonderful to be proved wrong, of course - to find that an unmonitored, unverifiable election already pronounced unfree and unfair by the US, Britain, the EU and Serbia's opposition somehow produced a peaceful, democratic transfer of power. What a joy it would be to discover that Mr Milosevic was not, after all, preparing to engineer a massive fraud or to manipulate and intimidate his way to a second round victory on October 8; was not fully ready to annul Sunday's results, if unfavourable, on some trumped-up pretext and to use the military to suppress any subsequent street protests; and was not planning to provoke, if expedient, a post-election crisis in Montenegro and further destabilisation in Kosovo. How heartening it would be to learn that Mr Milosevic will not exploit the constitutional loophole that allows him, legally albeit dishonourably, to remain if office until next July even if Mr Kostunica wins by an unstoppable landslide. But plainly, the appalling, shameless Slobo is only too ready to do some or all of this in his personal life-or-death struggle to hang on.

Much, much less clear is what the west will or can do in response. As so often in the past, this ultimately (and depressingly) depends on Mr Milosevic. If he manages to steal the election without provoking excessive violence, he is unlikely to suffer more than a tightening of sanctions and a lot of verbal abuse. But if an infuriated, thwarted opposition finally digs in its heels and pushes Serbia towards civil war, or if he pretends to have unmasked a western conspiracy, declares an emergency, and moves, say, against Montenegro's leaders, pressure will quickly grow for some kind of renewed military intervention. Limited "surgical" air strikes on Yugoslav army units in Montenegro, for example, might just appeal to Al Gore and Tony Blair at this particular juncture in their political lives. They must resist the temptation if it arises. Deep though the dilemma runs, bombing alone will not make it better.

webTitle: Nursing unions seek big pay rise

fields.headline: Nursing unions seek big pay rise
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Nursing unions yesterday lodged a claim for "substantial" pay increases to avert a growing shortage of hospital staff that threatens the government's plans for expanding the NHS.
fields.body:
Nursing unions yesterday lodged a claim for "substantial" pay increases to avert a growing shortage of hospital staff that threatens the government's plans for expanding the NHS.

Their annual joint submission to the pay review body said there were 20,000 vacancies for nurses in UK hospitals, compared with 17,000 a year ago.

The government's NHS plan promised to increase nursing posts by a further 20,000 by 2005, but it would be hard to achieve this without extra pay to attract recruits and reward the increasing responsibilities of senior nursing staff, the five unions said.

The starting salary for qualified staff nurses is £14,890, 15.1% below the starting pay for a police constable. Top salaries for senior nurses are well below the average for medical staff, the unions say.

But the NHS Confederation, representing employers, said a large proportion of the extra funding in the NHS plan should be reserved for modernisation and increasing staff numbers.

 A third of Britain's physiotherapists are recruited from abroad, mainly from Australia, South Africa and New Zealand, the Chartered Society of Physiotherapy reported yesterday.

webTitle: Good for the poor, bad for the polls

fields.headline: Good for the poor, bad for the polls
fields.standfirst:
The pensions dilemma
Special report: welfare reform
fields.trailText: Sometimes, ministers find, a policy can be intellectually all right, but the politics is all horribly wrong.
fields.body:
Sometimes, ministers find, a policy can be intellectually all right, but the politics is all horribly wrong.

This may be the case with Labour and pensions, the issue threatening once again to overshadow the party's coming conference. Some leftwingers claim it will be a lightning conductor for concern about the collapse in the party's poll ratings.

Many ministers and Labour MPs are strongly sympathetic to the strategy of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, especially his efforts to target help on 2m of the poorest pensioners through his minimium income guarantee, currently £78.45 a week. This guarantee is due to rise in line with earnings rather than prices.

They also recognise the help he has given to pensioners through the non means-tested winter fuel allowance, worth £150. In addition, from November pensioners aged over 75 will receive the equivalent of an extra £106 through the free TV licence.

Yet Mr Brown is facing a nasty backlash not just from pensioners, but from union leaders and constituency parties. The problem is that his intentions may be good, and indeed socialist, but they are little understood on the doorstep.

With both other main parties offering big and simple increases in the basic state pension, Mr Brown is finding himself on the back foot. All that many pensioners seem to remember, and resent, is the 75p a week increase in the basic pension this year to £67.50 a week.

The Department of Social Security and the Treasury are finding this extremely frustrating. Overall, through this parliament, the government is spending £2bn more on pensioners than if ministers had merely linked the basic state pension to earnings, the policy advocated by the redoubtable Barbara Castle and the National Pensioners Convention.

Mr Brown's argument has been that with many pensioners enjoying good occupational pensions, the priority is to reduce the growing inequality in pensioners' incomes. On average pensioner incomes have risen more quickly than earnings. But the figures show the ratio between the incomes of the poorest fifth of pensioners and the richest fifth is 3.5 to one when in 1979 it was 2.5 to one.

The chancellor's aim has been to help the fifth of pensioners on the bottom of the pile. So the minimum income guarantee is aimed at anyone with income and savings below a certain level.

However, many pensioners either do not understand the MIG or resent needing to make a claim when they feel they have contributed to the basic pension all their life through their national insurance payments.

Government research shows that as many as 500,000 pensioners entitled to MIG fail to apply. As a result the government has written to 2m potentially entitled pensioners and has run a £15m television campaign. The Department of Social Security claims that more than 400,000 pensioners have subsequently inquired about their entitlement.

Yet the pensions minister, Jeff Rooker, admitted to the social security committee this year that he could not live on the MIG. He told the committee: "I do not think £78.45 is enough. The government has to do more for the poorest pensioners. It is the bottom."

He went on to hint that £90 might be a better figure for a safety net. But he then admitted there were constraints to other solutions. Any increase in the basic pension would simply be clawed back through the benefits system. Equally, restoring the link between pensions and earnings would be costly: £1bn in the first year, but £7.5bn by 2010.

The solution, he insisted, was to help the poorest pensioners by increasing MIG and then help the next poorest tranche through a pensioners' credit. "What we have to do for today's pensioners has to be done in a way that does not wreck long term policies for tomorrow. We have to do it in a way that we do not say to people, 'It does not pay to save'."

Details of the pensioner credit will be produced in the coming months. It will abolish the capital rules which discourage saving by denying extra help for those pensioners who have a little put aside.

But as John Prescott told BBC TV's On The Record after the poor local election results, a policy's worth does not arise just from its technical skill or intellectual purity: "Governments are elected by people, not by a scoreboard as to whether [the policy] is right".

Leader's speech: Other parties urged to 'tell it like it is' on tax, Europe and fuel as case is made for more honesty in politics

Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
Special report: Charles Kennedy
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Edited extracts from Charles Kennedy's speech in Bournemouth yesterday:
fields.body:
Edited extracts from Charles Kennedy's speech in Bournemouth yesterday:

Potentially, politics is at a crossroads. We saw that last week. The opinion polls have recorded that this week. That's been the backdrop for this, I think, one of our most successful conferences ever. Politics is about leading. But politics is also about listening. The events of the past 10 days, have demonstrated, graphically, that the current government, neither leads nor listens enough.

People want a better level of political dialogue. Just look at the crime debate. Ann Widdecombe and Jack Straw. They're competing in a dismal Dutch auction. Going for lowest common denominator politics. Over-claim. Over-blame. Over-reach. Undermine the entire point of the political process along the way.

Let me be quite clear. I'm not one of those who believe that all Britain's problems began on the first of May 1997. But Labour's poverty of ambition is quite remarkable. With a parliamentary majority - of 179, they behave like John Major did - with a majority of three.

Ethical

It's all about what will play well in the opinion polls. Britain was promised an ethical foreign policy. Britain demands legislation on the arms trade. But instead we get arms sales to Indonesia.

And all too often, they seem scared of their own shadows. Remember that leaked prime ministerial memo? What was it he said? "A sense that the government ... are somehow out of touch with gut British instincts".

So I ask you, Labour voter last time, maybe for the first time was it? Did you believe, that things could only get better? And have they? Millions of people believed it. Millions of people are disappointed.

The Conservatives won't improve these things for you. But the Liberal Democrats can. We can improve a lot on Labour. They are continually terrified to be called the party of boom and bust. That old Labour habit of splashing out in their first years in power, and then having to cut back at the end. Gordon Brown certainly hasn't done that. He's cut back and now he's splashing out. Bust followed by pre-election boom. We said that wasn't good enough. I'd like to think he saw the light. But the truth is, he felt the heat.

Now what of the Conservative party? Today, I want to address the millions of previous Conservative voters, who feel that William Hague's party offers them - nothing. I share many of the values, the beliefs, the concerns, of the people who used to be called One Nation Conservatives. Tolerance, decency, fair play.

If you believe in those things, and you look at your party. And it's not got room any more, at the top table, for the likes of Ken Clarke, Michael Heseltine, Chris Patten. Then your party's got no room for you.

To you, I say this. You have friends in the Liberal Democrats. Come and talk to us. You will be very, very welcome. What's gone wrong with the Conservative party - oh, so wrong - is not even so much the individuals, it's the issues and the instincts which today guide William Hague's Conservative party.

William jumps in with both feet, in the wrong place, at the wrong time, and for the wrong reasons. Desperate for a headline, desperate for a quote. Desperate to get attention. He's the world's first unpopular populist.

So how come the Tories have come up in the polls? I know the answer. It's not William's popularity. It's the people round about him that the country's warming to. It must be John Redwood, Michael Portillo and Ann Widdecombe the country loves.

Just look at what William's been up to this year. January -patient's guarantee. Ditched. February - tax guarantee. Ditched. March - the moral case for low taxation. Ditched with the tax guarantee. April - bogus asylum seekers. May - Romsey. June. He was quiet in June. Perhaps he had a 14-pint hangover. Or perhaps it was that Romsey hangover.

Record

Remember their record? Recessions. Crime doubled. Larger class sizes. Fewer nurses. Pensions slashed. Interest rates - through the roof. Arms to Iraq. BSE. Cash for questions. Sleaze. It must never, ever, be allowed to happen again.

William Hague is not the serious leader of a serious political party. That's the serious point. We are serious. Our pur pose is here in this document. It's the F word. Freedom. That's why we're in politics. We want politicians to promote freedom for all. So people can make the most of their lives. I am determined we will get our message across.

But as part of that, it is vital, absolutely vital, that we persuade people, that for every area where government can do more, there's an area where government should be doing less, or doing different.

We would scrap a range of regulations, that burden small businesses. We will cut bureaucracy in schools.

Tax and spend? Every party taxes and spends. But our priorities, are the people's priorities. That's what freedom means. It's not left of Labour. It's not right of Labour. It's ahead of Labour.

It's also honest. Where there is a cost, we say how we will pay for it. Saying that if necessary, we will pay for better schools, by asking everybody to pay just 1p more on the basic rate of income tax. And to fund decent pensions, we will ask those fortunate enough to earn over £100,000 per year, to pay a little more.

On health: Nurses and doctors - more of them. Prescription charges - abolish them. Eye and dental check-ups - free once again. Schools and colleges, cut class sizes for all 5 to 11 year olds. Abolish tuition fees for higher education.

And what about the pensioners? Forgotten and insulted by Gordon Brown. So we will give pensioners more, above inflation. £5 extra every week for every pensioner, If you're over 75, it's going to be £10 extra. If you're over 80, it's going to be £15 extra. Now that will make a real difference.

We say that a clean environ ment relates to health. To poverty. To transport. To education. To civil liberties. We understand that, instinctively so. And again, we're honest. We're clear, fuel taxes should be used, to improve the environment. In the months and years to come, we have got to get that message across. Positive gain, not pain.

Single currency

And let me say something about the single currency. As pro-Europeans we are not in favour, of rushing into the euro head first.

We don't believe Europe is perfect. And we will work to see that reform takes place. But we do believe that Britain can and must lead in Europe. Lead reform in Europe.

That's why, earlier this year, I asked a panel of experts, to report on what the government should be doing. And if the government chooses to ignore the experts, British businesses will lose, British workers will lose, British consumers will lose. So those of us in favour of the euro, must go out there and argue the case. We cannot sit on our hands.

This has been an outstanding year for the Liberal Democrats. The local elections - our biggest ever share of the national vote. Sandra's triumph in Romsey. At the next election, I believe we will win more votes, and more seats. 1997 was a staging post. It wasn't a high water mark.

So we must go into the next election, and tell people about our message of freedom. The difference between the Liberal Democrats and the disaster of William Hague's Party. The difference between the Liberal Democrats and the disappointment that Labour has become. Go out there and tell it to people as it is. What you see is what you get. This is what we will deliver. A truly modern, truly free, 21st century Britain. A Liberal Democrat Britain.

webTitle: Serbian elections 2000

fields.headline: Tyrant at the ballot box
fields.standfirst:
Sunday sees Serbia go to the polls to elect a president. But although Slobodan Milosevic's main rival, Vojislav Kostunica, is expected to get the most votes, he would do well to remember one thing - in Serbia nobody wins elections except Milosevic. Maggie O'Kane reports from Belgrade

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Sunday sees Serbia go to the polls to elect a president. But although Slobodan Milosevic's main rival, Vojislav Kostunica, is expected to get the most votes, he would do well to remember one thing - in Serbia nobody wins elections except Milosevic.  Maggie O'Kane  reports from Belgrade
fields.body:
The night in Belgrade belongs to the dogs - 60,000 of them now run wild because people can no longer afford to feed them. The city authorities are so broke that they frequently run out of drugs to put them down. So the dogs are clubbed to death instead. In the early morning the smell of freshly rotting rubbish hangs in the streets.

Yugoslavia's presidential elections take place on Sunday and the polls predict that Vojislav Kostunica, a previously unknown lawyer, will beat Slobodan Milosevic - despite the election rigging that Milosevic is famous for, and despite the fact that in Serbia nobody ever wins elections except Milosevic. But if Kostunica wins, it's likely that Milosevic will simply use the media he controls to declare victory anyway. He could do that as early as 10 o'clock on Sunday night, just two hours after the polls close and even before the polling boxes make it to the central sorting office. Welcome to Serbia 2000, where Serbs again will be left with no option but to go out on the streets. But the question is how many still have the energy left to go out and protest again.

In the winter of 1996, 50,000 people came out to protest against the rigged local elections, and the police special forces crushed them. They were crushed again in March this year when they came out against him on the anniversary of the war in Kosovo. And on Sunday, Milosevic fights not just for his political future, but to avoid spending the rest of his life in the Dutch seaside prison where the international court in the Hague sends its guilty men. "If we win, it will be great," said one of his long-time party workers. "If we lose, they will lynch us."

There are 120,000 police at Milosevic's disposal, and all holiday leave has been cancelled. They will do the job they have done in previous protests.

On Planet Serbia, closed off from the world, hundreds of thousands of people have turned the frustration and anger of Milosevic's last 12 years of rule into hatred for both him and his wife. He has been the force behind the three bloody wars - in Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo - as he tried to use nationalism to secure his own political future. Milosevic, the puppetmaster of the Balkans, has led his people into the wilderness, turning Serbs into international outcasts. A million of them were driven from their homes in those wars, and before their eyes, Yugoslavia, once the wealthiest, healthiest and most beautiful country in eastern Europe, has shrunk from 250,000 square kilometres of sea and mountains to a violent ghetto a quarter that size.

Milosevic will be 60 next birthday. His only vices - apart from an obsession with remaining in power - are whisky and Cuban cigars. Both he and his wife have tragic personal histories. His father, a teacher, shot himself when Milosevic was 21. His mother, also a teacher, killed herself 10 years later. But a former Yugoslav ambassador once said that "in his presence you can feel his strength of personality. You just feel yourself shrinking down in the armchair when he begins to talk. He is a powerful man". Richard Holbrooke, who chaired the Dayton peace talks in 1995, said he had a great sense of humour; even the waitresses in the Dayton airbase canteen were charmed by him.

He met his wife, Mira Markovic, at school in Pozarevac. Her mother was tortured and executed by the Gestapo in 1944 as one of Tito's partisans. They have two children: Marija, a 34-year-old former journalist; and Marko, a 26-year-old former racing driver who runs his own Milosevic mafia in their home town.

In the foyer of a Belgrade police station a nurse is trying to sort out her papers and wants to know if there are any jobs in England so she can get out of "this madhouse" before the elections. Behind the desk a fat, almost friendly policeman is frowning into his big yellowing ledger. He sits behind chocolate-coloured tinted glass; a full ashtray and grubby overflowing trays of carbon-copied identity papers. It's like being in eastern Europe in 1989.

Kostunica, who presents the first real political challenge to Milosevic, is a former communist but a man with clean hands and no past. The only dirt the regime has managed to get on him is to accuse him of keeping 17 cats - which, according to an editorial in Milosevic's paper Politika, shows that, like the average cat, he is untrustworthy and selfish. The editorial also said that he is supported by "Gays, lesbians and feminists".

On each of the 10 floors of my apartment block "Gotov Je" - he's finished - is plastered above the door of the lift. The opposition movement now claims to have 100,000 activists campaigning against Milosevic, but he is far from finished. Until election day he is fighting for his political life, primarily through the TV station he took over 13 years ago when he first came to power.

We are watching the news in a top-floor flat. Outside, across the city's skyline, most of the damage done in Nato's 74 days of bombing has disappeared. The news begins with an eight-minute item about the reopening of the chemical plant outside Belgrade. We see a crowd of slightly distracted looking workers shouting "Slobo, Slobo". The next 12 minutes are election speeches from around the country with "Slobo, Slobo" being chanted constantly in the background. The captain of the national volleyball team calls on people to vote for Milosevic. One hour into the news and they move on to the 100,000 houses that Milosevic will build in the next 10 years.

Sylvia, the mother of the house, stands up. "I can't watch it. I hate him. I could kill him with my bare hands." She is 40 years old and has a masters degree in engineering. "He stole the best years of my life. We have no money, my car is 13 years old. I survive by smuggling sanitary towels and chocolate from Romania. If he wins again there is no future for us."

Sylvia escapes to the kitchen. The news goes on about another new electricity plant being opened; then finally there's a mention of the opposition. They are all "fifth columnists" and "traitors". The hour and 48 minutes of Milosevic propaganda mentions his name more than 40 times and ends with the news that he is leading the "global battle against the agents of fascism".

Milosevic controls all the media, allowing only a few independents to preach to the converted in Belgrade. The rest of the country receive only his message, and it has worked. The latest polls say that Milosevic could legitimately poll more than 1.5m votes and Kostunica is expected to win by as few as 700,000. But Milosevic is free to fix the ballot in Serb regions of Kosovo and the sister state of Montenegro.

His biggest supporters are among the old former communists who hark back to Tito, like 64-year-old Dorde Erdeljan and his 61-year-old wife Stava. They say they watch the news every night - never miss it. "If it wasn't for Milosevic being so strong we would have had Nato troops on the streets of Belgrade," says Dorde. "Kostunica's coalition are traitors who would betray our country." Instead of blaming Milosevic for the hardships of the past 10 years, they point to sanctions and a western conspiracy. "Look at what happened in Britain over the petrol prices - your country would have collapsed in six months if you had to put up with what Serbia has been forced to suffer."

The only dissenter on the street is Dobrivoic Radanovic, a 50-year-old former boxer and mechanic. "Of course I'm voting for the opposition. The only people who won't are the old, the army and police."

"What will happen then?"

"Nothing. People will protest and that will be it. The police will crush them and that will be it. We are a special people, the Serbs. The Turks ruled us and we got used to being oppressed."

Jovan Dulovic works for the small independent magazine Vreme. He specialises in police affairs. "The special intervention force can be in Belgrade in a few hours. They are the cream of the force, usually athletes and young guys who do weights. In any normal country of our size the police force should be about 30,000; here we've got 120,000. If the people keep going on the streets, the police will beat them. I don't expect them to do anything immediately - he will wait to see how the protests go. Then if they continue it will be very brutal."

Milosevic is on the campaign trail, appearing at organised mass rallies. On Monday night, the TV broadcasts a ceremony showing 10,089 people gathering to join his party. Each was presented with a red rose and given 100 German marks for turning up. "We are living through some sort of tragic comic opera which might look funny but it is very, very dangerous," says Lubodrag Stojadivovic, a former spokesman for the Yugoslav army who was sacked for writing an open letter protesting about political interference, especially by Milosevic's wife in the army.

I think it is possible that the police will be used in a massive and brutal way. If that doesn't work his last card will be the army, but that is a very dangerous card to play - no matter what the generals say, the soldiers will not go against the people."

The town where Milosevic and his wife began their lives looks like a pleasant place in the early autumn. All along the main street there are white banners in red letters that read "Choose people not Nato" and "For Yugoslavia". There's not a single poster or banner for the opposition in sight. The chestnut trees in the square were turning red when Markovic went there last week to address a public rally calling on her town and her nation to support her husband.

"Only about 2,000 people turned up," says Mile Yeljkovic, a journalist with Beta, the independent newsagency. "Even those people were bused in. I heard afterwards that she was in tears, she couldn't believe there were so few people."

On Sunday, and in the days that follow, Serbia will find out what they already know - that Milosevic will play God to the end. He has no choice. Perhaps that's why this city of Belgrade on this warm September day is full mostly of exhaustion and despair. "Pandora's box has been opened and the only thing left inside for us now is hope," said a beautiful student, plastering opposition posters on a baker's wall. She is 19, and not so tired.

Life and times of Milosevic

Born:
August 29 1941, in Pozarevac, Serbia. Following the suicide of his father in 1962, Milosevic was raised by his mother, who also killed herself in 1973.

Early years:
Graduated in law from Belgrade University in 1964 and pursued a business career. He was chief of the state-owned gas company Technogas 1968-78, and member of the board of directors of Beobank (United Bank of Belgrade) 1978-82.

Political career:
Joined the communist party of Yugoslavia when he was 18. Entered politics in 1984. In 1987 he became leader of the Serbian communists. Elected president of the Serbian Republic in 1989. The following year he turned the League of Communists of Serbia into the Socialist party of Serbia and was returned to power in the election of December 1990.

Croatia:
Serb forces bombard cities including Dubrovnik and Vukovar as the conflict escalates in 1991. Croatian independence recognised by the EC the following year.

Bosnia-Herzegovina:
International recognition of the area as an independent state in April 1992 leads to civil war. Thousands of Muslims massacred by Serbs at Srebrenica in the summer of 1995. Milosevic agrees to peace in the Dayton accord in November of that year.

Kosovo:
The 1998 offensive by Serb forces against the Kosovo Liberation Army leads to the 78-day bombing of Serbia by Nato forces, March to June 1999, which ends when Milosevic agrees to withdraw his troops.

Milosevic controls all the media, allowing only a few independents to preach to the converted in Belgrade. The rest of the country receive only his message, and it has worked. The latest polls say that Milosevic could legitimately poll more than 1.5m votes and Kostunica is expected to win by as few as 700,000. But Milosevic is free to fix the ballot in Serb regions of Kosovo and the sister state of Montenegro. His biggest supporters are among the old former communists who hark back to Tito, like 64-year-old Dorde Erdeljan and his 61-year-old wife Stava. They say they watch the news every night - never miss it. "If it wasn't for Milosevic being so strong we would have had Nato troops on the streets of Belgrade," says Dorde. "Kostunica's coalition are traitors who would betray our country." Instead of blaming Milosevic for the hardships of the past 10 years, they point to sanctions and a western conspiracy. "Look at what happened in Britain over the petrol prices - your country would have collapsed in six months if you had to put up with what Serbia has been forced to suffer." The only dissenter on the street is Dobrivoic Radanovic, a 50-year-old former boxer and mechanic. "Of course I'm voting for the opposition. The only people who won't are the old, the army and police." "What will happen then?" "Nothing. People will protest and that will be it. The police will crush them and that will be it. We are a special people, the Serbs. The Turks ruled us and we got used to being oppressed." Jovan Dulovic works for the small independent magazine Vreme. He specialises in police affairs. "The special intervention force can be in Belgrade in a few hours. They are the cream of the force, usually athletes and young guys who do weights. In any normal country of our size the police force should be about 30,000; here we've got 120,000. If the people keep going on the streets, the police will beat them. I don't expect them to do anything immediately - he will wait to see how the protests go. Then if they continue it will be very brutal." Milosevic is on the campaign trail, appearing at organised mass rallies. On Monday night, the TV broadcasts a ceremony showing 10,089 people gathering to join his party. Each was presented with a red rose and given 100 German marks for turning up. "We are living through some sort of tragic comic opera which might look funny but it is very, very dangerous," says Lubodrag Stojadivovic, a former spokesman for the Yugoslav army who was sacked for writing an open letter protesting about political interference, especially by Milosevic's wife in the army. I think it is possible that the police will be used in a massive and brutal way. If that doesn't work his last card will be the army, but that is a very dangerous card to play - no matter what the generals say, the soldiers will not go against the people." The town where Milosevic and his wife began their lives looks like a pleasant place in the early autumn. All along the main street there are white banners in red letters that read "Choose people not Nato" and "For Yugoslavia". There's not a single poster or banner for the opposition in sight. The chestnut trees in the square were turning red when Markovic went there last week to address a public rally calling on her town and her nation to support her husband. "Only about 2,000 people turned up," says Mile Yeljkovic, a journalist with Beta, the independent newsagency. "Even those people were bused in. I heard afterwards that she was in tears, she couldn't believe there were so few people." On Sunday, and in the days that follow, Serbia will find out what they already know - that Milosevic will play God to the end. He has no choice. Perhaps that's why this city of Belgrade on this warm September day is full mostly of exhaustion and despair. "Pandora's box has been opened and the only thing left inside for us now is hope," said a beautiful student, plastering opposition posters on a baker's wall. She is 19, and not so tired. Life and times of Milosevic Born: August 29 1941, in Pozarevac, Serbia. Following the suicide of his father in 1962, Milosevic was raised by his mother, who also killed herself in 1973. Early years: Graduated in law from Belgrade University in 1964 and pursued a business career. He was chief of the state-owned gas company Technogas 1968-78, and member of the board of directors of Beobank (United Bank of Belgrade) 1978-82. Political career: Joined the communist party of Yugoslavia when he was 18. Entered politics in 1984. In 1987 he became leader of the Serbian communists. Elected president of the Serbian Republic in 1989. The following year he turned the League of Communists of Serbia into the Socialist party of Serbia and was returned to power in the election of December 1990. Croatia: Serb forces bombard cities including Dubrovnik and Vukovar as the conflict escalates in 1991. Croatian independence recognised by the EC the following year. Bosnia-Herzegovina: International recognition of the area as an independent state in April 1992 leads to civil war. Thousands of Muslims massacred by Serbs at Srebrenica in the summer of 1995. Milosevic agrees to peace in the Dayton accord in November of that year. Kosovo: The 1998 offensive by Serb forces against the Kosovo Liberation Army leads to the 78-day bombing of Serbia by Nato forces, March to June 1999, which ends when Milosevic agrees to withdraw his troops.

webTitle: Park and ride

fields.headline: Park and ride
fields.standfirst:
It is ironic, given the state of our transport system, that today is the first European car-free day. But the United Kingdom is not involved

Special report: Transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Given the state of road transport across Europe, it is a delicious irony that today is the first continent-wide "car-free day", when we are encouraged to leave vehicles at home. Thirteen of the European Union's 15 members signed up and a 14th, the Netherlands, is holding its own car-free day on Sunday. The odd man out is - no surprises - the United Kingdom.
fields.body:
Given the state of road transport across Europe, it is a delicious irony that today is the first continent-wide "car-free day", when we are encouraged to leave vehicles at home. Thirteen of the European Union's 15 members signed up and a 14th, the Netherlands, is holding its own car-free day on Sunday. The odd man out is - no surprises - the United Kingdom.

After recent events, the government may think abstention wise, though local authorities are taking part. But its curmudgeonly approach to the politics of the environment has not helped build support for fuel duties as part of any wider transport strategy. When the dust settles, transport in the UK will still be on an unsustainable course.

Even with July's £180bn plan for transport in place, road traffic is to grow 17% over the next decade. Transport is the fastest-growing source of carbon dioxide emissions, a principal cause of global warming. Inner cities will not meet national air quality standards by the target date of 2005, even if the spending plan is implemented.

The UK also lags in terms of car use, in spite of a relatively low level of car ownership. As the table shows, all EU countries depend on cars. But the UK has the highest level of car use (88%) and the lowest level of public transport use (12%), expressed as a share of motorised passenger transport (ie excluding cycling and walking). Italy by contrast has the highest per capita car ownership but the lowest car use (76%).

Gordon Brown will have to offer a palliative to motorists. Cutting vehicle excise duty for the smallest, most fuel-efficient cars would be more consistent with the environmental commitments and more socially progressive than cutting fuel duty.

Yet above-inflation increases in fuel duty between 1996 and 1999 did save the emissions of between 1m and 2.5m tonnes of carbon per year - a significant contribution to the UK's promise to cut greenhouse gas emissions overall by 12.5% and CO<->2 emissions by 20%. The royal commission on environmental pollution argues that greenhouse gas emissions will have to be cut by 60% by the middle of this century to avoid the worst effects of climate change.

As a lump sum annual payment unrelated to use, vehicle excise hits low-income rural motorists hardest. Although there is now a lower rate of duty for small-engine cars (and there will be four rates based on CO<->2 emissions for new cars from March next year), the current differential is too small to influence purchasing decisions and produce any significant carbon savings. The small-engine and most fuel-efficient cars could pay less than £100 - perhaps as little as a £10 administrative fee for vehicle registration - and gas-guzzlers could pay more than the current rate of £155.

For the longer term, our European neighbours have much to teach us, though all are struggling with traffic congestion and pollution. The commission for integrated transport, an advisory body established by the Blair government, has been asking how others manage to have a lower level of car dependence often with a higher level of car ownership.

In summary: they have given a higher priority to walking, cycling and public transport, including fare subsidies. They have also used their planning systems more effectively to reduce people's need to travel distances. The UK meanwhile has given way to urban sprawl and out-of-town developments, cut back on investment and subsidies for public transport, and neglected the needs of pedestrians and cyclists.

Praise, then, for the latest transport plan, which seeks to reverse the long-term under- investment in public transport, particularly rail. Even so, it falls short. Its proposals on buses are modest; bus market share will fall. Except in London, where there is a good combination of network planning and competitive tendering of bus services, local authorities will be hamstrung by their inability to plan services and subsidise fares. While local transport has otherwise done relatively well out of the plan, there is insufficient emphasis on walking and cycling, the most egalitarian and environmentally sustainable ways to travel. In Germany, which has higher per capita car ownership but lower car use than in the UK, 10% of journeys are made by bicycle compared to 2% in Britain.

Another area where other European countries are ahead is car clubs as an alternative to private car ownership. You join a club owning a range of vehicles that are parked in the neighbourhood and can be hired by the hour as and when needed. It removes the incentive to use the car because of the huge up-front investment in owning one.

Thousands of car club members in Switzerland and Germany have reduced their car use on average by about half and instead walk, cycle and use public transport more. The first commercial car clubs in the UK, in Edinburgh and Oxford, have yet to reach the critical mass of membership necessary to make them take off. A helping hand from the state could make the difference.

Above all, the government needs to build a popular agenda around environmentally sustainable and socially inclusive transport policies. In the past week it has paid the price of failure to do so. A small minority with an axe to grind has been able to hijack the agenda because of the passive support of the majority who one way or another do not think the government is doing enough.

Tony Grayling is a member of the Institute for Public Policy Research's sustainability team t.grayling@ippr.org.uk

webTitle: Offer for Allied Leisure

fields.headline: Offer for Allied Leisure
fields.trailText: The consolidation merry-go-round in the leisure industry continued yesterday with a tilt at bowling club owner Allied Leisure by entrepreneur Nicholas Oppenheim.
fields.body:
The consolidation merry-go-round in the leisure industry continued yesterday with a tilt at bowling club owner Allied Leisure by entrepreneur Nicholas Oppenheim.

Mr Oppenheim, the former chairman of Allied rival Northern Leisure, is making the bid through a specially formed firm, Georgica. He left Northern in May after a £360m buyout by Luminar.

Institutional investors holding around 40% of Allied - including Schroders Investment Management, Clerical Medical, Framlington and Henderson and UBS Asset Management - have backed the offer.

A one-for-one share offer has been made for the group at Wednesday's close of 92p. The offer values Allied at £50.3m but is conditional on Georgica obtaining an AIM listing.

A statement from Georgica said, "Georgica believes Allied has suffered from the changes that have taken place in relation to its strategic direction over the past five years". A spokesman said Mr Oppenheim did not want to change "any part of the group except the management team".

Allied chief Neil Goulden said: "We're naturally disappointed and surprised that a small number of Allied shareholders didn't wait until the publication of our results next week to see the significant progress we've made and our forward strategy, which we believed would have unlocked significant shareholder value."

He added that Allied's board would make a response after a board meeting today, and after seeing Mr Oppenheim; the shares went up 10.5p to 102p on the day.

webTitle: £1bn MoD ferry order to seal Birkenhead revival

fields.headline: £1bn MoD ferry order to seal Birkenhead revival
fields.trailText: Shipbuilding is to consolidate its return to Birkenhead after almost a decade as Cammell Laird is poised to win a multi-million contract to build six roll-on roll-off ferries for the armed forces.
fields.body:
Shipbuilding is to consolidate its return to Birkenhead after almost a decade as Cammell Laird is poised to win a multi-million contract to build six roll-on roll-off ferries for the armed forces.

The deal could throw a lifeline to Belfast's stricken Harland & Wolff.

Last night Harland confirmed that it will lay off 600 employees, half its core workforce, because of lack of work and cashflow problems caused by an outstanding £133m legal claim against a Texan oil company.

But the Belfast yard, a key Northern Ireland employer and the industrial icon that built the Titanic, could win work under the £1bn, 20-year Ministry of Defence contract for the ferries. The order, according to sources, will be awarded next month to a consortium of a Danish shipping group, Maersk, and Cammell.

The MoD and Ulrik Brandt, managing director of Maersk's UK business, said no decision had been made but several sources indicated that the order, under the private finance initiative, would be announced on October 25 in favour of Maersk-Cammell.

There has been ferocious lobbying by four consortiums and local politicians since the bidding process was reopened in June on speculation that the work would go to Germany.

Cammell, which was revitalised through ship repair work, recently expanded its Birkenhead yard which is now building two car ro-ros for a Norwegian group.

Mr Brandt said Cammell would build the six MoD ferries on the Mersey and in the North-east - most likely at its Tyneside yard at Hebburn.

Harland, which said it was linked to two of the four consortiums, could share some of the work if Maersk wins. It is completing work on two oil rigs but has no big orders to occupy the 1,200-plus workforce.

Last week an arbitration tribunal awarded Harland £21.8m in settlement of a dispute with Global Marine of Texas. The Belfast company is still claiming £133m for excess costs caused by alleged changes to specification.

The firm, which failed to win Cunard's contract for a new Queen Mary in March, said redundancies were necessary to meet financial problems which prevented it winning orders.

The news provoked union anger, with the GMB demanding government intervention to support British yards.

webTitle: Human rights court backs jailed director

fields.headline: Human rights court backs jailed director
fields.trailText: A businessman convicted of fraud has won £750 compensation and £8,000 costs in a human rights case because it took two years for his community service order to be increased to a jail term.
fields.body:
A businessman convicted of fraud has won £750 compensation and £8,000 costs in a human rights case because it took two years for his community service order to be increased to a jail term.

Jeremy Howarth, former deputy chairman of European Leisure, was found guilty in 1995, along with two fellow directors, of ramping the firm's shares to help its takeover of Midsummer Leisure. His 220-hour order and £151,000 fine were subsequently changed to a two-year sentence after an appeal by the attorney general.

Yesterday the European Court of Human Rights ruled the length of time between the sentences was unreasonable.

"The court finds that no convincing reasons have been given which could justify the period of two years it took to deal with the appeal," it ruled. "Apart from a refusal to reconsider the legal aid position, there was no judicial activity in the case from the grant of leave to appeal in December 1995 until the appeal was heard in March 1997."

Last night, Mr Howarth said: "I am obviously very pleased that at long last the judgment has been found in my favour. The period of delay between the original sentence and appeal was extraordinary. It had a very serious impact on me. I must be one of a few people who have served their sentence completely, only to then be given a second sentence."

His solicitor, Brian Spiro of Simons, Muirhead and Burton, said: "This is an important decision that makes it clear delay by the attorney general or the courts for no good reason will not be tolerated under the European convention."

webTitle: Saddam might spoil Opec's hand

fields.headline: Saddam might spoil Opec's hand
fields.standfirst: FTSE slips through oil crisis
fields.trailText: It is known, in market circles, as the "slow punch" - that is, a sharp fall in prices which happens over a number of days or even weeks rather than on one headline generating day. Market participants tend to find themselves taken unawares, suddenly panicking when they realise that what they are watching amounts to a wholesale re-rating of the economic outlook.
fields.body:
It is known, in market circles, as the "slow punch" - that is, a sharp fall in prices which happens over a number of days or even weeks rather than on one headline generating day. Market participants tend to find themselves taken unawares, suddenly panicking when they realise that what they are watching amounts to a wholesale re-rating of the economic outlook.

Yesterday's 80-point fall on the FTSE 100 to 6,199.2 took the cumulative loss to almost 600 points since September 4. Reasons to be bearish are stacking up: the long-running saga of the weak euro, the oil price and a host of other nagging reminders that new technology in the new economy has not abolished that old economy thing known as the business cycle. Yes, corporate earnings are still highly vulnerable to the price of basic commodities.

On the oil front, the word from Washington yesterday was that Bill Clinton may ride to the rescue by tapping emergency reserves stored in salt caverns along the Gulf of Mexico.

In a market fretting about surges of demand during the winter, this helped stabilise the price somewhat yesterday. After hitting a 10-year high of nearly $38 a barrel on Wednesday, oil was nearly a dollar cheaper in early afternoon trading.

Calming the wider jitters about economic growth in the west will not happen quickly.

Much will depend on the details of President Clinton's plan - specifically, how much extra oil and when?

Opec promised 11 days ago to boost production by 800,000 barrels a day - a move that is in theory expected to help lower the price of crude to around $25 a barrel.

But the American move might backfire by souring relations with Opec, whose members are due to meet in Caracus next week.

Before then, France has called for a special meeting between the oil producers, the European Union and the US to thrash out an agreement to end the crisis before the winter sets in.

Yet all the talking might be in vain. The United Nations compensation commission is due to rule on the long-standing claim for $16bn in war reparations from Iraq next week.

There is a view that if Saddam is asked to pay too much he will retaliate by turning off his crude tap - which at present is spewing 2.5m barrel per day on to the world oil market. No wonder financial market nerves are a-jangle

BoS crescendo

A bid for Bank of Scotland has been the talk of Edinburgh's Georgian squares ever since its audacious and hostile but ultimately ill-fated bid for NatWest, almost a year ago.

Yesterday, the chatter reached deafening crescendo, with one line of speculation suggesting BoS might even try to mark the anniversary of the start of its last hostile bid with a pre-emptive punt at a rival. Activity on the stock market was especially intense during the last half-hour of business, although there was no firm indication that we might expect an announcement to hit the screens first thing this morning.

That aside, both possibilities - hostile action by BoS, or against it - carry some credence. Even though the hostile bid for NatWest failed, it is generally agreed that the management of BoS is as good as it gets in traditional high street banking and, as a result, the institution carries the genuine confidence of its big institutional shareholders.

In large part this can be put down to the fact that Peter Burt, its chief executive, has always strived to keep his whole approach to banking resolutely free of charisma and marketing sex appeal. This is the man who talked about "banking in a box", and who yesterday appeared to set off all the speculation about corporate action by admitting in one interview that he was on the lookout for acquisitions.

Yet he is also a chief executive who has had to come to terms with life in Edinburgh, post-NatWest, where his perennial rivals at Royal Bank of Scotland are now sitting at the helm of one of the country's largest financial institutions. Pride, we can assume, is something of a motivator in all this.

But there are also suggestions that Mr Burt and his colleagues have, over recent days, been trying to massage down the City's expectations on the bank's interim figures, due next week.

The last set of results, in the immediate aftermath of the NatWest tussle, were certainly lacklustre.

The City forgave the management that time, since its focus had been elsewhere. But there will be a natural desire for some hard some evidence next week that the bank has regained some of its previous impetus.

All the while, partners for the BoS, either friendly or otherwise, are not difficult to list: Lloyds TSB and HSBC should be right at the top of any speculator's list.

Consolidation in this particular sector is by no means over.

There is a view that if Saddam is asked to pay too much he will retaliate by turning off his crude tap - which at present is spewing 2.5m barrel per day on to the world oil market. No wonder financial market nerves are a-jangle BoS crescendo A bid for Bank of Scotland has been the talk of Edinburgh's Georgian squares ever since its audacious and hostile but ultimately ill-fated bid for NatWest, almost a year ago. Yesterday, the chatter reached deafening crescendo, with one line of speculation suggesting BoS might even try to mark the anniversary of the start of its last hostile bid with a pre-emptive punt at a rival. Activity on the stock market was especially intense during the last half-hour of business, although there was no firm indication that we might expect an announcement to hit the screens first thing this morning. That aside, both possibilities - hostile action by BoS, or against it - carry some credence. Even though the hostile bid for NatWest failed, it is generally agreed that the management of BoS is as good as it gets in traditional high street banking and, as a result, the institution carries the genuine confidence of its big institutional shareholders. In large part this can be put down to the fact that Peter Burt, its chief executive, has always strived to keep his whole approach to banking resolutely free of charisma and marketing sex appeal. This is the man who talked about "banking in a box", and who yesterday appeared to set off all the speculation about corporate action by admitting in one interview that he was on the lookout for acquisitions. Yet he is also a chief executive who has had to come to terms with life in Edinburgh, post-NatWest, where his perennial rivals at Royal Bank of Scotland are now sitting at the helm of one of the country's largest financial institutions. Pride, we can assume, is something of a motivator in all this. But there are also suggestions that Mr Burt and his colleagues have, over recent days, been trying to massage down the City's expectations on the bank's interim figures, due next week. The last set of results, in the immediate aftermath of the NatWest tussle, were certainly lacklustre. The City forgave the management that time, since its focus had been elsewhere. But there will be a natural desire for some hard some evidence next week that the bank has regained some of its previous impetus. All the while, partners for the BoS, either friendly or otherwise, are not difficult to list: Lloyds TSB and HSBC should be right at the top of any speculator's list. Consolidation in this particular sector is by no means over.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Spruced up Selfridges
fields.body:
Spruced up Selfridges

Its dowdy image ditched, Selfridges yesterday reported sales increases of 7% in London and 21% at its new Manchester store for the first half but warned that Christmas sales would be crucial to its overall performance.

The firm is to open a store in Birmingham and is seeking sites in Glasgow, Leeds, Newcastle, Bristol and possibly Cardiff.

Selfridges reported a 47% rise in pre-tax profits to £12m and a 9% rise in sales to £169m. Its shares rose 3p to 294p. It will pay a 2p dividend, up 14%.

British Biotech doubles up

British Biotech has doubled its product portfolio over the past 12 months from three to six and will continue to add new ones by collaboration with third parties as well as its own research, its annual meeting heard yesterday.

The future of cancer drug marimastat is likely to be determined by results from studies later this year, the group said.

Packaging deal falls apart

British Polythene Industries, Europe's biggest polythene film maker, yesterday rejected a £92.3m bid from packaging company Macfarlane Group.

Macfarlane offered 250p in cash for each BPI share, a 40% premium to the price on September 5, the day before the company announced a bid approach, plus a 7p interim dividend.

Cameron McLetchie, BPI's chief executive, said: "The offer is totally inadequate. Its almost an insult at this price. It doesn't represent value for our shareholders at all."

A Macfarlane spokesman said the plastics market was consolidating and both firms would do better if they were together.

BPI's shares were up 52.5p, closing at 270p. Macfarlane shares closed at 62.5p, up 1p.

Axa profits dip in first half

The UK operations of French insurance group Axa suffered a downturn in profitability in the first half of the year. The €53m (£32m) reduction was in part due to the strength of sterling but also the result of €65m Axa had to plough into the UK business to bolster its reserves. Axa, which is in the process of paying out its so-called orphan assets to UK policyholders, also said it was seeking acquisition opportunities in the US.

Marconi buys Mariposa

Marconi is to buy Mariposa Technology for $268m (£200m), paid for predominantly in shares. California-based Mariposa makes integrated access devices (IADs) for building converged voice, video and data networks.

webTitle: At this price?

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: Morrisons
fields.trailText: City investors find it hard to get excited about Morrisons, the mainly northern-based supermarket chain. It shares have underperformed the sector over the past year. But that seems unfair. The company is the epitome of stability, regularly churning out decent results without setting the market alight.
fields.body:
City investors find it hard to get excited about Morrisons, the mainly northern-based supermarket chain. It shares have underperformed the sector over the past year. But that seems unfair. The company is the epitome of stability, regularly churning out decent results without setting the market alight.

Ken Morrison, its chairman and major shareholder, has a gritty, no-frills approach which means exciting, ambitious announcements are thin on the ground. Glitzy consumer offers are rejected in favour of basic cost cuts, but the formula has been a success and the canny investor would do well to add the stock to a portfolio.

Yesterday the debt-free company kept its reputation intact by announcing pre-tax profits of £86.4m, compared to £79.2m last time around. Sales were £1.71bn, up from £1.49bn. The stock rose 4p to 167p but analysts say the true value is nearer 190p.

SG Securities and CCF Charterhouse immediately put out "buy" notices, while another enthusiastic analyst said: "It's a very solid set of results and a typical Morrisons performance. People are taking the view it's never going to be an international superstar, but it's a very solid holding for your portfolio."

Morrisons, the fifth-largest grocery chain, is intent on growth. Another five stores are expected to open over the next four months, including the company's first in Wales, bringing the total to 111. A further six are planned for the next financial year.

There is still speculation over Mr Morrison's future at the helm and whether he plans to sell the chain. Observers are tipping the chain as a participant in future industry consolidation. This, they say, depends on the outcome of the forthcoming competition commission report into the sector.

Mr Morrison is optimistic about the verdict: "I've always thought it's a highly competitive industry and wouldn't have thought there were many blemishes to highlight."

webTitle: Market forces

fields.headline: Market forces
fields.standfirst: Rumours dog Bank of Scotland
fields.trailText: For days City traders have heard rumours that a bid for big FTSE 100 company is on the way, and yesterday Bank of Scotland emerged as the favourite target.
fields.body:
For days City traders have heard rumours that a bid for big FTSE 100 company is on the way, and yesterday Bank of Scotland emerged as the favourite target.

Various candidates for takeover had previously been put forward - most notably insurance group Royal & Sun Alliance, up 12.75p to 473.25p and more recently publishing group Emap, off 75p at £10.00. But yesterday afternoon the speculative money moved quickly into the Edinburgh-based bank.

From the dealers' perspective this was just as well, because it gave them a chance to earn some commission on a day when orders from the big institutional investors were few and far between.

Shares in Bank of Scotland ended 38p, or 6.81%, stronger at 596p - and the best performer in the FTSE 100 - as talk of an imminent 750p-a-share bid spread through City dealing rooms and electrified the rest of the sector.

Halifax closed 26p better at 530p, while Alliance & Leicester advanced 4p to 523p and Royal Bank of Scotland added 27p to £14.10p.

Abbey National closed down 6.5p at 848.5p, however, convincing the gossips that it was the predator and that the deal was already done and dusted.

Apart from such supposed evidence, which conveniently glossed over the fact Abbey has just splashed out £1.8b on Scottish Provident, sector specialists agreed that Bank of Scotland was looking vulnerable. Others suggested that Lloyds TSB, up just 1.5p to 579.5p, was a likely buyer.

The failure to win the hand of NatWest - it eventually fell to Royal Bank of Scotland - was, they say, a pivotal point in Bank of Scotland's history. The offer for NatWest was widely seen as last its last chance to compete on level terms with the large clearing banks.

Meanwhile, there was still some interest in Royal & Sun Alliance. In a variation on Wednesday's theme - a bid from a German or French insurer - the name being mentioned yesterday was Assicurazioni Generali, Italy's largest insurer and Europe's third largest. According to the gossips a merger will shortly be announced. Whatever the merits of such a tale, and most were treating it with caution, the stock did end higher a creditable performance given events in the wider market.

The benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 80.7 points to 6,199.2 - its lowest close in 17 weeks - as investors continued to fret that high oil prices could deliver a hard landing for the world economy.

At one point the FTSE 100 had fallen all the way to 6,150.5, only to recover in the afternoon. This followed soothing comments from Goldman Sachs chief strategist, Abby Joseph Cohen, who said equity market concerns about higher oil prices, a weak euro and corporate profits were overdone and would be "short-lived".

Once more telecommunications stocks bore the brunt of the selling, with already fragile sentiment undermined by a profit warning from US group Sprint and a negative note from Deutsche Bank on selected alternative carriers.

British Telecom fell 43p to 748p, while Vodafone lost 7.5p to 239.5p and Marconi slipped 40p to 945p. Elsewhere, Energis was marked down 30p to 495p after Deutsche Bank cut its rating to "underperform" and advised a switch into Colt Telecom , which also ended lower, down 87p at £19.53.

Meanwhile, cable company Telewest surrendered 17.25p to 142p after joint broker Merrill Lynch lowered its near-term rating to "accumulate".

Lower down the market, plasterboard maker BPB fell 33.25p to 206p after a profit warning on profits. Chemicals group Laporte picked up 29.5p to 409p on talk that a 600p a share bid was on the way.

Market newcomer ARC International got off to a flying start. Shares in the chip designer - trading on a "when issued" basis - closed at 428p, up a staggering 218p from their issue price.

webTitle: Hughes urges tougher curbs for most dangerous sex offenders

fields.headline: Hughes urges tougher curbs for most dangerous sex offenders
fields.standfirst:
Special report: child protection
Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Britain's most dangerous sex offenders could be held indefinitely in prison under new plans being considered by the Liberal Democrats.
fields.body:
Britain's most dangerous sex offenders could be held indefinitely in prison under new plans being considered by the Liberal Democrats.

Simon Hughes, the party's home affairs spokesman, said the use of "indefinite sentences" would not necessarily mean prisoners gained longer sentences, but there would be a more controlled release of them into society.

Serious sex offenders would be given a minimum tariff, but it would be up to judges to assess whether satisfactory arrangements had been made for them to be let out.

Mr Hughes' call for a review of the current sentencing policy came as the party addressed an issue which has been a national preoccupation following the abduction and murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne in July. There has been strong pressure for a "Sarah's law" which would allow parents access to the sex offenders' register.

Earlier this month the government ruled this out, but introduced other proposals, including fingerprinting and photographing offenders on their release and life bans on them contacting their victims.

Indefinite sentences are not an option at present unless a serious sex offender has re-offended, but the Home Office is looking at applying this to a small number of extremely dangerous sex offenders under separate legislation.

Yesterday Liberal Democrats called for "serious consideration" to be given to this measure, and called for the victims of sex offenders to be told where and when their abusers would be released. Proposing the motion, Gary Glover said: "Victims of serious crimes should not be terrified day after day, week after week by fear of meeting offenders."

Delegates also called for sex offenders convicted outside Britain to be placed on the register when they enter this country, and for the public to have access to this. But there was condemnation of the News of the World and its recent campaign to name and shame paedophiles, widely criticised by police and probation services at the time on the grounds it would drive offenders underground.

"It didn't take the News of the World to make the world aware of this problem," said Mr Hughes. "The News of the World were entirely irresponisble and entirely self serving."
