webTitle: Conference verdict

fields.headline: Conference verdict
fields.standfirst: Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
fields.trailText: Good week, Bad week
fields.body:
Good week

Charles Kennedy He survived it without gaffes or embarrassing photo-opportunites. His big speech, if not inspiring, was better than last year. The polls were good.

Sarah Gurling, Kennedy's girlfriend, wisely stayed out of the spotlight as much as possible. She listened to Charles' speech from the hall, not the platform. But kissed him in the crowd.

Sandra Gidley Victor in the Romsey byelection, her name evoked a cheer all week.

Alan Beith the modest deputy leader made a well-crafted speech with jokes. It won him a standing ovation. Next stop: the Commons Speakership ?

Bournemouth beach surfers The weather was bad much of the week. But the waves outside the conference centre got better.

Bad week

Don Foster Promised photographers he would sit in the sea on a deckchair to warn against global warming. Sea too cold, so he offered to sit, below, where the sea will be "if we don't do something about global warming".

Charles Clarke Labour's home office minister was heckled when he told Lib Dems to grow up - and mocked by old Cambridge ally, Simon Hughes MP.

Matthew Taylor The Lib Dem Treasury spokesman lost all publicity for his big enonomic speech when Mr Kennedy made an emergency speech on fuel duties.

Lembit Opik Welsh-Estonian MP's reputation for wackiness was confirmed when experts endorsed his warning against asteroid collisions

Delegate's view

Jean Sibley , 51, councillor from Southend and a librarian: " It's my 20th conference and it really has been a good one for the Liberal Democrats.

We've adopted some radical policies - such as voting for so-called gay marriages - and we've been really courageous, for instance by stressing our commitment to tax and spend. There's been a real turnaround for the party in the last 12 months. We've broken the barrier of being looked at as just some kind of pressure group and we're being seen as a real force to be reckoned with. You can't put that down to a change of leader - but I do think Charles's speech was very encouraging."

Key moments

Monday Liberal Democrats voted overwhelmingly for change in law to give legal recognition to gay partnerships

Tuesday Conference overwhelmingly backed the pre-election manifesto. Under the plans those earning more than £100,000 a year will face a tax rate of 50p in the pound. Additonal commitment to put 1p on the basic rate of income tax, if necessary, to fund a £3bn a year boost for education.

Wednesday Pledge to boost pensions by up to £15 a week.

Yesterday: Charles Kennedy appealed to millions of voters disillusioned by the Tories' drift to the right and Labour's "poverty of ambition" to defect to the Lib Dems.

Conference quote

Charles Kennedy: "William Hague is not the serious leader of a serious political party. That's the serious point. We are serious."

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Britannia to reward loyalty
fields.body:
Britannia to reward loyalty

Britannia building society is on target to pay out loyalty bonuses averaging £45-£50 to members in February after seeing "a strong start" to the year, it said yesterday.

About 800,000 members will receive payouts ranging from £1 to £500, the third largest building society said in reporting higher half-year profits of £70.2m. Britannia chairman Barrie Bernstein said the results, including a 49% rise in mortgage applications in the second quarter, "prove once again that the mutual model works well for our members".

£130m to speed mail deliveries

The Post Office is investing £130m in mail sorting technology to improve the efficiency of deliveries. Addresses will be read faster and more accurately using computer-based systems.

"This investment means a step change in the way letters are automatically sorted," said Mick Linsell, Royal Mail's managing director of service delivery.

Strong dollar aids industry

Manufacturing industry staged a modest comeback in September, helped by higher exports, according to the CBI's monthly trends survey. But further price cuts suggested the recovery of orders and output was at the expense of narrower margins.

Analysts said that, although exporters remained handicapped by the strength of the pound against the euro, its weakness against the dollar was compensating. Sudhir Junankar, associate director of economic analysis at the CBI, said: "Strong competition is taking its toll on manufacturers as more firms expect to cut prices. But the good news is that manufacturing demand, although weak, is reviving and output prospects are modestly positive."

Staff take a back seat

Despite saying staff are a company's greatest asset, managers tend to devote more energy and resources to finance or marketing, according to research released today.

Published by the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development, the researchby academics at Birkbeck College, London, questioned more than 1,000 senior executives in different sectors.

While saying that they relied on staff "a lot", only 1% of firms had in place more than three-quarters of a typical list of 18 effective personnel management practices.

webTitle: From King to God - yet it just keeps ailing

fields.headline: From King to God - yet it just keeps ailing
fields.standfirst: Turbulence blows airline off course again
fields.trailText: Collapsed talks between British Airways and KLM Dutch Airlines, after the two failed to agree on the structure of a joint airline, is the latest disappointment for BA.
fields.body:
Collapsed talks between British Airways and KLM Dutch Airlines , after the two failed to agree on the structure of a joint airline, is the latest disappointment for BA.

Rod Eddington - who, according to one profile of the new chief executive, was nicknamed God at university due to his academic and sporting prowess - has become the latest BA boss to hit turbulence. BA has fallen from the dizzy heights of profitability to losses.

A few months after Bob Ayling became head of BA on January 1 1996, the airline announced record pre-tax profits of £474m. A lucrative alliance with American Airlines was looking likely and Mr Ayling had embarked on a £1bn cost-cutting programme. Even after privatisation BA was still a national institution, the country's only flag carrier.

Then came the problems. In 1997 staff morale hit an all time low following a three-day cabin crew strike. The incident cost the company £125m.

Graffiti on the walls at BA's headquarters summed up the mood: "First we had King, then we had Marshall, now we are just Ayling."

More public embarrassments were to follow. The redesign of the airline's tailfins became a national joke and the airline faced derision as it was forced into an climbdown. The re-design was part of a £60m corporate revamp.

The proposed tie-up with American Airlines became bogged down in regulatory disputes. Mr Ayling had worked hard to join the two companies. It would have given them control of 70% of flights across the north Atlantic. Opposition from regulators and other airlines meant that it failed.

In February 1999 BA reported its first loss since it was privatised in 1987, falling £75m into the red. The failure of its London Eye big wheel to open on time was another public humiliation.

Mr Ayling was replaced by Mr Eddington, but the new man's reign has got off to a bad start.

webTitle: BA-KLM merger talks fail

fields.headline: BA-KLM merger talks fail
fields.trailText: British Airways' hopes of turning the corner under the leadership of Rod Eddington, its new chief executive, suffered a setback last night when it announced that merger talks with KLM, the Dutch carrier, had collapsed.
fields.body:
British Airways' hopes of turning the corner under the leadership of Rod Eddington, its new chief executive, suffered a setback last night when it announced that merger talks with KLM, the Dutch carrier, had collapsed.

The talks ended and irrevocably after months of promise. Mr Eddington had set great store by them, but when both sides realised they were not moving forward, they decided to cut their losses.

The merger would have turned the partners into one of the world's largest carriers and the biggest by far in Europe, with 500 aircraft.

Their joint statement stressed that competition concerns, plus strict regulations covering international air rights and price, had been largely responsible for scuppering the talks.

They came at a time of delicate negotiation between Britain and the United States over an extension of landing rights between the two countries. The merger would have allowed KLM and BA to use Heathrow and Schiphol, near Amsterdam, as hubs for travel into and out of Europe, a situation which could have put other carriers at a disadvantage.

The proposed merger also posed a problem for the European regulators, who argued that merger of two national carriers could unfairly affect other airlines.

Under the plan, in effect BA would have controlled KLM. But the Dutch company wanted to retain an element of national identity, which BA refused. KLM sources said this could have meant changes to livery, and the company was not ready to go that far.

Finally, the companies could not agree on a price. Although BA is the larger, its share price has been weak for months while KLM's has been rising.

In a joint statement, Mr Eddington and Leo van Wiijk, chief executive of KLM, said: "We always recognised that this would be a tough transaction, involving not only commercial and economic issues but also aeropolitical, regulatory and other matters. Although we made considerable progress it has not been possible to resolve these."

Although relations between the companies remained amicable, they had to decide to draw a line under the negotiations. They said there was no chance of the talks being renewed in the near future.

Mr Eddington, who had hoped to use the merger as a demonstration that BA had finally turned the corner and was on a rising profits path once more, said: "We shall continue to take steps to improve the performance of BA through our fleet and network strategy."

Coming after the grounding of the Concorde fleet following the loss of the Air France airliner in Paris in July, along with BA's continuing poor showing in the markets, this was a bitter pill for Mr Eddington to swallow.

But senior colleagues last night stressed that he was right to pull out of the talks when he realised that they might drag on for months; his predecessor, Bob Ayling, allowed merger talks with American Airlines to stretch to almost four years.

Mr Eddington and Lord Marshall, BA's chairman, emphasised that they did not intend to give up and that they would still press ahead with further consolidation in the European airline industry.

Lord Marshall said: "Europe is our back yard. We have al ways been a leading player in the market and will look for further opportunities to strengthen our position in it."

The talks appear to have stalled over the past few days, with BA staff being told recently to be ready for an optimistic announcement by the end of the month.

Mr Eddington will now have to tackle the issue of jobs at BA, which had been held up by the talks.

The company cannot sustain its current labour force of 63,000, even though some voluntary redundancies have gone through the system.

Union leaders were last night bracing themselves for news that there would an acceleration of job cuts, with thousands of posts having to be shed over the next few years in order to put the company on a firm financial footing again.

webTitle: Alder Hey surgeon halts heart ops

fields.headline: Alder Hey surgeon halts heart ops
fields.standfirst: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: A paediatric heart surgeon at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool has refused to perform any more cardiac operations on children because of a whispering campaign against him.
fields.body:
A paediatric heart surgeon at Alder Hey hospital in Liverpool has refused to perform any more cardiac operations on children because of a whispering campaign against him.

Roger Franks says he has taken the decision because it had become impossible for him to carry out operations at the hospital, where the organs of 893 children were retained without their parents' consent.

He said it had become increasingly difficult for him to operate on children's hearts while facing public attacks on his work. "This has affected both my professional and personal life and I feel the time is right for me to concentrate on other areas of work," he said.

Despite his decision, an internal hospital review of cardiac surgery showed that the mortality rates following Mr Franks's operations compared favourably with the national average.

A joint statement from Alder Hey hospital and Mr Franks said: "The public concern raised by the organ retention issue, coupled with personal attacks on Mr Franks's performance, have led him to the conclusion that he can no longer undertake cardiac surgery on children. He has come to the decision with great regret and the trust sympathises with his view."

The hospital has been rocked by the organ retention scandal and an independent inquiry is under way ordered by Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

The hospital trust is also conducting a more detailed analysis of its performance on cardiac surgery, in conjunction with the regional director of public health. It will examine the standard of heart operations performed by a team of surgeons over a 10-year period between 1989 and 1999.

Tony Bell, acting chief executive of the hospital, said: "Roger Franks has made a significant contribution to the hospital and I regret the fact that he feels he must stop all children's cardiac surgery."

He said Mr Franks, who is 55, will continue with lung and chest surgery, in which he has particular expertise.

Ian Cohen, the solicitor who is representing the families of 200 patients whose organs were retained, said the parents were angry at the implication they had forced Mr Franks to stop operating on children with heart problems.

webTitle: Scousers put the accent on success

fields.headline: Scousers put the accent on success
fields.trailText: The soft and friendly version of the Scouse accent has helped to turn Liverpool into Britain's favourite location for call centres.
fields.body:
The soft and friendly version of the Scouse accent has helped to turn Liverpool into Britain's favourite location for call centres.

Liverpool, where call centres have become an important strategy in economic regeneration, came top of a league table compiled by the recruitment agency Adecco. It was the only British city to win a place in the European top 10.

Adecco surveyed more than 250 call centre executives employing 40,000 staff in Europe who handle 550m calls a year.

Alice Powell, investment manager for the Mersey Partnership, which helps to bring jobs to Merseyside, said employers saw accents as an important factor in determining the quality of staff.

"The Liverpool accent used to be perceived as harsh and impenetrable," she said. "It still comes up as an issue at initial meetings. But we can quickly allay fears by showing that companies already here are successful.

"A Liverpool voice is now seen to be straight, understanding and friendly. It is not seen as a barrier to business."

Glasgow, Hartlepool, Belfast and Wolverhampton also fared well in the survey, suggesting that employers are not afraid of other distinctive accents.

But estuary English, the recognised accent of the south east, appears less popular: east London, Reading and Southend finished near the bottom of the list.

The findings complement research by the Henley Centre in which John Grimbaldeston, of Abbey National, which employs 250 call centre staff in Liverpool, said: "Our research showed us there was a very warm reception to the Liverpool accent.

"In a call centre, it's vital how people come across on the phone."

Paul Kerr, of Vertex, which has 800 staff in Knowsley, Merseyside, said: "Scouse accents came very high in customer appreciation. In call centres, all customers have to go on is the verbal presentation.

"So an accent can be pivotal to business success and people simply relate to Scousers."

The Mersey Partnership has been attracting call centre business for four years. The region now has 35 centres employing 10,000 staff.

Newcomers include Bertelsmann, the German media and distribution group, and US Airways, which has opened a £3.5m European reservations centre.

webTitle: New calls for dome chief to quit

fields.headline: New calls for dome chief to quit
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Lord Falconer faced fresh calls for his resignation last night after the Millennium Dome's financial director quit, the latest victim of Greenwich project.
fields.body:
Lord Falconer faced fresh calls for his resignation last night after the Millennium Dome's financial director quit, the latest victim of Greenwich project.

Accountant Neil Spence stepped down after a damning report uncovered a "black hole" when it was forced on the verge of bankruptcy to seek another £47m aid from the millennium commission.

An independent study discovered no proper record had been kept of contracts or assets, and his role was effectively taken over by a team brought in by City troubleshooter, David James.

But the New Millennium Experience Company's decision to continue paying Mr Spence's £127,700 salary until December 31 was criticised by opposition MPs, who also demanded Lord Falconer's head.

Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrats' dome spokesman, said: "It is incredible Mr Spence can resign and yet continue to draw a salary. Lord Falconer really has to go, and it is clear he is simply staying put to provide a shield for Tony Blair and Peter Mandelson."

Mr Spence's future as finance director was in doubt after Mr James was appointed three weeks ago. The chaotic state of the dome's finances was thrown into relief when Japanese bank Nomura pulled out of its proposed £105m bid to buy the Greenwich site.

webTitle: Comment; Mo Mowlam's departure

fields.headline: Hurry up and go, Mo
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: An impolite question, maybe - but one that must be asked. Does anyone remember "Mo" Mowlam? A grievous loss to the party, of course, a most grievous loss. But it is surprising how speedily these major upsets are forgotten. Nevertheless, those of us in senior positions in New Labour are only too well aware of the timely contribution made by "Mo" over the past few years.
fields.body:
An impolite question, maybe - but one that must be asked. Does anyone remember "Mo" Mowlam? A grievous loss to the party, of course, a most grievous loss. But it is surprising how speedily these major upsets are forgotten. Nevertheless, those of us in senior positions in New Labour are only too well aware of the timely contribution made by "Mo" over the past few years.

Scruffy, unruly, lazy and disorganised she may well be, but she enjoys cross-party popular appeal, in a way reminiscent of, say, Jeremy Thorpe in the early 1970s.

Of course, we did everything in our power to keep her happy, even to the extent of relieving her of her irksome Northern Ireland position when it seemed to be getting too much for her. Alas, nothing we did - even offering her full and legally binding responsibility for the Millennium Dome project as recently as a fortnight ago - was ever quite enough.

"But Mo!" I remember pleading with her late last month, "the next four months will see literally hundreds of people coming to the dome to have a Great Day Out - and you'll get all the credit!" I then let her know, in the strictest confidence, that Tony felt that if she made a halfway decent fist of the dome, the Welsh office could be hers for the asking. But like many undisciplined people, she has a stubborn streak, and she would not budge.

Hers is a grievous loss, and we all trust she enjoys a very long retirement, well away from politics. Speaking personally for a moment, I very much trust she gains a post commensurate with her abilities. There is no earthly reason, for instance, why the governor of Bermuda should always be a man - particularly as, in my experience, the (un)fairer sex are so very partial to brushing up their tans (!) on the golden sands.

Enough, then, of the eulogies: but one rather more pressing problem remains. Earlier this week I received a phone call from a senior figure close to the prime minister. For the sake of argument, let's call him "Alastair". He was, he said, busy finalising the running-order for this year's party conference. So far, everything was ship-shape. He had managed to reschedule the crucial debate on European monetary convergence to the prestigious 8.20am slot in the old Methodist Hall beyond the railway siding, and he had also arranged that my old friend and quaffing partner Lord Falconer would sadly be called away to a major international conference somewhere in the southern hemisphere. Sadly, for administrative reasons the fuel debate has had to be rescheduled the year after next. So it looks like being our best conference yet.

"Excellent!" I exclaimed. But, he went on to say, there was still the Mo Problem. "Ah," I said. "The Mo Problem." Through colleagues, he had tactfully suggested a variety of more attractive options open to the lovely Mo during conference week - a fact-finding mission to Belize, a weekend for two at a luxury hotel on a causeway off the north Devon coast, often cut off for weeks at a time - but, as usual, the lady wouldn't budge. She is, it seems, absolutely determined to take her place on the platform during key sessions, quite regardless of the harm it will do to this great party of ours.

"Could we not remove all the spare chairs on the platform?" I suggested to Alastair, but he said, no, she would take the opportunity to sit on Peter M's lap and once again make herself the conference darling. I said I'd don my thinking cap and get back to him within the hour. At the end of the hour, I had devised the following list of four (4) methods to frustrate Miss (Msss!) "Mo" Mowlam's conference ambitions:

1) Callard and Bowser's extra-strong toffee: Two nuggets to be offered to MM shortly before she takes to the platform. This will foil any attempt she might make to open her mouth and act the loose canon.

2) Roller blades: JP or WA to strap them to MM's heels while she waits backstage for her entrance. Result: her appearance onstage is followed by rapid exit offstage, arms flailing. Interpreted as curt dismissal of conference audience. MM's popularity plummets 30 points.

3) Novelty beard: Under guise of bear-hug, AC to place novelty beard over MM's face. When MM subsequently appears onstage, conference audience imagines her to be Frank Dobson. The applause that follows is thus short and sporadic, interrupted by uncalled-for barracking.

4) Petrol can: Full petrol-can to be placed in back of MM's car. AC subsequently unable to staunch press speculation about MM hoarding.

First-class suggestions, all. But how much easier it would be for everyone were she to stay at home. After all, the last thing New Labour needs now is the grim spectre of popularity past.

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • In a feature on page 9, G2, September 20, we quoted someone as saying: "I have been made aware of carcinogens in prepared food ... I've become particularly aware of the sweetener aspartame, which I hear is banned in the US ..." In fact, aspartame is not banned in the US. It has been widely used there ever since it was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration in 1981. Nor is there any proof that aspartame is carcinogenic.
fields.body:
 In a feature on page 9, G2, September 20, we quoted someone as saying: "I have been made aware of carcinogens in prepared food ... I've become particularly aware of the sweetener aspartame, which I hear is banned in the US ..." In fact, aspartame is not banned in the US. It has been widely used there ever since it was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration in 1981. Nor is there any proof that aspartame is carcinogenic.

In a report headed Alastair Hignell has multiple sclerosis, in our Sport tabloid, page 16, September 20, we wrongly suggested that the former England rugby player's beta interferon treatment was being paid for by Avon health authority. This is not the case. Anyone wishing to contribute to the fund to pay for his treatment should send a cheque to: Alastair Hignell Interferon Fund, National Westminster Bank, Henleaze Branch, Westbury on Trym, Bristol BS99 5AR

Spanish department, from an article headed Don't give in Gordon, etc, page 22, September 20, where we said, "So is the answer to sit tight ... and just say No Passeran to the truckers?" webTitle: How Milosevic can ensure he's an each-way winner

fields.headline: How Milosevic can ensure he's an each-way winner
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia's army chief ratcheted up the tension yesterday ahead of Sunday's election by claiming that Nato countries planned to send in special forces to help rivals of President Slobodan Milosevic seize power.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia's army chief ratcheted up the tension yesterday ahead of Sunday's election by claiming that Nato countries planned to send in special forces to help rivals of President Slobodan Milosevic seize power.

General Nebojsa Pavkovic's assertion sounded like a pretext for Mr Milosevic to clamp down on protesters or declare a state of emergency if he loses on Sunday - as all opinion polls predict he will. Voters will be choosing a federal parliament, local mayors and the Yugoslav presidency.

The army knew of a plan, Gen Pavkovic said, under which there would be disturbances on Sunday "provoked by special units of foreign armed forces who would be infiltrated into Yugoslav territory on that day".

They would come from the Serb part of Bosnia, from Montenegro and from Kosovo. They would dress in Yugoslav army and police uniforms, he said, and would stage provocations "under the guise of extending aid to the 'victors' - the opposition".

"Threats are being addressed to our country at the moment and as a serious army it is our duty to make all the preparations to prevent any surprises," he added.

Although the general also said the army would accept a genuine opposition victory, he is a Milosevic loyalist. Mr Milosevic has called the vote a choice between "patriotism and treachery" and the hint of military action worries western policymakers.

European Union foreign ministers offered voters a massive inducement this week to oust the president by announcing that foreign sanctions would be lifted if there was "democratic change".

The chief opposition candidate, Vojislav Kostunica, is a moderate nationalist who has walked a careful line in recent days by strongly criticising the United States while showing more sympathy for European positions. But he still calls for the unconditional lifting of sanctions and has denounced Nato's bombing of Yugoslavia last year.

While western governments can offer an end to sanctions, they cannot agree on what to do if Mr Milosevic "steals" Sunday's election by declaring victory on the basis of fraud and ballot-rigging.

Diplomats are uncertain how the president will play the election and are unwilling to speculate on his options or their reactions. The only certainties are that Mr Milosevic called the polls early thinking he would win easily because of the opposition's disunity, and that he is as surprised as any one by his opponents' strength.

The International Crisis Group, a think-tank that aims to strengthen the capacity of the international community to anticipate conflict, and which has good contacts in Washington and London, this week outlined four scenarios for Sunday's poll.

Fearing defeat, the Yugoslav president may call it off after "provoking some sort of internal crisis through a staged terrorist attack or simulated military coup, or major disruption in Montenegro". This is unlikely, says the ICG, because it would damage his image of being confident and in control.

Scenario two, is "the big steal" in which he cheats. A third option is that he plays by the rules on Sunday and accepts defeat knowing that under the constitution he need not hand over power until his mandate ends next August. In the meantime he transfers all power to the Serbian presidency and organises an election victory in Serbia next spring, leaving Mr Kostunica to inherit an empty shell as Yugoslav president.

The last option is again that Mr Milosevic accepts a Kostunica victory but over the next few months allows Montenegro to secede, thereby destroying Yugoslavia and leaving Mr Kostunica with no role.

Like most observers, the ICG believes the "big steal" is the likeliest. All will depend on the opposition's reaction, it says.

The opposition might accept cheating in the presidential vote while using its new strength in parliament and town halls to consolidate power for the long haul. Alternatively, it may mount street protests and confront the government, but Mr Kostunica has repeatedly said he does not want bloodshed.

webTitle: Ballot paper adds to Yugoslav fraud fears

fields.headline: Ballot paper adds to Yugoslav fraud fears
fields.standfirst:
As the opposition rides high, a completed voting slip suggests the president intends to be victorious - at any cost

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The first evidence emerged yesterday of vote rigging for this Sunday's crucial presidential election in Yugoslavia, as fears grew that President Slobodan Milosevic would use any tactic to stay in power.
fields.body:
The first evidence emerged yesterday of vote rigging for this Sunday's crucial presidential election in Yugoslavia, as fears grew that President Slobodan Milosevic would use any tactic to stay in power.

The discovery of a completed ballot slip containing a vote for the president adds to concerns that fraud on a massive scale would enable Mr Milosevic to overcome the lead of his chief rival, Vojislav Kostunica.

The slip was found in in the letterbox of an electoral monitoring group, the Centre for Free Elections (Cesid). The slip, bearing the official stamp, carries the name of the five candidates for president. Slobodan Milosevic is circled.

"We are deeply concerned. Is it possible that those ballots are circling Serbia?" asked Slobodanka Nedovic of Cesid, who was told by election officials that they would "discuss the problem tomorrow".

Many in Belgrade are not surprised by the find. Milan Nikolic, director of the Centre for Policy Studies, said: "They will use every means possible because they are in very bad shape."

Analysts say Kosovo provides fertile ground for dirty tricks - 300 polling stations will be open, but it will hard for non-governmental groups to verify the results. A second area of concern lies in the two electoral districts in southern Serbia: Prokuplje and Vranje, and in Montenegro.

In addition, several hundred thousand ethnic Albanians remain registered to vote in Yugoslavia and analysts fear their votes could be appropriated.

The Kostunica coalition, the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (Dos), is taking strenuous measures to curb voting fraud.

Its campaign manager, Zoran Djindjic, said almost every polling station in Serbia and Montenegro will have a Dos member on its electoral board, but that the coalition had been denied such representation in southern Serbia and Kosovo.

He said Dos was unable to monitor much of the election process. "The voting lists are made by police. The polls are controlled by the government. The courts are controlled by the Socialist party [of Milosevic] and Yugoslav United Left party [of Mr Milosevic's wife]."

He said the authorities turned down an opposition request to follow ballots from the polling station to the headquarters of the federal election commission and to watch the data being put into computers.

An application by Cesid for its observers to check the polls was also rejected. Cesid staff have been targeted across Serbia, with secret police raiding offices and making arrests.

 Judges in Belgrade yesterday sentenced Tony Blair, foreign secretary Robin Cook and ex-defence secretary Lord Robertson to 20 years in prison for crimes against humanity committed during the Nato bombing campaign.

webTitle: Eric's games

fields.headline: Eric's games
fields.trailText: Eric Moussambani, the swimmer from Equitorial (Swimmer sets Olympic record - the slowest, September 20) presents us with a serious problem. The Olympic games are supposed to be a showcase for the world's youth, but they show up, as no other forum can, the disparity between the rich and the poor. Few African countries can provide the resources for potential competitors to train in "sports" that might test some talent and prowess but ultimately depend on expensive training facilities and gear.
fields.body:
Eric Moussambani, the swimmer from Equitorial (Swimmer sets Olympic record - the slowest, September 20) presents us with a serious problem. The Olympic games are supposed to be a showcase for the world's youth, but they show up, as no other forum can, the disparity between the rich and the poor. Few African countries can provide the resources for potential competitors to train in "sports" that might test some talent and prowess but ultimately depend on expensive training facilities and gear.

The games should be held in settings that test the real-life skills of the world's youth. Swimming, for example, could be done in a real river or lake, even if crocodiles live in it. Then Eric would have his chance.
Kwasi Gyan-Apenteng
London

webTitle: Democracy and the Lords

fields.headline: Democracy and the Lords
fields.trailText: In an historic vote next week, the Labour party conference will decide its approach to a replacement of the House of Lords.
fields.body:
In an historic vote next week, the Labour party conference will decide its approach to a replacement of the House of Lords.

The party leadership favours a largely appointed second chamber. We believe strongly that Labour should commit itself to a second chamber in which at least half of the members are elected. The Campaign for a Democratic Upper House, which we support, has been set up to secure this outcome.

The basic reason is one of principle: in a modern parliament, legitimacy comes with election. On a tactical level, Labour could find itself alone at the next general election in backing a largely appointed second chamber.

Labour has to use this conference to get the principle right on Lords reform. It is up to delegates from the constituencies, trade unions and affiliated societies to urge the leadership to show how strongly the Labour party believes in the democratic principle.
Melvyn Bragg, Roy Hattersley, Diana Jeuda, Helena Kennedy, Martin Linton, Rhodri Morgan, Ivor Richard, Tony Robinson, Tony Wright
Campaign for a Democratic Upper House

webTitle: Good and evil in the Catholic church

fields.headline: Good and evil in the Catholic church
fields.trailText: Madeleine Bunting is right to highlight cases where nuns have been convicted of abusing children (In the name of God, September 20). However, she should have told us something of the positive side of the altruism and idealism that is part and parcel of the calling.
fields.body:
Madeleine Bunting is right to highlight cases where nuns have been convicted of abusing children (In the name of God, September 20). However, she should have told us something of the positive side of the altruism and idealism that is part and parcel of the calling.

Our agency, working with all children and families, irrespective of faith, has five nuns on the staff. They are all well respected and highly trained in their different roles, namely: child psychotherapy, school counselling, family therapy, adoption and management of a family centre. Long may children in need continue to benefit from such dedication.
JM Richards
Director, Catholic Children's Society
Jrichards@cathchild.org.uk

 From the age of seven to 13 (in the early 1960s) I was at a highly reputed Catholic day school. All but a couple of the brothers were bullies and five were outright sadists. While it may not have been a typical Catholic establishment, it was certainly, in comparison to any organisation I have since encountered, exceptional in terms of the high proportion of dysfunctional personalities within it.

The important point about child abuse and Roman Catholicism is the one Madeleine Bunting refuses to acknowledge: that it has been endemic for decades, and the church has done nothing of substance to confront it honestly or give comfort to the victims. The child remains always in the wrong.
Dave Juson
Southampton

 A Catholic nun has been found guilty of gross brutality, in a court of law, with evidence tested and challenged in a rigorous process (Nun guilty of terrorising girls in care, September 20). Mario Conti, the bishop of Aberdeen, is on record as saying that the allegations were concocted by former residents of the homes, encouraged by "unscrupulous lawyers". Are we now to assume that the Catholic church believes that victims are liars and that all priests and nuns are innocent? I find this attitude wholly unchristian and, for the victims who endured the cruelty, a further abuse and humiliation. Has the Catholic Church no understanding at all of the pain of the victims?
Margaret Kennedy
Macsas, London

webTitle: Letters; Portillo's dodgy steering

fields.headline: Portillo's dodgy steering
fields.trailText: Has Michael Portillo completely lost the plot (Portillo offers Mondeo Man 11p a day, September 21)? Years ago, the Tory government rightly started putting up fuel prices in response to worries about global warming, caused mainly by rising carbon dioxide emissions.
fields.body:
Has Michael Portillo completely lost the plot (Portillo offers Mondeo Man 11p a day, September 21)? Years ago, the Tory government rightly started putting up fuel prices in response to worries about global warming, caused mainly by rising carbon dioxide emissions.

It is true that new cars are emitting less noxious exhaust gases than older cars, but they certainly are not emitting any less carbon dioxide. And since everyone is driving around a lot more these days, and car ownership is also on the up, CO2 levels are rising inexorably.

By offering to cut petrol tax by 3p a litre because cars are getting cleaner, Portillo irresponsibly perpetuates the myth that the only problem with too many cars is bad air quality.
Richard Evans
London

 Every motorist can get a 3p cut in the price of a litre of petrol, without having to risk electing a Tory government. If you contrive to get 31 miles per gallon instead of 30, that is exactly what you achieve. Everyone can reduce fuel costs simply by driving smoothly and sticking to speed limits. This is also better for air quality and safer for other road users.
Conrad Cork
Leicester

 Three pence per litre off petrol tax, we are told, would deprive the Treasury of £1bn a year, with a meagre return to the motorist of only £3 a month and a threat of increased income tax to compensate.

If, however, petrol tax remains high and motorists decide to reduce their spending on petrol by £3 a month, where does Mr Brown get his £1bn from?
Joan Skinner
Anstey, Leics

 It was with some amazement that I read Frank Dobson's assertion (Crude exploitation, September 21) that oil companies are responsible for the current difficulties regarding fuel cost and supply. The government is now accountable for 76% of the cost of fuel; the suppliers, refiners and distributors account for just 24%.

It is reported that the UK government collects around £1bn per week from fuel taxation. The rationale for the high level of tax is environmental - which is justifiable. But only a small proportion of this money ends up in investment in transport infrastructure or new sustainable clean fuel technologies.

The dilapidated state of our transport infrastructure is very evident, particularly to those visiting to the UK. Mr Dobson, please tell us - where does all the money go?
Martin Lacey
Houston, Texas mwlacey@yahoo.com

 In 1950 we paid 3p for a litre of petrol. Since then, petrol prices have increased 30-fold. In the same period, earnings have increased 50-fold. Petrol today is cheaper than it was 50 years ago.
Joachim Liebschner
Midhurst, Sussex

 Since fuel prices are apparently so high, can we look forward to a new era in which coach, lorry, van and car engines are no longer left ticking over while drivers deliver, load, think, eat, doze or read the paper?
Godfrey Carr
Leamington Spa, Warks

 While I was stopped at traffic lights near Liverpool airport, a wagon drew alongside my car. On the door was the company name and the nature of business - environmental services.

As it pulled away in a cloud of fumes I saw written on the tailgate in bold capitals:"Cut fuel tax now! Listen Tony or get out! People power!"
Terry Wafer
Widnes, Cheshire

fields.headline: Burning issues
fields.trailText: Nice to see a woman advocating freedom for pregnant women to smoke cigarettes if they feel like it (Smoking for two, September 19). What is a "tiny" risk to a child anyway? Why should a small child have a better chance in life anyway? Emily Wilson is right.
fields.body:
Nice to see a woman advocating freedom for pregnant women to smoke cigarettes if they feel like it (Smoking for two, September 19). What is a "tiny" risk to a child anyway? Why should a small child have a better chance in life anyway? Emily Wilson is right. Women unite and rebel, forget the selfish doctors and scientists and live life for the moment.
Dean Bond
London

 How on earth did the explosives specialist mistake the MI6 building for the Millennium Dome (Blasts rock MI6 spy base, September 21)?
Rev Geoff Reid
Bradford

 Missile? Or was it that asteroid you warned us about a few days ago?
Brian Moss
Tamworth, Staffs
BrianMoss@NorthWarks.gov.uk

 Perhaps it was an exploding pen.
Adam Sandelson
London

 First Great Western is the only operator of high-speed trains to have an ATP system fitted (Diary, September 21). ATP, which prevents a train passing a red signal, is fitted in all the company's high-speed trains and operates on all high-speed train services where the relevant equipment is fitted at the trackside. At the Ladbroke Grove rail crash, the First Great Western train had a green signal and was authorised to proceed. ATP would not have been activated and thus ATP on the First Great Western service alone would not have prevented the accident.
Mike Carroll
Managing director, First Great Western
fields.bodyText: Nice to see a woman advocating freedom for pregnant women to smoke cigarettes if they feel like it (Smoking for two, September 19). What is a "tiny" risk to a child anyway? Why should a small child have a better chance in life anyway? Emily Wilson is right. Women unite and rebel, forget the selfish doctors and scientists and live life for the moment. Dean Bond London  How on earth did the explosives specialist mistake the MI6 building for the Millennium Dome (Blasts rock MI6 spy base, September 21)? Rev Geoff Reid Bradford  Missile? Or was it that asteroid you warned us about a few days ago? Brian Moss Tamworth, Staffs BrianMoss@NorthWarks.gov.uk  Perhaps it was an exploding pen. Adam Sandelson London  First Great Western is the only operator of high-speed trains to have an ATP system fitted (Diary, September 21). ATP, which prevents a train passing a red signal, is fitted in all the company's high-speed trains and operates on all high-speed train services where the relevant equipment is fitted at the trackside. At the Ladbroke Grove rail crash, the First Great Western train had a green signal and was authorised to proceed. ATP would not have been activated and thus ATP on the First Great Western service alone would not have prevented the accident. Mike Carroll Managing director, First Great Western

webTitle: Letters; Greenpeace wins key GM crop case

fields.headline: GM sauce for the gander
fields.trailText: My congratulations to Lord Melchett and the Lyng 27 for exercising the right to be heard by a jury in a crown court (Greenpeace wins key GM crop case, September 21). By using the jury system to successfully challenge the legitimacy of crop trials, Greenpeace has shown that yet again ordinary people can be relied upon to make an objective decision in a case where the vested interests of the government, farmers and the biotechnology industry were only too apparent.
fields.body:
My congratulations to Lord Melchett and the Lyng 27 for exercising the right to be heard by a jury in a crown court (Greenpeace wins key GM crop case, September 21). By using the jury system to successfully challenge the legitimacy of crop trials, Greenpeace has shown that yet again ordinary people can be relied upon to make an objective decision in a case where the vested interests of the government, farmers and the biotechnology industry were only too apparent.
Nicholas Milton
London nicholasmilton@hotmail.com

 I'm confused. Farmers complain about direct action by Greenpeace a week after taking direct action against fuel prices. What's sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander, I would have thought.
Ian Burdon
Edinburgh

 In view of the acquittal of Lord Melchett and his associates, may we now presume that it will be acceptable to destroy organic crops on the grounds that they are a reservoir of dangerous pests and diseases that may spread to neighbouring farms?
Prof John Bryant
School of Biological Sciences, University of Exeter

 Since every crop grown on Lord Melchett's own farm has been genetically modified by hundreds of years of selective breeding, can anyone now walk in and pull them all up?
Donald Reid
Watford

 Let's hope that Lord Melchett's acquittal doesn't set Tommy Archer off again. There's a limit to how much drama Ambridge can accommodate.
Peter Barnes
Milton Keynes

 In arguing for the continuation of GM crop trials, the spokesman for the Department of the Environment states: "Our top priority is to protect the environment and human health." What vacuous nonsense: it's obvious that, as usual, the government's first priority is to support commercial concerns above those of ordinary people: that's why its policy is to endorse GM in the first place. In contrast to our elected representatives, anti-GM activists understand that scientific crop trials can only ever tell us "no evidence of risk", not "no risk". This rational refusal to confuse "looks safe" with "safe", especially with such a powerful and unprecedented new technology, highlights the criminal irresponsibility of those who impose an even riskier future upon us all, without our consent.
Nick Hunt
Bath

webTitle: Bank rapped for debt relief delays

fields.headline: Bank rapped for debt relief delays
fields.standfirst:
Special report: The IMF and World Bank in Prague

Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: Debt campaigners reacted angrily yesterday to the World Bank chief James Wolfensohn's denial of responsibility for the delays which have bogged down the west's debt relief programme.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny  and  Larry Elliott  in Prague
fields.body:
Debt campaigners reacted angrily yesterday to the World Bank chief James Wolfensohn's denial of responsibility for the delays which have bogged down the west's debt relief programme.

Jubilee 2000, the umbrella group which has mobilised tens of thousands of people around the world to campaign for a better deal for the world's most indebted countries, said his disclaimer was disgraceful.

"It beggars belief that the head of one of the world's most powerful economic institutions, funded by taxpayers, can pass the buck in this way," said Lucy Matthew, a Jubilee 2000 spokeswoman

"The debt relief programme was designed and developed in Washington. Now that it isn't working, it's the job of the bank and the [International Monetary Fund] to make it work."

Mr Wolfensohn said the two institutions were doing everything they could to meet the target set by western finance ministers of getting 20 countries through the programme by the end of the year.

"One thing I'm wholly confident about is that if we don't, it won't be through any fault of the bank and the fund."

Oxfam said the failure to get relief to countries which had met all the conditions laid down by the bank was outrageous. "No one can doubt Mr Wolfensohn's personal commitment to the poorest people in the world, but the World Bank and its board continue to fail to deliver on its mandate and his vision, most visibly on debt relief, " its senior policy adviser, Tony Burden,said.

Bank and fund staff are now cooperating in a special taskforce to ensure that the G7 is not embarrassed by further delays. But campaigners said the two institutions could have done more to speed up the process when they overhauled the heavily indebted poor countries programme after the Cologne G7 meeting in 1998.

"If they had got the message about accelerating the ... programme when they were redesigning it, they wouldn't be trying to cram 10 countries through by the end of the year," said Matthew Martin, head of Debt Relief International.

Mr Wolfensohn said that he and the new managing director of the IMF, Horst Köhler, were personally committed to speeding up the programme, but both institutions had to be sure the money was being spent wisely on poverty reduction programmes.

"I don't think anybody would want us to relieve debt if we saw the money flying out of the window, so we are not prepared to do that ourselves.

webTitle: As always, it's the poor that get the blame

fields.headline: As always, it's the poor that get the blame
fields.standfirst:
Special report: The IMF and World Bank in Prague

Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: A hundred days before the G7 deadline for relieving the debt of the world's poorest countries, recrimination was in the air yesterday as a culprit was sought for the delay in turning words into action.
fields.body:
A hundred days before the G7 deadline for relieving the debt of the world's poorest countries, recrimination was in the air yesterday as a culprit was sought for the delay in turning words into action.

Not me, said James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank. Not us, said the International Monetary Fund.

The bank and the fund are fed up with being tarred as villains and insist that they are doing all they can to meet the target set by the G7 leading industrial countries at their Cologne meeting last year. Since the G7 states are also unwilling to accept responsibility, the poor themselves are being told that there are more hoops for them to jump through.

The attempt to shift the blame is infuriating campaigners, who say that the west has been slow to come up with the money and that the World Bank and the IMF are using the bait of debt relief to impose new conditions on poor countries. What is not in dispute is that the high hope raised when the G7 promised $100bn (£71.5bn) of debt relief has been dashed.

Originally, 24 countries were supposed to start getting their debt written off by the end of this year. So far only 10 have begun, only Uganda has completed the process, and there is a ferocious argument on whether the programme is generous enough to make a difference.

Some countries will have to pay their creditors more after they have completed the programme, and most will still be spending more on debt than on health and education.

Rumbles of discontent have started to emerge from finance ministries, including the British Treasury. Gordon Brown was instrumental in beefing up debt relief in Cologne last year. He thinks the west now has to deliver or explain why. He believes that the thousands of protesters in Birmingham in 1998 and Cologne last year are losing patience with the excuses from Washington.

Mr Wolfensohn said he was prepared to explore the possibility of more "flexible" conditions, which might speed up the process. But debt relief with strings was no bad thing, he added.

"I don't believe that conditionality in lending has had all the adverse effects that are asserted against it. I don't think that my colleagues and I at the bank get up every morning and see what are the conditions we can put on a loan that can ruin the country."

The blame game in western capitals is no comfort to a country such as Malawi, which has been waiting for debt relief since May. It produced a draft poverty reduction strategy -the first hurdle set by the World Bank and IMF - five months ago.

The fund and bank say they have to do an on-the-spot assessment of how much relief the country needs, and delays in completing this mean that Malawi may not get any relief until November. That has cost it $17m, Oxfam says: money that could have been spent tackling the HIV/Aids crisis or building classrooms.

With debt relief high on the list of grievances of protesters due in Prague in the coming days, there will certainly be efforts in the next three months to bring more indebted countries into the process. Campaigners say they are increasingly pessimistic about whether the target of 20 will be met.

It is already clear that the political momentum behind debt relief has been lost, primarily because of the stand-off in the US between the White House and Congress.

Responsibility for hastening the process and ensuring it leads to a real reduction in repayments lies with the G7 states.

If they make it a political priority, much could still be achieved. If they don't, the culprits will be exposed.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
A belated hello! to Giles Coren, who has taken over this week as my so-called rival on the Times (the whisper being that he only got the job because of his famous father, Bernard Levin). But already one Times reader isn't a fan. Alex Clarke wrote to young Giles opining that the Times Diary was now worse then ever. Sadly, Giles did not take this criticism at all well, and spent the rest of the day ringing Alex, trying vainly to find out his home address and complaining to Alex's employers ("Can't you give him more work to do or something?" he whined). The emails continued, and Mr Clarke reached for the "nuclear option": he threatened to pass the correspondence on to this Diary. "The Guardian isn't going to print a story about a diarist on another paper who is pissed off about a grumpy reader," Giles rather too confidently replied. "You'll be glad to know that my diary will be shitter [sic] than ever today because I've spent more time emailing you and being pissed off about you than I have on anything else," is Giles's farewell on the subject. And that's only Giles's third day on the job.

Following on from the Buxton pub that imposed a 10-pint limit during the fuel crisis, a pub in nearby Leek has a sign: "Fluid Crisis - No Shortage".

Brighton readers with a spare room and a kind heart might consider helping out Newsnight staff caught out by an accommodation drought at next week's Labour party conference. A memo circulated this week asking reporters covering the conference to stay with family and friends hasn't gone down well. Among the disgruntled staff is Jeremy Paxman, who looks likely to be accommodated in the less than nearby Gatwick Hilton. So anyone who fancies having Paxo dossing on the sofa, just ring the BBC. ("I put it to you, Auntie Marge, that I would prefer kippers.")

A joke has been doing the rounds at the Liberal Democrats conference in Bournemouth - but just the one, mind. The Lib Dems (say wags) used to have a leader who got up at 5am. Now it has a leader who goes to bed at 5am. And anyone who heard Mr Charles Kennedy's virtuoso performance on Radio 4's World at One on Tuesday will know that it hasn't affected him a jot. As part of their year-late "peanuts-pension" campaign, Anthony Bevins in the Daily Express yesterday calculates that the government's £19bn surplus would buy every peanut in the world for the next 18 months. The Express isn't the only paper indulging in totally un-bogus statistical calculations. Last Saturday's Dominion newspaper in New Zealand calculated that the amount spent by rich countries on agricultural subsides each year is enough to buy every cow in the OECD a first-class round the world air ticket, plus spending money. What the cows would spend it on wasn't revealed.

Many of our readers were surprised to learn here yesterday that Mr Tony Blair was writing a leaflet for the Fabian Society called The Case for Socialism. But of course that was a ludicrous suggestion, which happily has turned out not to be true. We apologise to Mr Tony for the idea that he would ever make the case for socialism. He's only writing the foreword to the Fabian pamphlet with the same title. It's only three sentences long, so we were at least right about it being easily reproduced on the back of a stamp.

I can now report on Puppetry of the Penis, the show in which two Australian men create "installations" with their genitalia. The climax of the show, the "Windsurfer", along with a phalanx of supporting acts such as the Millennium Dome (thankfully sans supporting struts, but no less excruciating than the real thing) was a hands down winner. And at just the right length, the show may earn a transfer for an extended run, perhaps on Shaftesbury Avenue.

webTitle: 'Former victims' help to convict serial rapist

fields.headline: 'Former victims' help to convict serial rapist
fields.standfirst: Civil rights group criticises Lords' ruling that enabled previous victims to establish pattern of attacks in landmark case
fields.trailText: A serial rapist was yesterday convicted of his third sex attack across a 17 year period, after a law change allowed evidence from five previous rape trials he has faced to be laid before the jury.
fields.body:
A serial rapist was yesterday convicted of his third sex attack across a 17 year period, after a law change allowed evidence from five previous rape trials he has faced to be laid before the jury.

Nicholas Edwards was jailed for life for the rape of a 23-year-old woman in 1998, after the Old Bailey heard it fitted a pattern consistent with five previous attacks over 14 years.

In an unprecedented move, the judge, Leonard Gerber, allowed the jury to hear evidence from four woman who went to court claiming Edwards raped them only to see him acquitted, and from a woman whom he was jailed for raping.

Before the trial began, the House of Lords agreed to make a significant change in English criminal law to allow the "similar fact" evidence to be put before the jury. But civil liberties campaigners last night warned that the Lords' judgment risked increasing miscarriages of justice.

In the charge he faced and in his previous trials, Edwards, 39, had claimed the woman had consented to sex, and juries had to decide between his word and that of the woman.

The Old Bailey jury did not hear from another woman whom Edwards had been convicted of raping at knifepoint in 1981, and another whose allegations he was cleared of, as they could not be traced.

Edwards was yesterday convicted solely for his attack on a young mother, Miss D, whom he raped in August 1998 in his flat in Sydenham, southeast London.

As in previous rape allegations against him, Edwards approached the woman and initially appeared charming.

As in at least one other allegation, he called her a "bitch" during the attack and ordered her to strip before pinning her under him and forcing her to have unprotected intercourse.

With Miss D, Edwards's mood changed in a "Jekyll and Hyde" way immediately before the rape, matching the testimony of the five other women.

Miss D, who had a five-month-old son, was left so traumatised that she was unable to breast feed her child.

She also bathed in bleach and Dettol to try and "wash him away".

Detective Sergeant Paul Astbury, who led the gathering of evidence, said Edwards had used knowledge gained from his previous trials to rape in a way that minimised his chances of being convicted: "As he was planning them, he was formulating his own defence ... knowing exactly what it took to get off, knowing exactly what was required for the police to prove his guilt.

"He is one of the most dangerous individuals I have come across. Without the similar fact evidence, the chances of securing a conviction would be less than average."

Privately, police officers believe he could have raped far more than the eight known about. Another two women have come forward since the Old Bailey trial began.

The prosecutor, David Perry QC, reading a victim impact statement from Miss D after the verdict, said: "She cannot kiss her boyfriend on the lips. She has never kissed anyone on the lips since the rape. She still suffers from flashbacks and nightmares and thinks she has changed since. She cannot get the face of the defendant's face out of her head and has become depressed."

A 42-year-old woman, Miss R, who saw Edwards's acquitted of charges of raping her in a churchyard in 1991, said she had to testify at the Old Bailey: "It has got him off the streets before he cannot attack other women. When I heard he had struck again, I wanted to do something to help put this man behind bars.

"He turned from a charming individual into a monster."

Mary Cuneen, director of policy for the civil rights group Liberty, said: "The House of Lords judgment goes too far. The facts of this case are obviously horrendous. In effect you are judging somebody's guilt not on the basis of the evidence of the offence they have committed, but on the basis of other matters.

"Clearly there is a strong interest in prosecuting rape cases properly, but there is a danger that the House of Lords has not had proper regard for the principles of general fairness."

The Lords dismissed defence arguments that allowing similar fact evidence to be heard would be prejudicial.

Judge Gerber said Edwards should serve a minimum of seven years imprisonment for attacking Miss D before he could be considered for parole: "You humiliated her and have not shown one iota of remorse."

Detective Chief Inspector Jim Webster appealed for any other women with information about Edwards to contact the police.

History of violence

August 25 1981 Raped woman in car in High Wycombe. Used knife. Jailed for 30 months, reduced on appeal to two years.

April 15 1984 Allegedly raped 19-year-old at his bedsit in High Wycombe. Cleared

February 13 1985 Raped woman, 17, at his home in High Wycombe. Jailed for five years, served three.

August 13 1985 While on bail, alleged to have raped woman at his home in High Wycombe. Acquitted.

May 2 1989 Allegedly raped 20-year-old in his car in south London. Cleared

March 2 1991 Allegedly raped nurse, 33, in south London churchyard. Cleared

July 18 1993 Allegedly raped virgin, 26, same churchyard. Cleared

August 31 1998 Raped 23-year-old at south-east London flat. Convicted yesterday

webTitle: Anonymous man whose only motivation was sex

fields.headline: Anonymous man whose only motivation was sex
fields.trailText: As Nicholas Edwards last night began a life sentence, the fact that he was no longer a danger to women was of little comfort to the victims whose lives he damaged.
fields.body:
As Nicholas Edwards last night began a life sentence, the fact that he was no longer a danger to women was of little comfort to the victims whose lives he damaged.

One had an abortion, one is still haunted by the memory 16 years on, another was never able to breastfeed her child, another is on anti-depressants, another cannot kiss or be kissed on the lips.

The legal system that Edwards exploited to get away with a campaign of rape pulled out all the stops to convict him of the eighth sex attack charge he has faced since 1981.

Edwards had asked the jury at the Old Bailey to believe that so many women were accusing him of rape because he was "unlucky".

In a totally different sense to what he meant, he was right. Less than one in 10 rapes reported to police result in conviction. Researchers believe those attacks which are reported also represent a tenth of the real total, meaning the chances of Edwards being convicted yesterday were less than one in100.

For 17 years he carried out a string of sex attacks, exploiting his knowledge of the legal system through his seven previous rape trials to gain acquittal. There was inconclusive or no medical or forensic evidence supporting the women's claims.

Detective Sergeant Paul Astbury, who built the case against Edwards, said: "I think the only purpose in his life was sex."

Police found it hard to piece together a coherent picture of his life. Edwards claimed to have fathered six children, but was never part of a stable family unit.

"What is more frightening is he has integrated into society perfectly normally, he's held down a job, he's fathered children," said Mr Astbury.

Edwards's family were noticeable by their absence from the three-week trial, with one of his daughters attending briefly.

From the witness box Edwards bragged of having lost his virginity at 13. He claimed, police believe falsely, to have slept with 2,000 women, and of having six children with five women.

His counsel, Richard Benson QC, said that Edwards had "the morals of an alley cat".

But Mr Benson continued: "No matter how much you want to doctor him, you cannot convict him of rape. His 2001 sexual scalps weigh so heavily on his belt it's a wonder whether he can stand up straight.

"If he's right about his 2000 women sexual odyssey, he's little more than a walking Viagra tablet."

But there was no levity when his victims testified. They sobbed as they recounted their ordeals.

He was convicted for his first rape, committed in 1981 at knifepoint in his car in High Wycombe. He was charged with a total of five rapes carried out while he lived in the town, and for another three after he moved to London, where he worked as a welder.

The prosecution strategy that led to the groundbreaking House of Lords ruling was masterminded by Treasury counsel David Perry, representing the crown.

With consent the key issue, it allowed him to argue to the jury that his case relied on more than Miss D's word against Edwards's. It allowed him to say the attack on Miss D fitted Edwards's method of raping.

Mr Perry listed 18 similarities between the various rape cases, among them the fact that Edwards maintained they all consented to sex; that victims spoke of him "engineering" the initial meeting; that he took them out on a date; that they described him as "friendly and charming"; and that he "flipped" very quickly from being pleasant to an "aggressive and intimidating person'"

Edwards also ordered the women to strip; the victims all talked of being "frozen" with fear; Edwards was always in control of the situation, ordering his victims to move their bodies as if it was normal intercourse; Edwards never used contraception; once intercourse was over "he reverted to his former self" and there was conversation from him as if nothing untoward had happened.

Twice Edwards called the victims "bitches", twice he said there was no point in them screaming because no one would hear. Two women, one a virgin, said they were raped in the same south London churchyard.

Mr Perry said: "If the defendant is telling the truth you may think he is a very unlucky man.

"Does lightning strike seven times? In the Guinness Book of Records the record for lightning striking a man is nine times and that may be so. But we are not talking about natural phenomena, we are talking about human behaviour.

"The statistical probability is that each of these women are not going to make identical allegations."

Sue Lees, of the University of North London, has studied the crash in conviction rates in rape cases and Edwards's career as a sex attacker: "Juries do not expect serial rapists to be nicely dressed, ordinary men, and don't know about the tactics serial rapists use.

"The balance of the courts is in favour of the defendant, the victim can't meet the prosecution beforehand, and past convictions cannot be introduced except at the discretion of the judge."

The legal device used to introduce the evidence of past attacks of which Edwards was cleared will present prosecutors with new weapons in cases against serial rapists and serial paedophiles.

Considering the rape of Miss D, the jury decided there was too much coincidence in the torrid life of Nicholas Edwards.

Several women said that after raping them, he used the identical words, "I suppose you are going to call this rape". That is what the jury did.

webTitle: Stricter food labelling sought

fields.headline: Stricter food labelling sought
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: The food standards agency is to press for changes in European food labelling rules, to prevent misleading claims, to tighten controls on genetically modified ingredients, and to provide better information for people with allergies.
fields.body:
The food standards agency is to press for changes in European food labelling rules, to prevent misleading claims, to tighten controls on genetically modified ingredients, and to provide better information for people with allergies.

The agency also wants a national code of conduct to prevent the promotion to children of foods that contain excess fat, sugar and salt, and are bad for them. These products are thought to be responsible for obesity and other health problems. It also wants a voluntary agreement with industry to make food labels easier to understand .

The new regime, agreed yesterday, follows nine months of consultation and consumer research. The agency is calling for compulsory EU listing of all ingredients that could cause allergic reactions, and wants to extend the listing to alcoholic drinks.

Misleading health claims - like low fat, fat free and 80% fat free - confuse consumers, according to surveys for the agency, and it will press for legally binding EU standards on nutrition claims and clear nutrition labelling. With one third of consumers still wanting to know if products contained GM ingredients, the agency is calling for clearer regulation on GM free labelling, and a requirement to label if animals have been fed GM products.

A spokesman for Tesco, the supermarket chain, said it was already working in the same direction as the the agency.

webTitle: Anger over NHS treatment of old

fields.headline: Anger over NHS treatment of old
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the future of the NHS
Special report: Liberal Democrat party conference 2000
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats yesterday attacked the "caste system" operating in the NHS as they called for laws banning the rationing of treatment on the basis of age.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats yesterday attacked the "caste system" operating in the NHS as they called for laws banning the rationing of treatment on the basis of age.

On the last day of the party's conference in Bournemouth, Paul Burstow, the Lib Dem spokesman for older people, called on the government to show "zero tolerance" to growing evidence of ageism in the health service.

Such ageism meant two thirds of kidney patients over the age of 70 had been refused dialysis, while women over 65 were not routinely screened for breast cancer, which could account for two thirds of the victims of the disease being in this age group, he said. "It's time the government owned up to age based rationing in the NHS," Mr Burstow went on. "We expect health care to be delivered on the basis of need, not on the basis of a person's date of birth."

The MP for Sutton and Cheam also rounded on Labour for being "complacent" in its initial response to the controversy over the resuscitation of frail and elderly patients.

In April Age Concern revealed doctors sometimes mark very elderly, terminally ill patients' notes DNR (do not resuscitate) without consulting the patient or relatives. In the event of a heart attack, no attempt is made to keep the patient alive on the basis that prolonging treatment will only lead to further suffering.

Earlier this month, the health secretary, Alan Milburn, told NHS trusts that "blanket" DNRs on any group of patients - including the elderly - were not allowed, and advised that patients and relatives should be involved in any decisions on the highly sensitive issue.

But Mr Burstow criticised ministers for initially insisting BMA guidelines adequately protected patients. This failed to account for the "chasm" between recommendations and practice, which meant doctors failed to consult patients in two thirds of cases.

The Lib Dems called for a series of measures to stamp out ageism, and improve elderly patients' NHS treatment, including giving them full access to their medical notes and increased accessibility for the over 60s to flu jabs and cancer screening.

In an earlier debate a significant spending increase was demanded to tackle "under-investment" in the NHS.

Nick Harvey, the party's health spokesman, said the proportion of the nation's GDP spent on health must be in creased to at least that of other European countries. "Only then can we start to address the problems created by 17,000 nurse vacancies and a rate of 1.7 doctors to every 1,000 head of population, compared to a rate of 3.1 in the rest of Europe," he insisted.

The Liberal Democrats are committed to recruiting an extra 5,000 doctors and 20,000 nurses over three years.

One delegate, a nursing auxiliary working in a special care baby unit in Crawley, west Sussex, said staff were leaving the NHS because of poor pay, and pointed out a senior staff nurse earned the same as a print engineer on night shift.

"That's why you are not getting your staff. That's why the (nurses) are leaving in droves. The only difference you can see between an engineer doing that job and a senior special nurse is that, at the end of the day, she has life and death in her hands."

webTitle: 'This is direct democracy'

fields.headline: 'This is direct democracy'
fields.standfirst:
Radim Hladek, 19, is a radical Marxist. He is a law student in Prague and writes articles for anarchist magazines. For weeks he has been preparing for protests against the IMF and World Bank. He says he and his friends plan to bring the Czech capital to a standstill and force the financial institutions to disband.

Special report: The IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: Radim Hladek, 19, is a radical Marxist. He is a law student in Prague and writes articles for anarchist magazines. For weeks he has been preparing for protests against the IMF and World Bank. He says he and his friends plan to bring the Czech capital to a standstill and force the financial institutions to disband.
fields.body:
"I was only nine when the Velvet Revolution brought an end to the former regime. It's largely just a few flashes in my memory, but I do remember the strange atmosphere that pervaded as we watched TV and saw events unfold.

"I put a Czech flag up in the window, as I was feeling a bit patriotic although my parents were afraid the authorities would get angry. It was an experience that helped to shape my personality.

"As we prepare for our demonstrations now, I have similar feelings: in 1989 the protest led to the toppling of a bunch of rulers who were responsible for huge damage and a lot of suffering.

"Those who led the revolution were largely ordinary, like Vaclav Havel, and people thought he could solve their problems, but he has become part of the power machine and is now detached from ordinary people.

"So now, in 2000, we're also hoping to bring a regime to its knees, but this time we want to shift the initiative to the hands of the ordinary people: this is direct democracy.

"I was drawn towards Marxism because as I grew up I was always hearing people denounce it. So, when I was 15, I picked up Das Kapital, and realised Marx was right in his criticism of capitalism. At school I soon began to recognise that the teachers were interpreting our history simply through the eyes of private capitalism and distorting the truth just like the former regime.

"My parents - my father is director of a bakery, and my mother who used to be a clerk at an agricultural cooperative is now unemployed - think I'm a bit of a dreamer. They always tell me my ideas are great, but say it would be impossible for them to be realised. My brother is 17, and doesn't remember the revolution, so he doesn't have the privilege of having lived in the two worlds - of state capitalism and then private capitalism - so he doesn't really understand my ideals.

"I feel great about what's happening in Prague now. There's a great sensation you get from this solidarity from people all around the world who have joined us in the fight. I get a sense of what we could become as a movement. But at the moment we're not strong enough to take control of our lives for the whole year, so we'll just have to make the most of this brief taster."

webTitle: Radio

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: In The Psychiatrist's Chair | Chance Of A Lifetime
fields.body:
The award-winning actor Antony Sher grew up in 1960s South Africa in what he describes as a noisy Jewish family. Now, appearing on In The Psychiatrist's Chair (9.0am, Radio 4), he offers Professor Anthony Clare the astonishing observation that he can sympathise with Germans who claimed they knew nothing about Hitler's concentration camps. His family regularly used to visit the beaches at Seapoint, opposite Nelson Mandela's Robbins Island prison. "But we didn't see it. We closed our eyes in the sun and closed our eyes to the system."

Jean McConnell's Friday Play Chance Of A Lifetime (9.0pm, Radio 4) recalls the 1989 kidnapping in Beirut of the former Battle of Britain Spitfire pilot Jackie Mann. This frail 77-year-old's relationship with his wife Sunnie was often crotchety. But when the authorities and friends urged her to return to the safety of Britain she stubbornly hunkered down in Beirut, fighting a tenacious one-woman campaign for her husband's release.
