webTitle: Over-65s resist flu jabs

fields.headline: Over-65s resist flu jabs
fields.standfirst: Special report: the flu epidemic
fields.trailText: The government's hopes of averting a crisis in the NHS this winter may yet run aground on the reluctance of the over-65s to have a flu jab - because it makes them feel old.
fields.body:
The government's hopes of averting a crisis in the NHS this winter may yet run aground on the reluctance of the over-65s to have a flu jab - because it makes them feel old.

Yesterday the government launched a campaign to persuade more people than ever to have a flu vaccination this winter. For the first time, people over 65 will be able to get one on the NHS - in previous years, this has been limited to those over 75.

But research by the charity Age Concern, published yesterday, suggested that take-up in the extended age group may not be high. Some 47% of over-65s questioned in a survey did not believe they were at risk from flu. A third said they were concerned about possible side-effects of the vaccine. However, 59% said they intended to have a flu jab.

"One of the issues is that older people are reluctant to view themselves as an especially vulnerable group," said an Age Concern spokesman.

The campaign will focus on the most vulnerable - older people, but also those with lung problems and those who live or work in residential and nursing homes. The government is putting in an extra £60m to cover the costs of the campaign, the vaccine, and the extra work of GPs.

Last year there were more than 20,000 deaths from the complications of flu, the highest figure for 10 years.

webTitle: New charge against Shayler

fields.headline: New charge against Shayler
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, was yesterday committed for trial at the Old Bailey on three charges of breaching the Official Secrets Act.
fields.body:
David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, was yesterday committed for trial at the Old Bailey on three charges of breaching the Official Secrets Act.

Mr Shayler, who accuses MI6 of plotting to assassinate the Libyan president, Colonel Gadafy, was informed of a new charge of passing on material obtained through telephone tapping, an offence against section four of the act, at a three minute hearing at Bow Street magistrates' court in central London.

The two other charges, of passing information and documents obtained by virtue of being a member of the security and intelligence services, breach section one of the act.

Reacting to the new charge, Mr Shayler said: "It is very strange that three years after the alleged offences took place the CPS do not have their papers in order and produce this new charge.

"I shall shortly be giving evidence to Special Branch about the Gadafy plot," he said. John Wadham, Mr Shayler's solicitor, told reporters that the new charge related to the same period as the other two charges. "This new charge will make it easier for us at the trial," he said.

A plea and direction hearing at the Old Bailey was set for November 2 and a full trial is expected to begin in six months.

webTitle: Tonight's TV

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Champion | The Hill | Rounders | The Last Days Of Disco
fields.body:
Champion
(Mark Robson, 1949)
7pm, Carlton Cinema

Classic boxing yarn: the hobo-to-hero tale of Midge Kelly (Kirk Douglas), a ruthless manipulator who destroys just about everyone he comes into contact with, in or out of the ring, without getting so much as a cauliflower chin. He has no redeeming features, and any good deed or "sensitive" moment turns out to be a put-on. The direction conspires to soften his character, but a steely-eyed Douglas pulls the movie back on its fatalistic course. Complete with moody noirish photography and brutal fight scenes.

The Hill
(Sidney Lumet, 1965)
9pm, TCM

Intense second world war drama starring Sean Connery as one of five soldiers sent to a North African detention camp ruled by sadistic Sgt Major Wilson (Harry Andrews). Shot in harsh monochrome, and with Michael Redgrave, Ian Hendry and Alfred Lynch in support, it's a blistering attack on a racist and authoritarian regime.

Rounders
(John Dahl, 1998)
9.30pm, Sky MovieMax

An ace account of young law student Matt Damon who realises he has a higher calling in life - playing poker. He loses every last cent to Russian cardsharp John Malkovich (Teddy KGB, they call him) and when buddy Edward Norton, just out of jail and in dire need of paying off his debts, asks for help, it's showdown time. Gretchen Mol plays the girlfriend trying to keep Damon's mind on his studies. Strong on characters, but the gambling scenes don't match up to Jewison's classic The Cincinnati Kid.

The Last Days Of Disco
(Whit Stillman, 1998)
12midnight, Sky Premier Final instalment, after Metropolitan and Barcelona, of Stillman's yuppie-love trilogy, wafting almost gently around the lives of a group of upper-crust young Americans, dispensing sharp satirical stabs of wit. The focus is on Chloë Sevigny (pictured) and an astonishingly adept Kate Beckinsale as junior publishing editors hanging out at a posh disco with the local Harvard set. Perceptive and sophisticated comedy.

webTitle: Arena full of damp canvas holds out distant prospect of a velvet demo

fields.headline: Arena full of damp canvas holds out distant prospect of a velvet demo
fields.standfirst:
Tent city awaits flood of protesters as World Bank denies responsibility for failure to help poor countries

Special report: The IMF and World Bank in Prague
fields.trailText: It is hard to believe that Strahov used to be an object of pride to Prague s citizens. The national stadium, built under the communists, is now a grey crumbling monolith which fails to meet international standards and in recent years has found little use beyond housing a tiny drive-in cinema.
fields.body:
It is hard to believe that Strahov used to be an object of pride to Prague s citizens. The national stadium, built under the communists, is now a grey crumbling monolith which fails to meet international standards and in recent years has found little use beyond housing a tiny drive-in cinema.

What to do with it was a headache for the authorities. Until, that is, the Czech camping king Tomas Doubek announced he could turn it into a "tent city" for the thousands of protesters expected for next week's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank.

Mr Doubek, who manages a tent factory, has acquired the stadium rent-free until September 29, the day after the summit ends.

In return for giving the protesters a place to sleep, wash and eat, the interior ministry has agreed to let him charge £26 admission and to keep all the profits.

So far he has so far ploughed £170,000 into the venture and hopes to reap as much again.

There are enough circus tents, teepees and pup tents pitched neatly in Strahov s midfield to cram in 15,000 protesters.

But yesterday, when the gates officially opened, the rain was tipping down. By mid-afternoon only half a dozen had turned up to claim a place to stay. Journalists, forced to pay a £20 accreditation fee to enter, and the rabbits which hopped around in the grass-covered stands outnumbered the campers many times over.

Mr Doubek said he was unconcerned, since more than 6,000 people had booked a bed on the company's website.

Those who had made it admitted that they were forced to admire a man who could capitalise on anti-capitalism.

"You know, I really resent having to pay some raving capitalist for a bed, said John, 27, an anthropologist from Norwich, who had just arrived by train from Helsinki with his Finnish girlfriend Anneli, 24, a student.

"But I suppose what he's done is quite impressive."

After some deliberation, and realising they would probably not get a cheaper bed elsewhere in town, they decided to stay.

Ushers pointed out the advantages: hot showers, vegetarian and vegan food, an internet cafe, copy shop, newsagents, pet drop-off centre, recycling point and the 200 portable lavatories.

A couple from a local bakery forced by security measures to close during the summit are selling home-made cakes from a tent at very low prices.

"It has the air of a village fete," John said, before wandering around the empty tents and picking number 28.

But many were quick to point to the possible disadvantages of staying at Strahov, mainly its out-of-the-way location in north-west Prague.

"I'd be too scared to stay here," said Sabine Fastner, 31, a free-trade economics teacher from Munich.

She opted for a £3.50 a night campsite on an island on the Vltava river.

"A lot of activists are concerned that the police could hermetically seal the area and block all of us in here, which would be a disaster for the Prague 2000 protest."

Mr Doubek, once a boy scout, says his initiative could begin a new era globalisation protest, and obviously fancies himself as the man who will earn Prague the reputation of the world's most protester-friendly city.

"If you give these people a place to sleep, take showers and have decent food, they're more likely to protest sensibly.

"The authorities are also very happy that they won't be sleeping in the parks and shop doorways.

"We have a dream that having shown the world the Velvet Revolution of 1989, we could soon show them the Velvet Demonstrations of 2000."

webTitle: TV: who is themed TV really benefiting

fields.headline: Themes and variations
fields.standfirst: We've had 70s Night, Blue Peter Night, and even an evening of Stirling Moss. Now Channel 5 are hosting Abba Day. But who is themed TV really benefiting, asks  Belinda Archer  . Viewers? Or could it be lazy station bosses?
fields.trailText: We've had 70s Night, Blue Peter Night, and even an evening of Stirling Moss. Now Channel 5 are hosting Abba Day. But who is themed TV really benefiting, asks Belinda Archer . Viewers? Or could it be lazy station bosses?
fields.body:
Even by Channel 5's standards, this Sunday's programming is close to the knuckle. At a time when children may be watching, the nation's most controversial station will be devoting the afternoon to the graphic exploits of two Swedish women and their partners. Unusually for Channel 5, all will be fully clad. Instead, viewers will be treated to X-rated, hardcore close-ups of flared trousers, satin bomber jackets and knee-length sequinned boots.

It is, of course, Abba Day, a scheduling tour de force which will include such treats as Abba Jukebox (a 30-minute showcase of their top ten most popular videos), 100% Abba (a quiz show, all about Abba trivia) and even a one-hour documentary on tribute band Bjorn Again. But if kitsch isn't your bag, tune in to Channel 4 the following Saturday. Heralded as "a landmark evening", John Lennon Night offers four hours of dedicated programming to celebrate what would have been the late Beatle's 60th birthday.

Such "themed" slots have been part of TV's scheduling mix since the early 90s - when BBC2 led the way with an Arena Food Night special - and now seem to be becoming more and more frequent and sophisticated. But what is the thinking behind them? Who watches them? Are they just a marketing ploy? A bit of fun? Or do they actually boost ratings?

Adam Perry, controller of special events at Channel 5, thinks the latter. "Themed weekends really drive viewers," he claims. "Ours tend to be male-oriented, and that's because we are more male-oriented than other channels anyway. By doing these, we can get more young males than we would otherwise."

It is debatable, however, whether anyone actually does sit through the entire event, from start to finish. Obviously, the hope is that if a viewer is interested in, say, sharks, then they might be interested in any number of different programmes about, um, sharks, but the battle is just the same as with ordinary programming to retain audiences. Industry estimates suggest that viewers will sample any given one-hour programme for, on average, between 17 and 27 minutes before reaching for the remote (or 12 minutes in a half-hour show). Loyalty is really a thing of the fondly remembered, four-channel past.

But David Mortimer, editorial executive of BBC2, insists "Viewers really do commit, especially when we screen big themes such as I Love The 70s, rather than one-off subjects. They are "appointment" television, and whereas in the past the programming was quite short and broken up, we're now using much bigger chunks that keep the viewers from one slot to the next."

Audiences can certainly be spectacular for these TV specials. BBC2 had a massive success with its Blue Peter Night, for instance, which garnered over four million eager Shep fans. Channel 5 also screened its inaugural Abba weekend last summer and pulled in an audience three times bigger than usual, while BBC2's I Love The 70s themed series has been attracting over four million punters regularly - double its usual audiences for Saturday nights.

But by the same token, ratings can dip just as dramatically - especially if the theme is wrong for the station or badly targeted or promoted. Extensive market research, for instance, suggested that Channel 5 was on to a sure-fire winner by staging a dedicated Valentine's Night on February 14 last year. There was an impeccable logic, of course: women love romance and would therefore lap up a mix of slushy movies, documentaries on lurve and a soft-focused mini-series starring several lantern-jawed men. Sadly, the station recorded its worst Sunday night ratings in over two years - it was, concludes Perry, "the wrong theme for our audience".

BBC2 experienced a similar disappointment when they attempted to capitalise on the Bridget Jones phenomenon and screened a night of dedicated "singleton" programming, while Channel 4 did a Stirling Moss evening that (perhaps not surprisingly) attracted just 600,000 viewers across the whole night. "A theme can turn someone off as much as on," concedes Channel 4 spokesman Alan McLaughlin, "and that's the whole evening gone if it isn't really someone's bag. You've got to be very targeted and you have to know your audience; the timing's got to be right as well as the relevance."

Since their launch, themes have come in just about every imaginable shape and size. We've had Charlie's Angels nights, we've had something called Wild, Wet And Windy (an entire weekend of programming about freak weather conditions), we've had martial arts specials and even TV Deaths, a rather desperate series featuring the most high-profile exits from the world of telly (kicking off with an intro by Leslie "Dirty Den" Grantham filmed in Kensal Rise Cemetery).

And now, given their overall success, the word is that we are going to get even more. Channel 5 says it likes to do one a month - "if not more" - while Channel 4 says there is "no set limit" to the number of zoned evenings it will treat us all to.

"They're great pegs around which to promote," says Perry. "If you have a theme, you can give people a coherence that they want to come to. They're a very, very strong promotional device..."

webTitle: The Guzzler

fields.headline: The Guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | Food on the net | Just out: Benecol Light Cream Cheese Spread | On the menu: beignet
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

The Patio Restaurant , 13 Swinegate Court East, York YO1 8AJ. Tel: 01904 627879.

A hidden gem in a rather too real sense: by the time you've actually located Patio you might actually have worked up a sufficient appetite. A bright stripped-wood interior is the setting for a menu blending northern British and Mediterranean. More than acceptable starters include delectable ptés and deep-fried Camembert (£2.95 to £4.95). The highlight of the main courses, at £6.95, is the seasoned Cumberland bangers with onions, gravy and a memorably creamy mash. There's also loin of lamb stuffed with garlic in a redcurrant and rosemary sauce at £8.95, as well as veggie options.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Pavement Cafe Bar , 10a New Street, York YO1 8RA. Tel: 01904 634321.

Trendy bars are invading York with gusto, but Pavement sets itself apart from the marauding hordes by being independently run, rather more mellow and tiny. Barely 20 people can squeeze inside the blue and bare-brick interior. The menu - consisting of light meals priced at around a fiver a dish - sports a fine tomato and mozzarella melt, generously filled pitta breads (including a lip-smacking chicken tikka) and a variety of home-made quiches and soups. Later in the day shoppers give way to the evening drinking crowd indulging in philosophical musings over their beers and lattes.

Food on the net

www.morel.co.uk

Internet arm of Morel Bros., Cobbett & Son, the high-class mail-order firm specialising in gourmet groceries.

Pros:
An impressive range of fresh foods and plenty for the pantry: flavoured olive oils and balsamic vinegars, foie gras and Nairobi coffees.

Cons:
Struggling to maintain its reputation for out-of-the-ordinary foods as specialist lines become more widely available.

Delivery:
Normally within 10 days, but during peak periods customers are advised to allow up to 21 days for standard orders.

Charges:
£3.95 for standard UK delivery. £7.95 for fresh food orders.

Coming up:
Christmas treats, more chocolates and a £5.95 flat rate delivery charge from the end of October.

Just out: Benecol Light Cream Cheese Spread

Form:
Semi-set plaster of paris.

Flavour:
Semi-set plaster of Paris with a scintilla of cheese; dense and claggy.

Verdict:
Benecol products contain plant stanol ester, which, it is claimed, reduces low-density lipoprotein (bad) cholesterol by "up to 14%". There's 8% of the ester in each 200g tub, but then there's 58% cultured skimmed milk, not to mention butter, cream powder and milk proteins. No cheese, oddly enough. There are 170 calories per 100g. It isn't actively unpleasant and it won't do you any harm (unless, possibly, you're a pregnant or lactating woman - see the very small print).

Price:
£2.49 per 200g.

On the menu: beignet

How do you pronounce it?
Baynyay, as in French.

Is it a food?
No. It's a cookery term.

So why are you bothering me with cookery terms this week?
Because chic chefs seem to have suddenly rediscovered the art of the beignet after years in the wilderness.

Such as?
Skate beignets, peach beignets, cauliflower beignets.

How do I spot a beignet at 10 paces?
By the light, deep-fried batter on the outside.

Aha! It's a fritter! Why didn't you say?
Because it can also be a choux pastry bun filled with ham - or ham and cheese - in the savoury section, or jam if you're looking for pudding.

So there's no end to the versatility of the beignet?
Who knows?

webTitle: Maggie Brown's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Maggie Brown's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Maggie Brown's TV gossip
fields.body:
During the fuel crisis, a picket was spotted with the following slogan: "Tony Blair. The Weakest Link. Out." Slick London media types will be hard-pressed to place this reference to the latest thing getting under the nation's skin, but teatime viewers know exactly what it refers to.

The Weakest Link is a new daily (5.15pm) BBC2 quiz show with a difference, hosted by Anne Robinson absconding from Watchdog. Its debut has been so successful, BBC2 this week ordered up an extra 90 shows, which means that it will run continuously to next summer. Devised by BBC's smart head of entertainment, David Young, who learnt his lessons at Peter (Big Brother) Bazalgette's knee, it's a show with claws - BBC2 controller Jane Root dubs it "Mean TV". At the end of each round of questions, contestants hold up the name of the person they think is the worst performer (viewers are told statistically who ought to go), and the one with most votes is asked to leave, with a curt "bye" from Robinson.

So its main audience comprises pensioners and housewives who've lapped up Countdown and Fifteen To One and then swell the figures for Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? But while Chris Tarrant wills contestants to win, Robinson, in black trouser suit and wire-framed spectacles, is beastly, as eight contestants struggle against each other to bank a measly thousand or two. "Who is causing this dismal performance?" she taunts, as the team clocks up £20 in a round when £1,000 is on offer. "One of you is about to leave with nothing."

Now, with audiences of around three million and a gush of complaints from blue-rinse viewers, the show is set to make an unexpected entry into the BBC2 top ten. "We went on our instincts," says Jane Lush, head of daytime television, "not showing it to focus groups, who would have said 'too cruel'." Expect it to run for years.

Devised by BBC's smart head of entertainment, David Young, who learnt his lessons at Peter (Big Brother) Bazalgette's knee, it's a show with claws - BBC2 controller Jane Root dubs it "Mean TV". At the end of each round of questions, contestants hold up the name of the person they think is the worst performer (viewers are told statistically who ought to go), and the one with most votes is asked to leave, with a curt "bye" from Robinson. So its main audience comprises pensioners and housewives who've lapped up Countdown and Fifteen To One and then swell the figures for Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? But while Chris Tarrant wills contestants to win, Robinson, in black trouser suit and wire-framed spectacles, is beastly, as eight contestants struggle against each other to bank a measly thousand or two. "Who is causing this dismal performance?" she taunts, as the team clocks up £20 in a round when £1,000 is on offer. "One of you is about to leave with nothing." Now, with audiences of around three million and a gush of complaints from blue-rinse viewers, the show is set to make an unexpected entry into the BBC2 top ten. "We went on our instincts," says Jane Lush, head of daytime television, "not showing it to focus groups, who would have said 'too cruel'." Expect it to run for years.

webTitle: They thought it was all over

fields.headline: They thought it was all over
fields.standfirst: Two years ago he was about to abandon musicals. But then he met Ben Elton. Their new show opens in the West End next week - and Andrew Lloyd Webber looks like he may have another hit on his hands.  Stephen Moss  meets the man Britain loves to hate
fields.trailText: Two years ago he was about to abandon musicals. But then he met Ben Elton. Their new show opens in the West End next week - and Andrew Lloyd Webber looks like he may have another hit on his hands. Stephen Moss meets the man Britain loves to hate
fields.body:
Why does Andrew Lloyd Webber generate such loathing? A friend, on hearing that I was interviewing him, told me she would never speak to me again if I said he was a good composer. He was, she insisted, a borrower of other people's tunes and Rachmaninov should have got a royalty for Aspects of Love. Victor Lewis-Smith, the scabrous TV critic of the London Evening Standard, said much the same thing this week, adding for good measure that Lord L-W was "plug ugly".

The latter can be quickly dealt with: he isn't particularly. He would be the first to admit that he is no oil painting, but then neither is Lewis-Smith. The music is trickier. There are clearly many influences on Lloyd Webber's tunes and you often feel you've heard them somewhere before, but nothing has ever been proved and litigants who have pursued him on grounds of plagiarism have always lost.

Lloyd Webber's new show, The Beautiful Game, opens next Tuesday at London's Cambridge Theatre. It marks a key moment in his career, because his last two shows - Sunset Boulevard and Whistle Down the Wind - failed to set the West End on fire and only two years ago he appeared to be on the point of abandoning musicals. "I thought I'd write an art book or something," he said.

That was before a dinner with Ben Elton that, in the best let's-do-the-show-right-here traditions, changed everything. "I thought I was beginning to tread water a bit with Whistle Down the Wind," Lloyd Webber told me when we met at the Really Useful Group's really lovely office in Soho. "So when Ben said he would be interested in writing with me it was a breath of fresh air. If musical theatre is to have a relevance, from time to time we have to take on subjects that are challenging, or we might as well be doing nothing but revivals. You can't go on looking back, and maybe I'm guilty of having looked back a little bit myself in one or two of my recent things. Now I feel refreshed."

In late 1998, Lloyd Webber had approached Elton to provide some new material for Starlight Express. Elton said no to that but suggested, as the wine flowed, that they collaborate on a contemporary piece. Lloyd Webber recalled seeing a TV programme about a group of Irish youngsters who played in a non-sectarian football team and, a few weeks later, Elton turned in a 40-page synopsis.

Lloyd Webber has taken some stick for "stealing" the story of the Belfast-based Star of the Sea team, for whom the hunger striker Bobby Sands played as a boy. The accusation is academic since there is no copyright on a life story, but Lloyd Webber may be sensitive to it as he says he does not recall the precise programme that triggered his interest.

"I remember seeing a documentary about young children in northern Ireland," he says. "Apparently there were several documentaries and I can't remember which one it was. I thought if you have something like a team, it's a bit like the pub in EastEnders - you've got a forum in which things can happen. It's not really about football at all. It struck me that there was just possibly the germ of an idea there. I have a hundred ideas like this all the time; this happened to be the first one I mentioned to Ben and he happened to pick up on it."

The musical follows the lives of the teenage players and their girlfriends as they grow up during the Troubles. There is a murder, a riot and an on-stage kneecapping. Critically, much will hinge on whether the bleak storyline, Elton's jokes and Lloyd Webber's lush music cohere. The story of young love in a divided community echoes West Side Story, and such comparisons might not favour Lloyd Webber, but it is a serious attempt to write a musical of and for our times. "We tried not to trivialise it and went for a tougher ending," he says. "We were very keen not to go for a sentimental ending."

Lloyd Webber once said that he didn't mind people hating his music, but he did dislike those who questioned his integrity. It's a fair point. The art is a legitimate target - can complex politics be got across in a few anthemic songs? - but the intention is not. He has been criticised for latching on to the trendy subject of football, but, as he says, that is only a starting point for the show. In any case, he is no latecomer to the game, having supported Leyton Orient since he was a boy (his mother used to drop him off at the ground while she taught piano to impoverished pupils in east London).

Lloyd Webber has the look of a man who thinks he has a hit on his hands, but doesn't want to tempt fate by saying so. "It's going the same way as Cats went. The box office took off last week. It's one of those shows that might have a lousy first night for some reason, and it might not fly, but it has had a couple of preview nights when it has flown."

Lloyd Webber looks a great deal happier than he did in 1997 when troubles were coming, as ever, in battalions. Polygram had bought a majority stake in his company and was threatening to take full control, which would have meant him losing his lucrative copyrights. Sunset Boulevard had underperformed, hitting the Really Useful Group's profitability. Then, as the election loomed, he became a national laughing stock when he was reported (wrongly, he insists) as saying that he would leave the country if Labour won. Wags put much of the huge Labour majority down to his intervention.

The real crisis was the potential loss of the copyrights. "That would have taken control of the company away from me," he says. "We had to stop that somehow and due to various twists of fate we were terribly lucky and pulled off the impossible." The company is now entirely his again, though he says he is hands off.

"We have very good people here and if they want to do something I let them get on and do it. For example, they're developing a musical with the Pet Shop Boys at the moment. This is written up in the press as Lloyd Webber produces Pet Shop Boys, but of course it isn't. What we're thinking of doing, to allow the young people here some space, is having a wholly owned subsidiary with a different name, so that Really Useful doesn't produce anything other than mine. There are a couple of plays they've optioned, and that appears in the press as me doing it. But plays are not my forte."

Lloyd Webber is both composer and businessman: he writes musicals for a West End that is now largely owned by his company. The Really Useful Group's travails in the mid-90s made him realise that the days of the blockbuster were over. The Beautiful Game is accordingly less extravagant than some of its predecessors, a return to the relative simplicity of Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat. He thinks Sunset Boulevard, a perfectly good show in his view, was sunk by its extravagance. "There were places where it could never make money. It shouldn't have been done. You can't have a show that will only work if it's playing at 90% capacity." His rule of thumb now is that investors should recoup their money in under a year with a show running at 85% capacity.

Sorting out the politics has been almost as difficult as regaining control of the business. He denies that he threatened to leave the country if Labour were elected. What he actually said was that a high-tax regime would cause technicians to leave, and that in turn would make it hard for him to work here. He was ennobled by John Major and still takes the Conservative whip in the Lords, but he says he is a most reluctant Tory.

"I knew John Major and liked him a lot, but I'm not sure what I'm going to do in the future. I think that, despite the glitch that is happening at the moment, this government has done pretty well. I'm not a particular fan of the opposition. I voted with the government on section 28 because I felt very strongly that that was wrong; so I don't know that I am necessarily a natural conservative. I'm lucky in one sense that I'm not in the House of Lords as a working peer. I'm an honorary peer and I took the Tory whip because I knew that John Major must have had a huge hand in it. In my heart of hearts I know that I'm a cross-bencher."

He enjoys making occasional interventions in public affairs. He wrote to the Telegraph last week to suggest that the Dome be burned in a conflagration that would attract paying spectators (his old collaborator Tim Rice called him to say the letter was the best thing he had written since Evita). He also wrote a column for three years for the Telegraph - he gave it up to write The Beautiful Game - and says he misses it.

Perhaps he is loathed because, like Melvyn Bragg, he won't stay in his artistic box. He is composer, entrepreneur and public figure: bright, opinionated and uncompromising. He is also, of course, extremely rich, with a personal fortune of £420m, according to the Sunday Times Rich List. He and his third wife, Madeleine, own a stud; they have racehorses; he has the world's finest collection of pre-Raphaelite paintings; he once shelled out £18m for a Picasso.

Artists are supposed to be broke; he manifestly isn't. Artists are collected; he collects, with the obsessiveness of the small boy who adored trains. He is a curious and interesting figure: steeped in serious music yet in love with musical theatre; rich enough not to fret about politics but fretting anyway; oddly delighted to have won an award at the Newbury show last weekend for his organic peas; and anxious enough to run out into the street in the rain to give me the name of a horse of his that he thinks will win at Ascot tomorrow. Crystal Music. That's the horse, not a comment on the show, just in case my Lloyd Webber-loathing friend was worrying.

webTitle: Obituaries; Gherman Titov

fields.headline: Gherman Titov
fields.standfirst: Quiet hero of the Soviet Union's second manned space mission
fields.trailText: One of the most evocative photos of the space age shows a white-suited astronaut standing on the grey and dead surface of the moon. The visor of his helmet reflects barren surroundings and maintains his anonymity. Just visible in the reflection is the photographer, Neil Armstrong. While many people could name Armstrong as an astronaut, far fewer remember Buzz Aldrin, the subject of Armstrong's epochal image - and the second man to walk on the moon. The selectivity of fame, as it immortalises the "first" but becomes hazy on the "second", proves as fickle with the first ever spacemen.
fields.body:
One of the most evocative photos of the space age shows a white-suited astronaut standing on the grey and dead surface of the moon. The visor of his helmet reflects barren surroundings and maintains his anonymity. Just visible in the reflection is the photographer, Neil Armstrong. While many people could name Armstrong as an astronaut, far fewer remember Buzz Aldrin, the subject of Armstrong's epochal image - and the second man to walk on the moon. The selectivity of fame, as it immortalises the "first" but becomes hazy on the "second", proves as fickle with the first ever spacemen.

The Soviet Union's first cosmonaut, Yuri Gagarin, rocketed into the collective consciousness of the world when his Vostok 1 opened the era of manned space flight in April 1961 with an orbit of the earth. But the name of his successor, Gherman Titov, who has died aged 65, is only familiar to the history books and aficionados of space flight.

Titov piloted Vostok 2, but had also been the back-up cosmonaut to Gagarin. This meant that he had to train with, and mirror, Gagarin's preparations right up until their walk to the launch site of Vostok 1, at the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, 1,300 miles from Moscow. But Gagarin remained fit, and Titov had to wait until August 6 1961 for his turn.

The timing of Vostok 2 was decided by Nikita Khrushchev. So great had been the global reception accorded to Gagarin that the then Soviet leader realised that, in the space programme, he had a formidable propaganda weapon. Titov's mission was therefore timed to occur just a few days before construction of the Berlin Wall was started.

Titov's space flight lasted just over one day, in which he completed 16 orbits of the earth. He took photographs of the seas and land, blurred by the speed of his spacecraft, and, unlike Gagarin, experimented in steering the Vostok. A naturally quiet man, he was none the less elated with the experience and shouted over the radio, "I am Eagle" - Vostok 1's call sign - as he hurtled around the planet.

Less enjoyable was the first manifestation of space sickness, the nausea felt by many astronauts and cosmonauts as their inner ears struggle to deal with weightless conditions. Titov was simply trying to get to sleep, and it was when he closed his eyes that the waves of sickness came over. He persisted, and by keeping as still as he could, eventually managed a healthy eight hours, 30 minutes more than that originally allocated.

This quiet determination was characteristic of the man, and still evident in his polite reluctance to talk openly when I met him briefly in Stockholm in 1998.

Titov was born in the village of Verkhneye Zhilino, in the Altay republic of western Siberia. His father, a language teacher, instilled in his son a love of poetry that stayed with him for the rest of his life. Many were the times he would reel off verses from memory for his fellow cosmonauts. His sophistication did not hold him back from adventure, and, in 1953, he enrolled as a aviation cadet. By 1957, he had graduated from the Volgograd Air Force Pilots Training School and, in 1960, he was selected as one of the "six", the Soviet Union's first group of cosmonauts.

That Titov made it this far was all the more remarkable because of an old injury that he had nursed through hundreds of gruelling hours spent training. As a child, he has fallen from his bicycle and broken his wrist. So severe was the fracture, and in order to hide it from the officials, that he put in an extra hour of training before his scheduled gymnasium sessions to warm up his painful bones and ligaments. This steely reserve was there for all to see when, during training for Vostok, he set a record of 15 hours in the isolation tank.

Titov never flew a second space mission, although he was selected as lead cosmonaut for the ambitious Spiral spaceplane project in the late 1960s. He furthered his qualifications and, in 1968, graduated from the Zhukovsky Air Force Engineering Academy. Spiral was a small, two-manned interceptor boosted into the upper atmosphere by a larger hypersonic aircraft. Drop tests were carried out with unmanned BOR vehicles, but the programme was cancelled in 1968. Titov also worked on the early Salyut space stations, which were essentially manned military reconnaissance platforms.

His great disappointment was in not being able to see the prediction he made in 1965 come true: "I myself dream of flying around the moon. Today's cosmonauts have a good chance of getting a close look at the moon." Alas, as the former Soviet Union crumbled, so too did Titov's dream.

In later years, he continued to promote space flight. Then, in 1995, his career moved with the times and he entered politics. He had served as a deputy of the Supreme Soviet between 1962 and 1970, but was now elected to the lower house of the Russian parliament. Titov was married with two children.

Gherman Stepanovich Titov, cosmonaut, born September 11 1935; died September 20 2000

webTitle: Obituaries; David Aidley

fields.headline: David Aidley
fields.standfirst: Animal biologist who enthused his students with grace and wit
fields.trailText: David Aidley, who has died aged 63, was a member of a small group of animal biologists and biophysicists who came together in the 1960s in the newly-founded University of East Anglia (UEA) with a brief to design and establish a school of biological sciences fully integrated in all its teaching, research and administrative activities.
fields.body:
David Aidley, who has died aged 63, was a member of a small group of animal biologists and biophysicists who came together in the 1960s in the newly-founded University of East Anglia (UEA) with a brief to design and establish a school of biological sciences fully integrated in all its teaching, research and administrative activities.

When he arrived at UEA in 1967 as a lecturer, Aidley immediately saw, and supported throughout his career, the advantages of a "school" structure. While completing his book, The Physiology Of Excitable Cells, he realised the importance of a sound physico-chemical understanding, and was influenced by the discussions he had with colleagues in the school, and the ease with which such boundary crossing could occur. He entered into the early debates about the structure of the school and its courses with knowledge and enthusiasm. In discussion, he was wise, steady and reliable.

Aidley's academic background had been traditional. He attended Manchester grammar school from 1948 to 1955, leaving with a scholarship to Queens' College, Cambridge, where, and after two years of national service in the RAF, he read the natural sciences tripos, with zoology as his specialist subject, graduating in 1960. His postgraduate research in the general field of insect neuro-muscular physiology was supervised at Cambridge by JWS Pringle and AL Hodgkin. His first job was as a demonstrator in zoology at Oxford University in 1963, and he received his PhD a year later.

Aidley was an excellent teacher; his practical classes, based on the profligate use of plasticine, were a delight. The extent of his interests was amazing. In 1967, he joined the Amazon expedition of the Alpha Helix, a research vessel from the Scripps Institute, La Jolla, California. On that trip, he became interested in insect sound production and hearing. In 1973-74, he went to the International Centre of Insect Physiology in Nairobi, where he carried out research on the physiology and migratory behaviour of the African armyworm, a pest of grasses. He also developed his interests in ornithology and bird migration, and he and his wife, Jessica, did a lot of field work together.

This period in Nairobi triggered a deep interest in African biology, and he returned in 1980-82, first as a visiting researcher in ornithology, and latterly as visiting professor and head of department at Bayero University, in Kano, Nigeria.

Aidley's books are also a delight. He had a most unusual talent for explaining difficult scientific concepts. His style was graceful and his aim in identifying the crucial experimental evidence was unerring. His most notable achievement remains his first book on excitable cells, now in its fourth edition. He recently launched another specialist book (written with PR Stanfield) called Ion Channels: Molecules In Action, which was well reviewed and is proving popular. In between, Aidley wrote several reviews, an elementary text (with RD Keynes) on nerve and muscle, and edited a book on animal migration.

He was a keen bibliophile and, as chairman of the university library committee, devised a programme of budget cuts based on sound psephological principles, which he published in the British Journal of Academic Librarianship. He also wrote Analyse Your Diet, a computer programme for students to analyse their daily intake of nutrients and consider the implications, which sold well commercially.

Although he was still "living with questions", Aidley was a Christian, who believed that man's role on earth was to serve others, as he did, genially and diffidently.

His first marriage, to Patricia, ended in divorce. His marriage to Jessica in 1971 was a deeply happy partnership and they had four children: Richard, Timothy, Kate and Jack. They all survive him.

webTitle: Indian troop recall shifts onus to Nato

fields.headline: Indian troop recall shifts onus to Nato
fields.standfirst:
The UN's peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone is in more disarray following the withdrawal of 3,000 soldiers

Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: At least one Nato country is expected to dispatch troops to Sierra Leone to bolster the crumbling United Nations peacekeeping force following India's decision yesterday to withdraw its 3,000 soldiers and abandon command of the operation, according to western diplomatic sources.
fields.body:
At least one Nato country is expected to dispatch troops to Sierra Leone to bolster the crumbling United Nations peacekeeping force following India's decision yesterday to withdraw its 3,000 soldiers and abandon command of the operation, according to western diplomatic sources.

The Indian pullout comes amid bitter infighting with the Nigerian contingent, and follows accusations of weak leadership and fears that the mission could collapse because of poor quality troops and equipment.

The UN security council has already agreed to increase the size of the largest peacekeeping operation in the world to 20,500 troops. With the withdrawal of the Indians, about 10,000 new soldiers now have to be found to serve in Sierra Leone.

The sources said that a sizeable number is likely to be drawn from one or more eastern European members of Nato and from Latin America, but that agreements with the governments concerned have to be finalised.

Britain has ruled out joining the UN force in Sierra Leone although it has more than 200 soldiers there to train the new army and to provide security.

The decision to bring in European and Latin American troops is a marked shift away from the UN security council's - and consequently the British and American - policy of encouraging regional peacekeeping forces in Africa.

It comes amid accusations that western nations are not prepared to risk the lives of white soldiers in Africa, and much hand wringing by world leaders at the millennium summit earlier this month over the dire state of peacekeeping on the continent.

Although the Indians say their withdrawal is routine and expected, it follows a stinging attack by the force's Indian commander, General Vijay Jetley, on the sizeable Nigerian contingent in Sierra Leone.

In a confidential report first made public in the Guardian, Gen Jetley accused Nigerian political and military officials at the top of the UN mission of "sabotaging peace" in favour of national interests, and alleged that Nigerian army commanders illegally mined diamonds in league with Revolutionary United Front rebels.

After the report was published, the Nigerian army called for Gen Jetley's immediate resignation and said it could no longer work with him. But the general's comments reflected considerable concern within the UN mission about the conduct and intent of the Nigerian army which has plundered Liberia and Sierra Leone during earlier military interventions.

The Indian withdrawal could be a blow to the British strategy in Sierra Leone of pushing the UN into confronting the RUF through a peace enforcement role while trying to keep the Nigerians from taking control. But it might also prove an opportunity if it can be used to persuade other European armies to join the peacekeeping force and provide the quality of troops and equipment now lacking.

The Jordanian contingent - whose troops were strongly criticised for fraternising with the West Side Boys who abducted 11 British soldiers last month - has added to the pressure for western involvement by saying that it too may pull out unless at least one Nato country sends troops.

Britain's minister for Africa, Peter Hain, who ruled out direct UK participation in the peacekeeping mission yesterday, said that the UN force would not be allowed to collapse.

"All options are being explored with member countries, including Nato countries, but Britain is very overstretched in Kosovo, with Iraq and in Northern Ireland," he said. "There will be a fully fledged UN peacekeeping operation in Sierra Leone. It will be a better force with an improved command structure."

The Sierra Leone army has occupied the village of Magbeni, one of two West Side Boys bases stormed by British troops earlier this month. The Sierra Leone military said its troops "encountered no resistance".

webTitle: Diary aids search for ex-PoWs

fields.headline: Diary aids search for ex-PoWs
fields.trailText: A poignant personal account of a young British soldier's experiences in the second world war was revealed by the Ministry of Defence yesterday as part of an effort to return the papers, medals and other possessions of former prisoners of war.
fields.body:
A poignant personal account of a young British soldier's experiences in the second world war was revealed by the Ministry of Defence yesterday as part of an effort to return the papers, medals and other possessions of former prisoners of war.

Combining light-hearted episodes with moments of fear, the diary is written in pencil on a battered spiral-bound notebook and begins with the author's decision to sign up on September 3 1939.

The next entry is for November 15, when he enlists and notes: "Parents furious".

The diarist, a driver with the Royal Army Service Corps, sails to France in February 1940. By the end of the month he is in Nantes "with my pal, having the time of my life, don't know there is a war on".

In April, he tells of a whirlwind romance with a "nice- looking" French girl. Soon he notes "affair going strong, promised to marry her".

On April 18, when he hears that Belgium has capitulated, he writes: "Now we shall know all about it"; "have told my wife to evacuate".

His first taste of warfare comes on April 22 when his lorry is machine gunned and he writes: "Am I scared."

The author returns to Britain in July 1940, and then embarks for the Middle East. The diary reflects the ebb and flow of allied and German offensives in the Western Desert. The last entries are for January 23 and 24 1942. One reads: "General Rummil's [Rommel] army breaks through. I am left on the desert on my own, enemy armerd [armoured] troops about."

Alex Ward, head of Army historical branch at the MoD, said: "Perhaps the author was captured there and his German captors took his diary then. Perhaps he lost it and the Germans found it in the desert, or perhaps he was killed during the subsequent fighting. Unless we can identify him, we shall never know."

Possessions taken from the PoWs were sent to Berlin, where they were seized by the Russians when the Red Army occupied the city in 1945.

Efforts to trace the diarist, and 79 other former PoWs, began in 1997 when the Russian government handed over photocopies of old British paybooks and diaries to Tony Blair. The originals were given to Robin Cook last year. All but 25 of the rightful owners, including the anonymous soldier, have been traced.

On November 7, the defence minister, Lewis Moonie, will return the possessions to surviving veterans and the families of those who died, at a cere mony at the Imperial War Museum, London.

webTitle: Lavish spending union told to make £3m savings

fields.headline: Lavish spending union told to make £3m savings
fields.trailText: The troubled Manufacturing, Science and Finance union is being asked to impose an emergency £3m savings package to balance its books in the wake of a year of overspending and huge payouts to staff.
fields.body:
The troubled Manufacturing, Science and Finance union is being asked to impose an emergency £3m savings package to balance its books in the wake of a year of overspending and huge payouts to staff.

A confidential report from the union's accountants, HW Fisher, which was discussed by the union's finance and general purposes committee yesterday, calls for the union to impose £3m savings and introduce a virtual freeze on most activities until the end of this year.

One senior MSF officer told the Guardian: "We are facing a financial catastrophe". The accountants' report offers a series of unpalatable options to prevent the union going permanently into the red.

These include selling either the union's Dublin headquarters, housed in the former American embassy, or its residential training institution, Whitehall College at Bishop's Stortford in Hertfordshire, and imposing big cuts on staff by reducing the headcount from the present 375 to a maximum of 300.

Proposals discussed include scrapping an autumn campaign on health and safety issues in the workplace; wholesale cancellation of union publications until the end of the year; reducing union training courses at the college, including new ones on equal opportunities for women and ethnic minorities; banning officials from travelling to meet one another on union business; and cancelling meetings of sector committees to discuss industry issues.

The cuts arrive as Roger Lyons, the union's general secretary, has come under fire for alleged lavish expense claims, and for losing and then having to settle a series of employment tribunal cases, which have cost members £900,000.

Allegations were made by one "whistleblower", Marcia Solomon, who won a £50,000 settlement for unfair dismissal, that Mr Lyons and Nelson Mendes, head of the finance department, fiddled thousands of pounds in expenses.

Mr Mendes is on sick leave, and according to a national executive report is not likely to work for the union again.

The union has instructed lawyers to fight an unfair dismissal case being brought by Bryan Keegan, former chauffeur to the general secretary, which is due to be heard in January.

Lawyers are also being asked to take action to close down a website run by MSF member David Beaumont, which details Mr Lyons' alleged expense claims, lists articles in the press on the lifestyle of the general secretary, and reports on tribunal cases.

The union is having to pay back £600,000 a year to the banks to cut its overdraft and needs to put aside £750,000 fully to fund its pension scheme. Earlier this year the union's pension trustees in their report indicated "dismay and anger" over Mr Lyons' failing to consult them on a £200,000 payout to three senior union staff who took early retirement.

Minutes of MSF's finance committee and national executive for the last four months - obtained by the Guardian - revealed a steadily deteriorating financial situation as the union lost a series of tribunal cases.

Last year the union was running a £182,000 surplus each month. By last April the surplus had dwindled to £4,000 a month, falling to £2,200 a month in May.

The national executive was told in June by HW Fisher that to remain viable "on an income of £26m, the union should be generating a 'basic' surplus of £1m per annum as a minimum level for an efficient organisation."

The report added the union could not continue to pay £600,000 off its overdraft by selling property, and that pension contributions would have to increase from 6% to 19% to protect the scheme.

The July finance committee was told that savings of £2m were urgently required - but the committee told the accountants these savings were now not enough and ordered them back for a rethink.

Other changes being implemented include new expenses forms, which for the first time require NEC members and the general secretary to obtain counter-signatures.

Paul Talbot, secretary to the finance committee, said last night: "These recommendations from the accountants are good housekeeping measures. Our aim is to bring more management control into the union without stopping our frontline activities.It is part of ongoing discussion on how we run our finances over the next three years."

The union insisted that its finances were stable.

webTitle: Bishops take a dim view of the Tories

fields.headline: Bishops take a dim view of the Tories
fields.standfirst:
Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Proof that the Church of England is no longer the Tory party at prayer has been provided by a survey of Anglican bishops today in which not one of them could find a single Conservative politician to name as a moral role model.
fields.body:
Proof that the Church of England is no longer the Tory party at prayer has been provided by a survey of Anglican bishops today in which not one of them could find a single Conservative politician to name as a moral role model.

The survey, carried out for the Church of England newspaper, found nearly one in five naming Tony Blair - closely followed by Mo Mowlam - as the best role model for British Christians on television today.

The bishops listed a host of other politicians, including Gordon Brown and Tony Benn - all of them Labour apart from Liberal Democrat Simon Hughes and Martin Bell, the independent MP for Tatton - together with other Christians such as the broadcasters Libby Purves and Simon Mayo, pop star Cliff Richard, and the England cricketer Mike Atherton.

But not a single one could think of a Tory to look up to. If it is any consolation to William Hague, who has been making efforts to woo evangelical Christians in recent months with his offers to turn over social services to religious charities, only 3% thought the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, was much of a role model either.

Jonathan Wynne-Jones, production editor of the paper, said: "We were quite surprised that not a single bishop mentioned any Tories as role models, not even Ann Widdecombe."

More generally, the bishops' bench revealed their favourite television programme was Friends and nearly two-thirds had watched Big Brother - though not one mentioned the Vicar of Dibley.

webTitle: Bush puts Star Wars ll on hold

fields.headline: Bush puts Star Wars ll on hold
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A George W Bush administration could delay the decision on America's controversial national missile defence system until 2002.
fields.body:
A George W Bush administration could delay the decision on America's controversial national missile defence system until 2002.

Mr Bush wants time to assess all the options on missile defence if he is elected president in November, and he may not ask Congress for funding for new programmes until the January 2002 budget, his chief foreign policy adviser, Condoleezza Rice, told a press briefing.

Mr Bush does not intend to be any more precise about his defence thinking and military spending plans during the remaining phases of the election campaign, she added.

"He is an excellent decision maker, but you don't have time on the campaign trail, nor really the resources on the campaign trail, to make a decision of this magnitude."

So far Mr Bush's speeches have implied that he is committed to expanding the national missile defence (NMD) system being developed by Mr Clinton's administration.

This limited programme, involving about 100 interceptor missiles stationed in Alaska is supported by the Democratic presidential candidate, Al Gore. Mr Clinton announced on September 1 that he was leaving the decisions whether and how to go ahead with NMD to his successor.

Ms Rice's comments do not change the likelihood that Mr Bush will go for a bigger and more ambitious programme if he is elected, but they suggest that his team accepts that it will have to spend some months negotiating on the issue next year.

America's allies and foes remain opposed to Mr Clinton's plan, which would breach the 1972 Anti Ballistic Missile treaty between the US and Russia and would involve building radar ground stations in Britain and Greenland. But they are even more apprehensive about Mr Bush's plans, because he would almost certainly like to install interceptors far more widely.

Mr Bush wants to examine other additional systems, Ms Rice said. These may include as yet untested weapons in the early stage of development, such as lasers on aeroplanes and short- and medium-range interceptors on ships.

One upgrade to the Clinton system most discussed in Republican circles would allow the US to shoot down missiles in the "boost phase", when they are travelling more slowly just after take-off and the debris - potentially including chemical and biological agents - would fall near where they were launched.

Mr Bush will examine all these options from a technological and strategic point of view, Ms Rice said. She refused to say how many new weapons might be under consideration or what their cost might be.

"What the governor has said is that this is a very high priority within defence and that he will find the resources to do it, but we do not have a number."

If Mr Bush wins he will conduct a "top-down" review of all military structures and strategies, Ms Rice said. It would be as sweeping as one which followed the second world war, which led among other things to the creation of a separate US air force. It might not be finished in time for inclusion in the 2002 budget, she said.

"We are at a real turning point for the armed services. It is more akin to 1946 than anything we have experienced."

One reason for her note of slight caution on Mr Bush's defence plans is that he has made a series of spending promises, including a sweeping tax cut, which could put previously unexpected constraints on the amount he would have available for missile defence. In that case several existing weapons programmes, especially for new fighter planes, might be cut to pay for missile defence.

Mr Bush continues to make defence one of his main campaign themes and enjoys a strong double-figure lead over Mr Gore on the issue in the opinion polls.

Ms Rice's comments do not change the likelihood that Mr Bush will go for a bigger and more ambitious programme if he is elected, but they suggest that his team accepts that it will have to spend some months negotiating on the issue next year. America's allies and foes remain opposed to Mr Clinton's plan, which would breach the 1972 Anti Ballistic Missile treaty between the US and Russia and would involve building radar ground stations in Britain and Greenland. But they are even more apprehensive about Mr Bush's plans, because he would almost certainly like to install interceptors far more widely. Mr Bush wants to examine other additional systems, Ms Rice said. These may include as yet untested weapons in the early stage of development, such as lasers on aeroplanes and short- and medium-range interceptors on ships. One upgrade to the Clinton system most discussed in Republican circles would allow the US to shoot down missiles in the "boost phase", when they are travelling more slowly just after take-off and the debris - potentially including chemical and biological agents - would fall near where they were launched. Mr Bush will examine all these options from a technological and strategic point of view, Ms Rice said. She refused to say how many new weapons might be under consideration or what their cost might be. "What the governor has said is that this is a very high priority within defence and that he will find the resources to do it, but we do not have a number." If Mr Bush wins he will conduct a "top-down" review of all military structures and strategies, Ms Rice said. It would be as sweeping as one which followed the second world war, which led among other things to the creation of a separate US air force. It might not be finished in time for inclusion in the 2002 budget, she said. "We are at a real turning point for the armed services. It is more akin to 1946 than anything we have experienced." One reason for her note of slight caution on Mr Bush's defence plans is that he has made a series of spending promises, including a sweeping tax cut, which could put previously unexpected constraints on the amount he would have available for missile defence. In that case several existing weapons programmes, especially for new fighter planes, might be cut to pay for missile defence. Mr Bush continues to make defence one of his main campaign themes and enjoys a strong double-figure lead over Mr Gore on the issue in the opinion polls.

webTitle: Figures reveal UK rivers cleaner than ever

fields.headline: Figures reveal UK rivers cleaner than ever
fields.trailText: Rivers and canals in England and Wales are probably cleaner than they have been since the industrial revolution, with 92% classed as good enough to support fish life, according to the Environment Agency.
fields.body:
Rivers and canals in England and Wales are probably cleaner than they have been since the industrial revolution, with 92% classed as good enough to support fish life, according to the Environment Agency.

This 1999 figure is a big improvement on 1990, the year after water privatisation, when 85% of the 25,000 miles of rivers and canals were classified in the top two categories of "good" or "fair".

If Scotland and Northern Ireland are included the figure is 95% in 1999, compared with 92% in 1990.

Since privatisation, water companies have been forced by EU legislation to invest heavily in sewage treatment plants and other clean-up measures which have resulted in higher water bills but better water quality. Hundreds of miles of rivers now have fish life where there was none nine years ago.

Rivers in the "poor" and "bad" classifications have probably been devoid of almost all life for decades, many of them in the old industrial heartlands of Britain, where chemicals used to be indiscriminately poured into the nearest stream.

In 1990, 2.3% of all rivers were still in the "bad" category - meaning about 575 miles of rivers had no life - but last year this figure had gone down to 0.6%, around 150 miles.

The biggest improvements have been in industrial areas of the midlands and northern England, where around half the rivers and canals have improved by one grade or more. The net improvement, taking into account the fact that some rivers have deteriorated over the same period, is equivalent to upgrading 40% of the total river and canal length in the midlands and north.

The quality of rivers is one of the government's 15 indicators of "quality of life" in Britain, which it pledged to improve. Water companies are due to spend another £7bn over the next five years making further improvements.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, said: "Clean rivers are not only a vital source of water for drinking and industry, they also support a wide variety of wildlife and are enjoyed by millions for recreation.

"The billions being invested in cleaning up our rivers are really bearing fruit. These are the best ever water quality results, and they reflect the government's commitment to delivering a cleaner, better quality environment for everyone to enjoy."

The south west of England and Wales have the highest proportion of high quality rivers, with respectively 97% and 98% of river and canal length classified as good or fair.

The Environment Agency chairman, Sir John Harman, said: "The survey shows real improvements in the quality of many urban and semi-urban rivers, creating real amenity for people in areas where river environments have in the past been poor, or in some cases, lifeless, polluted eyesores.

"However, we cannot be complacent. Around 8% of rivers in England and Wales are still graded poor or bad. Planned investment over the next five years should tackle many of these problems."

 The agency has a website, www.environment-agency.gov.uk, where users can enter a postcode to discover the quality of rivers in their given locality.

webTitle: Troops held for killings in West Timor

fields.headline: Troops held for killings in West Timor
fields.trailText: Indonesian police have arrested some soldiers in connection with the murders of three workers for the UN refugee agency in West Timor earlier this month, and the preceding killing of a militia leader that sparked the attack on the UN staff.
fields.body:
Indonesian police have arrested some soldiers in connection with the murders of three workers for the UN refugee agency in West Timor earlier this month, and the preceding killing of a militia leader that sparked the attack on the UN staff.

The move suggests Jakarta is at last responding to threats of international isolation if it fails to rein in the militias holding sway in West Timor.

Their incursions disrupt and terrorise newly independent East Timor and keep more than 120,000 East Timorese in squalid refugee camps along the border between the two parts of Timor. Some aid agencies also say food for the refugees is running low, though the government denies this.

Western diplomats believe that the arrests - announced yesterday by Indonesia's attorney general, Marzuki Darusman - bear out their repeated assertion that not only are elements of the military helping the militias but that the armed forces are fractured, with some key generals not obeying President Abdurrahman Wahid.

The three workers for the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) were killed on September 6 in the border town of Atambua, where hundreds of militiamen attacked their office. They were hacked to death and their bodies set on fire. With the security authorities standing by, the mob then ran amok in the town.

Yesterday Mr Darusman said six people were being picked up. "The identification of the suspects has been made and they are in the process of being summoned and interrogated," he said. "They include elements of the military."

Seven others have been arrested in connection with the death on September 5 of a militia leader, Olivio Maruk. These also include members of the armed forces.

Mr Darusman said he did not know how many of the suspects were soldiers or what their ranks were. He said they were rogue elements and that the military as an institution was not party to the murders.

The chief military spokesman, Rear Air Marshal Graito Usodo, said people should not jump to conclusions about the arrests of soldiers.

Militia leaders said the rampage and the killing of the UN workers was sparked by the murder and castration the previous day of Mr Maruk.

Analysts believe he may have been killed because he had been named as a suspect in the investigation into the destruction wreaked in East Timor last year when the territory voted for independence, and might have implicated senior soldiers when questioned.

The UN has said it will not send staff back to West Timor to help the refugees until the militias have been disarmed and disbanded. Indonesia's senior security minister, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, promised the UN security council at the weekend that the militias would be given until Monday to hand in their weapons; then the military would seize them.

Marshal Usodo said yesterday that negotiations had begun with gang leaders to hand over weapons but said the process would not be easy as the militias were insisting on compensation for their guns, most of which they obtained from the Indonesian army.

The US and the World Bank have both said in the last week that if the militias are not disarmed and disbanded rapidly then Jakarta could find itself isolated and its aid cut off.

Conditions for the refugees are deteriorating. Red Cross officials in West Timor said food supplies were critically low. Indonesia's vice-president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, is to visit the refugees this weekend with 100 tonnes of rice.

 Around 1,500 aid workers marched in Geneva on Thursday to demand better protection in dangerous parts of the world. "We are aid workers, not martyrs," Naveed Hussain, head of the staff council at the UNHCR told the rally.

The agency said its staff would protest in at least 28 cities after the murder of the three in West Timor and the murder of one and abuction of another in Guinea in less than two weeks.

webTitle: Floods return

fields.headline: Floods return
fields.standfirst:
Rain brings more misery to India

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Villagers in large parts of north-east India were left reeling again last night after floods caused by three days of torrential rain engulfed entire communities, leaving around 50 people dead and 500,000 homeless.
fields.body:
Villagers in large parts of north-east India were left reeling again last night after floods caused by three days of torrential rain engulfed entire communities, leaving around 50 people dead and 500,000 homeless.

Much of West Bengal, which was still clearing up after severe floods in August, remained underwater as the army and relief agencies tried to rescue survivors and take aid to homeless families.

Several districts remained cut off. Army helicopters and boats bringing supplies were yesterday unable to reach the worst affected areas, Murshidabad and Birbhum, because of rain and huge waves. Most of those who died were killed when their mud houses collapsed, while others were the victims of snakebites or drowned when their boats capsized.

"It has been raining for the past three or four days. There is water coming into our villages. The paddy fields are completely submerged. Now even snakes are entering our houses and several homes have collapsed," one villager told India's Star TV.

The latest floods come less than a month after unusually heavy monsoon rains brought destruction to south and north-east India, and to Bhutan, Nepal and Bangladesh. More than 400 people have died so far.

Some 10m people have been marooned by the latest rains, with road and rail links severely disrupted. Telecom workers protest ing against imminent privatisation had already paralysed phone lines in West Bengal. Last night the state's deputy chief minister, Buddhadev Bhattacharya, asked them to go back to work, saying their action made the relief effort more difficult.

The Indian Red Cross yesterday began distributing rice, pans, cooking oil, tarpaulins and mosquito nets. The International Red Cross has launched a $3.5m appeal, warning that with crops destroyed many villagers face severe debt.

"People are taking shelter wherever they can find it, in areas of high ground and in school buildings," N L Sharma, the Indian Red Cross's deputy director, said.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Heavy security for Yates funeral
fields.body:
Heavy security for Yates funeral

Police have launched a big security operation for the funeral of television presenter Paula Yates tomorrow at Davington, near Faversham, Kent. Paul McCartney is among the celebrities expected to attend the service at the Church of Mary Magdalene.

Salad days warning

If you want to stay healthy, avoid the salads served by some fast food restaurants. The public health laboratory has found that salads at small independent fast-food outlets are the likely source of an outbreak of salmonella among the country's teenagers.

Another suicide at Wandsworth

A west London greengrocer awaiting trial for grievous bodily harm killed himself at Wandsworth prison, a Westminster inquest jury decided yesterday. Trevor Stow-Tucker, 38, the sixth prisoner to have died at the prison this year, hanged himself after being refused bail.

Mothers under stress

Being a full time mother is the most stressful job, a survey in Having a Baby magazine revealed yesterday - 51% regularly feel stressed, compared to 29% of women who work full time.

Heaviest dog

Kell the bull mastiff, at 19 stone, has made it into the Guinness Book of Records as the heaviest dog alive. Kell is owned by Tom Scott of Loughborough, Leicestershire.

webTitle: Blowing away the froth of pollution

fields.headline: Blowing away the froth of pollution
fields.trailText: The first time the government examined the state of its rivers, in 1866, the results in northern England were so disgusting   that the civil servants made an imaginative point.
fields.body:
The first time the government examined the state of its rivers, in 1866, the results in northern England were so disgusting that the civil servants made an imaginative point.

"The water of the river Calder in Yorkshire makes a tolerably good black ink," they told MPs, "and we have demonstrated this by using Calder water to write a small part of our report."

Yesterday the Calder and its sister river the Aire, which wind through the industrial heart of West Yorkshire, won their cleanest bill of health since the time of the industrial revolution.

The Calder, which used to be dyed orange by corduroy makers in Hebden Bridge and purple by Halifax carpet mills, now supports a thriving fishery; the Aire has seen 40 miles rescued for the two lowest grades of water quality since 1990.

"It has been a victory for sustained environmental pressure," said Kevin Grady of the pressure group Eye on the Aire.

"When it became clear that Leeds businesses were determined to pour millions of pounds into riverside development, they weren't going to stand for a river of froth and smells."

Sir John Harman, chair of the Environment Agency, emphasised the point from his own experience as a boy. He said: "I used to cross the Aire and Calder at Castleford and I didn't come up as high as the bridge's parapet - but the foam in the river from the wool scouring works did."

Today's Aire has joined the Calder as an unexpected fishery - to the extent that expensive hotels in Leeds provide rods in rooms overlooking the waterway.

The turning point, says Dr Grady, was the government's move in the mid-1990s to allow water rates to rise on condition that the money went exclusively to water quality improvement.

Some £60m was set aside for the Aire and Calder catchment, whose past horrors included the Bradford canal where in 1866 "... it was found practicable to set the water on fire with a match on the end of a stick, the flame rising 6ft and running along the canal for many yards, like a will-o-the-wisp."

webTitle: An ominous ticking for the Republicans

fields.headline: An ominous ticking for the Republicans
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Like the old grandfather clock in the corner, the US presidential election swings back and forth. At first, the Republican George W Bush had a dominant lead. But when he faced a more daunting challenge than the Democrats' Al Gore did in his primary for the party nomination, the latter took the lead.
fields.body:
Like the old grandfather clock in the corner, the US presidential election swings back and forth. At first, the Republican George W Bush had a dominant lead. But when he faced a more daunting challenge than the Democrats' Al Gore did in his primary for the party nomination, the latter took the lead.

Then, it was Vice-President Gore who stumbled and went strangely quiet in the post-primary period; Mr Bush regained the advantage.

At the Republican convention in early August, Mr Bush took a decisive lead, only to hand it back when the Democrats met later that month. The seminal event of the campaign, so far, has been Mr Gore's magnificent convention speech accepting his party's nomination.

Auditioning for the presidency, Mr Gore delivered a speech devoid of oratorical flourish but so laden with substance that it resembled a president's annual state of the union address.

Mr Gore took America on a tour of his agenda. He proposed important initiatives in areas from education to child care to help for the el derly to health reform to crime fighting to environmental protection and, in the process, touched on a dozen other popular themes.

Now, one month later, the echoes of Mr Gore's speech still sound in the race, staking the vice-president to a small but so far enduring lead over Mr Bush.

For his part, Mr Bush has countered by "triangulating". This was the strategy Bill Clinton used in 1996 to steal the other side's issues. With all the basic Republican concerns basically solved - such as eliminating the deficit (the US has a surplus), cutting crime (down 50%), and reducing dependence on the dole (also cut in half) - Mr Bush has crossed into Democratic turf to find his issues.

His convention emphasised his commitment to education and he recently unveiled a plan to pay for medicine for the elderly. The logic of the Bush strategy is that if he can draw even with Mr Gore on the issues, he will win on image - the calculation being that barring a transplant of DNA, Mr Gore cannot win the personality battle.

The flaw in the Republican approach, so far, is Mr Bush's huge proposed tax cut. Seeking to reduce tax payments by $1,300bn (£865bn) in the next 10 years, the nominee is betting his house that voters want their taxes cut first and foremost. But most surveys show they are far more apt to favour spending on education, gun control, police, and help to impoverished areas.

Either side can win this contest. But it is worth noting that not since 1948 has the candidate who is behind at this stage come back to win the election.

Richard Nixon in 1960, Hubert Humphrey in 1968, and Gerald Ford in 1976 all came close, but none won. Bad news for Mr Bush.

Dick Morris, chief strategist for President Clinton in his successful 1996 bid for re-election, will be writing a regular column during the US election campaign. He is head of www.vote.co.uk an interactive website designed to give users a voice on public issues
